XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Speaker’s Ruling, Alleged Deliberate Misleading of the House by a Minister
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, I have ordered that a ruling regarding a complaint by the member for Gaven against the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading of deliberately misleading the House be circulated. I have decided not to refer the matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee. I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in the parliamentary record.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: SPEAKER’S RULING--ALLEGED DELIBERATELY MISLEADING THE HOUSE
On 25 November 2010, the Member for Gaven wrote to me alleging that the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading had misled the House on 23 and 25 November 2010.
The member’s complaint was that the Minister misled the House as to the member’s position on hotel trading hours.
In accordance with Standing Order 269(5) on 26 November 2010, I wrote to the Minister, enclosing a copy of the member’s allegations and requested a response.
On 23 December 2010, the Minister provided a letter of response.

The Minister’s response quoted the member for Gaven’s comments in Hansard and argued that from those comments a reasonable person would conclude that the member was in favour of a reduction of trading hours.
For the benefit of the House, I table a copy of the correspondence in this matter.
It is well established that are three elements to be established when it is alleged that a member has committed the contempt of deliberately misleading the House:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • first, the statement must, in fact, have been misleading;
• secondly, it must be established that the member making the statement knew at the time the statement was made that it was incorrect; and
• thirdly, in making it, the member must have intended to mislead the House.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There is always a danger that a member, in referring to an earlier speech by another member, will misrepresent that member’s comments.
It is clear that a misrepresentation can constitute a deliberate misleading of the House and a contempt only if all the elements described above can be established.
In this case, I do not believe that any of the elements have been sufficiently been made out. Furthermore, I consider it unlikely that further investigation by the IEPPC would adduce such evidence.
I have, therefore, decided not to refer the matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Speaker’s Ruling, Alleged Deliberate Misleading of the House by a Member
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, I have ordered that a ruling regarding a complaint by the Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland against the member for Cleveland of deliberately misleading the House be circulated. I have decided not to refer that matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee. I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in the parliamentary record.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: SPEAKER’S RULING--ALLEGED DELIBERATELY MISLEADING THE HOUSE

On 21 October 2010, the Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland wrote to me alleging that the Member for Cleveland had deliberately misled the House on two occasions in debate on 5 August 2010 deliberately misled the House.

The Minister’s complaint was that the member purposefully took his quoted him out of context and consequently misrepresented him and misled the House. He asserts the use of the quote was misleading in the context of the issue of whether the over fishing of snapper requires government action.
In accordance with Standing Order 269(5) on 25 November 2010 I wrote to the Member for Cleveland, enclosing a copy of the member’s allegations and requested a response.

On 17 December 2010, the member provided a detailed letter of response. The member asserts that the context of his speech was of overall fish stock sustainability and the need for green zones, not the specific snapper context, and therefore submits that his quote of the Minister was in context.
For the benefit of the House, I table a copy of all the correspondence in this matter.
It is well established that are three elements to be established when it is alleged that a member has committed the contempt of deliberately misleading the House:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • first, the statement must, in fact, have been misleading;
• secondly, it must be established that the member making the statement knew at the time the statement was made that it was incorrect; and
• thirdly, in making it, the member must have intended to mislead the House.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There is always a danger that a member, in referring to an earlier speech by another member, may misrepresent that member’s comments.
It is clear that a deliberate misrepresentation can constitute a deliberate misleading of the House and a contempt, only if all the elements described above can be established.
In this case I do not believe that any of the elements have been sufficiently been made out.

On balance, I find that the Member for Cleveland has adequately explained his comments and that there is no clear evidence that would establish the above elements. Furthermore, I consider it unlikely that further investigation by the IEPPC would adduce such evidence.
I have, therefore, decided not to refer the matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Speaker’s Ruling, Alleged Deliberate Misleading of the House by a Minister
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, I have ordered that a ruling regarding a complaint by the member for Mermaid Beach against the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading of deliberately misleading the House be circulated. I have decided not to refer the matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee. I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in the parliamentary record.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: SPEAKER’S RULING--ALLEGED DELIBERATELY MISLEADING THE HOUSE
On 28 October 2010, the Member for Mermaid Beach wrote to me alleging that the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading had deliberately misled the House on 27 October 2010.
The member’s complaint was that the Minister deliberately misled the House as to the ownership of the Gold Coast Turf Club facilities.
In accordance with Standing Order 269(5) on 24 November 2010, I wrote to the Minister, enclosing a copy of the member’s allegations and requested a response.
On 23 December 2010, the Minister provided a letter of response.

The Minister asserts that his comments in the House were intended to correct the member’s implication that the government owned racing assets but concedes that he did not achieve his intent in that he was unable to finish his sentence due to interjections.
The Minister states that, in hindsight, he appreciates that he should have clarified this matter when the member rose on a matter of privilege on 27 October 2010.
For the benefit of the House, I table a copy of the correspondence in this matter.
It is well established that are three elements to be established when it is alleged that a member has committed the contempt of deliberately misleading the House:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • first, the statement must, in fact, have been misleading;
• secondly, it must be established that the member making the statement knew at the time the statement was made that it was incorrect; and
• thirdly, in making it, the member must have intended to mislead the House.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It is clear that a misrepresentation can constitute a deliberate misleading of the House and a contempt only if all the elements described above can be established.

I find that the Minister has adequately explained his inaccurate statement. Furthermore, I consider it unlikely that further investigation by the IEPPC would adduce evidence that would make out the third element of intent.
I have, therefore, decided not to refer the matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee.

In doing so, however, I remind the Minister of the importance of the accuracy of statements made in the House and the requirement to correct the parliamentary record as soon as possible after becoming aware of an incorrect statement.

In this particular instance, this could have been when the Hansard transcript of the Minister’s comments became available, though certainly no later than when the Member for Mermaid Waters raised the matter as a matter of privilege.
I take the opportunity to remind all members in a similar fashion.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Speaker’s Ruling, Alleged Deliberate Misleading of an Estimates Committee by a Minister, Referral to Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, on 26 October 2010 I received correspondence from the member for Burdekin relating to statements made by the Minister for Community Services and Housing during estimates committee hearings regarding the pending closure of the Women’s Infolink Service. The member for Burdekin alleges that the minister deliberately mislead the House in relation to these statements.

In accordance with Standing Order 269(5) I sought a response from the minister. The minister challenges a number of the member’s assertions in her response. I do not intend to canvass the details of the claims and counterclaims. Suffice to say that there is considerable examination of fact required to determine the matter.

Accordingly, I have decided to refer the matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee. In doing so, I emphasise that I have formed no view as to whether there has, in fact, been a breach of privilege but rather that there are sufficient issues in play to warrant the further attention of the House via the committee.

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: A proposal under section 32 of the Nature Conservation Act 1992 and a Brief Explanation of the Proposal
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.35 am): I lay upon the table of the House the public report of ministerial expenses for the period 1 July 2010 to 31 December 2010. This report shows that ministerial expenditure has remained reasonable and that fiscal responsibility remains a key priority of our government. When compared to the same period in 2009 overall expenditure has increased by $449,267 or 2.73 per cent. The major areas where expenditure has increased, when compared to the same period in the previous year, are an increase in total salary costs as a result of enterprise bargaining and an additional FBT charge in 2010-11 relating to 2009-10. Total administration costs, including depreciation, have increased overall by $91,000 or 1.64 per cent due to increases in building services and ICT costs but these have been offset in part by decreases in media services, domestic travel, overseas travel and photocopy charges.

In terms of my own office, when compared to the same period in the previous year total expenditure has increased by $67,792 or 2.74 per cent. Increased expenditure of $113,309 occurred in salary costs related to enterprise bargaining increases and an additional FBT charge in 2010-11 relating to 2009-10. Total administrative costs, including depreciation, decreased overall by $45,517, with decreases in my office of media services, overseas travel and telephone costs.
I believe that this report clearly shows that ministerial expenditure is being maintained at reasonable levels in what have been tough economic times and I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Report titled ‘Public Report of Ministerial Expenses total for all Ministerial Portfolios for the period 1/07/2010 to 31/12/2010’.

XML.Hansard-Body:
Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts)
(9.37 am): In these last two months our state has been through some terrible times and the rebuilding effort will rightly take much of our resources and efforts in the months ahead. But it is equally important to remember that our government was already building tomorrow’s Queensland, building a stronger Queensland, before these disasters struck and we are determined to maintain those efforts.

Our record $17 billion capital building program means that projects continue to deliver jobs and real results all over our state. In that respect I am happy to report to the House that the first of two massive tunnel boring machines working on the Airport Link project is due today to break through into the enormous purpose-built Kedron caverns. This breakthrough is an important milestone for this massive project and it marks the halfway point of the tunnel boring machine’s two and a half kilometre journey underground from Kalinga Park to Lutwyche. Since its launch from Kalinga Park in July, Australia’s largest tunnel boring machine, known as Rocksy, has already excavated around 1,200 metres of tunnel. This is quite an achievement when one considers that this time last year these two 36,000 tonne machines were still in pieces yet to be assembled.Working around the clock, seven days a week, Rocksy and sister TBM Sandy, have progressed at rates of up to 110 metres a week. As these impressive machines dig the tunnels, they then line them with concrete segments as they go, considerably speeding up the construction process.

A total of 11,000 precast concrete segments have been used, and Rocksy and Sandy have excavated more than 2.2 kilometres. That means that 300,000 cubic metres of spoil have been generated and transported to Nudgee Road via a two-kilometre spoil conveyor. This is good news for the residents of the north side, with the conveyor eliminating almost 80,000 truck movements from the local streets, especially around the Clayfield area. The journey from Kalinga Park to Wooloowin has taken Rocksy underneath Kalinga and Melrose parks and under local streets in Clayfield and Wooloowin.

I would like to congratulate the 22 workers from Rocksy’s tunnelling team. Tunnelling is a difficult and dangerous job, and the team is to be commended on its safe performance in the tunnels to date. Over nine kilometres of tunnelling have been completed across the project and almost 15 million hours have been worked. The projects have surpassed their expected employment-generating capacity, with jobs now totalling 3,600.

By the middle of next year, Airport Link will provide six extra traffic lanes between Bowen Hills and Kedron and four additional lanes from Kedron to Toombul. Motorists will then be able to bypass up to 18 sets of traffic lights between the CBD and the airport, one of our major destinations. The Northern Busway, a major public transport project, will provide for 47,000 bus passenger trips every day by 2016--more than five times the current number of bus trips. These are just some of the congestion-busting solutions that we are providing for South-East Queensland as we build a stronger state.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.41 am): Charities and not-for-profit organisations are often the first point of call during a natural disaster. During the floods and again in the aftermath of Cyclone Yasi, not-for-profit organisations were on the front line, coordinating emergency assistance for thousands of families--blankets, toys and meals--or just being a reassuring voice. We all know what a terrific job our community groups have done in responding to the needs of others. Many from both sides of the chamber spoke about them in the motion debated in the House earlier this week.

XML.Hansard-Body: What is less publicised is that many of these groups have themselves been directly impacted by floods. As is so often the case, not-for-profit organisations are often so busy looking after others that their own needs come second. Our government is determined to ensure that these community groups get the assistance they need to get back on their feet. That is why I wrote to the federal government requesting the activation of NDRRA funding for charitable businesses and not-for-profit organisations. I am pleased to advise the House today that this request has been agreed to and that NGOs in both flood and cyclone affected parts of Queensland will now be eligible to apply for category C grants of up to $25,000--in a similar category to small businesses and primary producers. In addition, charities and not-for-profit organisations will also be eligible under category C for concessional interest rate loans of up to $100,000 to help them get back on track.

I have spoken to a number of people in this particular circumstance. I recall visiting the member for Toowoomba North in Toowoomba, where the mayor and I spoke to people from the Kath Dickson Family Centre whose centre was affected. They had lost a number of their toys and books and the equipment they use for running playgroups. Given that they run playgroups right down into the Lockyer Valley, I think everybody who knows their work would commend them for it. This is just one example of an organisation that will be able to benefit from these funds.

I hope that these funds will go some way to giving back what these organisations give out to us all so often. I ask members of the House to draw this to the attention of relevant non-government not-for-profit groups in their own electorates.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.43 am): As we know, there is now a commission of inquiry looking into events surrounding the recent floods and seeking to answer questions that Queenslanders have about those flooding events that devastated much of our state. People directly affected by unprecedented flooding will have the chance to have direct input into the inquiry. But we understand that many communities are also suffering unprecedented heartbreak. Many will be reliving traumatic and terrifying events when they recount their personal stories to the commission. These are Queenslanders who have lost loved ones and lost homes and they are Queenslanders who come from communities that have been torn apart.

XML.Hansard-Body: Making submissions or providing evidence may be a prospect that, for some people, is simply too overwhelming on their own. That is why I am pleased to advise today that the Department of Communities will provide $300,000 to Lifeline to provide face-to-face support services to people who seek to appear before the inquiry or who are involved in the inquiry’s community consultation process. This will include help for those people who seek it to prepare submissions.

Lifeline has been chosen to deliver this vital service because it is independent of government, because it has a well-deserved reputation in local communities of providing support to people who need it when they need it most and because it is already working in many of the affected communities. In fact, Lifeline counsellors have already been out and about in disaster affected communities around Queensland, counselling and providing support. Six Lifeline counsellors will be deployed in Ipswich over this weekend, five will be deployed in the Lockyer Valley and two will be deployed in Dalby. This comes on top of thousands of contacts already made by phone and outreach visits into the affected communities over the past month.

Leading Queensland to recovery following unprecedented natural disasters is without doubt a very big job. Our government is committed to being there and helping until the job is done. That includes making sure that people have the emotional and social support they need at every stage of the process. Our recovery will be measured not only by rebuilt buildings but also by communities, families and lives that are restored to wellbeing. We hope that this service will help in some cases for those people who need it.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (9.46 am): Yesterday I outlined to the House the economic and fiscal pain we can expect from the summer’s floods and Cyclone Yasi. These are disasters that will take years, not mere weeks or months, to recover from. The government’s message to all, however, is clear: Queensland remains open for business.

Not only will our traditional strengths of mining and agriculture recover and recover at pace; new industries--the industries of the future--will also continue to blossom over time. To that end, today I can announce that Queensland has secured a major new investment with a new solar equipment manufacturing facility to be built on the Gold Coast.

Eco-Kinetics, a leader in solar manufacturing in this country, will build a cutting-edge manufacturing facility that could well be the first of its scale in Australia. The facility will produce locally assembled photovoltaic modules and manufacturing mounting kits that will help feed society’s growing hunger for solar technology. Eco-Kinetics will build the facility at Stapylton, with support through the Queensland Investment Incentive Scheme.

We have a clear interest in supporting alternative energy industries. The government has long supported solar as a critical power source for the present and the future. Secondly, this is an investment that will see real jobs growth. Eco-Kinetics believes that this will create 244 full-time jobs between now and 2015. That is the government in action, securing new investment and new jobs.

Our action today stands in contrast to a report this morning which takes a somewhat arbitrary look at the state’s fiscal settings. The report itself acknowledges that its assessment is made as at 30 June last year--before the dividends of our fiscal reform program had been received. As outlined in last month’s midyear fiscal and economic review, the government’s balance sheet restructuring has seen projected debt reduced by $10 billion. Given the report’s selected time frame, it fails to incorporate this benefit. A proper contemporary assessment would.

I do not accept the report’s conclusions on tax competitiveness. The midyear review also detailed that Queensland’s tax per capita is $2,136--$500 below the average of the other states, which tax $2,636 per capita. The independent Commonwealth Grants Commission’s last assessment concluded that our taxation burden was below the national average.

The government acknowledges that out state was hit harder than any other state by the global financial crisis and has since been dealt the twin blows of the summer floods and Cyclone Yasi. There are challenges, and we are determined to meet them head-on. But make no mistake: Queensland’s economic and fiscal fundamentals are strong and our future is bright. We said that we would prioritise jobs, investment and our building program and invest in new industries like solar. That is exactly what we are doing today--just like we said we would.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Natural Disasters, Building Services Authority; GBG, Former Member for Greenslopes

Hansard-Body.A: (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (9.48 am): Queensland is gradually recovering from one of nature’s most violent assaults on this state. Like all Queenslanders, I give thanks to the volunteers, the emergency services workers, the police, the Army, QBuild--mighty QBuild--charities and others who were there to help at the height of the crisis. We are now moving to the recovery phase, and people will need other support services to get their lives back on track.

XML.Hansard-Body: The Building Services Authority--the mighty Building Services Authority--announced last week that it is conducting 17 seminars and shopping centre information booths to help homeowners and tradespeople rebuild homes. The seminars and information booths are in flood damaged cities and towns including Ipswich, Gatton, Emerald, Rockhampton, Dalby and Brisbane. The seminars will give information about when repair work should start, choosing a licensed contractor, the importance of homeowners signing contracts and of home warranty insurance, dealing with asbestos, and building planning and approvals. Similar BSA seminars will be announced for Far North Queensland and other centres in the near future.
I am also pleased to announce that the BSA opened a new office in Bryant Street, Tully, at the beginning of this week.
Mr Cripps: Hear, hear!

Mr SCHWARTEN: I take the interjection from the shadow minister. I understand a relative has already been in contact. A similar office was opened in Innisfail after Cyclone Larry in 2006, and now the same service is available in Tully.

I also want to advise the House that the BSA has produced a new natural disaster repairs contract for use in natural disasters. The new contract can be used for repairs to a home, duplex or home unit after a natural disaster such as a flood or a cyclone. The new contract is free and can be downloaded from the BSA website.

Finally, I want to update the House about an independent review of the BSA by KPMG that I commissioned last May. It has been five years since the last organisational review of the Building Services Authority, and this review aims to improve and streamline BSA processes to make improvements for both consumers and licensees. I met with KPMG earlier this week and I was advised that KPMG expects to complete its report next month. The report will go to the BSA board, which will then examine its findings before being forwarded back to the ministerial office.

I also want to correct the record in relation to a matter that I raised in this parliament late last year--I think on the last sitting day. It was concerning a firm called GBG. In that speech I made a statement which I have now found to be incorrect. That was that a former member of this House, Gary Fenlon, was in fact a director of that company. He has since advised that he is a shareholder of that company. So I want to correct the record accordingly.

Hansard-Body.A: (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (9.51 am): Despite the adverse weather experienced across Queensland during December and January, the Bligh government is getting on with the important job of building new schools for Queensland students. I am pleased to inform the House that three new schools are currently being built in high-growth areas north of Brisbane.

XML.Hansard-Body: A $20 million high school is being built at Murrumba Downs, a primary school at Bundilla and a primary school at Mango Hill--both funded under the $1.1 billion public-private partnership project. All three are currently in the late planning or early construction phases. They will provide students and families in these areas with more options for a world-class education. In addition, the Mer Island campus of Tagai State College is being relocated to a greenfield site on Mer Island. The three new schools and the relocated campus are on track to open for the first day of the 2012 school year--wet season permitting.

These new schools are in addition to the eight new and relocated schools open for the first day of the 2011 school year. The brand-new Springfield Central State School, Springfield Central State High School, Woodlinks State School at Collingwood Park, Augusta State School at Augustine Heights and Coomera Rivers State School at Coomera welcomed their first students on 24 January, while students and teachers at the $73 million Bremer State High School, the Federal State School and the Brisbane School of Distance Education also began the school year at new campuses. These new schools and campuses are providing students with modern facilities and resources for a 21st century education. Students and staff at the relocated Wynnum State School are looking forward to starting classes at the new campus from term 2 this year.

In addition to building new schools, the Bligh government’s unprecedented investment in education also includes the $850 million State Schools of Tomorrow building and refurbishment program, the $321 million kindergarten services and building program and the $60 million solar schools program. We are delivering on budget commitments and meeting the population needs of Queensland by putting millions of dollars each year into school infrastructure to ensure Queensland children get access to the best possible education facilities and get a flying start to learning and life.

Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (9.54 pm): Plainly the first priority of this government is to rebuild Queensland in the wake of recent natural disasters. In my portfolio I am pressing forward with plans to unlock the full economic potential of our state. This is a crucial task to getting Queensland back on its feet.

So I am pleased to announce that the draft terms of reference for Adani Mining’s Carmichael coalmine and rail project have been released for public comment. This project is the fifth coalmining project proposed for the Galilee Basin, which is the last undeveloped coal resource in Queensland and is likely to become the state’s largest coal-producing region.

Projects previously announced include Kevin’s Corner and Alpha Coal by Hancock Prospecting, South Galilee Coal by AMCI and Alpha Coal Pty Ltd, and Galilee Coal by Waratah Coal Pty Ltd. Together, these projects and the associated rail and port infrastructure facilities involve capital expenditure of $33 billion. This is great news for the economy and jobs creation, with the potential for 20,000 new jobs during construction and approximately 10,000 operational jobs. This is a massive part of the Coordinator-General’s program of projects under assessment, now totalling $57.8 billion--38,100 estimated construction jobs and 18,600 ongoing jobs, mainly in regional Queensland.

The Bligh government will also help to prepare the community for this growth. We will develop a Galilee Basin economic and social impact study which will be used by state government agencies, local councils and other organisations to help the region prepare and manage the impact of these projects. We are also working on plans for common user water and power infrastructure to deliver these essential services to the Galilee Basin. The development of the Galilee Basin as a major centre for coalmining, processing and exporting is important to the future economic prosperity of Queensland, and it puts us firmly back on the track to economic recovery.

Hansard-Body.A: (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (9.56 am): The Bligh government has put in place strong laws to manage the development of Queensland’s coal seam gas to LNG industry. Our priority is to strike the right balance between the needs of the community, the environment, the industry and economic development for regional Queensland. These laws quite rightly demand very high standards of this emerging industry.

XML.Hansard-Body: We are determined to make sure that industry meets the high standards that we and the community expect of it. The resource sector was hit hard by the recent natural disasters. That is why it is important that we now help restore confidence across the industry and show that we are indeed back to business. In November last year the Bligh government made a commitment to increase the enforcement capability and to focus resources through the creation of a one-stop LNG enforcement unit. Today we are delivering on that commitment. I am pleased to advise the House that Mr Andrew Brier has been appointed to establish and have overall management responsibility for this new unit, which will comprise multidisciplinary specialists tasked with monitoring this emerging growth industry.

Mr Brier will be in charge of developing strategic compliance plans that include proactive and spot investigations, as well as monitoring the compliance reporting required of the industry. The unit will also investigate formal complaints from landholders and lead prosecutions where investigations provide evidence of wrongdoing. The unit includes environmental and groundwater experts, who will form part of the team monitoring environmental impacts, water quality and pressures, and will ensure environmental authority conditions are strictly adhered to.

This team will also work closely with the Queensland Water Commission in monitoring bores across the Surat region. Additional petroleum and gas safety inspectors also form part of the team. They have the important task of making sure this industry operates safely, both for its own workers and for the community.

Our mining registrars are also a valuable support to landholders and will be called on to ensure industry meets its land access obligations. They also will be available to help resolve impasses in access and compensation negotiations as an alternative to the matter being taken to court. The team is backed by the full policy and operational machinery of supporting departments, including DERM and DEEDI. In short, this team is equipped with the power and the resources to make sure this emerging industry adheres to its legislative and moral obligations to the Queensland community.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Corrective Services and Emergency Services, Infrastructure Projects

Hansard-Body.A: (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (9.59 am): The Department of Community Safety is getting on with the job of delivering a capital works program that is providing new and refurbished facilities for our emergency services and corrective services personnel. Of the 21 major projects listed in the budget papers for the Queensland Ambulance Service in 2010-11, four projects--Moranbah, Runaway Bay, Springfield and Stanthorpe--are now complete. Contracts have been awarded and works are underway on QAS facilities at Ashgrove--which is nearing completion--Biggenden, Chermside, Ipswich, Jimboomba and Winton. Work is also progressing on staff housing at Blackwater. A contract for the replacement ambulance station at Gayndah was awarded on 9 February and works are expected to commence in March. Tenders have been called for Gordonvale, Ravenshoe and South Mackay.

XML.Hansard-Body: Of the 11 major projects within the Queensland Fire and Rescue Service, two--Agnes Water and Toowoomba, Kitchener Street--are now complete. Contracts have been awarded and construction is underway at Dysart and Pullenvale, and the contract for the Noosa station redevelopment has recently been awarded and work is expected to start by March. Tenders have been called for the replacement fire station at Craignish, near Hervey Bay.

The new Queensland Emergency Operations Centre at Kedron is nearing completion and has already been put to good use as the nerve centre for the response to the widespread flooding and cyclones that impacted Queensland this wet season. The recently completed $20 million Queensland Combined Emergency Services Academy at Whyte Island is continuing to be enhanced, with improvements such as a new road crash rescue pad and upgraded simulations at the live-fire campus.

Works are continuing on major capital works programs within Corrective Services, including the $442 million, 300-bed upgrade of Lotus Glen Correctional Centre and the new $485 million, 300-bed South Queensland correctional centre at Gatton.

There is no doubt that the adverse weather that has impacted Queensland in recent weeks will delay some projects in our capital works program. However, the department will continue to drive the capital works program to ensure our emergency services and corrective services personnel have the facilities they need from which to ensure the safety of the communities they serve.

Hansard-Body.A: (Thuringowa--ALP) (Minister for Main Roads) (10.01 am): I would like to take this opportunity to update the House on the mighty efforts of Main Roads crews to get Queensland moving again--to reopen our highways and to rebuild and repair our vast road network. It is important to note that 70 per cent of the state controlled roads cut by flooding were reopened to traffic within two days. When it comes to our major infrastructure projects, Main Roads is back in business.

XML.Hansard-Body: Despite the floods and cyclone, the majority of our big projects are on time, on track and on target. The Bruce Highway upgrade between Sankeys Road and Traveston Road is on track for completion in June next year. The Douglas Arterial duplication in Townsville is on schedule. The Townsville Port Access Road will be up and running at the end of next year as planned. The Griffith Arterial Road and the intersection upgrade of Mains and Kessels roads is still scheduled for completion by June 2014. The Mount Lindesay Highway between Rosia Road and Chambers Flat will also be on time--that is, ready at the end of this year. That is good news.

Main Roads has embarked on the biggest reconstruction job in its history. While road crews are busy repairing and rebuilding roads right across the state, our sights are still firmly fixed on the road ahead. Today I can announce that a study has been completed on the Fitzroy River flood plain. I commend the members for Keppel and Rockhampton for being the driving force behind this study. It could not have come at a better time. For the first time, we are asking the community to look at the formal options on the table. We want the community and industry to help us shape Rocky’s road network of the future. We want to come up with a solution that is in everyone’s best interests.

Today I can also announce that Port Connect in the state’s south-east will be even bigger. Some $385 million will deliver a four-lane expansion of the Port of Brisbane Motorway. Our port is crucial to Queensland’s economy. Port Connect alone will generate more than 800 jobs and support thousands more for decades to come. Port Connect will see a four-lane extension and a duplication of the motorway all the way through to Port Drive. It has always been our hope to deliver a full four-lane upgrade, and now we are able to do it for significantly less money than first forecast. It is about value for money and it is about planning for and managing growth in Queensland, even in the toughest of times.

Hansard-Body.A: (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability) (10.04 am): The natural disasters that have devastated our communities over the past summer have also caused major destruction to our natural environment and native wildlife. That is why we have hundreds of scientists and rangers across Queensland working around the clock to help our environment recover. Right now, teams of rangers are out in the water in the Great Barrier Reef working with scientists from CSIRO, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and other research partners conducting reef health surveys across the area hit by Cyclone Yasi. Around 350 sites will be inspected to look at coral damage and marine health. This is a clear example of the huge effort underway to understand the impacts on this unique marine environment.

XML.Hansard-Body: This morning I am advised that the first series of surveys, conducted this week, has already found damage to coral reefs and, in some places, green algae covering the coral. The damage caused by the cyclone--a natural event--provides yet another reminder of the importance of building resilience in our Great Barrier Reef through our broader reef protection measures, which have now been in place for many years.

Our staff are also working tirelessly to assist some of our most threatened species affected by the cyclone, such as the rare cassowary population at Mission Beach. I can report that, as of today, we now have a total of 21 feeding stations between Mission Beach, Tully, Cardwell, Tully Heads, Etty Bay and Mount Mackay. Some 1,200 kilograms of fruit has been distributed to the feed stations as part of aerial food drops. This is the result of a huge effort by our rangers, volunteers who cut up the fruit and the local North Queensland businesses who donated this fruit.

Our national parks have also taken a big hit this summer, with natural disasters causing closures in almost half of our parks at some point. Our rangers are doing everything they can to get our parks back open for visitors, but it is a big job and in some cases access can be difficult. This week we have rangers travelling out to the islands off the coast from Townsville to Cairns to assess the damage and to identify where clean-up efforts can begin. Weeks of hard work have already gone into repairs and track clearing in parks across the Queensland mainland.

Safety is our priority. I thank the community for their patience as we undertake this major task of assessment, repair and reopening parks across the state. We want to see visitors return to our iconic parks to again enjoy the beauty of our natural environment.

Hansard-Body.A: (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (10.06 am): The state government is getting on with the job of rebuilding Queensland after the devastating floods and cyclones of our recent summer. I can also assure Queenslanders that we are also getting on with the job of strengthening disability services throughout the state. We want to ensure young people with a disability are making the most of their lives, that they are making an active contribution in their communities.

XML.Hansard-Body: Last week I saw firsthand the incredible difference our Post School Services program is making to young Queenslanders with a disability. I travelled to Townsville to open the Endeavour Foundation’s newly renovated Post School Services centre with the member for Townsville, Mandy Johnstone, and the member for Mundingburra, Lindy Nelson-Carr. The Bligh government committed $500,000 to this refurbishment, which will now benefit school leavers with a disability in North Queensland--enhancing their education, employment and social opportunities.

Also during this visit I met with dedicated staff from the Department of Communities who were working tirelessly in the city’s recovery call centre. This centre was contacting disaster affected residents and organising outreach for those unable to travel to access assistance. I want to pay tribute in this House to all Department of Communities staff and all non-government organisations out there who continue to help people during these times.

I am also pleased to today announce an extra $1 million for an early intervention program which will support 1,000 young Queenslanders. The Building Family Capacity initiative will benefit children aged up to 18 right throughout Queensland, from Ipswich to Innisfail. It will also reach families in Bowen, Rockhampton, Gympie, the Darling Downs, Brisbane, Logan, Redlands, the Gold Coast and the Sunshine Coast. Organisations funded through this program will help link children with a disability with training, education and social support opportunities.

The Autism Early Intervention Initiative is another example of our commitment to giving children with a disability the very best start in life. Next week I will be announcing the approved tenders for new autism centres of excellence to be established in Mackay and Bundaberg. Last year I did an autism listening tour around Queensland, and these two communities in particular sent the government a very strong message that they needed dedicated autism early intervention services. We listened, and we are delivering for families in Mackay and Bundaberg. The new autism services will make a real difference to their young lives, just like those already up and running in Cairns, Townsville, Rockhampton, the Sunshine Coast, Logan and Brisbane.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships

Hansard-Body.A: (Cairns--ALP) (Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (10.09 am): The Bligh government is keeping the pedal to the metal to close the gap on Indigenous disadvantage. This is happening across many portfolios--health, education, natural resource management, employment and even in sport. It applies to the Torres Strait Island communities, to the discrete Aboriginal communities and in the cities and towns right across Queensland. Very importantly, in the discrete communities there is a massive housing build underway. In its first year, the Remote Indigenous Land and Infrastructure Program Office has made major strides through much needed township-wide land surveying and town planning schemes. In fact, currently 13 land use planning schemes are underway. The program office is also on target with Main Roads to deliver draft road network surveys--in fact to be available in March--for Aurukun, Doomadgee, Napranum, Mornington Island, Pormpuraaw, Woorabinda and Wujul Wujul. We are finally in Cape York resolving land tenure, and the option of homeownership is on the table. I have no doubt that resolving land tenure will lead to a burst of public and private sector activity in the cape communities.

XML.Hansard-Body: This year we will deliver the first ever urban and regional strategy in which one of the key planks will be a focus on training and employment opportunities. We are also working on a new justice strategy to improve community safety in urban, remote and regional communities, targeting crime prevention as well as reducing reoffending. In education in this first term of 2011 there are 315 Indigenous students in the Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Foundation program being supported with scholarships totalling $1.1 million.

Next week, 23 February, will be the first anniversary of the new preamble to our Queensland Constitution, recognising the rightful place of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Queenslanders as the first Australians. Last week I was one of 21,000 people who came to celebrate the success of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people at the Indigenous All Stars rugby league showdown and other associated events on the Gold Coast. It was great to see pride in culture and a new confidence amongst many of our Aboriginal and Islander people, both on and off the field. It is a great sign of things to come.

Hansard-Body.A: (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (10.12 am): Today I want to welcome the appointment of a new tourism development officer for South-West Queensland. This appointment comes at a crucial time for the industry, with much of the state now on the road to recovery from the natural disasters. The new officer is Mr Denis Kenny and the role is an investment in the future of tourism in South-West Queensland. The role involves working with operators, tourism associations, local councils and industry to develop new tourism opportunities and build on the attractions of the region. Based at Charleville, Mr Kenny will drive tourism development across the south-west and southern parts of the central west. He will work closely with the tourism department teams in Toowoomba, Longreach and Brisbane. Mr Kenny has been involved in business and tourism planning, marketing, investment attraction and industry development for over 25 years, making him highly suited to this role.

XML.Hansard-Body: With much of Queensland recovering from the recent floods and cyclones, we need all hands on deck to get back on track. I am confident Mr Kenny’s experience will be a great help to growing the south-west tourism sector, which is worth $147 million to the economy each year. South-West Queensland already boasts attractions such as the Cosmos Centre and the Charleville Bilby Experience, and these products can be built upon and promoted. As with other regions in Queensland, one of the challenges facing the south-west region is to turn around the incorrect perception that all of Queensland is a disaster zone. Promotion of the south-west tourism offerings will help attract our important drive tourism market back to the region.

Outback Queensland and South-West Queensland in particular rely heavily on the grey nomad market to keep the industry going. In relation to this, I also want to take the opportunity to congratulate Ron Chapman and his board at Caravanning Queensland on their initiative to develop and fund a $400,000 campaign to promote road based tourism, which is worth millions of dollars of course to our economy each year. It is this sort of get up and go from Caravanning Queensland that shows that even if we get knocked down there is nothing that can keep us down. Through initiatives such as the new tourism officer and marketing campaigns we will see our tourism industry rebuilt better and stronger than before.

Hansard-Body.A: (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Transport) (10.14 am): While the government’s focus is on reconstruction in the wake of natural disasters, in my portfolio we are also getting on with the job of planning for the future transport needs of our fast growing state. Today I am pleased to release the final report and design for the Sunshine Coast’s CoastConnect. CoastConnect is a 23-kilometre green transport corridor which is set to improve sustainable transport options on the Sunshine Coast. It includes bus priority lanes, on-road cycle lanes, bus stations in key activity areas, bus stop upgrades, and bus queue bypasses so that buses can get more quickly around the lights. CoastConnect is an important part of our long-term plan to meet the transport needs of the fast growing Sunshine Coast by providing faster and more reliable public transport. CoastConnect will slash up to 13 minutes from bus travel times between Caloundra and Maroochydore and we will begin protecting the corridor so that users can enjoy the benefits sooner.

XML.Hansard-Body: Construction of the Noosa Junction bus station is already underway and construction on the route itself is planned to begin in 2014, with final completion between Caloundra and Maroochydore scheduled for 2019 as part of the government’s $13 billion boost to green transport on the Sunshine Coast. Under CoastConnect, public transport will become more reliable--buses will have their own space in the transport network; it will be more rapid, with significant travel time savings, making the bus a more attractive option than the private car; it will be more comfortable, with new bus stations being built at Maroochydore, Kawana, Currimundi and Caloundra and improvements being made to more than 70 bus stops; and it will be more accessible, with additional stops, more accessible locations and feeder bus services to main transport routes.

Planning for CoastConnect will be consistent with the local council’s planning, and we are working very closely with the Sunshine Coast Regional Council, which, as members know, has a strong commitment to public transport, as part of this project. I thank the Sunshine Coast community for its valuable input into shaping this plan. Government has listened. Throughout the development of CoastConnect we have incorporated community feedback in a number of ways, including minimising impacts on Alexandra Parade and Aerodrome Road, as the member for Maroochydore sought for us to do, increasing car parks and fast-tracking the Maroochydore bus station. Over $13 billion has been allocated to boost public transport and cycling infrastructure on the Sunshine Coast over the next 20 years as part of the South East Queensland Infrastructure Plan and Program. Copies of the documents are available now on my department’s website.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (10.17 am): The unprecedented combined effects of flooding and Cyclone Yasi that we have experienced in recent months have affected every primary industry sector in Queensland. Since the initial flooding events in Central Queensland in mid-December, I have visited around 24 communities in Central Queensland, South-West Queensland, Darling Downs and the Cyclone Yasi impacted region of North Queensland. Our initial estimates for total primary production losses for these combined events of unseasonal rain and December-January flooding are estimated at $1 billion, with around another $700 million in primary production losses from cyclones Anthony and Yasi.

XML.Hansard-Body: I have been speaking to primary producers, small business, industry and local government about the flooding and the cyclone damage suffered and the levels of assistance required for recovery. We have been working with the federal government and yesterday we announced a comprehensive assistance package for primary producers and small business to continue the recovery process. Cotton crops in central and southern Queensland have sustained an estimated $150 million to $200 million in flood damage. The grain sector on the Darling Downs and South-West Queensland has also suffered heavy losses in the range of $125 million to $250 million. The dairy industry on the Darling Downs experienced supply chain issues resulting in around $15 million to $25 million in losses.

Cyclone Yasi largely impacted the cane, banana and tropical fruit growing areas of the North Queensland coast and the Tablelands. Close to 100 per cent of the banana crop on the coast between Innisfail and Cardwell has been affected, with estimated losses between $100 million and $200 million. However, the banana crop on the Tablelands received minimal damage, meaning that banana supplies should not reach the critical levels that were experienced after Cyclone Larry.

Other horticultural losses, including papaya, lychees, avocados and other exotic fruits, are estimated at between $275 million and $400 million. Sugarcane losses due to Cyclone Yasi are estimated at around $200 million to $300 million. We have been working with the federal government to provide the most appropriate assistance required to enable primary producers and small businesses to rebuild, replant and recover.

In all the communities I have visited there has been a feeling of shock but also resilience. Producers are philosophical about their individual circumstances and mostly want to get on with the job of recovery. We will provide every assistance we can to aid.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Flood and Cyclone Legal Help Service

Hansard-Body.A: (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (10.20 am): For the past two days this chamber has heard some heartbreaking and harrowing accounts of the impacts of floods and cyclones on communities across Queensland. Now that the floodwaters have receded and the cyclones have, for now, dissipated, the Queensland government is focused on helping affected communities recover as quickly as possible. This is certainly a primary concern within my portfolio areas of Justice and Industrial Relations.

XML.Hansard-Body: One of the key responses, as I mentioned yesterday, was the Flood and Cyclone Legal Help service. This free service is operating in all regions affected by the recent natural disasters--areas such as Brisbane, Ipswich, the Darling Downs and south-west, Bundaberg and Wide Bay-Burnett, Rockhampton, Townsville and Cairns. Last week, more than 500 people attended free community forums organised by this service at Ipswich, Goodna and Karalee. Another eight forums are planned for South-East Queensland and extra forums will be arranged for regional Queensland. Almost 2,000 hits have been recorded on the website that was set up for this service--floodlegalhelp.qld.gov.au--and more than 100 people have received free legal advice. Flood and Cyclone Legal Help can also be accessed through toll-free number 1300651188.

Several other initiatives are also being implemented within Justice and Industrial Relations to help Queenslanders get back on their feet sooner. Fees to replace important documents such as birth and marriage certificates have been waived in areas affected by floods and cyclones. We are also allowing flood and cyclone victims who have outstanding fines with the State Penalties Enforcement Registry to have enforcement action suspended.

From a workplace health and safety perspective, inspectors have conducted almost 1,600 field visits to flood affected businesses. Asbestos experts have also been deployed in Far North Queensland to help residents, employers and councils manage the risks posed by asbestos during the clean-up. A special hotline--1800177717--has also been set up to provide advice about asbestos safety. These initiatives are designed to assist flood and cyclone affected communities and are part of the Bligh government’s commitment to helping victims recover from these disasters as quickly as possible.

Hansard-Body.A: (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (10.22 am): As members are aware, this sitting week has been dedicated to a condolence motion regarding the recent natural disasters and to debating the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill, which will establish an authority to coordinate the state-wide reconstruction and recovery program. As many members have commented during the week, while these disasters have caused devastation across Queensland, the Queensland spirit has been strengthened and the response of individuals and communities has been courageous and heroic.

XML.Hansard-Body: The Premier has previously announced that Queensland Week this year will be extended--it will run from 4 June to 13 June--and will be dedicated to the heroes and everyday volunteers of the disasters and recovery. Events will be held across Queensland to recognise these individuals and, given the significance of these ceremonies and their importance to communities, members of parliament should be able to be in their electorates to participate.

Therefore, I wish to advise the House that the budget sitting week, which was scheduled to occur at the same time as Queensland Week, will be postponed by one week to commence on Tuesday, 14 June. The government considered the option of rescheduling budget week to be a week earlier than Queensland Week. However, that would have meant that the House would sit for the regional parliament in Mackay and that that sitting week would be immediately followed by budget week. This was considered to be impracticable with respect to prebudget planning. A memo outlining the revised sitting dates for the first part of 2011 will be distributed to members shortly.

Hansard-Body.A: (Nicklin--Ind) (10.24 am): I rise to make a personal explanation. Yesterday in my contribution to debate on the Premier’s condolence motion I named and thanked people who had volunteered at The Shack drop-in centre and travelled to Brisbane to help in the clean-up. Unfortunately, in my speech I referred to these people as people who often do the wrong thing. I was wrong. The people I named are the volunteer leaders at the drop-in centre and not clients of the centre. I apologise to these people for this mistake.

XML.Hansard-Body: Ms NELSON-CARR (Mundingburra--ALP) (10.25 am): I lay upon the table of the House three reports of the Social Development Committee: Report No. 11, titled Meeting with the Commissioner for Children and Young People and Child Guardian held on 12 November 2010 ; Report No. 12-- Meeting with the Health Quality and Complaints Commissioner held on 12 November 2010 ; and Report No. 13-- Meeting with the Family Responsibilities Commissioner held on 12 November 2010 .
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Tabled paper: Social Development Committee--Report No. 11--Meeting with the Commissioner for Children and Young People and Child Guardian held on 12 November 2010.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Social Development Committee--Report No. 12--Meeting with the Health Quality and Complaints Commissioner held on 12 November 2010.
Tabled paper: Social Development Committee--Report No. 13--Meeting with the Family Responsibilities Commissioner held on 12 November 2010.
XML.Hansard-Body: These reports put on the public record the formal meetings the committee held in order to fulfil its obligations to monitor and report on the Commission for Children and Young People and Child Guardian, the Health Quality and Complaints Commission and the Family Responsibilities Commission. The meetings enabled the committee to examine a range of issues relating to the operation and functioning of the commissions and provided a valuable opportunity for the committee to follow up on issues raised during previous meetings.

I would like to thank the commissioners and their staff for assisting the committee in this process and look forward to meeting with them again in the near future. I commend these reports to the House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Bundamba--ALP) (10.26 am): I table the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s report No. 45--a report to the Legislative Assembly on the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011.

XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Scrutiny of Legislation Committee--Report No. 45--Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (10.26 am): I table report No. 5 of the Economic Development Committee titled Inquiry into developing Queensland’s rural and regional communities through grey nomad tourism , an executive summary and submissions Nos 88 to 93 as well as second parts to submissions Nos 2, 16, 19, 22 and 57.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Economic Development Committee--Report No. 5--Inquiry into developing Queensland’s rural and regional communities through grey nomad tourism.
Tabled paper: Economic Development Committee--Report No. 5--Inquiry into developing Queensland’s rural and regional communities through grey nomad tourism--Executive Summary.
Tabled paper: Economic Development Committee--Inquiry into developing Queensland’s rural and regional communities through grey nomad tourism--Submissions 88 to 93 received in relation to the inquiry.

Tabled paper: Economic Development Committee--Inquiry into developing Queensland’s rural and regional communities through grey nomad tourism--Submissions 2, 16, 19, 22 and 57 received in relation to the inquiry--Additional parts to submissions.
XML.Hansard-Body: Tourism plays an important role in regional Queensland, with potential economic, social and environmental benefits if managed correctly. Grey nomads make up a specific niche market that caters towards older travellers, and this market is only likely to increase as Australia’s population ages. Although grey nomads appear to spend less per day than other tourists, they tend to take longer holidays and spend time in regional areas. For some small rural and regional communities, grey nomads are likely to be very important tourists.

In order to manage and grow this tourism market, the committee made a number of recommendations, including the Queensland government offering marketing support to local councils to help council officers develop their skills marketing to this group, making available grant funding to regional tourism organisations outside South-East Queensland for the purpose of marketing attractions to grey nomads and investigating the benefits of employing grey nomads in social service areas such as child protection and community corrections.

The committee process is an important opportunity for public participation in the parliamentary process. I would like to particularly thank the submitters and witnesses who gave of their time, expertise and experience to assist the committee’s deliberations. I would like to thank the members of the committee for their deliberations and work in compiling this report. I would also like to thank the committee staff who have assisted the committee through this inquiry.

Hansard-Body.A: (Condamine--LNP) (10.28 am): I give notice that I will move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That subordinate legislation No. 354, Fisheries Amendment Regulation (No. 1) 2010, tabled in the House on 16 February 2011, be disallowed.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Natural Disasters, Rural and Regional Queensland

Hansard-Body.A: (Beaudesert--TQP) (10.28 am): I give notice that I will move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House:
Notes the devastation caused by the natural disasters to primary producers and the need to develop a long-term strategy to rebuild these essential industries in Queensland; and

Calls on the Premier to implement a ‘buy 100 per cent Queensland’ campaign which can be made visible to consumers on purchasing, similar to the successful proudly Australian Made campaign to boost business confidence in rural and regional Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Natural Disasters, Rural and Regional Queensland

Hansard-Body.A: (Burnett--Ind) (10.28 am): I give notice that I will move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House notes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. The recent unprecedented natural disasters (cyclones and floods) have caused catastrophic financial hardship for many rural and regional Queensland families and small businesses.

2. The government assistance packages, loans, grants and hardship payments have failed to provide the funds needed to prevent many rural and regional small businesses and families from going broke or declaring bankruptcy.

3. The trial establishment of special economic and tourist zones, which significantly cut or abolish taxes like payroll and stamp duty, will dramatically increase the chances of job creation, survival and prosperity for many rural and regional small business and communities.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And calls on the Treasurer and Premier to form an all-party committee to plan for the establishment of special economic and tourist zones for rural and regional Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Today in the House we will be visited by parents, students and teachers from Ironside State School in the electorate of Indooroopilly and from St Eugene School in the electorate of Morayfield, which I am told is also the school once attended by the member for Morayfield. I do not know whether that is a warning or an example. The students of Ipswich Grammar School will be visiting in the Speakers’ Hall today.

Mr LANGBROEK (10.30 am): My first question without notice is to the Premier. Yesterday the Premier was asked to release all documents provided to state cabinet, along with the minutes of the meeting relating to the briefing on 18 October 2010 by the Bureau of Meteorology warning of multiple natural disasters. The Premier responded stating, ‘I do not see any problem with that being made public.’ Will the Premier now publicly release for Queenslanders the minutes and the cabinet documents as she undertook to do yesterday?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. I am happy to advise the House that the material that was presented by the Bureau of Meteorology to cabinet on 18 October was posted on my website at six o’clock this morning and has now been available for about five hours. As I indicated yesterday, the material is made up extensively of Bureau of Meteorology website material. In fact, everything that was presented to the cabinet was already available either on the Bureau of Meteorology site or on other weather sites, with the exception of one document which is listed as ‘embargoed’ and it was released the following week by the bureau. It was presented to the cabinet while it was still being refined and on 26 October it was put on the website.

What was the conclusion of the bureau’s presentation? The conclusion was that we could ‘expect with some degree of confidence a fairly active cyclone season and a continuation of the above-average rains and associated flooding’. We were advised that we could expect up to six cyclones. What did I do with that information? I issued a press release on the same day in which I said that the bureau had told cabinet ministers that Queensland could experience up to six cyclones and well above average rainfalls. I went on to say that we had not seen predictions for up to six cyclones since the 1970s, that there was a 75 per cent chance we would experience much higher than average rainfall and that we were actively heeding those warnings. I table that for the benefit of the House.
I then held a press conference on this issue which was attended by all media outlets.
Mr Robertson: Stop being so secretive!

Ms BLIGH: Yes, and I secretly told an entire media gallery that the last time these sorts of weather patterns were observed was in the mid-1970s and that the bureau was warning not only of a higher risk of cyclones but of a significantly higher risk of intense levels of rainfall and monsoonal activity right across the coast coming down as far as the south-east.

What happened? What did the Australian , the national broadsheet, report on page 3 the next day? It reported, secretly on page 3, that Australians along the coastline faced a summer of double the number of tropical cyclones, heavy rainfall and warm wet conditions. You could find the same in other newspapers--on the front page of the Queensland Times , ‘Be warned. Huge flood is overdue’; the Cairns Post , ‘Prepare for the worst’; the Gold Coast Bulletin , ‘Braced for stormy time’; and the Courier-Mail , ‘State on full alert for storm season’. Every one of them were quoting me, quoting the bureau and quoting the material that had been provided to the cabinet.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question without notice is also to the Premier. I refer to the emergency response room for the Queensland government water grid managers, and I have a picture of it here that I will table.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Photo of Emergency Room located in a flood zone.
XML.Hansard-Body: The emergency response room was rendered useless during the floods as it is located in a building that was closed down because it was built in a flood zone. Which Labor minister is responsible for locating the emergency response room in a building that cannot be used in an emergency?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. What we have seen in these unprecedented floods that took rivers to unprecedented and record highs right across the south-east and right across other parts of the state is that buildings have been located in less than desirable places. This is not the only one. You will find that councils have done the same thing. You will find schools and buildings where, frankly, governments of all political persuasions in the last 40 years have forgotten some of the lessons of 1974 and forgotten some of the lessons of the floods in regional Queensland prior to 1974.

What is the challenge for us as a government, as a community and as a state? It is to learn those lessons and to remember them. That is one of the reasons we have a commission of inquiry and it is one of the reasons we are setting up a Queensland Reconstruction Authority--so that any lessons that need to be learned can be learned. Mr Speaker, the clock was not on but I think I have said as much as needs to be said.
Mrs KEECH: My question is to the Premier. Can the Premier update the House on the progress of the government’s $321 million election commitment to build 240 extra kindergarten services by 2014?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. The honourable member, along with I think about 11 other members of the House, today celebrates the 10th anniversary of her election as a member of parliament in 2001, so I congratulate the 2001 members who are here. It has been a decade of great achievement by them. A number of them were cruelly referred to in their first term as ‘oncers’ and they are still sitting here 10 years later, so well done.

As I said earlier this morning, as we rebuild and recover from these disasters, one of the challenges will be to ensure that we do not take our eye off the ball when it comes to the other responsibilities and the other priorities of our government. We are a government that is absolutely committed to the power of education to transform lives, and nowhere in the education system is that more true than in the early years of education. For a range of historical reasons, the last 50 years of the last century saw Queensland underinvest in those early childhood years, particularly in comparison to other states and, in some cases, councils and local governments in other states of Australia. We are determined to overcome that legacy.

That is why we made a $321 million election commitment to build 240 new kindergartens right across the state. We are now rolling those out. Fourteen new services opened for the 2011 school year and three more are scheduled to open this year, building on the six last year. I am very pleased to advise that the program is now starting to ramp up and the latest 28 services have been approved. I table that list for the benefit of the House.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Additional state schools with new kindergarten service to open in 2012.
XML.Hansard-Body: I am sure the whip will be pleased to know that both Highland Reserve State School and Mount Warren Park, which are both in her electorate, will be homes to two new kindergartens in the 2012 year. All of these services are in areas of high demand: from Cairns to the Gold Coast and in places like Mackay, Rockhampton, Bundaberg, Gladstone, Bribie Island, Beaudesert, Springfield, Logan and Bowen. These are all places which have not had the services that families there need and we are going to rectify it. We are going to rectify it because we understand that investment in early childhood education is an investment in our children but it is also an investment in the long-term prosperity and strength of our economy and state. Dollars spent in this area repay taxpayers over and over and over again for many decades to come. We are determined to continue to roll out those kindergarten services.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Premier. I refer the Premier to the mounting legal costs for government departments and agencies as they prepare to defend themselves for government decisions relating to the floods. Will the Premier give an undertaking to publicly release monthly updates on the internal and external legal costs incurred by each department and agency, along with the names of legal firms and practitioners engaged?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question. Our government has established a commission of inquiry. I should point out that we established it four days after the Brisbane River peaked so I think it is probably one of the fastest established commissions of inquiry in our state’s history. We established that commission of inquiry because we share the questions of Queenslanders and we believe that they are entitled to answers to their questions. It is absolutely imperative to the safety and wellbeing of our state and the people who we represent here in this chambers that we ask those questions; not only ask those questions but also provide a forum with this inquiry that has all the powers necessary to get the answers to those questions. We understand that that can only be done with the full confidence of the public by a commission of inquiry with all the powers necessary to seek that information.
In doing so, yes, government agencies will be called by the commission to present evidence. So they should be.
Mr Schwarten: And local government.

Ms BLIGH: Local governments will be required to do the same. So they should be. There is no way that the commission of inquiry can do its work unless government agencies fully cooperate with it. Does that mean that some public servants will have to collate material for the inquiry? Of course it does. That is a good purpose; that is something that they should be doing. Does it mean that legal advice will be sought where appropriate? Of course it does. In every commission of inquiry ever held by either side of politics in Queensland every single time the full legal costs to government have been disclosed, and of course they will be on this occasion. Equally, it will be entirely evident which barristers or lawyers or firms are representing government because they will be at the inquiry. Some of them might be wearing bags over their heads or maybe secretly talking to the commission, but I do not expect so.

This is a deeply serious business. There are people who have lost their lives, people who have lost loved ones and people who have been through a deeply traumatic event who want answers to some of these questions. They need to have absolute confidence that this commission of inquiry will do its job and do it fairly, impartially and rigorously. I have absolute confidence in the people we have appointed. I have absolute confidence in their impartiality and their ability. I can give absolute confidence to the public that every single government agency over which I and our government have control will fully and totally cooperate with anything that the commission requires. That means giving evidence, that means providing documents, that means assisting in any way that we are requested to do so. Will all of the costs of that be made public? Of course they will be. They always have been.

Mr O’BRIEN: My question without notice is also to the Premier. Could the Premier update the House on the policy of governing the state from the regions and the Premier’s excellent choice for the next region to benefit from this strategy.

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for Cook. I believe that I have made an excellent choice in deciding that next week we will take the lessons from governing from Townsville to the wonderful city of Cairns. For four days next week I will be governing from Far North Queensland. I will be based in an office in the CBD of Cairns. I will be meeting with people from the Cairns city and the Cairns region. I think everybody knows that since the GFC Cairns has been one of the areas that has struggled to get back on its feet. Its tourism industry has been hit hard and its construction and property investment industry is still reeling.

I have spent a lot of time with the business community in Cairns but far too often because of my obligations to be in other parts of Queensland I am in there for maybe a day and then out again. The opportunity to totally immerse myself by living and working in Cairns will give me the same chance that I believe I had in Townsville to really get a much deeper understanding and I look forward to the chance to do that. It will also, given all of the terrible misfortunes that have occurred in those towns to the south of Cairns, in the Cassowary Coast and Hinchinbrook regions, give me a chance to be located close to those places and to travel into them and spend a bit more time with the people and the mayor of that area than I have been able to do to date because of things like my parliamentary commitments.

I look forward to joining with the member for Cook and the other Cairns members. I know that a number of members have already made it their business to get a list of not only people who they are keen to get through my door to talk about their issues and concerns but also people who have actually got some good ideas and solutions that they would like to see the government pick up. I am very much looking forward to being there next week. I expect that it will be a busy time.
