I should also note on behalf of all of the House that just as we have this week marked the devastation caused by Mother Nature across our state, it seems that few places in Australia are escaping the wrath of weather. As people who live in or love North Queensland, our thoughts today are with the people of Darwin and the Northern Territory as they battle their own stormy weather. Thankfully Cyclone Carlos does seem to have gone off the coast but not without battering the city of Darwin. There are many homes in Darwin that are today reported as inundated. Those of us who have been out to flooded cities and towns across Queensland know the heartbreak and the devastation and I will certainly be conveying that on behalf of Queensland to the chief minister, Paul Henderson, and his team and offering whatever assistance we can as they go through their own version of these events.
Mr NICHOLLS: My question without notice is to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the most recent damning economic report, this time by the Centre for Independent Studies--
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Those on my right, the member for Clayfield has the call.

Mr NICHOLLS: I refer the Treasurer to the most recent damning economic report, this time by the Centre for Independent Studies on state taxes, borrowings and spending--fiscal management. Given this report rates Labor’s fiscal management of Queensland as stone cold motherless last, will the Treasurer tell Queenslanders how he rates his own performance?

Mr FRASER: I am aware of the study from the CIS. I am entirely sure that it is a centre and having looked through it I can call it a study; I am just not so sure that I would give it the moniker of being independent. The reality of this report is that it goes through the statements from the states as at 30 June last year. As I said in my address to the parliament earlier this morning, by using the arbitrary date of 30 June last year that just so happens to not include the significant dividends from the balance sheet restructuring that we have undertaken. The midyear update that the government has already released shows that our projected debt levels are, in fact, $10 billion lower than was projected at budget time. The challenge here for the report in its independence is that it is only out by a factor of $10 billion, but other than that I do accept its findings.

The reality is that this government made very clear decisions about what we would do in order to prioritise an infrastructure program and a capital works program to keep people in jobs, to keep regions moving and to keep industries moving through the global financial crisis. Yes, that put a great deal of stress on our balance sheet. Those facts are clear. But equally this government, while having the courage to make that decision, had the courage to put in place a program in order to balance that entry, in order to divest those things to ensure that the balance sheet had a position of strength and is returning to strength. The midyear update details that by a factor of, as I said, around $10 billion.

While this report takes a point-in-time analysis, I might say that I would look forward to the report from the centre for studies on 30 June next year. I presume at that time it will independently incorporate the facts of the matter, and that is what has been achieved over the last six months. Of course, what we do not know in this context is anything that the opposition would have done during this time because all it has been interested in doing for the last two years of this parliament is to oppose and to criticise without ever proposing and putting forward a policy. What have we seen so far as we look to rebuild the state’s economy? Have we seen any positive endorsement of Queensland business by those opposite? No, we have not. What we have seen is yet again a continuation of its campaign to talk down Queensland and our economy. Right now we need to stand above the politics. We need to rise above it. It is in everyone’s interests in this parliament and around the state to join together to advocate for the interests of Queenslanders, not to take a report which, as I detailed earlier today before question time, has a massive gap in its analysis. What we should be seeing from the opposition instead is a bit of positivity and a bit of proposing, not just criticism and opposing.

Mrs ATTWOOD: My question is to the Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development. Can the Treasurer update the House on assistance available to manufacturers and small businesses affected by the floods?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Mount Ommaney for her question and, indeed, for her strong advocacy for the businesses of her electorate. Her electorate, like mine, was significantly impacted by the floods. I know that a great deal of both the member’s residential and business community were massively affected by the floods. She contacted me in the immediate aftermath of the flood event on behalf of her local businesses. We were able to send out teams of people from the department of economic development and innovation in order to provide on-the-ground assistance out of the back of a van to businesses to ensure that they were able to access assistance. I thank the member for Mount Ommaney for her advocacy on their behalf.

We now see more than 30 local government areas in which assistance is being provided to small businesses, including $5,000 immediate recovery grants plus a further $20,000 available in concessional loan arrangements. That is there to help small businesses, which are vital employers in the state, get up and running. That is a key mechanism to ensure that we keep small business moving. It is the engine room of employment. It is the engine room of any economy, and Queensland is no different.

Manufacturing in particular has seen an impact from both the flood and the cyclone around the state, most particularly from the flood. Together with QMI Solutions, which has a well regarded reputation around the state and enjoys the support of both sides of the House, we will be conducting a range of clinics across the state, starting next Wednesday on Brisbane’s south side, to help out those businesses in the south-west corridor. We will be providing practical help about overcoming supply chain constraints, about equipment shortages and those things which can be a challenge for businesses.

We have also launched a new program to get the rest of Australia to help support Queensland. I encourage all members to log on to the Queensland government website. It is www.qld.gov.au/backinbusiness. Through social media, we are out there putting forward Queensland business to the rest of the country and, indeed, the world. We have prominent Queenslanders like the Young Australian of the Year, Jessica Watson, the Governor-General, Lydia Pearson and Pamela Easton and ‘king’ Wally Lewis, who are all providing testimonials through social media to encourage people to use Queensland businesses, holiday in Queensland, make a choice to access Queensland produce and to provide their support in their normal, everyday life. I encourage all members to log on to the site and circulate it through their own channels so we can get this campaign up in the social media through Facebook and other methods to ensure that all of Australia and, indeed, the people around the world, who have done so much to help out Queensland to date, can continue to help by making the simple choice of buying Queensland first, putting Queensland first. That is to the benefit of business. That is going to be to the benefit of the economy and to the benefit of all Queenslanders.

Mr DOWLING: My question without notice is to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to today’s report by The Centre for Independent Studies that specifically states that Queensland ‘is not in as strong a position to deal with the aftermath of the recent flood disaster as it would have been several years ago’. Given this independent finding, could the Treasurer advise to what extent economic mismanagement and squandering of the state’s finances will hinder the speed and the scale of recovery from the floods?

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow minister for his question and congratulate him on his appointment to the front bench. It seems that one of the qualifying criteria for joining the front bench of the LNP is to be a global financial crisis denier. The reality, of course, is that there was something that happened over the last couple of years. Yes, it was a global financial crisis. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition missed it. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition completely missed it during the election campaign. At the end of last year he said that it happened a year later than it did, such was his denial of it. Of course, we have seen the member for Redlands rocket on to the front bench because he obviously has the rocket scientist approach to denying the global financial crisis. Of course there was a global financial crisis. No-one here or outside is denying that except for those on that side of the chamber.

What happened is this. We took a view about prioritising the building program and we made decisions in order to position the state for an economic recovery. As I said, what was occurring yesterday? As I detailed yesterday, we saw business investment growing for two quarters--at a rate above the nation in the September quarter. Business was coming back. What have we seen? We have seen 18 months of jobs growth. We positioned this economy ready for a recovery. It was building towards the end of last year and building into this year, and what has occurred since then? Yes, there has been an intervening event over the Christmas period. That, of course, was going to knock the state back down. That report may well say that, but I cannot find an economy in the world that is in the same position that it was two and a half years ago before the global financial crisis. If the honourable member can say that no economy suffered any impact from the global financial crisis whatsoever, I would be glad to hear about it. I am sure he can ring the ‘centre for non-independent studies’ and get them to send him a note about what might have happened.

However, as we have said many times before, yes, Queensland was impacted by the global financial crisis. We did take a big hit. We are the second most trade exposed economy in the nation. Of course it was going to impact on us more so than in other places around Australia and indeed around the world. What did this government do? It put in place a program to recover. That recovery was underway. The evidence about that is clear. I am equally confident that by this year’s end, according to the forecasts we have seen, this is an economy that will be hitting capacity constraints rather than suffering from a lack of demand. That is because we are going to see the sort of investment decisions that we have seen come home and build strength in the economy. We are going to see a reconstruction effort add to that. The Queensland economy deserves the support of the opposition and the LNP, not a campaign to talk it down.

Ms JOHNSTONE: My question is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. Can the minister inform the House about the lessons learnt from Cyclone Yasi regarding cyclone shelters?

Mr SCHWARTEN: Before I go any further I just want to assure the House that, further to my statement yesterday, we now have 25 day labour QBuild people and two qualified asbestos aid contractors on site at Tully Heads and Hull Heads to assist in the clean-up. That shows the advantage of having a day labour workforce.

I thank the honourable member for her question and her interest in this matter coming from a cyclone affected area herself. I must congratulate the members in Townsville on the efforts that they put in during that cyclone recently. Having been there a couple of days later, I know it was a pretty horrific experience.

One thing to take away from the experience is that the majority of buildings in North Queensland withstood this damage. So the advice for people to stay in their homes was, in fact, the best advice, especially if their home was built after 1980. That message went out very loudly and clearly and it turned out to be the right one because there has been no loss of life.
I am not going to do what the opposition did and just go out and make idle promises to people that we are going to build evacuation centres in places where we do not have the money to build them.
Opposition members interjected.
Ms Bligh: That was not the election promise.
Mr SCHWARTEN: No, that was not the election promise. You can dress it up as much as you like--
Mrs Stuckey: Undress it.
Mr SPEAKER: The minister will direct his comments through the chair. The member for Currumbin will cease interjecting.

Mr SCHWARTEN: The fact that all of the buildings there survived proves that they are cyclone proof. The new buildings that were constructed under BER are included in that. Some of those are not suitable to be made into shelters. An $500 extra per square metre is what it costs to strengthen these buildings. I contend that we ought to be looking at the best possible options of how to do that, instead of going around and saying, ‘We’re going to build evacuation centres from Bundaberg through to the Torres Strait with money that we do not have.’ What an idiotic proposition that is. We saw the opposition leader up in North Queensland promising that the other day, but guess what? The members opposite are in here today asking about the budget. That seems of little interest to them when they go out big-noting themselves and talking about evacuation centres. It does not seem to matter that the money must come from somewhere.
Ms Bligh: Are they going to do it before or after they underground the power?

Mr SCHWARTEN: Undergrounding the power, $60 billion. That is spending money like water. I have never seen a group of people who are so overinflated with their own view. I would like to buy them at my price and sell them at theirs; we would solve the deficit problem.
The bottom line is that the common-sense view here is to look at the buildings that have survived and look at how we can further strengthen them rather than build new ones.

Mr CRIPPS: My question without notice is to the Minister for Public Works. Yesterday the minister was asked if the government had delivered on its promise following Cyclone Larry to develop a construction timetable to build cyclone shelters within 100 days of the 2006 state election. The minister canvassed a number of issues, concluding that the government was now considering ‘whether we want to squander money on evacuation centres’ but did not commit to release the timetable. Will the minister now commit to publicly release, for the information of all Queenslanders, the promised 100-day timetable to build cyclone shelters in Queensland communities vulnerable to cyclones?

Mr SCHWARTEN: I think I just answered that question, but let us go through it again. The decision that was taken following Larry--and a promise was made--was that we would deliver, as part of our building program, the strengthening of buildings, and that has already happened. That has already happened, and within 100 days--I have a letter here somewhere that I wrote to the previous Premier that I will table that outlined exactly what we did in that regard.
Opposition members: Table it.
Mr SCHWARTEN: When I find it.
Mr SPEAKER: The minister has the call. Those on my left will cease interjecting.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I said I would table it. Just sit there and relax. The bottom line is that we undertook that, as part of the building program, we would strengthen buildings in Far North Queensland. We have done that and we will continue to do that. Despite the misquoting from the honourable shadow minister--he has got off to a good start, tangling the words. I can tangle my own words without needing any assistance from him. He has fitted into the mould of the dishonesty over there quite well.
Ms Spence: I think he’s doing better than his predecessor, though.

Mr SCHWARTEN: He is doing a little bit better than his predecessor; that is true. The bottom line is that I did not say that the government was looking at this. I gave an opinion yesterday. I actually said that I had not discussed it with the Premier, but my view was that the common-sense approach that we ought to take to this is to have a look at the buildings that are there, evaluate with the emergency services people exactly what happened and see what we can make out of those buildings that are there. That is part of the promise that we made.

The Commonwealth government did not want to come to the party in the BER stuff--fair enough. Had they been buildings that we built then they would have fitted into that mould--no problem. I do not see what the issue is. They are out there desperately trying to invent an issue out of this. I want the honourable shadow minister to come into this parliament and tell me the costings of the promise that you made yesterday that you would build--
Mr Cripps: What about the promise that you’d release the timetable?

Mr SPEAKER: Order!
The honourable the minister will direct his comments through the chair. The member for Hinchinbrook will cease interjecting.

Mr SCHWARTEN: The promise was made by the wet-behind-the-ears shadow minister yesterday that he was going to build these centres all over Far North Queensland, from Bundaberg to the Torres Strait islands. I want to know what the budget allocation is for it. I want to know how much it is going to cost. You made the promise, not me. I want to know how much. The opposition leader was in Townsville last week promising this. I want to know how much it will cost. What I am offering, as a different point of view, is to look at the infrastructure that is there and strengthen it where need be--add toilets and showers to those buildings, for example. Do we need to go and talk to the private operators of the Earlville shopping centre and upgrade that somehow to make an evacuation centre out of it? There has been another crisis here, and we should learn from it.

Mr FINN: My question without notice is to the Minister for Education and Training. Can the minister inform the House how Queensland students are showing their support for flood and cyclone affected schools and students?

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for the question. Today is SchoolAid relief day right across not just Queensland but also Australia, led by non-government charitable organisation SchoolAid, which links a number of agencies encouraging support to staff and students of schools in disaster and related emergent circumstances. Indeed, after Cyclone Larry SchoolAid, through its initiatives, raised approximately $170,000 to assist the schools in Far North Queensland in response to that cyclone.

This morning I had the privilege of attending Brisbane State High School to open a conference about spinal injury and raising awareness about spinal injury and to introduce internationally renowned Rick Hansen, whom the Premier spoke of in parliament on Tuesday, who at the age of 15 suffered a debilitating spinal injury and who has done remarkable things. There I discovered that Brisbane State High School has embraced the voluntary program of supporting schools and students through the relief day. A day or so ago the students there raised a significant sum of money to contribute to the Premier’s disaster relief fund. Today they joined with me in observing a minute’s silence, which is the second way in which schools are being invited to participate. Further, they had lowered the Australian, Queensland and ATSI flags to half-mast as a sign of respect for those families and those people who have lost loved ones in these disaster. That is happening right across Australia today.

It is illustrating the breadth of community support for what is happening here in Queensland. That has happened on a number of other fronts. An 80-year-old lady in Sydney, because she had no money, sent three rugs that she had knitted to be given to schools for their first aid room for students. A lady in Stanthorpe went down to the local shop and purchased back-to-school gear, put it in her car and drove from Stanthorpe here to Brisbane to give it to OneSteel Pty Ltd to donate to schools. Tony Schreiber from one school--he does not want to be mentioned but I will mention him--filled up his car, drove to Condamine and delivered a load of gear to the Condamine school. He organised aircraft to do drops at a number of schools that were flood isolated. That is an illustration of what the community is doing.
Mr Schwarten: I table the document I referred to earlier.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 14 December 2006, to then Premier Beattie regarding the cyclone proofing of public buildings.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr ELMES: My question without notice is to the Minister for Emergency Services. After Cyclone Larry, Labor promised to hold annual cyclone summits. I table the announcement.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Media statement, dated 8 December 2006, by then Premier Beattie regarding new measures to help prepare for cyclones.
XML.Hansard-Body: In 2008, the minister himself reiterated this pledge ‘to hold annual summits at the end of the cyclone season’. Why did Labor, after Ms Bligh became Premier, cancel these vital summits in 2009 and 2010?

Mr ROBERTS: The summits were not cancelled. In fact, last year--I cannot recall the exact date--I think it was held in Townsville. It was jointly held on the last occasion with the Local Government Association of Queensland. The original commitment was to hold those conferences immediately following the cyclone season. I made a decision, in consultation with the department, that it would be far better to conduct those forums prior to the seasons, particularly gaining the experience of what had happened the year before.

I do not have the date with me, but I can assure the member that a conference was held within the last 12 to 18 months and additional conferences will be held. The last one I attended was in fact I think up in the Burdekin region. That was held in cooperation with the local governments. A whole range of issues affecting emergency services personnel in responding to disasters were discussed. Indeed, local government has been the foundation of our disaster management system. That was a key focus at that particular conference.

The member has raised issues about preparation for the cyclone season. I might just talk a little bit more about that, because local governments are in fact the foundation of our cyclone response. As I have indicated, since I have been minister there have been two of these forums held--and I will get those dates and locations to the member. I can assure the member that, following the briefing that was given to cabinet in October last year, there have been extensive preparations undertaken by state government departments, local governments and emergency services agencies to prepare for these disasters.

As the Premier has indicated, she secretly held a media conference to advise Queenslanders of what preparations had been undertaken and secretly put out a media statement advising that directors-general and ministers had been advised to make sure that their departments were ready. In fact, Emergency Management Queensland, in a very sneaky move, went around North Queensland and put up massive billboards advising people to prepare for the cyclone season. Every single year--
Ms Bligh: A cunning plan.

Mr ROBERTS: It was a cunning plan. They did it in the middle of the night. They put these billboards up reminding people to be very careful and to seriously remind them about the need to prepare for cyclone season.

Every single year the disaster management agencies and local authorities meet not just at this annual forum--and I will get the dates to the member--but also at workshops conducted by Emergency Management Queensland. Preparations are made to ensure that communities are prepared. Extensive media campaigns are undertaken.

I launched the storm season late last year. In the far northern region the local disaster management groups and councils conduct extensive media in terms of preparing people and providing information for the cyclone season.

Mr HOOLIHAN: My question without notice is also to the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services. Could the minister advise the House of any initiatives that are helping to enhance the great work done by rural fire brigades across the state?

Mr ROBERTS: I thank the member for Keppel for his question and acknowledge the great support that he provides to his local rural fire brigades. I particularly acknowledge that the brigades in the areas of the member for Keppel and the member for Rockhampton fought some of the worst fires in history in the Rockhampton region.

Many members might be surprised to know that the volunteers in our rural fire brigades actually play a very active role in responding to storm, cyclones and floods. The skills and expertise that rural fire brigade members have are transferable to helping respond and recover from not just fires or fighting fires but also responding to disaster events. For example, during the recent cyclone and floods I met up with many rural fire members. In Ingham I stayed at the same hotel as a large group of rural fire volunteers who were operating chainsaw teams to clear debris and support evacuation centres and the like. Those volunteers play a very important role in supporting all of the other emergency service agencies in responding to all types of disasters.

We have 34,000 volunteers in the rural fire brigades across Queensland. Around 10,700 of them are actually qualified as firefighters and many others support those activities. As I have said, as well as firefighting they do a range of support activities.

The number of rural firefighters has grown by more than 700 from December 2009 to December 2010. Today, the government is very pleased to announce the reallocation of some funding that was originally allocated to support what was expected to be a very severe bushfire season this year. We all know that we had one of the worst bushfire seasons on record in 2009. We expected a similar season this year. Because of all the rain it has not happened. Money that was allocated to support those operations--and a lot of additional money was allocated to aerial operations et cetera--has now been reallocated.

Of that, half a million dollars will go to station upgrades, $250,000 for additional equipment, $150,000 for GPS units to assist local identification of water supplies et cetera and around $50,000 for station wear uniforms. The rural brigades obviously get their protective equipment supplied but the station wear for formal occasions, which is very important to them, is being rolled out and the service will continue to do that.

In terms of the equipment they may purchase and upgrades to station amenities it may include solar systems, tanks, training rooms, new equipment such as generator kits, stand pipes, portable water dams, reversing cameras for fire appliances. All these pieces of equipment and upgrades will be available under this $900,000 plus program which has been reallocated from the allocation for fighting the fire season this year.

Mr HOPPER: My question is to Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland. I refer the minister to the milk price war between Coles and Woolworths and its likely impact on the sustainability of milk production and family farms in Queensland. Can the minister inform the House what actions he has personally taken to ensure that the supermarket turf war does not further harm the Queensland dairy industry which is already suffering greatly from the impact of recent floods and cyclone damage?

Mr MULHERIN: I thank the honourable member for the question. This is an issue that the member for Condamine and I are at one on. I have met with the Queensland Dairymen’s Organisation regarding this issue. The pricing of milk is a commercial issue. It is not generally government business since deregulation, but I am concerned about the likely impacts that it will have on our dairy farmers. Since deregulation I think there are about 600 producers producing 500 million litres of milk for Queensland.

The price cuts for generic brand milk is driving more and more people away from the processor brands to the generic brands. This enables the larger supermarkets to put leverage on the processors. That is passed on to the milk producers, the dairy farmers. Over the last nine years we have seen about a 25 per cent shift away from the processed brands to the generic brands.

Woolworths and Coles are saying that they will not be forcing the reduced price back on to the processor and the milk producer, the dairy farmer. This is really not the case. For example, under some of the contracts that dairy farmers have with Pauls the price is linked to the processor’s brand. As there is a shift more away from the processor’s brand that will drive the price down. Over time my concern is that we will have a situation where more and more people will move to the generic brand.

What we need is a very transparent process. I understand there is also a Senate inquiry in relation to this matter. I have written to the federal Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry concerning the issues that I have raised this morning. I am waiting on a response from him.

Mr WETTENHALL: My question without notice is to the Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships. Would the minister inform the House of any progress on fulfilling the Bligh government’s commitment to deliver land justice for the people of Mona Mona?

Ms BOYLE: I thank the honourable member for the question. I put on record that the member for Barron River has relentlessly pursued the resolution for the people of Mona Mona and their wish to be connected for all time to the future of the Mona Mona Reserve. It is spectacularly beautiful country, situated as it is adjacent to the World Heritage listed Wet Tropics area.

It was during the 2006 election campaign that the member for Barron River first brought Mona Mona’s interests to the fore, and the Bligh government committed to reexamining the future land tenure of this site. A proposal was developed, but it was not agreed. So in 2009 the Bligh government committed to getting the Mona Mona land sorted out once and for all.

Mona Mona itself has had a varied history. It was established as a Seventh-day Adventist Church mission in 1913. In 1957 it was re-gazetted by the Bjelke-Petersen regime for the purpose of building the Flaggy Creek hydroelectric dam. That led to the mission closing in 1962, with residents moving on to the communities of Hope Vale, Yarrabah, Palm Island and elsewhere.

While the dam was never built and many people had moved out, a strong connection was retained to this beautiful place with its cultural significance. Over the past two years there has been extensive consultation with the Mona Mona people to ensure decisions about the future of this land reflected the best interests of all concerned. It has been critical throughout this process to ensure that the proposed lease conserves the social, cultural and environmental values and assets of the land.

I am pleased to report to the House that on 12 December a 30-year lease agreement was signed with Mona Mona Bulmba Aboriginal Corporation. I was especially delighted to be part of the celebrations alongside the member for Barron River that were led by chairman Andy Duffin and the Mona Mona elders and the Mona Mona Bulmba Aboriginal Corporation. They were huge celebrations of great emotional depth and significance to the people of Mona Mona.

We have delivered nearly 1,600 hectares of land back to the people of Mona Mona. I am very pleased to report that the Mona Mona lease was then formally registered in the titles office on 31 January 2011. Most importantly, this outcome will ensure that elders and young people can maintain their sense of country and their sense of belonging now and for future generations. A new and significant chapter for Mona Mona people has begun.

Mr MESSENGER: My question without notice is to the police and emergency services minister. I refer the minister to his answer given to the member for Keppel and also correspondence I have received from valued community member Mr Hank Repard, who served for 27 years in the military before founding, joining and becoming the group leader of the SES at Woodgate and then he and his wife Pam becoming highly qualified members of the Rural Fire Service. Hank says in relation to his Emergency Management Queensland qualifications--
Mr SPEAKER: Order! There is far too much preamble. Would you get to the question please?
Mr MESSENGER: Mr Repard says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I can go out and cut down trees for the RFS, but I can’t cut down trees for the SES because the two organisations don’t mesh up anywhere.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Order! I would ask the honourable gentleman to get to the point of his question.

Mr MESSENGER: Can the minister explain why qualifications gained while volunteering in either the SES or the RFS are not automatically recognised and interchangeable between both emergency Queensland services? Will the minister agree that if qualifications gained in the RFS were also recognised automatically in the SES it would strengthen both groups and stop the loss of good people who get sick of duplication, unnecessary red tape and waste?

Mr ROBERTS: I am happy to look at that particular issue. I do not know the particular qualifications that the member is talking about, but, as most members in this chamber are aware, we have had nationally consistent accreditation of training courses in this country for many years. I would hope that, whether it be the Rural Fire Service or the SES or indeed any other organisation that is using nationally accredited modules and competencies, they would be transferable between agencies. So I do undertake to follow that issue up, because I think that is an important issue. If people are trained to use a chainsaw in the SES, they should be able to use it in the rural fire brigade. So I will follow that through.

On that issue of training, both the Rural Fire Service and the SES commit a considerable amount of their resourcing each year to training of our volunteers. It is important to have people appropriately trained and appropriately accredited due to workplace health and safety requirements, not just for the operators but also for the people who might be nearby when those operations are taking place. I thank the member for the question and I will follow that up. I would hope that the transferability between both of those agencies is achievable. In fact, I know many members of the SES who are also members of the rural fire brigade, and we would hope that that consistency applies.

I might just follow on from the question that the member for Noosa asked. With his first question to me as the shadow minister for emergency services, it is really disappointing that he got it so wrong. I would have hoped that he would have tried to follow in the footsteps of his predecessor--who got a lot of things wrong as well, but he did try hard to get the facts. I had to come into this chamber on many occasions to correct the record, because anything that came out of the mouth of the member for Mirani on emergency services issues needed to be very closely scrutinised to get to the truth.

For the benefit of the member for Noosa, I put on the record that following that commitment I became minister in 2007. In April 2008 the Natural Disaster Summit--Building Resilient Communities was held in Townsville which emergency services agencies and councils attended. In 2009 the Natural Disaster Summit--Building Community Resilience Through Collaboration in partnership with the Local Government Association of Queensland was held in June in Emerald which I attended. In 2010 the Natural Disaster Summit--Disasters Just Happen But Building Community Resilience Does Not was held on 4 June in the Burdekin, as I indicated. That commitment that was given by former Premier Beattie has been continued with. In fact, that process has been strengthened by developing the program in consultation with the Local Government Association of Queensland, which is a very strong partner in responding to emergencies across the state.

Ms JARRATT: My question is to the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading. The floods and cyclones we have seen have affected many areas of the state and many industries. Could the minister inform the House what the government and the tourism industry are doing in partnership to help the rebuilding process?

Mr LAWLOR: I thank the honourable member for the question. Just last week of course cabinet meet at Airlie Beach in the beautiful electorate of Whitsunday, and that is a good example of one of the problems that we have with tourism after these weather events. In Airlie Beach the weather was absolutely perfect, the sun was shining and there was a light breeze. But people were cancelling their holidays, and that is what we have to combat--the perception that Queensland generally is a disaster area. I stayed an extra day and met with many tourism operators and there was a common complaint against the media because of the idea that they wanted to persist with the description that it was ‘cyclone alley’. As one of the tourism operators explained to me, there has been no damage from a cyclone in Airlie Beach since 1970, so one could say that it is one of the safest areas of the state when it comes to any property damage.

Following the cyclones and floods the Queensland tourism industry is back in business. Indeed, most tourism destinations have never been out of business. Resilient and resourceful operators across the state are ready to welcome visitors. Most operators affected by the floods and cyclones were back in business within just a few days, and I pay tribute to their determination and hard work to achieve this. To assist, the Bligh and Gillard governments have jointly committed $10 million in emergency funding to spread the message that Queensland is open for business and ready to welcome visitors. Further to this, Tourism Queensland has launched a five-year global incentive travel strategy aimed at putting Queensland on the map as one of the world’s top travel destinations. The strategy was launched at the Asia-Pacific incentives meetings and events convention in Melbourne this week to an audience of the world’s top incentive travel planners. The Asia-Pacific incentives meetings and events convention is a premiere meetings and incentives event for the Asia-Pacific region and it draws event planners from all around the world to discover the latest ideas, to network and to do business.
Mr Elmes: How much funding?

Mr LAWLOR: Incentive travel is one of the most lucrative travel markets based on unique experiences that are used as rewards for companies’ top-performing staff. I hear the shadow minister say, ‘How much funding?’ He verballed Daniel Gschwind yesterday. I have actually spoken to Daniel Gschwind, who rang me, and you should talk to him about the furphy that you put around about him demanding $50 million.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The minister should direct his comments through the chair.

Mr LAWLOR: In fact, that was a number that was suggested by a journalist. In fact, it was a media conference in which Daniel Gschwind was congratulating the Bligh government and the Gillard government for the contribution of the $10 million. He said that it would go a long way to dispelling the story--

Mr EMERSON: My question is to the Premier. I refer the Premier to the damage caused to CityCat terminals in my electorate, including the major terminal at the University of Queensland, resulting from the floods caused by the release of water from Wivenhoe Dam. Will the Premier publicly release for Queenslanders all documents forwarded to the federal government seeking a special circumstance ruling that would immediately release funding for the Brisbane City Council to rebuild these vital CityCat terminals?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. I answered a very similar question yesterday, and I am sorry that he was not listening. I have not sent documents. What I have done is met personally with the Prime Minister and, as a result of that meeting, established a working party between federal Treasury officials and state Treasury officials, and done so for a very good reason. There is no precedent for these sorts of facilities to be included in natural disaster relief arrangements, so we have to work through what sorts of facilities would be included in any definition of a change, what the implications of that would be, what the costs would be et cetera.

Those discussions have been entered into by the Commonwealth with a great deal of goodwill and we are systematically working our way through them. I, however, do share the shadow minister’s concern about the CityCat terminals. They are a very important part of the public transport network of our capital city and, like him, I want to see them up and running as soon as possible. To that end, this is a good example--and I think we have waived the anticipation rule so I can talk about this--of how the Queensland Reconstruction Authority could actually help make that happen faster. Without the Reconstruction Authority and the powers available to it--and I think there are some seven CityCat terminals that are inoperable--the city council would have to submit to the department of environment, to the department of resource management and to the department of transport seven separate applications for seven separate approvals in seven separate environments.

Under this legislation they could present a plan, we could declare each of those as reconstruction areas and require decisions to be made within a dedicated time frame for each of them. This is an opportunity, I accept, for the city council. Each of these CityCat terminals has been developed over a number of years. This is a unique opportunity for them to look at everything that they have learned about what makes a good CityCat terminal over the past 15 years and rebuild to a higher and better standard that is more uniform and that will add something to the aesthetics of the cityscape.

I certainly want to see the CityCats back and operational. I understand just how important they are not only to the city council but to everyone who lives in the city and to everyone who visits it, because without them it puts more pressure on our bus and other public transport systems, including rail. I can reassure the House that the work that is being done is serious work. As I said, it is work that is being done in a spirit of goodwill and cooperation and I think a little patience would not hurt.
Mr SPEAKER: The time for question time is over.

Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (11.30 am): I advise honourable members that the House can continue to meet past 6.30 pm this day. The House can break for dinner at 6.30 pm and resume its sitting at 7.30 pm. The order of business shall then be government business, followed by a 30-minute adjournment debate.

Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (11.31 am): I present a bill for an act to provide for the powers of inspectors under legislation about fair trading, and to make consequential amendments, and other amendments for particular purposes, of the Funeral Benefit Business Act 1982, Introduction Agents Act 2001, Land Sales Act 1984, Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act 2003, Residential Services (Accreditation) Act 2002, Retirement Villages Act 1999, Second-hand Dealers and Pawnbrokers Act 2003, Security Providers Act 1993, Tourism Services Act 2003 and Travel Agents Act 1988. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Fair Trading Inspectors Bill 2011.
Tabled paper: Fair Trading Inspectors Bill 2011, explanatory notes.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (11.31 am): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Fair Trading Inspectors Bill 2011 represents the Bligh government’s ongoing commitment to a fairer and safer Queensland by protecting consumers and promoting a competitive, fair and informed marketplace. The bill does this by providing a stand-alone act which provides harmonised and consolidated inspectorate provisions for investigating, monitoring, and enforcing compliance with fair trading legislation. These inspectorate provisions deal with the appointment, powers and responsibilities of Office of Fair Trading inspectors, as well as offences relating to their exercise of power.

Effectively, the bill establishes that there is a spectrum of enforcement powers available to the Office of Fair Trading, ranging from least to most intrusive, relative to the seriousness of the potential breach. It is not intended, for example, that search and entry provisions be used to settle a dispute over a refund between a trader and a consumer. On the other hand, where there are serious and systemic breaches afoot, the bill provides for immediate and substantial powers that can protect consumers from suffering substantial losses.

The bill implements recommendations made by two separate reviews, the first being a 2002 internal review of the Fair Trading Act 1989, with the second being a 2007 review of the then Department of Tourism, Fair Trading and Wine Industry Development by the former Service Delivery and Performance Commission. Both reviews identified that there were inconsistencies in the inspectorate provisions contained in fair trading legislation, and that there was no substantive reason for the inconsistencies. Additionally, the bill is consistent with moves at the state and federal level to harmonise legislative provisions, creating an environment in which inspectors and traders alike are left in no doubt as to what enforcement actions are possible and appropriate.

The bill provides common inspectorate provisions for the following acts, which are referred to in the bill as ‘primary acts’: Funeral Benefit Business Act 1982, Introduction Agents Act 2001, Land Sales Act 1984, Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Act 2003, Residential Services (Accreditation) Act 2002, Retirement Villages Act 1999, Second-hand Dealers and Pawnbrokers Act 2003, Security Providers Act 1993, Tourism Services Act 2003, Travel Agents Act 1988.

The bill will also apply to the proposed new acts which repeal and split the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act 2000 into industry-specific acts. As members would recall, on 24 November last year I introduced the Agents Financial Administration Bill, the Commercial Agents Bill, the Motor Dealers and Chattel Auctioneers Bill and the Property Agents Bill.

The bill represents a harmonisation and consolidation of the inspectorate provisions contained in fair trading legislation and has been drafted using the most recent precedent provisions developed by the Office of the Queensland Parliamentary Counsel. These precedent provisions have been developed to have sufficient regard to fundamental legislative principles. This is an acknowledgement of how critical it is to ensure that inspectorate provisions are exercised appropriately and with sufficient regard to the severity of the situation.

Members should note that the Office of Fair Trading does not merely investigate and prosecute breaches of legislation. It also proactively monitors and ensures compliance with the legislation, for instance, by conducting spot checks and requesting information and documents from traders. In fact, in 2009-10 the Office of Fair Trading monitored over 11,870 entities for compliance.

The bill therefore contains powers to enter and search places, obtain documents and information, obtain offence related and monitoring warrants, and seize and forfeit evidence. These powers essentially continue those currently available to Office of Fair Trading inspectors across fair trading legislation. The bill also introduces a new power for inspectors to stop vehicles, which is naturally required if inspectors are to be able to search vehicles. The power to stop and search vehicles is necessary as vehicles are just as likely to contain evidence as places, particularly for itinerant traders.

In order to strike an appropriate balance between generic enforcement provisions and specialisation, a schedule to the bill contains provisions which modify the common provisions in the body of the bill for certain primary acts. Finally, the bill repeals the inspectorate provisions in the primary acts and makes the necessary consequential amendments.

By addressing inconsistencies and providing a stand-alone act dealing with the appointment and powers of inspectors, the bill should improve the enforcement and compliance activities of the Office of Fair Trading. The Fair Trading Inspectors Bill 2011 represents the Bligh government’s ongoing commitment to protecting consumers and promoting a competitive, fair and informed marketplace. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Mrs Stuckey, adjourned.
Resumed from 16 February (see p. 193), on motion of Ms Bligh--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr DOWLING (Redlands--LNP) (11.37 am): Today I rise to speak to the Queensland Reconstruction Authority bill 2011. This bill seeks to amend six acts: the Building Act 1975, the Disaster Management Act 2003, the Integrity Act 2009, the Land Valuation Act 2010, the Public Service Act 2008 and the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act 1971. I am not entirely clear why the amendment to the Building Act 1975 has been proposed. Could it be because of the impossible deadlines that were set only some six months ago in relation to the pool fencing legislation--something that was echoed here in this House? I am also not sure--and when you read it, it is ambiguous to a point--whether this amendment applies immediately right across the state. Obviously, these questions will come out in the course of the consideration in detail. Why would the amendment relate to communities that have not been affected--areas like mine, for instance? Redland City was unaffected by flood. This pool safety initiative was heralded by the government as a must-do thing to preserve life at all costs. The Redland community has not been affected in any way, shape or form by the floods other than through their generosity. Why would that community be in this deferred plan for pool compliance. It also begs the question about communities like the Gold Coast, which was not affected, and the Sunshine Coast, which was largely not affected. It throws up some questions and I suggest to the House that it could relate to the impossible deadlines that were set back then and the lack of a capacity for communities to comply.

The second amendments I have questions about--and, again, it is probably more about the process--are the amendments to the Land Valuation Act from a UCV to a site based valuation. Again, I believe there were some impossible deadlines and that that is primarily why these amendments have been included with this bill. I would also question again why it involves communities like Redlands, the Gold Coast and a number of other communities around Queensland which were not affected, which had no flood issues and which had no properties involved. Why has it been moved out unnecessarily for these councils? These councils rely upon these valuations to determine their rate base, their strategy and their budget. It raises questions about the broad, sweeping nature of some of the conditions within this legislation as well as some of the more specific ones.

The LNP will be supporting this bill because the bill is an essential step towards restoring Queensland’s flood affected communities--or at least that is the intent. While it is not a perfect bill and it is not a response without risk, it is a response. More importantly, we have a responsibility to our communities. They need the reassurance of this parliament that the recovery effort is underway and is being done in a cohesive and bipartisan way. As outlined by the Leader of the Opposition during his condolence motion, we have a higher responsibility now, in the period post the floods and during the recovery, to ensure that no-one is left behind. I recognise that the Premier spoke about this in her second reading speech, when she said that our message to Queensland is that no part of Queensland will be forgotten. That is important as we go forward, so I recognise that.

Communities that have been through this trauma need to know that we will rebuild and we will protect them. They need to believe that lessons are being learned from the floods and the cyclones, and they need that bipartisan commitment that we will assist them. In the last couple of days we have spoken in this House about the grief that has struck at the heart of our communities and our state. We have heard harrowing recollections and we have saluted the courage and bravery of everyday Queenslanders who have made us proud. We now need to show action. We need to make a start on building a better Queensland--a stronger Queensland and stronger communities--from the debris and the wreckage. This bill is an effort in that direction. It is one step and it must be accompanied by the commitment of this government to listen to criticism, to improve on its performance, to measure its achievements and to learn from its failings.

The commission of inquiry is underway and its first report is due in August. Under this legislation, the authority has no role in the hindsight issues of floods and cyclones. Its job is to rebuild; it is not to provide blame nor exoneration. That is rightfully the role of the commission. It was, however, of concern to me when reading the explanatory notes to this bill that one of the authority’s functions will be the ‘possible implementation’ of the commission’s recommendations. If we do not learn from history, we are doomed to repeat it. Answers are needed and answers will come. When they do, our communities deserve to hear them and they deserve a response to them. The implementation of the recommendations of the commission will be core to that response.

A recovery effort does not need escape clauses. It needs the government to front up to its responsibilities. There is no point in having a commission if the government intends to ignore its findings. I am pre-empting the findings, but I believe that an issue that will be spoken about is advance warnings. When I travelled through some of the west country, through Cecil Plains and that area, I heard from farmers, locals and business operators that the river warning systems along those rivers are inadequate in some areas and non-existent in others. That advance warning system is critical if we are to do anything towards preserving life and making communities immune to flood. Those types of issues need to be addressed in the creeks, waterways and rivers right across Queensland.

There will be questions about the management of Wivenhoe, both generally and on the day. I suspect there will even be questions about how the Wivenhoe management strategy has been able to change post the flood as compared to pre the flood. There will be questions about insurance--how this government manages its own insurance issues and how insurance companies behave and perform within our community. There will be questions about flood immunity.

The flood mitigation measures will have to be implemented quickly, in time for next summer. The first findings of the commission will be released in August, in a preliminary report. That leaves very little time for the authority to act to implement any strategies. I also note that the authority has been given the responsibility for facilitating flood mitigation. While it is necessary, it is of concern that these responsibilities have been so freely and happily handed over to the authority.

While this is a time for compassion, support, recovery and rebuilding, it is not a time for the government to escape responsibility for its neglect. Floods are not a new occurrence in this state of Queensland. The devastation wrought in the last few months is not an opportunity for a handover of forgotten responsibilities. Previous disasters have brought torrents of promise and commitments. Unfortunately, we have seen many of those discarded with the debris, forgotten soon after the houses were rebuilt and the communities were re-established.

The aftermath of Cyclone Larry is a case in point. So much that should have been learned from Larry has again been shown up in Cyclone Yasi to the detriment of Queensland communities. The greatest result this bill can deliver is effective assistance and rebuilding. The worst is a jungle of bureaucracy, buck-passing and conflict between levels of government and departments. My fear is that the layers of bureaucracy already evident in this legislation will slow down the process, will divert resources from those in need and will make the rebuilding a saga to be endured rather than a process to be enjoyed. This is part of the reason that a separate ministry for recovery and reconstruction is required. The priority for the state is the reconstruction, and that needs the dedication of a minister who can concentrate solely on the important task--someone who can be devoted to ensuring communities and individuals get back on their feet.

The priority for this state will be to act as quickly as possible and to keep the bureaucratic impositions and processes to a minimum. The factor in this is cooperation between the levels of government, yet the authority has overriding powers in the legislation. While the need is evident, my hope is that those powers will be used cooperatively and not confrontationally.

Our councils have been battered; they have been as battered as the communities they represent. They deserve the support of the government and not the Big Brother approach of dictating directives. The government has a record of telling communities what is best for them instead of listening to the voices of the communities. This is a good opportunity for the government to change its approach and start listening to what our communities need. Never has it been more evident than in the accolades given to local authorities the length and breadth of Queensland because of the way their mayors and councillors stepped up to the plate and worked in partnership with the emergency services and police and delivered on the ground. I think they have demonstrated that they have the capacity and the ability and that they are willing, so they should be very involved in that process. Instead of sidelining communities and decisions which affect them, it is time the government realised and learned from the experience and common sense that those people possess. Their input is to be valued.

The legislation before us gives the minister a number of powers of oversight and intervention. There is a great onus on the responsible minister to utilise those powers wisely without being political. The communities that will emerge from the rebuilding need to be a sign of the respect and consideration that is owed to their residents. The rebuilding is not a memorialisation of government or the Premier; it is a chance to give our communities the best possible future and to provide them with a safer place to live, better infrastructure and economic re-establishment. The economy in smaller communities particularly is essential. If we do not get those businesses functioning, if we do not get those men on the land spending and investing in their communities, those communities will cease to exist. There are towns that are reeling and will continue to reel from the disaster. These areas urgently need infrastructure and services to ensure their continued viability. They need to have attention paid to the social impact on an equal par with the economic impact. Without restoration of the heart of these communities the economic lifeblood will also drain away. The response to these disasters needs to be quick and effective. It cannot be a hastily put together job that fails to fulfil its brief. It cannot be a drawn-out process that would allow the damage to accrue and fester.

Under this legislation the powers of the authority will be quite wide ranging. There are a number of interventions that can be undertaken. Land can be declared as acquisition land. This rightfully allows the owners to remain on the land until a later time but the owner cannot dispose of the land to any other entity. While the value of the land will be compensated to the owner there have to be questions raised over the effect that such a declaration will have on the value of the land such as the time at which it is done and who the entity will pass on to. There are questions about what will occur when the authority disbands. Will the particular department or local authority still pay for that property?

Several of the clauses are breaches of fundamental legislative principles justified by the fact that they are required to effectively and safely rebuild communities. However, provisions such as entry to land are necessary to ensure full and proper knowledge of the facts. Others such as the power to require information from any person, a penalty-accompanied measure, have an obvious basis but also raise concerns over the limitations of its use.

Putting into effect the strategic priorities of the board is essential if these priorities best serve the communities. If political interference weighs heavily in the process it will be to the detriment of all. While those who are affected by the disaster need our support and attention we must be vigilant that in assisting those people other people are not disadvantaged. The paramount considerations in the rebuilding should be cooperation, teamwork and compassion. That is a solid foundation for the future. As long as those principles are kept at the forefront of operations the bill will serve our community well. If they are forgotten, lost in the process or overlooked for expediency’s sake then the community will lose all over again.

Instances of profound tragedy still haunt our state. The disaster experienced in Grantham, Toowoomba, Murphys Creek and Withcott, in isolation an event so filled with grief and hurt, is one particular tragic piece of the overall picture of loss and sorrow. Our thanks and gratitude go to those who have demonstrated the spirit of Queensland. Our sympathy and our thoughts go to those who have lost so much. Our hopes and optimism go towards the rebuilding that will occur throughout the community and our state. The experiences will ensure that we forget neither the people nor the lessons. We need to ensure that advance warnings are better and more accurate. We need to include rural communities and farmers as a priority. We need to ensure that employment and economy are at the forefront of any recovery. We need to ensure that waste is minimised. We need to ensure that red tape is cut. We need to rebuild the economy. We need to rebuild infrastructure. We need to rebuild community. Tragically Labor has a pedigree of waste, mismanagement and debt. We need to learn from the past or we are deemed to relive it at our peril.

Mr SPRINGBORG (Southern Downs--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition)
(11.54 am): In rising to contribute to the bill before the House, which, as previous speakers from the opposition have indicated, is a bill that the LNP will be supporting, we will be asking some questions. Whilst the bill might not be perfect, it goes a fair way to putting processes in place that will be necessary to ensure proper recovery from the flooding events that we have seen and also after the quite significant devastation caused by Cyclone Yasi.

The impacts of the floods we saw around Queensland were many and varied. As I indicated in this House on a previous occasion during the condolence motion, there were some areas of Queensland where the flood level did not exceed the levels in the 1990s, in some areas it exceeded 1974 and in other areas it did not, and the same for 1976 and 1956. Depending on where one is in Queensland, there are various markers, not only physical markers but markers that are burned in the psychology of those communities, of the flood that they always refer back to. There is no doubt that it was a major flooding event.

Later on I will make some comments about the language that was used to describe the flooding event which in itself I think probably caused people in some areas to become more concerned than they needed to be. As far as my electorate was concerned, there was a significant impact in some parts but the majority of people were not personally physically affected. That is also true across Queensland. The greatest majority of Queenslanders were not personally physically affected. There was a small minority of people in my electorate, as there was a small minority of people in Queensland, who were very deeply and personally affected because of the loss of life and the inundation of their homes and businesses that they have worked so hard for. It is also fair to say that, as a consequence of the fact that people know so many people and images were being beamed into our homes on a 24/7 basis, just about every Queenslander was indirectly affected. In many ways a lot of those Queenslanders became so personally traumatised by those images that it will have a profound and long-term effect on them. The same effect will be present in relation to Cyclone Yasi.

In my electorate it is true to say that people had their homes flooded. They will recover. There will be ongoing scarring for many of those people. A lot of those people accept the fact they will have a flood every now and again. They are fortunate enough to have insurance or fortunate enough that they have put in place contingencies such as raising their home so that the property loss will be mitigated as a consequence. We have had significant property inundation. Small businesses have been inundated. The biggest impact in my electorate has been on the infrastructure--the roads and railway lines. I will come to the impact on sporting infrastructure in some of our communities in a moment. They are areas that people have concerns about in relation to the short, medium and long-term recovery.

The dairy industry in my electorate was profoundly affected because there were supply issues. Many of those people were cut off. Trucks to pick up their milk were not able to reach them. In some cases they had to dispose of 20,000 to 30,000 litres of milk. Not only that, there is a significant animal welfare issue. As anyone involved in the dairy industry knows, it is not a matter of not milking your cows for a couple of days. If you do not milk your cows for a couple of days it has a significant impact on their capacity to be able to produce at a high level in that lactation cycle but also there can be a real issue in regard to mastitis in those animals. So there is an animal welfare issue for those farmers and that concerned them very much.

There was a major impact on the cotton industry in my electorate. I have mentioned severe soil degradation in the past around Cecil Plains that has had a major financial impact on those farmers. If it is good enough for the government to declare category D assistance in Cyclone Yasi affected areas--which were absolutely devastated, no doubt about that--there are farmers in my area who are similarly equally affected financially with hundreds of thousands and millions of dollars of exposure and I would encourage the government to look towards their inclusion in that category.

The grain industry has been very much affected as well. People have lost not just the winter crop but also the summer crops; they lost one summer crop and then replanted and lost another summer crop. In a drought people lose a lot but they lose it over a long period; it is a slow bleed. In a flood all of that which they have worked so hard to actually preserve can be destroyed virtually overnight. That applies also in the case of livestock in many cases. People may have actually kept them throughout the drought and then severe wet weather conditions can have quite a fatal effect on those animals. There are a lot of issues there.

Fruit and vegetables in my area have been impacted. Believe it or not, that impact has come from the speculation of high prices. As soon as people start to talk about the supply chain being affected and high prices, the prices actually go up. One of the vegie growers at Stanthorpe said to me the other day that they are actually getting less for their fruit and vegies on farm than they were before the floods. We have to understand that sometimes those who market beyond the farm take advantage of the disaster to skim something off the top. We have to be very aware of that.

A moment ago I mentioned the impact on sporting facilities. This is a major concern in my electorate. Looking at Warwick, for example, there is the Condamine flood plain. In many ways, that particular area, which does inundate in times of flood as it did this time, is put to good use. The Warwick Hockey Association is wondering how this recovery process is going to affect it. It is a wonderful organisation of volunteers, a magnificent local sporting club which has spawned previous Olympians like Lee Bodimeade. Back in the nineties that club was able to garner state government assistance, it loaned funds from the council and it was able to use a fair degree of its own finances to lay down a wonderful artificial surface. Only two years ago that surface needed to be replaced. Again, assistance from the state government was given as well as a loan from the council, which the club will pay back over a period.

That surface is now two years old. The minister is very much aware of this. The other day I went and had a look at that magnificent surface. The club is devastated by what the Condamine River has done. The waters got underneath the surface and it has rolled up like a huge caterpillar. Honourable members would not believe the power of nature. A thousand of the strongest men would not be able to do what nature did in this case. The river has probably rolled up 70 tonnes of sand in there as well. Just the disposal of that surface is a major problem.

It is a wonderful sporting club which put down its new surface only a couple of years ago. It had planned to pay that off over a period of time with the inevitability it would have to resurface some 10 years or so down the track. Now it is in the terrible situation of having to meet its obligations for the existing surface not knowing whether it will be able to fund a replacement surface. Of course, it will probably only have a few months to make decisions because it will start to lose players. The organisation, which is a part of the Warwick culture, could fold and that would be a major concern. I say to the minister--and I hope to speak with him at some stage--that there are these exceptional areas. I know that there probably is a limit on funds, but this is an organisation that is more than capable of standing on its own two feet. We have to do everything we possibly can to assist it in the future. I also went to the Warwick Cowboys rugby league the other day. Despite its level of damage and exposure, it has shown a great degree of resilience. That club suffered damage to its facility as well.

Another organisation in my electorate which has been significantly affected is the Southern Downs Steam Railway Association, a marvellous group of volunteers who have refurbished their own steam locomotive. They have also refurbished some carriages for Queensland Rail. They include an extraordinary range of skilled tradesmen and volunteers. It is a magnificent organisation and has been very financially viable. It is a non-profit organisation that runs steam railway trips for people. A lot of people travel on these steam trains from Brisbane and Ipswich down to the wine country, to Wallangarra and sometimes west to Goondiwindi. They also use the rail up towards Clifton and beyond. They have also been given the right to lease a small piece of rail line near Allora. That organisation has been dramatically impacted because it now cannot run even though it has bookings. If those lines are not open for it to use--and there have been some small rock slides south to Wallangarra; we know that there is a limit to the resources available to Queensland Rail--it may not be able to continue beyond April this year. That has been a labour of love that has continued for the best part of 15 years.

This is the impact which is floating at the moment below the surface in many of our communities in Queensland. I am not sure how the flood recovery organisation is going to be able to deal with those sorts of things, but there is capacity to be able to declare an area or a particular impact in a community. I am not sure how the bill’s declaration of areas will impact my electorate, but I do encourage that this does happen in the areas of greatest need.

The Queensland economy is also a significant worry. This statutory authority is going to put a lot of its efforts into dealing with community and economic infrastructure, which is going to be important for jobs and getting Queensland up and going as well. Over the last 24 to 48 hours we have heard a lot from the government about how we address this impression around the world that Queensland is somehow closed for business when indeed it is open for business.

I go back to what we saw during the flooding events. Not only the media but also government ministers and the Premier were actually talking about Queensland being three-quarters covered by floodwaters. That oversimplifies and overdramatises the reality of the situation. At that stage most of the tourism areas of Queensland were still open for business, whether it be Cairns, Townsville, the Sunshine Coast or the Gold Coast. Is it any wonder that this impression was built up around the world? We have to be very careful about the language being used and the way that language is being reported. Once people start to say that an area as large as Europe was affected, that seeds in the minds of people all over the world. An area as large as Europe--that is a multiplicity, that is scores of countries. People do not have a realistic perspective of what that actually means in the context of Queensland.

A lot of the flooding in areas such as the western part of my electorate was across vast levels of farmland. It isolates farmhouses and that is bad enough. A lot of those people are very resilient. Only a couple of days ago I talked in this parliament about farming families west of Goondiwindi who have been cut off, by and large, since the end of September. They are resilient; they are able to deal with that. That is also included in there as well.

However, when using this sort of language we have to be careful to say, ‘Yes, it covers a vast area of Queensland, but at the same time there is a lot of Queensland which continues to be open for business.’ The language was being used at that particular time but no thought was given to its psychological impact in the minds of people not only in Queensland but also interstate and overseas, which the government is now madly scrambling to try to correct. Whether it likes it or not, that actually sets the scene and creates the context in which a lot of people who might want to visit our country or do business judge what is happening here. I think that is a classic example of how we have to be very careful about the perceptions we build as we go along.

We have also heard the Treasurer carrying on in this place about the fact that we did not have the funds because of the global financial crisis. Let us revisit that crisis. This government predicted that it was going to lose $14 billion across the forward estimates as a consequence. It did not lose that at all. It did not lose near that. Once again, the government is taking it out there, using that as a shield and a veil and now tries to offer that as a reason for being unable to deal with this. It cannot blame other parts of Australia who might be saying, ‘Our governments insure, our governments re-insure.’ Queensland did not. What we saw from the Treasurer only recently when he was asked about this was very instructive. He said, ‘We did not think we would bother about it. We checked the market soundings. It was not good, but we knew the Commonwealth would come in and bail us out to the tune of three-quarters of the money that was owing.’ People in the other states who are levy payers are not going to be very happy about that when their own governments in South Australia, Victoria or Western Australia, which also has cyclones, or New South Wales or Tasmania actually re-insure their assets.

If the government makes a decision not to re-insure, that is a matter for it. However, it should do what governments in Queensland have always done until this Labor government came to power in the mid-1990s and that is make sure there is enough money in contingency to allow for it. We had no money in contingency, no insurance and no re-insurance. The government cannot blame people for wondering where all the money has gone. Where did the $34 billion in unforeseen revenue, which was accrued by this government between 2000 and 2008, go? It just went up in smoke. Some of that should have been put away in contingency as well. If it does not want to insure, it has to put the money in contingency, and that is what this government has not done.

This authority has a very important role to play as it goes forward. It has an important role to play in rebuilding and strengthening communities for the future. It has an important role to play in making sure that we do learn the lessons of the past. I mentioned the other day in this place that, after the 1893 floods, which in my electorate are still considered to be the largest floods, there were communities in my electorate which were moved a very small distance--sometimes just a few hundred metres--to take them out of flood prone areas. That, by and large, was a positive move. This Reconstruction Authority needs to consider that, and I am sure that it will with regard to areas where we have seen the most traumatic impact of these particular flooding events, because future generations will not praise us if we do not take that step now.

I know there is an extraordinary emotional connection. We have seen that in this place over the last few days from members of parliament who have stood up and said, ‘We are going to rebuild. We are going to do this.’ That is all fine. I understand that particular emotion.
