But what we also have to do is make sure that we inject an amount of common sense in how we go forward with regard to taking ourselves and people out of harm’s way. That can be done compassionately and that can be done properly. There is a very small window of opportunity, because we know that, with the effluxion of time, what often happens is that we tend to forget those lessons and we tend to think, ‘That is not as serious now as it seemed to be a little while ago.’

We have to re-engineer infrastructure to make sure that we are not just rebuilding it in the same substandard way or in the same place where it was damaged. We need to re-engineer the infrastructure in a better way and in better positions, whether it is roads or railway lines or other infrastructure. That is extremely important, because what this flooding event has taught us, and in many ways what Cyclone Yasi has taught us, is that infrastructure has let us down because we have too many eggs in one basket.

It is important that we have a sunset clause in this legislation, and we do have that. There are a couple of issues that I specifically want to raise. One is the suspension of land valuations until 30 June. I do not know how this will have an impact. It does not make sense to me, because most of those valuations today are done on a desktop. We have very few site inspections anymore; they are done on a desktop. I would hope that the government is not concerned about what has been a significant drop in valuations or property sales in recent times out there. The government has framed its budget, framed its midyear review, based on previous property values insofar as crown rent is concerned and also insofar as land tax is concerned. So if the government puts it off till 30 June, that will allow it to frame the budget on what will inevitably be higher valuations than what we would see before 30 June. I hope that is not some sort of excuse the government is using.

We need to look at the Q100 levels as well. I understand that there is some significant concern at the moment from within the property industry in Queensland that this is something that has to be addressed, because they need clarity with regard to what can be built, with regard to new development applications and also with regard to what can be rebuilt. It is very, very important, and I understand that a number of councils around South-East Queensland have those concerns.

We now see the suspension of pool fencing laws. We have all received emails from people in what they now describe as the ‘pool fencing inspection industry’. I do not like that term. We create regulations and a whole industry comes up around them. Nevertheless, it was deemed to be important enough a few months ago. We now have people who have skilled themselves and set up businesses. They are now concerned that they are going to be impacted upon in a major way, that they are going to lose their jobs and lose their homes. There is also the issue of safety of children in Queensland which was the primary motivator. Those things need to be addressed.

With regard to the suspension of deeming in this legislation, I implore that that not be used as an excuse for some sort of turgid dragging of the feet when it comes to consideration of development applications, because sometimes those things can be hidden behind the veil of flood. They have to be used properly and they have to be used appropriately.

Similarly with the acquisition of land, we have to make sure that that does not impact upon people with regard to the use of their property as collateral when it comes to the purchase of other investments or the purchase of other property. I think the acquisition provisions are a good idea, but we have to make sure that people are properly compensated when the property is acquired and that it does not have an impact on collateral.

There are a range of issues I should touch on, including the major contamination in my electorate with regard to the trickle hose upstream of Texas. This is a task beyond the council, and the government should move to help out as much as it possibly can.

Mr SHINE (Toowoomba North--ALP) (12.14 pm): I congratulate the government and particularly the Premier on this legislation that we see before the House today. It demonstrates a determination to face up to the issues arising out of the floods in terms of infrastructure damage immediately and with great resolve. The legislation that we see here gives to the government the power necessary to facilitate cooperation, coordination and prioritisation where it is needed.

At the outset, however, I thank the Premier for her announcement this morning which did not relate to infrastructure as such but related to assistance to community groups, non-government organisations and the like, which up until now were not eligible to receive a government grant or loan similar to businesses or farmers. That is a great move forward and will be appreciated by many organisations throughout Queensland which have been affected by the floods. The Premier did indicate the brief meeting she had in Ruthven Street, Toowoomba, with representatives of the Kath Dickson organisation, who are principally involved in child care. They will benefit, no doubt, from this, as will an organisation like 4DDB, which is a community radio station that was flooded out as well. I am very grateful to the Premier for advocating with the Prime Minister the extension of the scheme to cover these types of organisations so that they will be on the same footing, as I said, as businesses, farmers and, indeed, sporting associations and clubs as well.

With respect to the legislation before us today, I just want to mention a smattering, if you like, of examples of the infrastructure damage that was sustained in my electorate, my city and my region. If I can start with the most dramatic damage, I suppose, particularly to state government assets, and that was with respect to the rail damage on the Toowoomba range. This rail line was built in 1867 and, to a large extent, the route has not changed much since that time. Some of the original tunnels, I believe, are still in use. It has been, obviously, a vital link from the Port of Brisbane to the Darling Downs and South-West Queensland. It extends from Brisbane right out to Charleville, Quilpie and so on. It is absolutely important. In the other direction, it goes to Warwick, Dirranbandi and places of that nature. Its importance should be readily appreciated, and it certainly is by me.

The Treasurer travelled to Toowoomba, along with the Minister for Transport, whose responsibilities include QR. With them, I visited the damage sustained at or near Spring Bluff, just below the Toowoomba range, just below my electorate and in the electorate of my friend the member for Lockyer. We saw there an example of great damage done to the railway line, to the bridges, to the culverts, to the tunnels et cetera. It was estimated at that stage by QR personnel that the work involved would take about six months to repair to enable the track to be used again for normal purposes. But, with the effort that is being applied and the resources that are being applied by way of contracting Thiess, the work will be done within three months. I think that has now been shortened somewhat as well to a date in early April. It is pleasing that that massive work can be completed within that time. I congratulate all those involved, all those who have already done a considerable amount of work and all those who will be involved in the work yet to be undertaken.

In the meantime, we have seen a tremendous impact in terms of the usage of the Warrego Highway and the range crossing. Those goods that were normally transported by rail are now being transported by road, principally on the roads that I mentioned. That is creating a huge impost on the road system. I have spoken repeatedly in here, as have other members, about the very poor state of the Warrego Highway over the last five to 10 years, but particularly in recent times. The floods have made it a mess. Now we have the extra load on it that would otherwise have been--
Mr Rickuss interjected.

Mr SHINE: I take the interjection from my friend. One of the immediate solutions is for critical work to be done on the range crossing and the Warrego Highway. A lot of that has been done in recent times. I am sure the honourable member would agree with me when I say that, to me as a layperson, the work being done between Withcott and Helidon at the moment seems to be of much higher quality than the patchwork that was done before. I note that the honourable member nods in agreement. That is pleasing.

I am not familiar with what is happening between Toowoomba and Oakey in the electorate of Condamine. No doubt the member for Condamine will make some comment about that later. If there is any good to come from the terrible events starting on 10 January this year it has been to bring the focus of the nation onto the range crossing and Warrego Highway issues. We do hope, through our advocacy in here and the advocacy of others in other places, that what we have been after and, I believe, have been justly entitled to for a long time with respect to the range crossing and the Warrego Highway will be achieved. Let us wait and see.

The honourable member for Lockyer would agree that the rail link is of vital economic importance as well. He would be aware, as the House may be aware, that about eight years ago a study was done on a Gowrie-Grandchester rail link. A new railway line was proposed to be built across the Toowoomba range. It would more or less proceed in a straight line rather than follow all of the ridges as it does at the moment. In those days it was supposed to be a $1 billion project. One can only imagine what it would be worth today. The events that we have just seen highlight, in my view, the need for closer attention to be paid to that project, taking into account the additional change since eight or 10 years ago which is the opening up of the Surat Basin.

The damage done to the railway near the electorate of Toowoomba North in the electorate of Lockyer coming up the range was, I am advised by QR, 262 individual sites where damage has been found, comprising major and minor wash-outs, major landslips, drainage blockages and damage and destroyed structures such as bridges. To its credit, Queensland Rail has mobilised all available employees. It has contracted Thiess and smaller operators including earthmovers and trucking companies.

The Toowoomba range corridor is a vital piece of infrastructure for our community and for our local businesses, but the work associated with getting it back on track will exceed, according to QR, $50 million. That is a lot of money. That is what one project is costing. Work has to be done on the Rosewood-Toowoomba track. Work has to be done elsewhere along the rail line, particularly between Toowoomba and Oakey and west of Oakey as well.

I am advised that Queensland Rail has engaged Thiess to undertake restoration work at six major sites--the replacement of Kings Bridge plus five other landslips at Spring Bluff, Ripper Creek and Rangeview. As of 11 February this year, on-site there are 150 Queensland Rail personnel, Thiess contractors, 12 excavators, two graders, several dozers and 45 trucks to handle flood rock. We can see that, notwithstanding what has happened in North Queensland since with Cyclone Yasi, a great deal of commitment in terms of labour and capital has been made to fixing up what is the major economic obstacle that we have to overcome in and around Toowoomba.

As I mentioned before, the major problem for us at the height of the trouble which started on 10 January was the closure of the range crossing which is part of the Warrego Highway. Toowoomba was isolated for the best part of a week. Clearly the presence of a second range crossing would have obviated that problem.

Within Toowoomba itself the bridges crossing Gowrie Creek, in my electorate at least, were damaged in one way or another, including those at Griffith Street, North Street, Jelicoe Street and Bridge Street. The Bridge Street bridge is still half closed. The Jelicoe Street bridge is fully closed. The Griffith Street and North Street bridges have reopened.

Of great concern to me is the fact that there was an article in the Chronicle about a week ago indicating that council felt that it would take about 12 months to fix up or rebuild the Jelicoe Street bridge. It is disappointing if that is the case. I have expressed my concerns about that to the Toowoomba Regional Council. If there is anything that the government can do to hasten the replacement of that bridge well within that 12-month period I would be very supportive of it. I would hope that the powers given under this bill may well facilitate progress in that regard.

What has also been mentioned in the press in Toowoomba in recent times is where the tragedy involving the Rice family occurred, at the corner of Kitchener and James streets, and the fact that reconstruction there should take into account flood mitigation. I suspect that the problem with flood mitigation along East Creek is more substantial than what might happen at that intersection. That call has been made. I repeat it here. I ask the Minister for Main Roads to take note of that issue. James Street is part of the Warrego Highway and a federal government responsibility, but Mains Roads--
Mr Wallace interjected.
Mr SHINE: Thank you, Minister, for that indication. I appreciate it, as do the people of Toowoomba.

Also of great concern to me is fact that the Hampton to Esk Road is down. I have been told by the Toowoomba Regional Council that it will cost at least half a million dollars to repair a huge wash-out on that road. That is an important access road between the Brisbane Valley and the Darling Downs and Toowoomba in particular. Again, this legislation hopefully might facilitate the repair of that roadway at an earlier time. There are many other rural roads that come within the area of Toowoomba Regional Council--too many to go through on this occasion. But no doubt the council is compiling its list of roads and other assets that need to be replaced.

On top of the state and council assets, we as a community suffered considerably in terms of private property and business losses. An article in the Courier-Mail of 12 February set out at least three or four businesses in Toowoomba which were suffering as a result of the floods.

One business was a long way away at Picnic Point, which is 710 metres above sea level. The problem there, given that it was a cafe and restaurant, was the lack of tourism and the lack of business. That has been repeated downtown in Russell Street with a family business called Wings Over the Downs owned by Mr Rob Mercer. That was also repeated at a business called The Boogie Shack owned by Lynette Bannister which is a place where one buys milkshakes and burgers. Most of the business there was from tourists, and they have dried up completely. So it is not just Cairns, the Gold Coast and the Sunshine Coast that are suffering from a lack of tourism; it is places like Toowoomba and the west. In that regard, I thank the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading for the work that he has done recently to ensure that considerable money has been given to the organisation that deals with the promotion of tourism in Toowoomba, Toowoomba and Golden West Tourism. I am sure that will be of great help in promoting tourism in our area as well. My friend the member for Waterford heads a committee which recently released a report relating to grey nomads, and obviously Toowoomba and the west are centres very relevant in that regard.

There were numerous other businesses and industries affected, one of which was Allied Mills which used to be Defiance flour. That is still closed even though it employs dozens of workers. Many businesses in Dent Street, Prescott Street, Ruthven Street, Chalk Drive and Gowrie Creek are still shut and the people who worked there are unemployed or off work as a result. That is an indication of the extent of the effect of the floods in Toowoomba. This bill of course gives the Premier and the government extensive powers to prioritise the work that needs to be done on a state-wide basis to coordinate and manage the rebuilding and to distribute financial assistance, things which I believe are necessary and worthy powers. I again congratulate the government and the Premier on the work that has been done in that regard.
Debate, on motion of Mr Shine, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology

Hansard-Body.A: (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (12.32 pm), by leave: Just after the last election I met with the Premier and indicated to her that I did not know whether I would stand at the next election but that if I did make a decision not to stand at the next election then I would not see out the third year in the ministry because I have a very firm view that once you make up your mind to retire you really owe it to the team to allow a new person to come forward. So as of Monday I will be tendering my resignation as the Minister for Public Works. Did I hear anybody say, ‘Hear, hear!’? It has been a great privilege that I have been handed by the Australian Labor Party and my colleagues: almost 13 years as the Minister for Public Works; 11 years as the Minister for Housing; three years in a glorious time as the racing minister, every day of which I enjoyed, and of course everybody knows it is the second biggest industry in Queensland; and 4 years in IT, which I became a great convert to and I have really enjoyed that, and it is great to finish my career with a young adviser in that area. It has been an absolute challenge for 13 years.

XML.Hansard-Body: I see Lindsay Marshall in the public gallery--my original scribe trying to make sense out of the words that I say and trying to convert them into some form of English. The first day that he was there he typed a letter and it said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: My dear Premier
I haven’t been feeling well lately and I am afraid that I have to tender my resignation because of my activities ...
XML.Hansard-Body: He just left that blank, because he thought that there was a guarantee that at some stage in the next 12 months or whatever I would have to use that. It is still in the computer, but I am sure that at some time or other either of the premiers probably would have wished that I could have furnished them with that. So I do apologise for any issues of embarrassment I have caused you or my colleagues or anybody else over that period of time.

I want to pay tribute to a number of people, first of all to my family--a great Labor family. I wish they were here today. I wish my dad was still here today. But 13 years ago we were all together and we celebrated that moment. I was talking to my son last night. He was 14 then. He is now a journalist with AAP in Cairns. My other son, who is a journalist in Rockhampton, was 11 at that time. My wife has done a wonderful job in looking after those boys. I have spent very little time with them during that period of time. Evan reminds me that I went into local politics when he was six months old and Christopher was not even born. This job is a difficult job when you spend so much time away. So to my wife Judy I say thankyou. You have always been there for me and it has been great, and I look forward to getting under your feet in retirement. To my mother--she is of course the matriarch of the family and just salt of the earth--and to my brothers Steven, Peter, Mark and my sister Christine, I thank them similarly. They are very harsh critics from time to time when we sit around our lunch table every Saturday when we meet with my mum. We have a robust discussion. We do not all see eye to eye in the Schwarten household; that might surprise some people. But they are a great family to me. They have provided enormous support to me and it has been a terrific journey with them.

I also thank my parliamentary colleagues. There are very few of them left from the 1989 days. There is Judy. We have been mates ever since we came here in 1989, and we are the last of them. I have seen them all come and go during that period of time. Some have wanted to go. I went for a while--involuntarily, I have to tell you! I experienced a break in my career I guess. Some called it a sabbatical; I called it bloody hell actually. It was terrible! So I do know that dreadful, gut-wrenching feeling of losing an election. There is nothing quite like it and I do not recommend it to anybody. You only go out of this place two ways--either you retire or somebody throws you out, and I am glad that I am going on my own terms at a time of my own choosing. Very few get the privilege of doing that, and I am deeply honoured to be able to do that.

All of those people who have come in today and who are sitting in the public gallery have worked with me during parts of that time, and many of them could tell a story about me I guess. We started off on day one with Cheryl Packer and at that stage Peter Johnson was working in the show society in Toowoomba driving up and down. Then Lindsay came on board and ‘Father Jack’ John Luttreral. My very dear friends Lynne and Esmae came on next--the ‘golden girls’ as they are colloquially called by these young cheeky imps beside me here. I would never dare say such a thing! But it was a great team to start with--it really was--and we hit the ground running. Some of you stayed longer than others, but all of you went at a time of your choosing.

Of course Emma started with me on the first day and she was a young single girl then. Since then she has been married and had a couple of kids. I used to say when Kate worked with me we went from the nursery to the infirmary. Well, now it is pretty well the infirmary! Burgess, my old mate from a long time back, has stepped into the breach in that regard and there is Glen who is driving me. We had Blake Westlake of course who nearly killed me over the years driving out to the airport. I do not know whether I nearly killed him or he nearly killed me, but he stuck loyally to me. Glen still gets me to the airport on time and Jordy answers the phone. It has been a great group of people. I am just sorry that Cheryl Packer is not here. She will not be speaking to me when she comes back because I let her know by text this morning that this is what I was going to do and she said, ‘Thanks for telling me on my holidays.’ She would have said a lot more if she had been around!

Right from day one Mal Grierson was the acting DG, and we have been together ever sense. I want to thank Mal for the great job that he has done in Public Works. Mal repaid me for getting Racing by getting IT over. I thought I would put one over him and said, ‘We’re going to get Racing,’ and he said, ‘I have just had this talk to the people over at Treasury and I have had a talk to so-and-so and I think we should really have the IT stuff over here.’ Actually, he started his career over at CITEC. So it has been a great ride, mate. I do not think in the history of Queensland there is anything that comes close to 13 years of the same DG and the same minister. I just want to say that about Natalie MacDonald, too, as the Housing DG.

I guess I had the best of both worlds. I held a position where I could help people--among the poorest of our people. You cannot get much better than that as a Labor bloke. I think the stuff we did in Housing was absolutely terrific. We started off with no money from the federal government and we had to make do. I think we have created the best housing department in Australia with the best policies, the most efficiency and the most--what is the word--
Ms Bligh: The fairest.
Mr SCHWARTEN: Fairest, yes. I was trying to think of a smarter word than that, but anyway--
Ms Bligh: Sorry I couldn’t help.

Mr SCHWARTEN: Yes. I want to also thank Graham Cuthbert from Master Builders. We have had a great relationship with Master Builders. They are a great organisation. They speak from the heart and the head. They are not frightened to have a go on behalf of their members. They know that the industry is a very important cornerstone in this state and they play their professional role. The friendship that I have had with Graham I am sure will continue.

It is similarly the case with Ian Jennings over at the BSA. I got that from Judy Spence; it was Judy who did all the hard yards in that regard for me. So when I came along most of that work had been done. I used to sit next to her in those days with mountains of letters from the BSA. Along came ‘Jenno’, of course, and he took to it like a terrier to a rat. ‘Mr Fixit’ himself was going out to people who used to abuse him--and they still do, apparently. I do not know how he does it, but I thank him for his leadership there also. That has been great.

I think we got the best reforms. I will never forget the day that I banned builders. I rang Master Builders after the event and copped a tirade for not consulting them. Then I said, ‘If we had waited for you blokes to consult all of your members, we would never have done it,’ because it is pretty hard for an organisation to agree to ban their members. But they got in and supported that, and that has been a really valuable tool in managing the building industry in this state.

I have been so privileged to indulge in that passion of building. It has been great fortune. I want to thank both Premiers--both the previous one and the current one--for giving me that opportunity, because the construction industry, where I started my working life, is an absolute passion of mine. I believe in it and I see and feel the effects of it. Every time I go into a job and I see the young blokes who are working in it, I absolutely continue to be mesmerised by it.

I see Greg Quinn, who has just arrived. He could tell a very good story about the first time we met and the cordial relationship with Master Builders and the building reforms. We were heading out to the airport and I said, ‘Get in the car and come with me.’ We had a blazing row the entire way out there and when we got out there Quinny said, ‘How do I get back?’ I said, ‘You go back in the car.’ He said, ‘Oh, I thought that would be the end of it.’ We have been mates ever since also.

I do not want to prolong this much longer, but it is good to see Rose, Stephan and the McGuire brothers. They have been very solid mates of mine during this time in a world in which you do not get many mates. I have a basic philosophy about mates: friendship is a chain of gold; the mates you have are the ones you hold. I still have mates that I started school with, and each of these people here today I still regard as a mate.

As I say, it has been a wonderful, wonderful experience. My son the journo said to me, ‘It doesn’t get any better than this--going at your own time, at your own pace, happy about it and delighted to have made a contribution,’ as I have. I intend to work as hard as I can to ensure that we retain government in Queensland. I not only think it is possible; I think it is crucial. I see the quality of what is over the other side and--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: You did not expect me to congratulate you, did you? Right to the end--and I shudder, because--
An opposition member interjected.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I know you wish I would go now, but I am going to be sitting up on that backbench there where Betty Kiernan is. Before I resign on Monday I want the Premier to guarantee that I can sit in my old seat--the one I sat in when I first came here--because I get a direct field of vision over to there.
An opposition member interjected.

Mr SCHWARTEN: Yes, I am going to love it up there, too. Anyway, it has been a great ride, meeting great people along the way. The world is about people. I have enjoyed this not just for the contribution we have made during that period and for all of those people who have done it with me, but also for the people I have met along the way. I have met people who are absolutely dirt poor and people who are billionaires. I have met good and bad in both and it is what continues to motivate us.

To my dear old mate, Judy: thanks again for all your support and friendship during our cabinet days. I am sorry that Terry Mackenroth is not here. They used to call us the ‘terrific trio’. We used to call ourselves that, anyway. When we would go to community cabinet meetings we would go and have a drink and have a meal and all the rest of it. But time moves on and there is a whole bunch of talent in this room that is going to fill this seat. I am glad that I am not going to make that decision; that has all passed me now, too, thank God. But thanks, everybody. Thanks for turning out here today. I will have more to say about the locals of Rockhampton if I get a chance at a valedictory later as a member of parliament. But I leave with my head held high and a smile on my face, and I am looking forward to having a beer this afternoon.
Mr Rickuss: I am sure all the government will be sad to see you go.
Mr SCHWARTEN: Yes. I just missed one. We always miss one--my old mate John Battams. We were in the Teachers Union together and we have remained very good mates.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. D BOYLE (Cairns--ALP) (Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (12.47 pm), by leave: Last night I announced to the people of Cairns that I will not be contesting the next state election, due in early 2012. I have been privileged indeed to represent the electorate of Cairns for close on 13 years. I assure the people of Cairns that I will represent their interests vigorously over the year ahead and make sure to do all I can for Cairns before this term of government comes to an end.

This is indeed how I wish to finish up my political years: by concentrating on the city I love. It was a concern for Cairns’ future that first got me involved in politics, which led to my becoming an elected member of the then Cairns city council and later to my election to the state seat of Cairns.

While being conscious of this, I now also announce that I will tender my resignation from cabinet to the Premier effective Monday, 21 February. I have been honoured indeed to have served in a range of portfolios over the past seven years. Much as I care and have so much more I would like to do in my present portfolios of Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships, I think it better that I stand down and provide an opportunity for a younger person with the best years of their political life still ahead. Over these years I have been well supported by members of the Labor caucus, by hardworking, marvellous staff--both in Brisbane and in Cairns--and by my family, my children in particular, Charlotte, Jake and Rachel.

Without hesitation I express my admiration for the mayors, councillors, CEOs and staff of Queensland’s 73 councils. I particularly recognise the enduring leadership of the local government sector provided by the LGAQ, so ably led by president Paul Bell and executive director Greg Hallam. I have been so warmed to see the progress being made by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. They are on the move towards a much better life in their own country. I will remain a strong supporter of our first Australians and advocate for them not only for their own sake but because their success now and in the years ahead will make Australia better for us all.

I thank the Premier for her excellent leadership in tough times. I affirm again my commitment to the Bligh Labor government and to the Australian Labor Party and first and last to the people of Cairns.
Sitting suspended from 12.50 pm to 2.30 pm.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Office of the Leader of the Opposition
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (2.30 pm): I seek leave to table the public report of office expenses for the Office of the Leader of the Opposition for the six months to 31 December 2010.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Public Report of Office Expenses, Office of the Leader of the Opposition for the period 1/07/2010 to 31/12/2010.
XML.Hansard-Body: I am pleased to advise that in line with LNP principles my office is operating well within our allocated budget. In fact, my office is currently significantly under budget.
Resumed from p. 235, on motion of Ms Bligh--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP) (2.30 pm): I rise to support the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill which will set up the mechanism to coordinate rebuilding after the devastating floods and cyclones of January and February 2011. The Premier will become Minister for Reconstruction and will have responsibility for overseeing the Reconstruction Authority. The authority will have wide-reaching powers and have a board chaired by Major General Mick Slater which will report directly to her.

The recent floods and cyclones have turned Queensland upside down and the next challenge is to rebuild to ensure that we are much stronger and better prepared in the future. We all have lessons to learn from our experiences. An essential part of the bill is that the authority have wide-ranging powers to ensure the job is done efficiently and in a timely manner. The minister’s power under the act will include: the declaration of designated reconstruction areas where rebuilding can be fast-tracked; the ability to intervene in regulatory or approval processes to get things moving; independent planning powers to slash red tape and begin rebuilding as soon as possible; and the ability to actually undertake reconstruction or development works as soon as possible.

It is important that the authority works together cooperatively with local government to ensure timely completion of the projects. It will have a dedicated North Queensland office to ensure that there is a local presence in relation to devastation caused by Cyclone Yasi. No-one knows their area better than the local community and they will be able to provide guidance and information to the authority in this way. The Premier’s message is, ‘No-one and no part of Queensland will be forgotten.’

As explained in the state parliament’s condolence debate earlier this week, there were many devastated communities right across Queensland, including within my own electorate of Mount Ommaney. Every elected member in the state parliament was somehow affected directly by the flood and/or provided assistance to those electorates that were underwater or devastated by Cyclone Yasi. As families, individuals, businesses, farms and communities begin to piece their lives back together, the Premier and the state government are committed to be there standing beside them to help them rise again.

In the week before Christmas 2010, I sent out my final email news for the year telling residents that there was more rain and storms to come and providing them with some information about preparation for the bad conditions ahead. Little did I know at the time how bad the conditions would become. In my local area, there was a sequence of events which occurred early on Tuesday, 11 January. There was continued constant heavy rain and flood warnings as some residents prepared for the possible flooding of their homes. The day before, Jindalee residents lost their water supply and efforts were made to restore broken pipes through Urban Utilities. Some families evacuated to friends or relatives. People rang my office for flood maps; however, there was difficulty accessing the council website because of the large numbers of people trying to get information. There was a rush for sandbags at the Brisbane City Council depot in Darra which created traffic congestion and queues of people. The depot quickly ran out of sandbags.

Community groups emailed and telephoned my office asking how they could help. Many people rang the electorate office to ask if they should evacuate. They were told not to take any chances and to stay safe. The elderly in nursing homes were evacuated and the disabled were contacted by their service providers and were assisted to evacuate where necessary. The electorate office printed out 1974 flood maps to advise local people if they were vulnerable. The police began evacuating people as water was encroaching on their properties.

On Wednesday, power was cut and homes became flooded. Some were completely inundated and boats were used by the police to assist those people who were stranded. My electorate office was advising people to get to evacuation centres and was ringing the SES to assist them. I was visiting people and contacting people in need. Local roads and the Centenary Motorway and Jindalee Bridge were cut.

On Thursday, staff from my electorate office were sent home as the roads leading to the shopping centre entrance were becoming flooded. That day, I prepared a flyer with recovery and emergency contact information to be doorknocked to the flood affected and distributed to other properties. On Friday, people were in shock and were distressed as they panic shopped. Large numbers of people were ringing to ask about power, food and shelter. The BCC website was again on and off, with large numbers of people trying to access the site for information. I started doorknocking flood affected residents as the waters receded and the clean-up began.

These are some of the issues which came to light. Residents in the Centenary area advised that they had no warning and that their areas were not published on the council’s list of ‘suburbs likely to be affected by flooding’. Therefore, some of those people who did not experience the ’74 floods did not realise their properties would be affected. In a state of distress, other people froze in disbelief not knowing what to do.

Many people were of the belief that with the Wivenhoe Dam a repeat of the ’74 flood would be avoided. People whose homes were completely inundated did not know where to start or how they were going to get the funds to start again. Some people were waiting for the insurance companies to assess the damage before taking the walls down. I contacted insurance companies to get a clearance for them to start getting rid of caked on mud. Some injuries had occurred as people cleaned out the rubbish from their home. People asked for tetanus shots and I asked the Minister for Communities to provide that service in the recovery centres.

After the clean-up, residents were keen to get their power restored so that they could start rebuilding. They were advised to get an electrical contractor to inspect their home for safety before a clearance could be provided to Energex. People asked if there was a way that they could access their superannuation in advance to cover the cost of rebuilding.

Landlords who were cleaning up their rental properties wanted to know if the government was going to provide help to them. They stated that there would need to be more rental properties available for people to live in. Those more at risk of foreclosure are considered to be the investors who will lose their rental income stream and will not be able to afford to make the mortgage payments.

People were advised about the recovery centres which were set up the weekend of the flood and the types of assistance that would be available. Some people wanted to know if the water was contaminated and what to do about houses that appeared unoccupied. Community leaders asked if there was any assistance for community clubs and sporting clubs which had been flood affected. Working couples who could not get insurance were not eligible for government assistance because the income test precluded them. They wanted to start repairing the damage and move back in but had no ready funds. Some community groups did not fit into the category of small business to be eligible for assistance; neither did they entirely fit into the category of not-for-profit groups because of the rental income they received from the hire of their facilities. The Premier announced assistance for these groups this morning in parliament.

Residents in units administered by a body corporate had concerns about whose responsibility it was to take out flood insurance for the complex. Depression has started to set in, with some families in a state of flux and uncertainty after the clean-up. About 75 per cent of people I spoke to did not have flood insurance or did not know whether they were covered by their policy. People have paid insurance premiums for most of their lives but they have been told that they will get nothing. Some people said that they could not get coverage because of their location. Others said that they could not afford the premium they were asking because of their location--$3,500 a year. These people will be up for considerable expense to get back into their homes.

Bowls clubs and other community sporting clubs act as a central hub for a large number of local groups such as the RSL, Meals on Wheels, Probus, Seniors and the like. Unless work is done to restore these flood damaged clubs, the community cannot work effectively to assist people they care for or provide support to club members in need. People who are flood affected need to have the support of people around them.

Some of the clubs in my area that need some funds to start rebuilding are the Oxley Bowls Club, which received more than two metres of floodwater inside the buildings and on the greens; the Ukranian Centre, which was almost totally inundated; the Carrington Boat Club, which was totally inundated and its moorings were lost; the Centenary Rowing Club, which was covered by floodwater over 1 times its height and the pontoon was lost to raging waters--over the past few years $800,000 of government grants have been put into this facility to get it up and running; the Jindalee Bowls Club, which was totally inundated and the car park area severely damaged by subsidence; the Jindalee Jaguars Football Club, which was totally inundated; Centenary Little Athletics, which lost all of its valuable equipment; the Jindalee Golf Club, which had over a metre of water in the clubhouse and its course was totally inundated; the McLeod Golf Club, where the building was unscathed, however the entire course and pumping station was destroyed; the Jindalee pool, which was totally inundated; and most of the child-care centres in the area which were flooded or had families who were affected by flooding.

Some of the reconstruction of these facilities will need to be done in stages due to massive costs of up to $1 million in at least one of them. All of these clubs support other community organisations and it is important that the rebuild starts immediately. This and assisting those residents who do not have any other way financially of getting back into their devastated homes are the priorities in my electorate of Mount Ommaney and a great place to start in rebuilding Queensland.

The Centenary Motorway, particularly high-congestion hot-spot areas such as Sumners Road, continues to be high in priority on my list for the area. I commend the work of QBuild, which worked extremely hard to repair flooded classrooms at Oxley and Jindalee state schools. Their work on the prep classrooms, including removing the asbestos roofs at my request, the school hall at Jindalee and the prep building at Corinda State School was a massive task but was completed without fuss and without disruption to school operations. Businesses in Sumner Park and Seventeen Mile Rocks were devastated. Availability of trades and materials in the short term will be tight as costs rise. The impact of new resource projects and infrastructure is still unknown in many parts of Queensland, but any impact on projects affects job prospects and therefore the ability of Queenslanders to rebuild.

Analysis by the National Australia Bank shows that the short-term impact on the economy will reduce GDP by one per cent due to lost production. This GDP loss, however, would be restored through spending on rebuilding vital infrastructure, restocking and repairs. The destruction caused by the recent floods and Queensland disasters may provide short-term work opportunities for some sectors of this industry, but there is still concern about the medium- and long-term prospects. These are challenging times for our economy and our labour market. Queensland is now undertaking an extensive rebuilding program which will mean more work and more Queensland jobs throughout 2011. Notwithstanding the enormity of the task, I praise the Premier for her drive and determination to get Queensland powering again as quickly as possible after our massive losses. I commend the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011 to the House.

Dr FLEGG (Moggill--LNP)
(2.43 pm): I rise to speak to the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill. I note that the opposition has indicated it will not be opposing the bill. In part we have arrived at that conclusion because we are taking the government at its word that the role of the authority will be to coordinate and manage the rebuilding and recovery of affected communities, including the repair and rebuilding of community infrastructure and other property. We have taken the government at its word that it will coordinate and cooperate with the existing local authorities, state instrumentalities, NGOs and federal agencies.

I say very bluntly that I have never seen circumstances in which the answer to the problem is just a new bureaucracy. In fact, there are considerable warnings to the government to avoid becoming embroiled in just another bureaucracy. In particular what springs to my mind is the failed Queensland Water Commission, which principally filled roles that should rightly have been carried out by local water authorities and state government agencies and which simply ended in an expensive bureaucratic mess. Queensland needs the objectives as outlined by the government implemented effectively. That is why we are working with the government’s preferred model. I hope it gets it right. The objectives as described in the notes to the bill are--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... to plan and facilitate an effective and coordinated program of reconstruction of community infrastructure and other property. The Authority will have the specific function of facilitating flood mitigation and ensuring the protection, rebuilding and recovery of disaster-affected communities is carried out effectively, efficiently and appropriately.
XML.Hansard-Body: We support those objectives, but they must be delivered as stated--effectively, efficiently and appropriately. Of course, the task before this authority is enormous as we are looking at unusual circumstances. We have communities such as those in the Lockyer and Toowoomba that were subject to flash flooding, we have communities in Brisbane that were subject to river inundation, and we have the communities in North Queensland that were affected by cyclone. The challenge to this authority goes way beyond what we could possibly have imagined following the likes of Cyclone Larry or the reconstruction of Darwin after Cyclone Tracy where the task was much more contained both geographically and in terms of the nature of the disaster threat.

I commence by making comments about the communities for which I have responsibility to represent. I use the word ‘communities’, plural, deliberately because with the January 2011 natural disasters we were cut into multiple communities. I indicate at the outset that I will write to the authority and request that they visit the Moggill electorate. There are particular challenges here for disaster planning. We are large urban communities within the City of Brisbane. It is by far the largest land area of any constituency in Brisbane. We are vulnerable to an array of natural disasters and as a consequence of most, if not all, of them access will be cut, as it has been many times in the past, given that there is only a single road in and out--Moggill Road. Community infrastructure is extremely limited. For example, there is no hospital. The only police station is the one at Karana Downs.

I will be writing to the authority. As far as I know, during the flood crisis Brisbane’s largest constituency was not visited by a single government minister or parliamentary secretary. I will be requesting on this occasion that the authority actually visit and talk to local residents. I will be asking it to look at four things, in particular the extreme vulnerability of access on Moggill Road to these very large metropolitan communities. I understand that I have a role in ensuring local residents’ expectations are realistic. When it was brought up at a recent public meeting that we should be seeking an all-weather access road it was my responsibility to ensure that people understood that this may not be realistic, that the money involved in making Moggill Road flood-free at each of the points that are subject regularly to inundation was not likely to be forthcoming. People need a reality check. However, the current access for in excess of 30,000 people involves one very average-quality road that is simply in part a two-lane road and highly vulnerable to be cut by floodwaters, flash floods, any cyclonic or rain event, bushfire, smoke or man-made disaster such as, God forbid, a petrol tanker explosion or the like. Given the size of the community, how we improve access is well within the scope of the authority.

Secondly, I will be asking it to look at and hopefully make recommendations in relation to three river crossings that are the only connection between this large area and the other side of the Brisbane River around Ipswich. They are Colleges Crossing, Moggill Ferry and Mount Crosby Weir. Whilst the case for a bridge at the Moggill Ferry is weak because most of the proponents see it as an alternative route to Brisbane without realising that most of that route between Moggill and the city of Brisbane comprises substandard roads that are already well above capacity and have no capacity to serve as an alternative route or to take additional traffic, Colleges Crossing is a different kettle of fish.

Unlike the community of Moggill and Bellbowrie, the community of Karana Downs, Mount Crosby, Karalee and surrounding areas is essentially a single community divided in two by the Brisbane River. People live on one side and work on the other. The shops are on the Karalee side. Many of the people on the Karalee side attend Mount Crosby State School, one of the state’s largest primary schools. Many Karana Downs residents work in places like Amberley. The government provided high school for this area of Mount Crosby and Karana Downs is, in fact, in Ipswich as are many of the private schools. The crossings go under with the least whiff of additional water.

Interestingly, I note that this issue of access was raised in the media this week. I have been corresponding with the minister to ensure that the government is aware how important this connection is and to explain the reasons for the need to upgrade it, not necessarily in the first instance to a full flood-proof bridge--I do understand the financial constraints on the state at this time. However, this major Brisbane-Ipswich road link needs to remain open to traffic when events such as planned releases of water from Wivenhoe Dam, for example, take place. Interestingly, in my correspondence as recently as November last year, the government was completely dismissive of my suggestion that we look seriously at upgrading this vital access crossing. That dismissiveness did not appear to come across in the minister’s comments this week on ABC Radio, and I hope that heralds a more open mind. The third crossing, Mount Crosby Weir, is a little local road that can sometimes stay open when Colleges Crossing is inundated. However, when I contacted Seqwater for information, for some time it did not even appear to be aware that it was one of its assets.

Since I have been the representative, the large community of Moggill-Bellbowrie has been isolated on many occasions by an array of different events. The shopping centre, supermarket, medical centres and community facilities all in the Birkin Road precinct are in a low-lying area which is subject to heavy inundation during a flood. They cannot be relied on to function during any future disasters. I think the authorities should look at this situation, particularly where such a large metropolitan community is regularly cut off from the rest of Brisbane and has its main community resources under threat of inundation. It will be months before this community can even see a supermarket service restored.

Other matters that the authority needs to look at include that of local and state government acquisition of high flood-risk properties. I think there are a few cases where this is necessary. However, as was illustrated in the Lockyer Valley, there are two types of flood threat to properties that the authority should consider. Properties, for example, in Kilkivan Avenue at Kenomre are subject to severe inundation whenever either Moggill Creek or the Brisbane River floods. This has happened on a number of occasions in recent years. Some of these householders have been seriously flooded twice in the last three years alone. Properties subject to this sort of inundation with any major rain event, even where it is not accompanied by flooding of the Brisbane River, should be considered for voluntary acquisition by the authority.

The other issue that the authority needs to look at--and I am sure it is going to come up again and again across the state, particularly in the cyclone prone north--is the vulnerability of power supplies. One of the major problems that we confronted in this area was the loss of power for lengthy periods and, with it, information, refrigeration and the like. The issue around the Birkin Road area of Bellbowrie appears to be even a little more difficult than that around Moggill Creek in that the properties are very low lying and will be flooded any time the Brisbane River breaks its banks. However, they are not quite so exposed to the risk of flash flood. In the present environment they will be very difficult, if not impossible, to sell. I know that bank valuations have been so severely impacted that rebuilding is nearly impossible for some owners. When the valuation is hit, people cannot borrow money against it to rebuild. The authority will need to arrive at a set of criteria that could be applied to voluntary property acquisition. In my view houses subject to frequent inundation are an obvious decision.

Hopefully, Brisbane River floods will continue to be rare events, but I think it is now evident that we will see further Brisbane River floods perhaps two to three times in a century. Interestingly, as a former resident of Fig Tree Pocket, one factor that was significant for many Brisbane residents was that they were victims of the great myth--and I note the member for Mount Ommaney mentioned this as well--that the Brisbane River could not flood after the construction of Wivenhoe Dam. When I bought my home in that flood prone area and I expressed some reservations about the fact that it had been inundated in 1974, it was certainly said to me by many people that such properties would not flood again. It is now apparent that Wivenhoe may well be reducing the frequency and perhaps the height of Brisbane River floods, but it will in no way eliminate their possibility.

As the authority seeks to achieve its goal of improving the disaster proofing of different communities I will emphasise that the only thing we can be sure of with future disasters is that we must expect the unexpected. The authority needs to be forward thinking. When I was at school we learnt a little ditty called the Arkansas Traveller . It went something like this. An old man sat on the porch of his shack as the rain bucketed down, flooding through a hole in his roof. The Arkansas traveller saw him as he was passing by and said to him words to the effect, ‘For goodness’ sake, man, why don’t you fix the hole in your roof? Your house is flooding.’ The resident looked up at the traveller in disbelief and said, ‘I can’t fix it now. It’s raining.’ So the traveller, not deterred, said, ‘What you should do is on the next fine sunny day get up on your roof and fix it.’ The resident looked at the traveller as though he was an idiot and said, ‘My roof doesn’t leak when it doesn’t rain.’ That is pretty much how Queensland has been run for the last 10 years. We waited until we were running out of water in a drought before we thought about spending billions in a panic to bring water supply infrastructure on line just in time for the next flooding wet cycle. We held back water despite widespread authoritative predictions that we were entering a dramatic wet La Nina. We held Wivenhoe Dam at or above 100 per cent and only after the city was flooded did we decide to release a quarter of the city’s drinking water. We decided to release it after the city had flooded, not before.

Having been a resident of Darwin, I know how well people in North Queensland and in the cyclone belt are aware and plan for the known risks of cyclones. Yet in spending hundreds of millions of dollars on school building projects, including around 100 in ‘cyclone alley’, nobody in the government thought to build them to cyclone shelter standard, despite shelters having been promised after Cyclone Larry just a few years ago. Of course, it adds insult to injury when we hear ministers in this place say that these building projects should be used as cyclone shelters anyway, despite not being built to cyclone shelter standard. Also, because of the maladministration of these funds, many of these buildings do not even have walls. I do not think I would like to be in a cyclone shelter without walls.

It must be a very difficult way to govern when you are only able to look backwards and not forwards. Interestingly and instructively, the $3 million allocated to the Mount Crosby State School, one of the large communities of some 12,000 or more people that was completely cut off, was not enough to buy a school hall that was actually enclosed by walls. So we saw another lost opportunity to provide the relevant community infrastructure that this very vulnerable community needs and that would be suitable for multiple purposes.

Mr WILSON: I rise to a point of order. The member is misleading the House. The Mount Crosby State School wanted to spend $6 million when there was only $3 million available from the federal government.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Kilburn): Order! If you feel the member is misleading the House there is an appropriate mechanism for you to make that statement.

Dr FLEGG: How good would it be for the people of Mount Crosby and Karana Downs to actually complete the walls of the $3 million hall so that it could be used in disaster relief work. Sadly, that is not going to be the case.

The government is a genius in hindsight. It recently decided to release the drinking water component of Wivenhoe Dam but only after Brisbane was flooded, not before. Yesterday the government announced that it would reconsider its policy of not taking insurance or reinsurance. The problem is that disaster has already happened. We cannot afford to see this same sort of thinking that led to the construction of some of Queensland’s most expensive ever infrastructure for water supply such that it came on-stream after a drought, not when it was needed during a drought. Good governments plan ahead.

If the next disaster is assumed to be the same as the last one, then we are doomed to make the same mistakes, responding to what has passed, not to what may or will happen in the future. Preparedness in Brisbane and the south-east appears to me to have been dramatically less than in the cyclone belt. The next natural disaster to strike the City of Brisbane--and let us hope that it is many, many years hence--could well be a cyclone. A cyclone crossing the coast has been recorded as far south as Coolangatta. Given the unpredictable paths of cyclones, at some time in the future a cyclone will hit the Brisbane area. It may well be in the very distant future--let us hope so. But it is a very real risk that needs to be factored into future planning.

It is a frightening prospect in an area with millions of people. In a flood we move people to higher ground, but a cyclone, however, could leave a large proportion of buildings--perhaps as high as 50 per cent--seriously damaged or destroyed. It would not be at all clear to residents of Brisbane where safety is to be found. Attempts to move to higher ground to avoid the storm surge would create chaotic circumstances and panic on our roads. Hurricane Katrina in the US is an obvious example of what can happen when these sorts of disasters hit highly populated areas.

I have frequently been concerned about the risk of bushfire, particularly in the hillier, heavily vegetated outer suburban areas of Brisbane and South-East Queensland. Access, particularly in places like Upper Brookfield, is so tenuous that early warning and very well-planned individual bushfire responses would be critical. In fact, I identify bushfire as the highest level threat to human life throughout my area.

One of the key issues to be confronted by the Reconstruction Authority will be how much money is available to it. The budget for projects will be critical, particularly in their objective not to automatically replace like for like infrastructure but to consider the relocation or building of alternative natural disaster resistant infrastructure. This is an enormous task and could only realistically be approached with the possibility of having a substantial budget available for projects. It will require the authority to look ahead at the array of possible threats, not just to look back as though they are simply responding to what we have just seen--and this is a vital point.

The LNP want desperately to see Queensland rebuilt. We want to see it not just patched up but rebuilt bigger, better and safer. We certainly want to see it better prepared. As LNP members, many of us representing flood and cyclone ravaged parts of Queensland, we have enormous goodwill towards the Reconstruction Authority. Whilst it is described as being an independent statutory body, clearly ministers and the government have enormous involvement. We cannot afford for the authority to lose its way or be hijacked. The members of the board have impressive and distinguished careers and have displayed great capability in their areas of expertise. We look forward to working with them.

Resourcing and funding will be so critical that without them the objectives of the authority can never be achieved. Queensland has seen enormous wealth during the boom that preceded the financial crisis, but we never squirrelled anything away. We never saved, pardon the pun, for a rainy day. Financial management has impaired the financial capability of the state today to respond.

Hansard-Body.A: (Lockyer--LNP) (3.03 pm): I rise to say a few words on the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill. These are very important words too, because my area has been greatly affected. I would like to acknowledge my wife and my son Joel in the gallery.

XML.Hansard-Body: The Reconstruction Authority actually has a special function of facilitating flood mitigation and ensuring the protection, rebuilding and recovery in disaster affected communities. This is really important in our areas. This has to be looked at with clear thinking, but it has to be done quickly and it has to be done with community consultation. The people of Grantham are at the moment wondering whether they can rebuild on their blocks of land and what they can do on their blocks of land. This is something that has to be handled appropriately but it also has to be handled very quickly. Some of the older generation are saying, ‘No, we do not want to rebuild there.’ Some of the younger generation are saying, ‘Yes, of course we want to rebuild there. This is our community.’ So let us have this discussion quickly. Let us make sure the authority gets on the ground and talks to the people of Grantham and Murphys Creek and Postmans Ridge, places that have been dramatically affected.

I spoke with the infrastructure minister the other day. He has advised me that they are looking at some of the higher land around Grantham as being an opportunity to make some higher blocks available if people wish to build there. But it is always going to be a difficult situation with people giving over their land or selling their land. I have seen some figures where the Brisbane City Council had made an offer to buy back some flood prone areas, but a very small percentage of these flood prone blocks were taken up. It is a difficult situation--what is the market value and what else can you buy? This is something the Queensland Reconstruction Authority has to look at. How will they manage that? How will that sort of thing be managed appropriately?

In some areas, the old Queenslanders did manage these floods fairly well. In my area, most of the houses that were on six-foot stumps or two-metre piers actually did survive fairly well. Houses that were on one-metre piers did not survive anywhere near as well. The reason for that was that the volumes of water that could flow underneath the higher houses were nowhere near as damaging. Some people still had water in their houses and the houses were damaged slightly, but they were nowhere near as damaged as others. Unfortunately, we now have this attitude of building low brick houses on slabs. Some houses are built on high pads, even metre-high pads, but that still did not protect them too much. My son Luke’s mate, Paul, has a brick house in Grantham and it went about 1 metres underwater. It is very difficult to lift up a brick house.

I was speaking to an older gentleman in Grantham and I said to him, ‘What are you going to do? You have a brand-new brick house here. If the Reconstruction Authority advises you to lift it up, what are you going to do?’ His response was almost immediate and pretty logical I thought, too. He said, ‘I will just build a fire escape.’ I said, ‘Yeah?’ He said, ‘A fire escape in reverse. I’ll have a ladder up to the ceiling, whether up to the attic on the inside or just outside a window on the outside wall.’ When you think about it, it is fairly logical. You have fire escapes to come down out of buildings; you could have flood escapes to go up out of buildings. He said, ‘I can’t afford to build a new house, but I can afford to replace cupboards.’

Those are the sorts of logical things that we have to do in consultation with the community. The community has a vast amount of knowledge out there of what goes on. We will have to look at some of those areas of Postmans Ridge and Murphys Creek, where some of the smaller lifestyle blocks of land have unfortunately shown not to have an appropriate house site on them. Some of those blocks of land actually had brick houses on them that were totally washed away. That is something that the Reconstruction Authority will have to look at.

We as a government will have to be compassionate about this. This might only be a one in 150-year flood or a one in a 200-year flood. I do not know. When the hydrology studies are completed, that is the sort of data we need to accurately work out what is going to happen. Also, it is totally inappropriate to try to tell people what to do, but they have to have accurate flood heights. They have to have accurate data that shows them what the flood heights are.

May I make a suggestion here through you, Madam Speaker. Instead of having that airy-fairy sustainability document that has to be part of every land sale, we should actually have appropriate flood height data that goes with every land sale. We should flick the sustainability document and replace it with a flood height document. That would make a lot more sense, to replace the sustainability document with a danger document, or an emergency services document--whether it be outlining the bushfire risk or the flood height risk or whatever. The sustainability document is really a buyer beware document, because a lot of people do not know how old their air conditioner is or what sort of insulation is in their ceilings. But, really, that is never going to be life threatening to them. What is going to be life threatening to them is if their house burns down or if their house gets flooded or swept away.

Surely there should be some type of appropriate data to show the purchaser of a property that the land they are looking to purchase would go under 1 metres of water in a one-in-100-year flood or in a one-in-200-year flood. That is the sort of thing they should know. How many times have we heard an old fella say, ‘I wouldn’t have built that house down there. Don’t know why those people did that’? Along comes a flood and what happens? They get 1 metres of water through their house. Locals have this information, but new people to an area do not know. This is totally appropriate to provide.

I have even wondered whether a flood marker post should be at each village so that people can see the flood heights. Gatton actually has one. On the railway bridge it has a ’74 flood height marker. Unfortunately, the water this time went about 12 inches over the ’74 flood height twice.

That is the sort of data that I think it is imperative that people have. Unfortunately, a lot of people in the lower socioeconomic group buy these blocks of land because they are a bit cheaper in the lower ends of town. Let us give them a break. Let us not punish them for their lack of local knowledge. They think they are doing the right thing. They see a nice little house for $250,000 and buy it. They are punished eventually because they end up with problems.

The Bischofs, a lovely family in Forest Hill, have one of the lower houses in their street. Unfortunately, they have had water up past the windows. When the Premier visited the area, the question they asked was whether assistance would be made available to lift up the house. A lot of houses around them have been lifted up since the ’74 flood. They bought this house without realising that the water could come up quite that high. They did not know anyone in the street to ask and were probably a bit shy to ask.

Supplying flood height data is one way we can realistically assist people. I am sure the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning would be interested in that. In New South Wales, flood height data has to be supplied to people purchasing land. That is the sort of thing that would assist people. Since we are in a dry area, why do we not throw in some bushfire data as well? Those are probably two of the most pertinent pieces of data to people purchasing property. Let us be realistic about this. Let us improve the situation.

I have spoken to the member for Ipswich, the Minister for Transport, about the railway line. The member for Toowoomba North earlier mentioned the railway line. Railway lines are important in this. I had a meeting with an engineer about the railway line. I invited a couple of the elders of the little village of Forest Hill--a town of about 300 people. The railway line is acting as a levee. I invited four people to the meeting and 40 turned up. They were accusing me of not inviting them. I said, ‘Hang on, this was supposed to be a private meeting.’ They were saying, ‘Why weren’t we invited?’ I said, ‘Because I only wanted a couple of elders to give me some local knowledge.’ Forty people turned up. They were well meaning and wanted information.

When the water rushed through the levee of the railway line, the town water level dropped two feet in about 20 minutes. Those sorts of things have to be looked at. I have spoken to engineers and I have spoken to the minister about this. I know that it is important that we get this railway line rebuilt and operating, but let us do something about improving the viability of it. It has not worried us for the last 10 years, but the floods will come again. Let us work with the councils, the railways and DERM to make sure the appropriate data is available so that when the railway line is built again it does not act as a levee. That is really important.

In two places I saw that this had happened--Murphys Creek and Grantham. The railway line fence was washed both ways. The wave of water hit the fence and folded it over one way and then the wave hit the railway line and the high bank and it came back and folded another part of the fence the other way. Because the railway lines have been there for 140 or 150 years, many communities are very accepting of the railway. They want to see the trains start again. I was told that the community of Forest Hill quite likes the trains and wants to see the trains running again, but they want to improve the flow of water underneath the railway line so that it does not create any angst in the town.

That is the sort of data available. Because of the El Niño events over the last number of years we have moved away from undertaking appropriate management of our creeks, streams and rivers. I spoke to the Premier about this when she was in the Lockyer Valley. Wherever there is a man-made structure--wherever there is a weir or railway bridge or whatever--we have all the data about the bed height when that structure was originally put in. Let us clean out those weirs and creek beds to that level. We have the data on that. If the bed was two metres lower than it is now, that is capacity the creek does not have because the man-made structure has allowed the sand, silt or trash to bank up behind it. At the moment, if someone wanted to do that they would have to undertake an environmental study. Thousands of dollars would be tied up in that. Most of the small contractors, who might own a truck and a couple of machines, would look at that and say, ‘I might get $10,000 worth of material out of here but it will cost $8,000 or $10,000 to get an environmental report, and that might say that I cannot go ahead.’ We have to be realistic.

The man-made structures have created the blockage. They have caused material to build up behind them. Let us allow contractors, with appropriate documentation, to do this work. It will actually bring some money back to the government because there will be a royalty on the soil or sand that is taken out. Let us do the common-sense things that are easy. That is what this Reconstruction Authority hopefully will come up with. Some of these common-sense things are easy to do.

This might show the government how we can get rid of some of the red tape that exists. That is hopefully where this will lead to. We seem to be overly bureaucratic when it comes to a lot of our processes. These are the sorts of things that we want to see happen.

We support the bill and the need for speed to make things happen. I am sure that things will happen appropriately. I encourage the government to make sure that the Queensland Reconstruction Authority works with local members and local councils. That is what we really want it to do. People need information about what they can do. I encourage the Reconstruction Authority to get back to the people on the ground and tell them what they can do and how they can do it.

I am sure that the member for Hinchinbrook and the member who represents the people of Mossman want to know what people can do. They want to know what they have to build and how they have to build it in order to get on with their lives. Apparently it is a magnificent spot. Let us give them that advantage. It is the same in Grantham and Murphys Creek and Postmans Ridge. Let us tell them what they have to build, how they have to build it or where they have to build it--set some parameters--and let them get on with their lives because that is what they want to do. This will take a couple of years. I can fully understand that. I do support the authority and the bill. I will be making an appointment to talk to the authority very shortly.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind)
(3.18 pm): In the face of unprecedented loss of life and destruction of property caused by the recent natural disasters, I agree with the Premier who said that the task before us is greater than any we have faced. I accept that she has brought this legislation, the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011, before this place to spearhead the work needed to help our state rebuild and recover from the forces of nature. The three actions of this bill will be to scope, to coordinate and to cut through red tape.

For the majority of my contribution today I am going to focus on some of the red tape that my constituents have encountered. I am glad that this government has identified that red tape or unnecessary bureaucratic waste as being one of the major barriers that stands in the way of swift recovery and rebuilding. We all want to see this state get back on its feet again. Throughout this speech, as I have mentioned, I am going to give practical examples of red tape my constituents are battling with. Mr Stuart Johnstone, who contacted my office today, is a primary producer and the owner of Johnstone Products located at 156 Capricornia Drive in Baffle Creek. Stuart’s property was affected and he was advised by QRAA that he would be eligible for financial assistance.

However, the governing body, DEEDI, has overruled that and determined that Stuart does not fit into the flood zones. Quite understandably, Mr Johnstone is furious as he has just spent $9,000 on repairing his equipment. This morning he had to sack two employees because he will need to pay the $9,000 overdraft back to the bank. He is also annoyed that the Baffle Creek management group keeps coming to him about his dams. He has told them to go away, although he used different language, as he is no longer, according to DEEDI, within the flood boundaries involved with Baffle Creek. It appears that DEEDI has only selected some pockets of Baffle Creek, so it appears as though the email from Ravi Chandra from the Premier’s office contained false and misleading information. I am going to raise this issue with the Parliamentary Secretary for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Trade, Michael Choi, after he kindly agreed to meet with me today. However, I believe it would certainly lessen the burden of the Reconstruction Authority if these matters were dealt with. I table a letter that I have just written that I am going to send to the Premier today on behalf of Mr Johnstone and I hope that this matter can be dealt with.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 17 February 2011, from Mr Rob Messenger MP, Member for Burnett, to Hon. Anna Bligh MP, Premier, relating to flood relief flooding.
XML.Hansard-Body: As I said, I certainly hope that the burden of the Reconstruction Authority is lessened.
