One way it can be lessened is if the insurance companies of Queensland were a little bit less legalistic and more compassionate in their decision making so that people are able to go about the business of rebuilding and reconstructing Queensland. I have paid a compliment to an insurance company in this place, as have other members as well. We were contacted by representatives of Suncorp very early on in the piece, and I have to pay a compliment again to the Suncorp insurance company which has displayed a lot of common sense, decency and compassion. Its actions, however, are in stark contrast to another insurance company which I am going to name--Allianz--which has decided not to honour a policy of a lady I met on New Year’s Day at East Bundaberg amid the mud and the stench of the flood.

Miss Jenny Shaw has five children. She paid over $100 per month for at least three years to Allianz insurance for flood insurance, so she has paid around $3,600 in premiums on her modest home in East Bundaberg and now she finds that Allianz has refused to pay her for flood damage to a maximum of $50,000. I will table the documentation that Miss Shaw received from Allianz Australia Insurance Ltd.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 11 February 2011, from Elyse Wilkinson, Allianz Australia Insurance Limited, to Miss J Shaw relating to unsuccessful insurance claim.
XML.Hansard-Body: Miss Jenny Shaw is an Aussie battler. She has had to fight for everything that she has received in this world. She was devastated after the flood. She is devastated by the decision of Allianz to refuse her claim. The actions of Allianz may very well be legally correct with its hydrologists and experts, but as far as being ethically or morally correct it is a long way off the mark. In support of Miss Shaw and her five children, I urge all Queenslanders to cancel their insurance policies with Allianz and to sign up with insurance companies that have shown love, respect and compassion for Queensland natural disaster victims. Allianz deserves to be strongly condemned for its actions and dealings with Miss Shaw.
I also want to bring to the attention of this chamber another issue from a constituent of mine, a retired water engineer by the name of Rod Coleridge. He wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Western Society now runs on debt ... this is going to make recovery very difficult.
XML.Hansard-Body: I also remind this place that this wise piece of advice can also be applied to Queensland. Our state’s record debt and the financial management which caused it are also going to make recovery very difficult. The bleeding obvious from a state finances perspective is that we were in big trouble before Yasi hit and the Christmas flooding disaster. We spent more than we earnt. We lost our AAA credit rating. We were forced into a fire sale of our state assets. We were $85 billion in debt and counting, and we are in even bigger trouble after the natural disasters. Forecasted economic growth is down by 2.25 per cent from 3.25 per cent to one per cent. There is $5 billion in damages from the flood and $800 million from Cyclone Yasi. While we need to be positive with our actions, we also cannot be delusional. We have to assess the situation in a very stark, clear, prudent manner.

The first thing we would do in the recovery of Queensland is to start with a different mindset. It is different. We did things differently before the natural disasters and now we are going to do things differently again. In order to increase the chances of recovery, first of all we need to stop spending more than we earn. We need to stop borrowing. The red tape that the Premier talked about in her speech is not an orphan. We know who its parents are. If the government and the Premier were to be completely honest in their assessment of the challenges we face, they would have to take ownership or credit for the creation of the red tape that this legislation will be used to fight against. This bill is proof and acknowledgement that we have too much red tape and bureaucratic waste in Queensland. I hope this bill is also proof that this government is sincere about an attitude change in undertaking a battle against red tape in that it has created this mechanism to fight red tape, because if it is, on behalf of the people of the Burnett, then it will have my full support.

Even before our flood and cyclones the issue of red tape waste had been on my mind and on the mind of my constituents, especially with the introduction of the new Wide Bay development plan which is made up of a lot of extra red tape. I assume that the clauses in this bill will be able to take on the extra red tape that the Wide Bay development plan and other development plans within different regions of Queensland will impose. If not, ultimately it leads to higher housing prices and higher rebuilding costs and, quite frankly, it puts homeownership out of the reach of young people. If we are going to rebuild and recover, we are going to have to keep housing prices as affordable and as low as possible.

Most people are aware of the fact that government red tape--or, in many cases, green tape, as is becoming more and more common--is creating a shortage of housing land and is one of the main reasons why homes are becoming so expensive. There has been wide community discussion and condemnation of the state government Wide Bay development plan and I ask the Premier and Treasurer to carefully consider the submissions--the alterations--made by my community regarding the inadequacies of the current plan. I particularly mention the submissions on behalf of the Isis Chamber of Commerce by Wayne Sweeney, a draftsperson there, in consultation with the business owners and the community of Isis. It has put in a very comprehensive submission and I ask that the Premier and this authority look at those submissions.

During a break in a briefing on the Wide Bay draft plan I had a light-hearted chat with a Bundaberg regional councillor. While we discussed the red tape and the Wide Bay development plan and buildings, he confided in me that during an overseas holiday to visit some family in Italy last year he confessed to having one of those historical moments while standing in Rome’s Colosseum. I have never been there, but I could imagine walking in and feeling the atmosphere of the great building and while thinking about the life and death struggles, the human tragedy, the courage and the rise and fall of civilisations which occurred there of being overwhelmed by the weight of history. After the councillor shared this experience with me, I then said, ‘And as a councillor I know what else you were thinking about.’ He was not quite sure what my point was, so I continued, ‘You were also thinking, “Imagine the development application for this place.”’

Before our natural disasters, our Australian civilisation and society was in danger of crumbling--like the ruins of ancient Rome--because of unnecessary, convoluted and costly government rules. After our natural disasters, that danger has increased 1,000-fold. Our potential for greatness as a nation, as a state and as a region is being undermined by red tape and bureaucratic waste that workers, pensioners, ratepayers, home builders, businesses and developers fight with every day. After this series of natural disasters, it is not our greatness as a nation but our chance for survival that depends on our ability to get rid of red tape.

I know of one recent major regional development company whose cost for up-front headworks charges was $1.6 million. That figure was reduced to $600,000 and went ahead only because a very hard-nosed CEO of the company wanting to carry out the development threatened to go public and expose the exorbitant council bill presented to him. I have feelings for that council as well, because we have to remember that this state government also removed its subsidies for capital works and vital, major pieces of infrastructure like sewerage works and the like. So the councils then have to pass on the hole in their budget to the end consumers.

I know that those excessive charges are not only found in local government. Yesterday, I took a delegation of local constituents and spoke about the problems that they have with a new layer of red tape--wetland declarations--which will guarantee to add tens of thousands of dollars to the cost of developing in regional coastal areas. That is tens of thousands of dollars to the costs of farming in our coastal areas. Once again, that will be a piece of red tape that this legislation will have to battle.

So it appears that, although we applaud the legislation for its red tape cutting powers, already this government is out there on the other hand creating more red tape. It is like having Superwoman in charge of the red tape fight on the one hand and sprinkling kryptonite on her muesli with the other. We are competing against countries in this world and states within this country that understand the lessons of history and have kept government red tape and bureaucratic waste in check. In China, a fast-rail link just happens. I wonder if that leap into their future would have been possible if the Chinese had had to deal with Queensland red tape and bureaucratic waste.
In the Herald Sun on 4 February this year, Alan Moran wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Last week, the think-tank Demographia released price data for detached housing in 325 housing markets in seven countries. Prices in Melbourne and the rest of Australia were, except for land-starved Hong Kong, the highest among the countries examined.

The analysis showed that to buy the average Australian house in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide or Perth required 7.1 years of the average household’s income (nine years for Melbourne). For comparable US cities, it is 3.3 years, and in Britain, where houses are smaller, 5.1 years. For the sample of 82 world cities with populations over one million, Melbourne’s house prices are the 79th highest (Sydney’s are 81st).
XML.Hansard-Body: The only problem I have with this article is that it did not examine Brisbane or Queensland house prices, but I can imagine that we are in a similar league. The article states further--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Demographia demonstrated that government planning restraints creating a scarcity of housing land were the overwhelming cause of Australia’s high prices.

Self-proclaimed housing experts have denied that high housing prices in Australia result from our planning and regulatory system. Some have said high prices in Australian capital cities are seen in all seaside cities.
Yet house prices in US coastal cities like Houston and Tampa are a third of Melbourne’s. Inland Bendigo’s house prices are actually double those of Houston, the world’s space research centre.
Some said high Australian house prices stem from low interest rates making them more affordable. Yet interest rates are far lower in Britain, the US and Canada, but houses are cheaper.
Others blamed high house prices on demand pressures from immigration.
But low house prices in cities like Houston, Dallas and Atlanta are accompanied by far higher immigration levels than in Australian cities.

The Demographia analysis shows the high Australian house costs are overwhelmingly caused by the high costs of land. For a block on the Melbourne outskirts planning regulations, on my reckoning, add $80,000 to the cost of a new house.
XML.Hansard-Body: Within the Bundaberg regional area and the Burnett area the UDIA has estimated that to develop a building block will cost between $25,000 and $30,000 in state government charges and local government charges whereas those charges, I believe, are capped to around $5,000 in the western suburbs of Melbourne. So we as a state are now going to compete very strongly with the rest of Australia for development money. People might decide just to walk away from Queensland if the red tape becomes too expensive and too hard. They will go. So we need to be able to create, for example, special economic zones.

I talked about this issue in parliament this morning when I gave a notice a motion. I do not want to pre-empt any particular debate on that motion, except to say that we need special economic zones. Childers wants a special economic zone. Childers is a region that produces in Australia the most tomatoes, the most avocados and the most stone fruit under a single netting. If those businesses are going to be able to rebuild and develop, they need to have special economic incentives. For example, we need to be able to get rid of payroll tax. Andrew Philip, the managing director of SP Exports, who wants to build, has said, ‘You’re supposed to be paying a tax if you are making a profit. We are definitely not making a profit but we are still paying payroll tax.’ This is a holistic approach to developing this state.

In the brief time that I have left to me, I would like to commend Major General Mick Slater and the military for their contribution to the rebuilding. Major General Slater is on the board and also chairs the board of this Reconstruction Authority. As I have said before in this place, my only criticism is that there is not enough military. I believe it is in the national interest to have a significantly increased military. I think there were 1,500 military people--Army lads and lasses--helping out. I would have liked to have seen a lot more on that initial recovery work but I understand that, because of the small size of our military, we are constrained in a national sense in responding to these disasters and to contributing to the reconstruction. If you put together the Army, the Navy and the Air Force, they would half fill the MCG--just about 50,000 people in total. That is a very small number of people. We should have far greater members in the Defence Force. We should be looking at doubling those Defence Force numbers not only for our national protection but also from the point of view that they play a vital role in the reconstruction of our community after natural disasters.

We cannot afford to have any waste or red tape in order to dig ourselves out of the financial mess, the social mess that we are in. We cannot afford to do things the way we did before the flood. We need a new mindset where we do not accept waste or bureaucratic red tape. I join with the Premier, the opposition and other Independents in supporting this legislation.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mount Isa--ALP) (3.38 pm): I rise to speak in support of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill. This bill delivers on Premier Anna Bligh’s promise to rebuild Queensland in the wake of the devastating floods and cyclones during December and January. We have witnessed devastation on an unprecedented scale and each of us have been touched in some way by the devastation and the tragic personal and community loss. The graphic images of tragedy, heartache, devastation and destruction that Queensland has been subjected to will not be forgotten. Massive expanses of floodwaters have consumed whole cities and communities. Whatever way you want to look at it, three-quarters of our state was affected one way or another.

XML.Hansard-Body: While we know that the floods hit mainly our cities and communities along major rivers, we also know that many communities were isolated and are still isolated by floodwaters and that this situation will remain in some instances for many weeks.

Whatever we think of the modern media, right across the state, the country and the world we witnessed once calm creeks turn into wild killers, tossing trees, homes and vehicles around as if they were feathers and consuming almost everything in their paths. We had a cyclone so frightening that it lifted houses from their slabs. We saw human tragedy which reduced us to tears for the pain and the loss felt by those who saw loved ones swept away in the raging waters.

But out of tragedy rose the Queensland spirit, the determination to not let freaks of nature beat us--real Queensland courage, real Queenslanders struggling to cope with the devastation but turning up day after day to help others they believed to be much worse off. They turned out in their thousands to lend a helping hand, to offer a shoulder to cry on or to just be there. As the Premier and my colleagues have said, rebuilding Queensland will take time and effort from each and every one of us. There will be more tears, I am sure. There will also be more stories and displays of selfless human efforts, and there will be success and there will be rejoicing. The recovery effort will require massive resources and a massive and sustained effort. I know that we the government and our fellow Queenslanders are up for the task. We cannot fail. We must rebuild those communities devastated by floods and cyclones and help those Queenslanders--our Queenslanders--who have lost so much, including loved ones, to rebuild their shattered lives.

I am certainly proud to be part of a government that has been so involved in the way that it has to this point in time. We will continue to be a key player, working in partnership for the recovery and rebuilding efforts right across the state. We can have confidence in Major General Mick Slater and the authority he heads. We know we can have confidence in our councils which are at the coalface and the people they serve. Our councils have demonstrated so clearly to us in these past months what they are capable of.

We have done it all before, albeit on a smaller scale. Queenslanders do not balk at the challenge and this is the biggest we will probably ever face. The task is daunting, rebuilding and repairing infrastructure in flood and cyclone affected communities across the state. There is little doubt about the scale of the job ahead of us. The authority will be responsible for developing and implementing a state-wide plan for rebuilding and reconnecting communities across the state. Its role will be to work with local governments and communities to ensure the unique characteristics of each community are not lost.

While my electorate escaped the full force of Cyclone Yasi, many of my communities, despite the fact that they were hundreds of kilometres from where Yasi made landfall, now know something about preparation for a cyclone and what destruction it can bring. When it passed over us, its damage had already been done but it left indelibly etched in everyone’s mind the thought--and most possibly the fear--of what might have been and what had occurred to our cousins on the coast.

Our government is a government for all Queenslanders. I have said this in this House and I will keep saying it in this House: being a member of this government and being from a far-flung electorate, I as the state member for the seat of Mount Isa do not ever feel at all isolated from my colleagues or from the people I work with right across Queensland. I am absolutely certain that under the leadership of Premier Anna Bligh we know we are up to the task of rebuilding this state. As I said, I have no doubts about that. On that note, I commend the bill to the House.

Ms FARMER (Bulimba--ALP) (3.44 pm): I rise to speak to the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. It has been a sobering week in this House, listening to the stories from all members of how their electorates were affected by the recent natural disasters. These stories have of course been most extremely poignant when told by the members whose constituencies have been completely overwhelmed and who have no idea when or whether they will be able to live in their own homes and communities again. Up until this week, most of us have been used to being slowly drip-fed the stories through the media--the horror images on TV every night, the gut-wrenching stories in the newspapers and on the radio. However, in the last couple of days, we have heard the personal stories--the far, far too many specific incidents of devastation. We have heard those stories one after another until they are now in a huge pile in our heads. I know for me, although I thought I understood, I have never been more aware than now of the magnitude of the damage right across the state. This magnitude is of course why it is so critically important that we pass this Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill as soon as possible--today.

It is clear that these communities need us to make life as easy as possible for them, to cut the red tape. There is no human reason at least why they cannot return to normality as soon as possible. Unfortunately for many, soon is not a realistic word. Many of us have felt powerless to help or make a physical difference in any way. We are not police officers, we are not emergency services personnel, we do not drive the trucks to clear away rubbish, we are not builders who can put houses back together again, we cannot build new roads. However, what we do do and what we can do is make laws that are right for our community. What is clear from this week and previously is that there are still so many stories to come about the fallout from the natural disasters--things we do not even know about yet. However, there are also the smaller scale stories which could never rival those of the devastation of whole communities but which nevertheless have huge impacts on local communities.

The Premier referred to one of these matters only this morning in the context of the proposed Queensland Reconstruction Authority when she talked about the plight of the CityCat terminals in Brisbane. The CityCats service an enormous number of commuters across Brisbane and provide a necessary, reliable and even enjoyable alternative to buses and trains for people living, studying, working and playing at numerous points along the river. In my own electorate of Bulimba where there was fortunately limited impact from the floods on dwellings, the much broader impacts of those floods were around public transport--and this was about the CityCats.

We rely on the CityCats. They are a big part of our life. They make life easier. They help reduce traffic congestion. For some, they are the difference between a 20-minute river commute to work and a two-hour car ride. Our terminals and jetties were not so badly damaged but, nevertheless, due to the work that needed to be undertaken to ensure the river was safe, the Apollo Road, Bulimba, Hawthorne and Norman Park ferry terminals and the iconic Bulimba to Teneriffe cross-river ferry were closed.

I knew the fallout from the suspension of the CityCat services was going to be huge, and huge it was. The residents of my local area are good people, they are patient and they are pragmatic about why it might take awhile for such an essential service to be restored, but the disruption has been enormous. Cars have been sitting in traffic on Riding, Hawthorne and Wynnum roads for twice the time they normally would, with enormous resulting congestion on suburban streets. Despite the state government’s immediate funding for additional bus services, those services were already too full before 7.30 in the morning and were leaving commuters stranded. Children were not getting to school on time. Workers were hours late for work. The stress on people’s daily lives was enormous.

I really have to thank the transport minister again for her attentiveness to these issues when I raised them with her--issues which I am sure were being repeated in many other places. She responded immediately and was able to provide additional bus routes within days. Local residents were elated, and if she arrived in my electorate today I know she would get more than a few handshakes for making such a difference so quickly.

Again, we are lucky in our area. On Monday of this week, all of our local ferry services were restored, along with 11 others, including importantly most of the major destination terminals for our area--that is, Riverside and South Bank. Commuters returned to them in droves and you could feel the stress palpably lifting. This was a huge thing for a local community. Effective public transport is one of the most important elements of a functioning and happy community. When it is dramatically disrupted, life cannot be quite normal. For those numerous communities along the river which unfortunately have had their ferry terminals destroyed, this sense of functioning normally could be a long way away. That is why it is so important that we have a mechanism which expedites the rebuilding of the seven ferry terminals that are still out of action.

The Premier referred this morning to the fact that since the terminals started being built 15 years ago much has been learnt about how to make them fit best with their purpose. If we are rebuilding we should use those learnings to build the most effective river transport options. Under normal circumstances the necessary approvals for this number of terminals could take just too long for a community to bear without significant stress. The Reconstruction Authority can fix this. There are hundreds, possibly thousands, of reasons that the Reconstruction Authority is so necessary. The rebuilding of the CityCat terminals is just one of these and one the residents of my electorate, including myself, know too well. I am positive they would join with me in supporting this important bill and I commend the bill to the House.

Ms SIMPSON (Maroochydore--LNP)
(3.49 pm): In the sombre aftermath of the condolence motion we stand with a weighty responsibility, to ensure the rebuilding of Queensland does not suffer the mistakes of previous infrastructure programs flowing from crises. A voice of reason is not a silent voice. It is about being willing to ask the questions and demand the answers in the search for better solutions and improved delivery. With the mammoth task at hand, it is clear that rebuilding Queensland requires a far smarter approach than the disastrous execution of the South-East Queensland drought response, with its bungled $9 million water grid. No-one wants to see repeated the mistakes that still burden this state economically. The salesmanship of the water grid was slick but the delivery and the cost blowouts were not. That is one of the reasons Queenslanders are paying the price today through our water bills and the state of the budget.

There are lessons to be learned from the crisis Brisbane faced of the threat, ironically, of running out of water. At that time this parliament enacted powers in order to urgently build drought response infrastructure. The then Premier, as Treasurer and infrastructure minister, presided over most of these powers and infrastructure delivery. The powers were sold to the public as being urgent and necessary due to the short time frame and the need for coordination. The principles were correct; the execution was not.

There were some significant powers in relation to acquisition of land and approvals for construction. They were accompanied, though, by very poor strategic planning of the projects, scoping and cost management issues. The result was the bungled water grid, a $9 billion network of assets built without a business plan--except for a very small section--and cost blowouts of hundreds of millions of dollars. There is a pattern here that we do not want to see repeated now that Queensland faces the aftermath of yet more crises and this parliament is being asked to pass laws with very strong powers and another government body to respond and implement. We are supporting this bill because we want to see the promised outcomes of better coordination and delivery so that affected Queenslanders can get on with their lives, but we rightly do it with reservations as it has to be done differently to the government’s track record in recent years. Queenslanders deserve that.

It is a cruel irony that Queenslanders answered the call to prepare their houses as they faced floods and cyclones, but the government of Queensland failed to do the same for this state when it came to its own economic preparedness. The poor execution and cost control of the water grid and other infrastructure projects, as well as the overall mismanagement of the budget, combined to ironically leave this state in the worst situation in the face of natural disasters. To lose a AAA credit rating off the back of the best years of prosperity and record income is inexcusable. It meant that when the flooding rains and stormy weather came there was no money saved for a rainy day, only an $84 billion anchor around our collective feet. Our beautiful Queensland, of vibrant resources and enviable lifestyle, had been left economically exposed and vulnerable, like a cardboard house on a flood plain.

A new Centre for Independent Studies analysis rates the Queensland Labor government’s financial management as the worst in the country. LNP shadow Treasurer Tim Nicholls rightly quoted this analysis today because it needs to be said. Queensland is last of all of the states in terms of spending, taxation and debt management. As he said, this report highlights a history of Labor mismanagement and incompetence which left Queensland in a vulnerable financial position before the floods and cyclone hit. Queensland, once the state that had the strongest budget position in Australia, once a state that carried no net debt, has seen this all change as a result of substantial deterioration in recent years which led to us being the only state to lose its AAA credit rating in the global financial crisis. That is worth hundreds of millions of dollars in additional interest payments. Thus, I do not want to hear government members feigning indignation if we demand accountability in the delivery of the rebuild. We support the rebuild. We want to see it done right. We want this to be about building the future for Queensland, not leaving a legacy that is a burden for future Queenslanders.

In the lead-up to this bill being tabled this week, I sought advice from the Department of Transport and Main Roads about how the proposed authority would interact with that department, what the operational relationship would be and how they envisaged this would work. They were still to be briefed at that stage and could not answer that specific question. However, hopefully it will be clear within the corridors of power by now how these operational arrangements will be worked out. It is absolutely vital that there is clear role definition and empowerment for timely and wise decision making. It is vital that any new structure aids, not hinders, the work that needs to be undertaken.

There is opportunity as well to tackle some of the big issues, not just put a bandaid on the big issues. There is an opportunity also, as natural disaster relief and recovery funding becomes available, to ensure that major issues with road networks, and freight networks in particular, in relation to flood immunity are addressed. It was somewhat disturbing to hear that the federal government was looking at rolling back projects that would have given greater flood immunity here in Queensland. I am calling on the federal and state governments to revisit the decision to re-order their priorities. We need to see a state network of roads that has greater flood immunity, not less flood immunity.

There is a very powerful lesson to be learned from the state being cut in half at Rockhampton recently. That is devastating not just for a handful of businesses but for all of North Queensland which is cut off from the south by road. Then, of course, the rail was cut at different times. That impacted on a wide range of businesses and people. That is still being felt, even though the floodwaters have receded.

I welcome the fact that the Yeppen flood study and the Fitzroy study have been released today. We look forward to looking at those options that are on the table. It is vital that there is a cost-effective way of improving the flood immunity of that highway and other critical networks. The freight network of this state is our economic lifeline. When people start to run out of milk and food and cannot do business, they start to realise how vital it is that freight networks operate. I take this opportunity to say that it is time for that freight network to be given proper status. It must have priority in regard to upgrades and flood immunity.

I understand that there is still quite an amount of money not yet spent out of the natural disaster relief and recovery fund from last year’s floods. A couple of weeks ago it was estimated that $2.5 billion had been allocated and there was still a residual amount to be spent before Cyclone Yasi came along. As I understand from the last briefing, there is $4.5 billion in total for the road and rail network, though no doubt those figures will be updated as more information becomes available.

I pay tribute to the hardworking transport crews who are out there in the thick of the crisis but also in the immediate aftermath. I drove between Bundaberg and Rocky recently. It is always quite an experience seeing the Bruce Highway after a lot of rain, but one would have to say that the potholes were caverns. What we hear complained about most in regard to the National Highway being a national disgrace is correct. It is time that this National Highway was finally properly funded. There is no doubt that basic maintenance funds have not been provided. There has to be urgent attention to ensure we see proper maintenance and upgrades of many critical sections of this road. What a shame that so much money was spent on pink batts which could have instead been spent on nation-building infrastructure. This is such a project and one that I would urge this state government and the federal government to pay attention to. I hear a lot about it as I am moving about the state.

I pay tribute to those crews that I saw undertaking the immediate repair work that had to be done as I was getting out on the road. It is hot and hard work. As we know, the weather has been steamy. It has not been pleasant weather in which to do a hard labouring job. However, they were among the many crews who were out there trying to restore our road network to allow people to get on with their lives.

There are some issues that we need to raise with regard to communication during the height of the various disasters. We appreciate that the extent of the flooding throughout the state meant that some of the systems in place were overwhelmed. There is an opportunity to review this. It needs to be done with rigour and honesty to ensure that the communication networks, particularly for motorists, are as accurate as possible and that appropriate signage is put in place in those areas where floodwaters cross roads. For example, I heard a number of cases where B-doubles found themselves on particular routes and the ‘road closed’ signs were situated at locations where they had no hope in hell of turning their trucks around safely. We need to take heed of those learnings from quite a number of communities where this issue of communication, of improved signage and getting accurate information out to people in a timely way is so vital. We also know there was a meltdown with the phone lines and the website and that this was an issue. Certainly we support there being an appropriate review of these systems so that they can be more robust in future.

As I said, we have heard many reports of outstanding work done by volunteers and also state agents and state public servants. However, a complaint was circulated to me and many other members of parliament, which I will table. I note that in the heat of these issues there can be things that break down and do not go as well. I table the email from Gary Briggs from the Darling Downs. He has some quite heated feelings that there were examples where more consideration needed to be given to local knowledge. He speaks of cases where motorists were not seeking to drive in flooded waters and were not seeking to take risks but simply needed to look after their stock, and authorities need to take some consideration of their needs. I will table that. I have written to the minister on that issue as I understand this was quite a serious complaint.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Email, dated 23 January 2011, from Mr Gary Briggs with subject title: plea for help to stop idiots in uniform.
XML.Hansard-Body: Overall, as we know, this is a big state. Most people did the right thing and they worked cooperatively. Where there are problems, they need to be worked through to ensure that people are not only able to safely and reasonably get on with their lives but also be protected where there are real and very present dangers on our roads.

There are many lessons to be learnt from the infrastructure that needs to be upgraded, the maintenance task and certainly cooperation with local government, which has a significant part of that rebuild on its plate. Local governments have a very small rate base but, in fact, have a very significant task at hand. We support any moves to assist them in the rollout of the timely provision of funds so that they can get their communities moving again. The issues with day labour and including that within the natural disaster relief funding has already been mentioned. If councils do not have contracting arrangements with external groups they currently are penalised because they have to use their own local labour who would be pulled off work they otherwise have to do.

We will certainly be keen to work with communities on the many and vast issues that will arise across the state and provide our support for the rebuild. However, as I said, it must be a rebuild that is done with accountability. Where there is red tape that does not serve the purpose and it needs to be cut, let it be cut. If that red tape is a process that does not serve the general systems of government, then there is an opportunity to say that other systems that might be bogging down the normal processes need to also be overhauled. There must be clarity about the relationships of how this new authority operates.

We support the legislation but we want to ensure that Queensland does not experience once again the failure of timely and appropriate spending with good scoping of projects which has left such a burden of debt. There is an opportunity to get it right this time. We want to see that Queenslanders do have a rebuild where the right decisions are made and that they are involved in the rebuild of their lives and livelihoods.

Hansard-Body.A: (Dalrymple--LNP) (4.05 pm): I rise to speak to the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. The necessity of this bill is self-evident; it is essential to the enormous talk of rebuilding this state. What is also self-evident is the need for this to be done well and with a minimal waste of funds and resources. The real and unavoidable cost of recovery is in the billions of dollars. This is a heavy burden for a state that has had to sell off its assets to stay financially viable. We cannot afford for bureaucracy to choke the reconstruction effort before it begins.

XML.Hansard-Body: The urgency of getting our primary producers--bananas and sugar in Tully and Cardwell; livestock and agricultural in the Tablelands, Burdekin and Charters Towers--and businesses back on their feet in as short a time as possible cannot be overstated. The current vulnerability of small rural communities decimated by the floods or obliterated by winds cannot be overlooked. The failure of one of these communities is the failure of the authority and it will be judged harshly by rural communities of Queensland, who are sick of being neglected and burdened by red tape and bureaucracy. It is important that rural towns do not collapse under pointless bureaucratic delays to funding and infrastructure. These towns have suffered to the extreme and deserve better than to be passed over because they do not fall within local government boundaries. This has already happened with the rural resilience package announced by the Premier yesterday. Cattle properties in the Charters Towers Regional Council area such as Maryan Vale, Reedy Brook Station, Chudleigh Park, Craigs Pocket, Valley of Lagoons, Lamonds Lagoon and many more were directly in the path of what the Bureau of Meteorology has classified as the very destructive winds of Cyclone Yasi. It is vital to remember that the winds that hit the region were the same strength as the winds that destroyed Innisfail when Cyclone Larry went through in 2006. These stations have sustained enormous damage over vast areas. The magnitude of the clean-up is not even fully known, but early reports suggest that the bill for primary producers in the area could run into tens of millions of dollars.

The Charters Towers Regional Council area was not included in the Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements launched by the state and federal governments. It is very important that it is included because properties in the top end of the Charters Towers Regional Council area were hit by category 4 destructive winds. There is absolute devastation throughout that region. I table this copy showing where that cyclone went through. It clearly shows that the northern end of the Charters Towers Regional Council area copped category 4 winds but has not received that financial assistance and support. I hope that this situation is rectified and resolved urgently. The support for these people is an important issue, and there is no support for these people who have been severely smashed.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Tropical Cyclone Yasi Track map.
XML.Hansard-Body: I understand that efforts are being made to rectify the oversight of these stations and that the geographical zones requiring assistance are being identified. However, it is an example of the desperate need for detailed information to be gathered from the ground to ensure accurate and efficient allocations of funds and resources. Commonsense and compassion must be the guiding principles of the reconstruction operation. The implementation of this legislation must be transparent, accountable and competent. Already we are seeing red tape and bureaucracy hampering efforts of local people in Far North Queensland to lend a hand.

The BlazeAid organisation is trying to arrange a base camp at the Mount Garnet showgrounds to provide assistance to farmers in the southern Tablelands and northern Charters Towers shires who have been stranded by Cyclone Yasi. However, they are unable to do that because the dongers on the showgrounds do not comply with regulations introduced by the department of resources last year.

There are families who are isolated on properties that have suffered massive damage to infrastructure and they need urgent assistance. One station owner was told that he could not clear his road because his chainsaw licence had expired days previously. This is exactly the type of bureaucratic nonsense that we need to be addressing swiftly and decisively.

There needs to be a practical, hands-on approach and a suspension of the excessive and unreasonable bureaucracy that has hounded recovery efforts in the past. The bill provides the authority with the power to override local government authorities. This power needs to be handled with consideration given to the superb efforts that many councils have put into disaster management so far. Local councils have the on-the-ground knowledge and local connections that are essential to the success of Queensland’s reconstruction. They have worked tirelessly coordinating the response to these disasters and have faced daily the tragedy and gut-wrenching realities of loss and heartache in their shires and regions. It would be a further tragedy for these councils to be railroaded and sidelined by outsiders who feel they can gauge the needs of these communities better than those who live and work there. The task requires cooperation, and this needs to be focused, rather than the overriding powers of the authority.

I would like to raise the issue of the Gregory Development Road. It is an inland highway, stretching from Mount Garnet right down to Clermont. This inland highway is a vital link for the north and south. I have brought up before--and many local authorities have brought up--the importance of having this road fully sealed, upgraded and flood proofed. When the coast was cut off for more than six days, word got out that there was an inland highway stretching from Charters Towers right through to Mount Garnet where trucks could get their supplies backwards and forwards. When they realised this was open, it became a convoy of vehicles. We have been pushing for this for many years. There has been money allocated to it, but it is too slow in coming.

I will name a few creeks that need to be built up and upgraded to flood proof this region--Hann Creek, Lolworth Creek, Fletcher Creek, Basalt River, Sandy Creek, Stockyard Creek, Snake Creek, Clarke River and other low-lying areas but only just a few. If we can raise those bridges three or four metres, that is all that would be needed and we would never have to suffer the result of the roads being cut off for long periods of time. We would have that inland highway and we would be able to get the goods, fruit and vegetables, tourism and transport to-and-fro without having the issue of it being cut off. That really needs to be looked at. The authority needs to look at this very intently.

Another issue is in relation to Telstra and the mobile phone towers. This is another issue that the authority needs to look at closely. When the power goes out, then there is no power to those towers to provide the telecommunications network. As an example, when the power went out at Ravenshoe--it is bad enough when the power is out for five days, let alone having your telecommunications out for five days--one business owner in the town was smart enough to realise, before Telstra did, that the place needed a generator. So he provided his own generator which gave telecommunications back to the region. That was so simple, but that area suffered without telecommunications. Do you know what it is like for Ergon Energy to try to get into these places that have been smashed to smithereens from the cyclone? They are unable to get access and they have no communications. This issue definitely must be resolved.

Also, another issue is the evacuation centres and the importance of having evacuation centres. I believe that the authority needs to investigate this. Mount Garnet, which is a community of nearly 1,000 people, had no evacuation centre. It is not that they did not have a place to go but there was no appropriate evacuation centre to go to that could withstand category 3 or 4 winds that were going to come through. I believe that the council and the authority need to work very closely and find ways of getting funding to build these evacuation centres, because cyclones are not going to stop coming. They are going to keep coming. We have cyclones zooming past us all the time in North Queensland, but we have never had one of this magnitude. They will come back, and we need to be very prepared for them.
I wanted to bring all of those issues to the attention of the House. Later on down the track we will be hearing much more, but I hope that the authority takes note of what I have just said.

Mr EMERSON (Indooroopilly--LNP) (4.14 pm): I rise to speak on the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. The bill establishes a new independent statutory authority to coordinate reconstruction of infrastructure and community recovery in areas impacted by the 2010-11 floods and Cyclone Yasi. This has been an extraordinary, devastating and heartbreaking time for our state, and the authority is needed. It has been given far-reaching powers. I acknowledge that the chair of the authority, Major General Mick Slater, has said that some of its significant powers would only be used as a last resort. The authority will advise on the ‘possible implementation’ of the recommendations of the commission of inquiry into the floods, including future flood mitigation, land use and the regulation of planning. We need to ensure that there is an effective and quick implementation of these measures and recommendations from the commission of inquiry before next summer.

That inquiry is of the utmost importance to my community. There are many key issues that it will examine and be possibly implemented by this authority, key issues that have the utmost importance to my community and the people who were impacted by the floods--particularly the management of the Wivenhoe Dam and its flood mitigation strategy. Serious questions have been raised about that management. Andrew Dragun, the Adjunct Professor for the Australian Rivers Institute at Griffith University, said that it was unbelievable the flood mitigation capacity had not already been boosted when warning lights had been flashing since June last year. Heavy rains last year saw dam levels rise quickly well above 90 per cent, with warnings of potential flooding to come.
Mr Kilburn: Your party wanted to fill it up higher.
Mr EMERSON: Let me take the interjection of the member for Chatsworth, because his side of politics sat there like lumps and did nothing during this whole process. They did nothing.
Mr Kilburn: We definitely didn’t take advice from you.
Mr EMERSON: They did nothing during this. They sat back and did nothing.
Mr Kilburn: Thank God we didn’t listen to you.

Mr EMERSON: They sat back and let the waters rise. They relied on a manual and just let it happen. Only this week, after the floods, they are saying, ‘Let’s release 25 per cent of the capacity.’ They are doing that only after the floods.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order!
We will cease this discussion across the chamber. Please make your comments through the chair, member for Indooroopilly. Those on my right--thank you.

Mr EMERSON: As I was saying, unfortunately the Labor side did nothing during this process. Only after Brisbane gets flooded do they decide to release 25 per cent of the dam’s capacity. The horse has truly bolted, but for the people in my electorate and in other areas of Brisbane they suffered from the flooding because Labor once again did nothing. They look backwards; they are not good at looking forward. They cannot plan.

As I was saying about Andrew Dragun, heavy rains last year saw dam levels rise quickly well above 90 per cent, with warnings of potential flooding to come. Seqwater argued that the manual had ‘served us well’. The manual does not seem to differentiate between El Nino and La Nina. The rules make no allowance for rain outlook, which seems ridiculous. If you are looking at flood mitigation, surely you would be having a look at the circumstances. But once again the manual does not look at what rains are happening or what the forecasts are in terms of its strategy.

The decision this week to release 25 per cent of the drinking capacity of Wivenhoe Dam is an admission that releases were not properly planned before the January deluge. Let me turn to what Andrew Dragun said in an article in the Australian on the 19th--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Since last October the Wivenhoe operator has had three warnings. On October 13 the dam reached 126 per cent of capacity, on October 21 it reached 111 per cent, and on December 29 it reached 123 per cent. In each case the operator reduced the water level only to 100 per cent.
XML.Hansard-Body: The dam level was 106 per cent on the morning of Friday, 7 January. That is the Friday before the week of the floods. It reached 148 per cent on the morning of Monday, 10 January due to limited weekend releases. Over that weekend the dam increased by more than 40 per cent of its capacity but there were only limited releases. This is in the lead-up to the floods that swamped Brisbane and affected 3,500 homes in my electorate.

Experts reportedly concluded that this seriously comprised the dam’s ability to store additional run-off. The dam reached 190 per cent by Tuesday when its operators made huge and unprecedented releases to prevent the system collapsing. The Australian reported that more than 80 per cent of the flood in the Brisbane River at its peak was the direct result of a critically urgent release from the Wivenhoe Dam of almost one-third of its capacity. It was forced to do that because they did not release the water sufficiently over the previous weekend.

That meant that a rain event that may have been comfortably managed by the dam if its flood compartment had been lower turned into a major flood that devastated thousands of homes. It is important that these questions about Wivenhoe Dam are answered. There are many, many people in my electorate who believe that the floodwater into their homes was caused by the mismanagement of Wivenhoe Dam. The inquiry must look at that and, of course, any recommendations of the inquiry must be implemented.

There is also immense confusion over insurance. This needs to be clarified. Homeowners must take responsibility for their own decisions. But those homeowners also trusted flood maps and official assurances of low risk. Some clearly took out insurance in the belief that they were covered but have subsequently discovered that they were not.

This morning I heard a story of someone I saw at Fig Tree Pocket whose house was inundated. The day after the floods he said to me, ‘We have had damage but we have insurance. We will be right.’ I have subsequently learnt now that his insurance company is still not saying that it will pay out. That is a person who felt that he had done all the right things--had his house covered by taking out insurance--but unfortunately he may not get that insurance. The confusion here is that the wording is not simple. The wording is not straightforward. The wording is confusing. It needs to be resolved.

The authority will have responsibility for rebuilding. The sad thing about that is that this government, which is setting up this authority, has a record of failing to deliver on rebuilding and keeping promises. Its record is appalling. Safeguards promised by this government after Cyclone Larry have not been delivered. That is a perfect example of what the people of Brisbane have to look forward to.

The Labor Party promised dedicated shelters for every community. They were supposed to be built as evacuation shelters after Cyclone Larry. The list of promises that emerged after Cyclone Larry and the subsequent Cyclone Summit remain largely shelved or dismissed. Only three cyclone shelters have been completed in five years. Inertia sets in. This government makes the promises, but its record shows that it fails to deliver or breaks those promises. That is its track record. It makes promises, fails to deliver or breaks those promises.

The Minister for Public Works now appears to be walking away from that promise completely. The reality is that he and Labor walked away from it as soon as the promise was made. That is what Labor does every time. It is good with the spin, it is good with the promises, but it cannot deliver, cannot plan and breaks promises.
Let me turn to the flood levy. Andrew Fraser, the Treasurer, may wish to take the lead from the Minister for Public Works and Ms Boyle and also resign because he is probably the worst Treasurer--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! The member will refer to members of this chamber by their correct title.

Mr EMERSON: The Treasurer should take the lead of the two ministers today and resign as well because is undoubtedly the worst Treasurer this state has ever seen. There is no doubt about that. He is the one who has lost our AAA credit rating. He has given us record debt. I have seen lots of Treasurers in my time and I can tell those opposite that he has the track record to show how appalling he is. He is appalling.
Government members interjected.

Mr EMERSON: You know that is the case. He is the one delivering the cost of living increases. It is interesting to note that those opposite are not listening to their own constituents when they say, ‘Why are we facing higher costs of living? Why are we in debt? Why are we in deficit? Why are we the only state to lose our AAA credit rating?’ It is because of the Treasurer. He is the worst Treasurer this state has ever seen.

The people know it. I wish Labor knew it. Those opposite know it, but they will not admit it. He is the one who sold them out. He is the one who is going to cost them at the next election because of cost of living pressures, because of debt, because of deficit, because he has destroyed our economy.

The Treasurer told ABC radio, ‘A new tax won’t help the flood recovery.’ Then a week later what did he say? He said he supports Julia Gillard’s new tax--the flood levy. One week he says, ‘A new tax won’t help the flood recovery.’ The next week he says, ‘Oh, no, it is okay; we welcome that tax by Julia Gillard.’ That is because the Treasurer puts his mates in Canberra in Labor ahead of Queenslanders. That is what he is concerned about--his mates in Labor, not about Queenslanders. ‘A new tax won’t help the flood recovery,’ he says and then changes his mind.

Costs of living increases do not help the recovery, but he keeps delivering those. So much economic damage was done before the flood by this Treasurer, by this Labor government, by this appalling administration. It is the enemy of small business. It is the enemy of jobs. It is the enemy of the economy.

Yesterday’s report from the Centre for Independent Studies further backed that up. What did it say? It said, ‘Queensland has been graded at the bottom of the Australian league table for financial management and can no longer lay claim to being the low tax state.’ It has not been the low tax state for some time. That used to be our cherished record--the low tax state.

The member for Hervey Bay would remember when we were the low tax state. The member for Morayfield probably remembers. It was before Labor got in. He remembers when we were the low tax state. We have not been for a while under Labor.
Let us go back to that study by the Centre for Independent Studies. The analysis from the Centre for Independent Studies--
Government members interjected.

Mr EMERSON: Those in Labor do not want to hear the facts. They do not want to hear the truth. They like to hear the spin about this. That is all they want to hear. They do not mind us not being the low tax state because the reality is that they have never seen a tax they have not liked. They love taxes. They love to tax small business. They love to tax people. That is what they do.
Government members interjected.

Mr EMERSON: You can hear them shouting out, ‘More taxes.’ They are in the pockets of people. The member for Toowoomba South knows exactly what we are talking about. Labor likes to slip the hand in the back pocket and rip it out.
Government members interjected.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Member for Indooroopilly, it is hard to protect if you keep doing that. I would ask you to direct your comments through me as the chair. Members on my right will cease interjecting.
Ms Jones interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! That includes you, Minister.
Mr EMERSON: Thank you for your protection.
Ms Jones: I have a headache from your yelling.
Mr Shine interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order, Minister! Member for Toowoomba South!

Mr EMERSON: I feel sorry for the minister that she has a headache from the taxes that Labor keeps putting up. She is clearly concerned about the fact that Labor keeps putting more taxes on. We all are on our side of the chamber, but on their side of the chamber they have no concerns about more and more taxes.

Let us go back to the Centre for Independent Studies. The analysis from the centre concludes that while Queensland once had the nation’s strongest balance sheet and until recently carried no net debt, that has changed as a result of the substantial deterioration in recent years leading to Queensland being the only state to lose its AAA credit rating through the global financial crisis.
Robert Carling, the author of that report, wrote in today’s Courier-Mail --
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... Queensland have increased more taxes than they have reduced.

Queensland, despite its tax hikes, has recorded the biggest increases in debt and other financial liabilities, which helps to explain why it is the only state to have lost the prized triple-A credit rating during the global crisis.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He goes on--and this is the important part--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Queensland’s fiscal predicament makes the cost of floods and cyclones more difficult for the Bligh Government to handle than if its budget management had prudently left more in reserve for contingencies such as these.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is what everyone in the community knows. They know that the meanness of the means test is because there is no money left in the bank, that this lot on the other side sent us broke in a boom, that they failed to bank the dollars and there is nothing left for contingencies like this flood. That is why the means test is so mean--because of Labor’s appalling mismanagement of our economy.
Let me turn to the issue of the authority and the lack of a separate ministry. The assumption of the portfolio--
Mr Hoolihan: It would help if you did--to be able to refer to the bill.

Mr EMERSON: It concerns me that Labor has no interest in these matters that I am raising about the fact that taxes keep going up, the fact that it keeps mismanaging, the fact that it cannot deliver when it makes promises. It likes to break promises on things--

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ryan): Order! Member for Indooroopilly, I ask you to come back to the purpose of the bill. The bill is for particular purposes related to the Queensland Reconstruction Authority and I direct your attention to those purposes.

Mr EMERSON: I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I was saying before the member for Keppel interjected, there is a lack of a separate ministry to oversee the reconstruction. The assumption of the portfolio by the Premier does not seem to give any accordance to the attention required of this job. It is going to be a massive job. It is an important job for the 3,500 people in my electorate whose homes were affected, the families in those homes and those people across Queensland who were affected, both those hit by the floods and those hit by the cyclone. It is a huge job. It is a priority for this state and it should be the focus of a dedicated minister. In the past we have seen this government fail to deliver on its promises or quickly break them. It needs a dedicated minister to ensure these promises are delivered and that the reconstruction does occur. Queenslanders can only hope that the authority performs better than this government with its appalling record of failure to plan and failure to deliver and an ongoing record of broken promises.

Hansard-Body.A: (Algester--ALP) (Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women) (4.32 pm): With so many Queenslanders affected by natural disasters, it is so critical that our recovery is quick, that it is coordinated and that it is enduring, and the recovery and reconstruction are well underway. There has been an army of workers right around the state from our Public Works officers, our Department of Communities staff in the housing area and the SES workers who are checking damaged and devastated properties. That work is well underway. The planning for the reconstruction is well underway, but it is so important that the Premier has shown the leadership to set up a ministry for reconstruction that she will responsible for and to bring this bill into the House so quickly to establish the Queensland Reconstruction Authority.

XML.Hansard-Body: The public can be very confident in the fact that the recovery--the reconstruction--is well on track and well underway. Many hundreds, in fact thousands, of people around our state are experiencing their darkest days. Many people each day are living with great anxiety and uncertainty. Many people are worrying about how they are going to get through the next day and the next week, how they are going to pay for the school trip for their kids, how they are going to pay for food. It is that desperate for many families, and that is why our recovery has included so much financial support and assistance to people around the state.

This authority will have primary responsibility for planning, coordinating and facilitating reconstruction and recovery in disaster affected areas. One of the chief concerns for Queenslanders right around the state--and I have visited many communities in the last month or so--is getting their lives back in order by having a home in their own community, and that is certainly one of the responsibilities I have taken on as Minister for Housing. While we in this state are a very resilient and, in many cases, self-reliant people, we certainly do need assistance. I pick up on a point that the member for Indooroopilly made about means testing. Remember Cyclone Sid, member for Indooroopilly? Who was the minister for communities or families at that time? It was Kev Lingard. What did he have to say about financial assistance when Cyclone Sid hit North Queensland, particularly Townsville, in 1998? He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Disaster relief is available to people on low incomes who have suffered loss resulting from ex-Cyclone Sid. The Disaster Relief Assistance Scheme is a means tested initiative which is jointly funded by the state and Commonwealth governments.
XML.Hansard-Body: That was in 1998, when Cyclone Sid devastated Townsville and the minister was Kev Lingard. It was a means tested scheme. It has been in place for decades. Your mob did nothing to change it. That is part of the financial assistance package.

But there are other sources of financial support for families. An average family--two adults and three kids--can walk out of a recovery centre with around $11,000, and that is not means tested. Why this concerns me so much is that people need confidence that help is available, and all that people like the member for Indooroopilly do is undermine that confidence and cause more anxiety and more fear. A family of two adults and three kids can either call the community recovery line or go to a community recovery centre and walk out with about $11,000 to be deposited in their account. That is the nature of the financial support that is available. There are three main sources--Centrelink, state provided funds and the Premier’s relief fund.

It is irresponsible to keep touting this notion that people are not getting help. Let me give members some of the data. Over 47,000 people have received financial assistance through payments administered by my department--47,000 people. Many people have also been put up in motels and temporary accommodation, and who is picking up the tab for that? The government. That is what we do when our mates are in strife. That is what we do when our communities are in their darkest days. We give them the assistance they need. The more you keep going on about this lack of support, the more it undermines that confidence. Some people still say, ‘I didn’t know help was available.’ Do you know why some people do not know that help is available? Because they hear the ravings of your mob telling them it is not available. I urge all opposite to understand the assistance that is available.

This recovery is very much an emotional recovery. We can talk about the need for bridges and roads and housing and hospitals, and many of us are planning and getting that in place. But we must also remember that people are suffering emotionally. People are in great anguish and despair, and all that people like the member for Indooroopilly are doing is fuelling that anger, fuelling that frustration, fuelling that despair and causing a lot of harm. People need to get on with their lives and rebuild their lives, and that is what this side of the House is doing. That is what this government, led by a very capable and compassionate leader, is doing, and the Reconstruction Authority is part of this recovery process.

I want to inform members of the House that for communities that have been devastated, like those in the Lockyer--Grantham and others--housing is already in those places. Temporary housing and factory built housing has already been delivered to communities like Emerald and Grantham. I was in Grantham last week. I thank the member for Lockyer for the work that he is doing out there because he is not fuelling fear. But many of his colleagues are. He is being a responsible community leader. It was really pleasing to see and to hand over keys for that demountable housing in Grantham.

It was really encouraging and heartening to look across the road and see the school. The schoolkids were playing. They were cajoling and pushing and shoving like all kids do, but they were there--and there are more kids at that school this year than there were last year. I understand that that school is at full attendance. Frankly, I was surprised by that because I know that many families have had to leave that community for the time being. But we are on the case. We are working with the council. We are working across our government agencies to get more housing in that community. We are looking at buying land. We are looking at putting temporary housing there so that those families can get their lives back in order and regain some sort of normality as soon as possible.

We will be continuing that effort in North Queensland. Those small communities that the member for Hinchinbrook is supporting so well need support. I have been talking to Curtis Pitt and others. I will be making a trip there as soon as possible to see firsthand the needs for housing there but already, as soon as we can, we are delivering housing. Tomorrow, there will be more housing in some of those communities in North Queensland. I know from talking to Mayor Bill Shannon, the member for Hinchinbrook and others that it is so important that people not have an exodus from those communities, but that they stay in those communities, support those communities and help the recovery of those communities. Our focus is very much on working very quickly to allow people to return to those communities and have a secure and affordable roof over their heads. To achieve all of this it will be critical for the Queensland Reconstruction Authority to coordinate activities across all levels of government, including our great efforts with local government, and for all government agencies to work as closely together as possible.

The public can have confidence that the Premier will lead Queensland through a period where we reconstruct resilient and stronger communities in Queensland. As I have said, the public can have confidence that this recovery is well underway. As the Premier said it very clearly herself, we have to put people first here. We have to put those communities first. We have to put the politics last and the red tape last.

Ms O’NEILL (Kallangur--ALP) (4.40 pm): I would like to take this opportunity to offer my condolences and those of my electorate to those who lost family, friends and property in these recent disasters. My heart goes out to them all. I give my congratulations and heartfelt thanks to all the services and volunteers.

I rise to speak in support of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. The main purpose of the bill is to be achieved by establishing the Queensland Reconstruction Authority to coordinate and manage the rebuilding and recovery of affected communities, including the repair and rebuilding of community infrastructure and other property; to work closely with affected communities to ensure that each community’s needs are recognised in the rebuilding and the recovery of the communities; and to develop an arrangement for sharing data across all levels of government to ensure the effective and efficient exchange of information to facilitate flood mitigation for affected communities and that the protection, rebuilding and recovery of affected communities is effectively carried out and is appropriate, having regard to the nature of the disaster event.

The scale of damage in my electorate is small compared to that of others, but it is devastating to these who were impacted. On 11 January, water released from the North Pine Dam combined with heavy rain and a king tide caused local flash flooding, with reports of water rising to the second level of one home in just three hours. Along the North Pine River below the dam wall 10 homes were severely damaged. In fact, some of them were completely washed away. Another 65 properties were damaged in some way. Fortunately, the community worked together and there was no loss of life. Houses are condemned and there are people who have lost everything. Community groups like our fabulous pony club have been devastated and businesses have lost equipment, tools and infrastructure.

Of course, this devastation has been repeated over and over again across our state. But owing to the size of the area, residents feel that their issues were not highlighted or reported on as larger, more obviously affected areas were and that their plight has been made public only due to the actions of their residents association. Indeed, as their representative I found it difficult to get official reports of damage and relied on friends and contacts in the area for updates. I see the Reconstruction Authority as being a way to make sure that that does not happen again.

I know that help and assistance is available for all Queenslanders and the formation of the Reconstruction Authority will give confidence to all communities that they are recognised and will receive assistance through a centralised process reporting to the Premier and we will see Queensland not just restored but transformed.

Mr CRIPPS (Hinchinbrook--LNP) (4.43 pm): I rise to make a contribution to the debate on the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill. The Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill proposes to establish the Queensland Reconstruction Authority to coordinate the reconstruction and recovery of the state of Queensland following the record floods in December 2010 and January 2011 and Tropical Cyclone Yasi in February 2011. In view of the scale of devastation caused by the record floods and by Cyclone Yasi, the Queensland Reconstruction Authority will be established as a new independent statutory authority to manage and coordinate the program of infrastructure reconstruction and recovery within disaster affected communities. The authority will include a dedicated North Queensland office with responsibility for reconstruction and recovery following Tropical Cyclone Yasi. Honourable members will understand and forgive me for being particularly interested in this part of the bill.

The bill proposes to give the new authority primary responsibility for coordinating, implementing and monitoring the rebuilding and recovery of communities that have been affected, damaged or destroyed by the floods and by Cyclone Yasi. It is proposed that the authority will work across all levels of government to plan and facilitate an effective and coordinated program of reconstruction of community infrastructure and other property. It is further proposed that the authority will have the specific function of facilitating flood mitigation and ensuring that the protection, rebuilding and recovery of the disaster affected communities is carried out effectively, efficiently and appropriately. In order to achieve this objective, the authority will be charged with facilitating and expediting regulatory approvals from both state and local governments to rebuild infrastructure and other property.

The bill proposes to provide the authority with the power to decide priorities for community infrastructure and the community services needed for the protection, rebuilding and recovery of affected communities. The explanatory notes accompanying the bill explain that it is intended that the authority will take into account the social, economic and environmental impacts of the flood and cyclone damage and the broader needs of the community. Importantly, the bill provides for the authority to be charged with considering whether or not existing damaged infrastructure ought to be repaired, replaced with like infrastructure, relocated or re-established with natural disaster resilient infrastructure. Significantly, while local government will retain primary responsibility for land use and building approvals, the authority will be vested with significant powers to enable it to effectively fulfil its functions.

The authority will be provided with a suite of powers that may be exercised in declared reconstruction areas. These powers include the power to expedite both state and local government regulatory decisions and approval processes by issuing notices requiring a decision maker to make a decision or advising that the authority itself will assume responsibility for making the decision in question. These notices are based on similar powers that are exercised periodically by the Coordinator-General under the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act 1971.

Finally, it is proposed that the authority will have the power to undertake reconstruction or development works in order to rebuild disaster affected areas of the state. In this regard, the authority will be able to undertake works under the direction of the responsible minister by regulation and will be able to acquire land in order to undertake works, implement a development scheme, or otherwise perform the authority’s functions.

I have taken the opportunity to put on the record an explanation of the role of the proposed Queensland Reconstruction Authority in the anticipation of many of my constituents in the Hinchinbrook electorate approaching me for such an explanation in the coming weeks and months. In particular, I believe my constituents will want to learn more about the role of the North Queensland office of the authority.

In the two weeks since Yasi hit, I have travelled far and wide throughout my electorate visiting devastated communities and speaking to and listening to my constituents. During those travels I have on a number of occasions encountered Major General Mick Slater, who has been appointed chair of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority. I have decided that I rather like Mick Slater and that I can have confidence in him now that he has, in many respects, the future of my electorate in his hands. Mick Slater has spent plenty of time in North Queensland. He has trained at the jungle battle school at the top of the Tully valley in my electorate. As a career soldier, Mick Slater has spent plenty of time deployed in Townsville. Mick Slater spent time supporting the reconstruction of many communities in my electorate after Cyclone Larry in 2006 under the leadership of another major general, Peter Cosgrove. I believe Mick Slater appreciates the circumstances of North Queenslanders and has considerable affection for them.

As the chairman of the authority, Mick Slater also has responsibility for overseeing the rebuilding of flood affected communities in central and southern Queensland. As such, Chief Superintendent Mike Keating has been appointed the director of the North Queensland office of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority. As a senior police officer in North Queensland, I have known Mike Keating on a professional basis for a number of years.
