I have also spoken with Mike Keating on a number of occasions since his appointment and I am similarly confident that he is more then capable of fulfilling this role.

Mike Keating has been stationed in North Queensland for 20 years, including in Cairns, Innisfail, Cardwell, Tully and Townsville. In North Queensland, the test to be able to refer to yourself as a local is very tough indeed. Many hard markers in North Queensland might still not acknowledge Mike Keating as a local but after 20 years surely he would have to go pretty close. What do Major General Mick Slater and Chief Superintendent Mike Keating have in front of them?

I would like to talk about my priorities and the priorities of my constituents. I would like to put these priorities to the Premier in that capacity and in her new capacity as the Minister for Reconstruction. These priorities are separate to those priorities that I have been advocating for over the last two weeks in conjunction with industry leaders and other community leaders to be part of the joint federal and state government NDRRA assistance package for businesses and primary producers. I understand the difference between the two.

NDRRA assistance funding is primarily targeted at short-term assistance and at restoring existing infrastructure. It is critical that the objective of the authority is much more than short term and much more than simply restoring existing infrastructure. If the authority does not aim to substantially improve the infrastructure in the communities affected by Cyclone Yasi in my electorate, then I believe it will have failed and I will be bitterly disappointed and my constituents will be bitterly disappointed at a golden opportunity lost.

I want to reiterate the urgent need for the provision of affordable housing to the cyclone ravaged communities in my electorate. On Tuesday during the condolence motion, I mentioned the urgent need to deliver affordable housing to the cyclone affected communities in my electorate, and I thank the minister for her attention to that matter. I am anxious about the pensioners, the farm workers and those people on low and fixed incomes in my electorate and their capacity to survive through this ordeal when so many of them have had their homes badly damaged. A shortage of affordable housing in my electorate will see many farm workers and award wage earners in a situation where they will have no choice but to leave their chosen community. This could lead to a serious population decline in my electorate, compromising our capacity to recover, restore and rebuild. This in turn would result in a downturn for small businesses in cyclone affected areas. As such, affordable housing is one of the key reconstruction issues in my electorate post Cyclone Yasi. I am confident that the Minister for Housing appreciates the integral nature of this issue and that she will respond effectively.

The tourism industry is an industry I mentioned during my speech on the condolence motion. The difficulties that it will face in my electorate are considerable. As I mentioned the other day, they relate not only to the damage to their business premises but also to the damage to the reputation of the destination when such graphic images in the wake of Cyclone Yasi were distributed nationally and internationally. Having said that, the tourism industry knows what it needs to do to re-establish itself. The tourism industry needs a plan for the future beyond simply re-establishing the infrastructure in place before Cyclone Yasi. The tourism industry is a major employer in my electorate, but many tourism operators will be seriously considering the prospects of another lean year when deciding whether or not to reopen. What is needed is a vote of confidence in the tourism industry in the Hinchinbrook electorate. The state and federal governments need to bring forward infrastructure projects that do more than simply restore what we had before Yasi.

The tourism industry has pointed directly to the urgent need to deliver much improved commercial and recreational boating facilities at Mission Beach, which is a hub of the tourism industry in my electorate. An opportunity to deliver this infrastructure was not seized upon in the reconstruction effort after Cyclone Larry in 2006. The tourism industry at Mission Beach knows what it needs. I know that Mission Beach Business and Tourism has put this proposal strongly to the government on a number of occasions, including since Cyclone Yasi. I table a copy of the briefing paper from Mission Beach Business and Tourism that I know has been put to the government since Cyclone Yasi.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Paper titled ‘Mission Beach: Surviving and Thriving post Tropical Cyclone Yasi’.
XML.Hansard-Body: The briefing outlines the history of disadvantage faced by Mission Beach as a tourism destination, but it also outlines its enormous potential--if only this opportunity to show confidence in the future of the Mission Beach community is embraced by the government through the Queensland Reconstruction Authority.

We also need to bring forward the proposed eco accommodation project at Wallaman Falls, north-west of Ingham in the Herbert River district. In November 2009, the government announced its plans to pursue the development of a number of eco accommodation projects to boost visitor numbers to Queensland’s national parks. The Wallaman Falls site would be excellent. Progress on this project is overdue, although there are several sites in cyclone affected areas of my electorate that would be perfect for such projects, including the old Cardstone village site north-west of Tully and Blencoe Falls at the top of the Kirrama Range Road north-west of Cardwell.

While it may sound unimportant, we also need to put a real effort into restoring roadside signage throughout the cyclone affected region that provides travellers with direction and information. This will really help tourism accommodation centres like Cardwell and Kurrimine Beach. After Cyclone Larry, tourism operators found that not having the numerous road signs that had been blown away really impacted on the ability for tourists, especially grey nomads and self-drive visitors, to navigate their way around the cyclone affected area.

In September last year during debate on the Disaster Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, I canvassed matters pertaining to the two most recent major natural disaster recovery efforts in my area, being Cyclone Larry in the Cassowary Coast region in 2006 and the serious flood event in the Hinchinbrook shire in 2009. The Larry reconstruction resulted in the refurbishment of the old Johnstone shire hall, a new emergency services building and a new secondary school in Innisfail. This is an outcome for the Innisfail community whereby infrastructure was put in place that was a considerable improvement on pre Larry standards.

In contrast, after the major flood event in the Hinchinbrook shire in 2009, I put forward, on the invitation of the Premier, a range of issues that would have improved the capacity of the Hinchinbrook shire to respond to future flood events. The hard stand area around the SES building in Ingham was sealed. Other issues that I raised included flood-free access over Palm Creek, relocating the flood prone Ingham fire station, improvements in local drainage infrastructure and improved access to the Ingham Airport. None of these things happened and it was very disappointing. They are still very important and pressing issues for emergency services in the Hinchinbrook shire, the Hinchinbrook shire council and the local residents of the Herbert River district. I would like to once again advance these projects on behalf of the communities in the Hinchinbrook shire which urgently need to have their capacity to respond to these major regular flood events improved. I am anxious that the post Yasi reconstruction experience in my electorate reflects the post Larry 2006 experience rather than the post Hinchinbrook 2009 flood experience.

Along with the commercial and recreational boating infrastructure at Mission Beach, other infrastructure outcomes that I believe need to be part of the reconstruction effort include rebuilding Tully State High School, redeveloping the facilities at the showgrounds in Tully, revisiting the issue of delivering affordable sewerage in Cardwell and protecting the foreshore in Cardwell to protect the Bruce Highway and the Cardwell community. In the days after Cyclone Yasi, the Premier visited my electorate to inspect for herself the damage to the built and the natural environment. The Premier visited Tully State High School and on doing so stated that Tully State High School would have to be completely rebuilt. I have asked the Premier and the Minister for Education that I be consulted and included in the development of plans to rebuild Tully State High School. Hopefully, as happened with the secondary school in Innisfail after Larry, we can achieve a positive outcome out of a terrible experience for secondary students in the Tully district.

The showgrounds in Tully are a hub of the community for many sporting clubs, the annual agricultural show, the rodeo and community events such as Relay for Life. The old pavilion at the showgrounds in Tully has been destroyed and the Stan Mackay Pavilion has been badly damaged. The Percy Pease grandstand is remarkably still standing. Percy Pease was a predecessor of mine who represented the Tully district in this place. Percy Pease was a Labor member for what was then the state seat of Herbert between 1920 and 1940. That should give the Queensland Reconstruction Authority a good indication of how old that grandstand at the showgrounds in Tully is. The Tip Byrne Indoor Sports Centre at the showgrounds is also a relic. Those two pavilions, the grandstand and the indoor sports centre at the Tully showgrounds desperately need redevelopment. This would result in a very positive outcome for the community and the Tully district, a community that has been devastated by Cyclone Yasi.

The issue of affordable sewerage for the town of Cardwell has been a complicated one in recent years, since an application for SCAP funding by the former Cardwell shire council was successful in 2007. Since that time the new Cassowary Coast Regional Council has found it difficult to secure approvals from DERM to proceed with this project. Several conditions proposed by DERM have seen the estimated cost of delivering sewerage to Cardwell significantly blow out without any corresponding increase in the size of the SCAP grant. With the Cardwell community seriously damaged by Cyclone Yasi, I put it to the government and the authority that the time is absolutely right to take this opportunity, while so much reconstruction is going on in Cardwell, to deliver affordable sewerage to these terribly disadvantaged residents. The local residents cannot afford to fund the blowout in the cost of the sewerage scheme, costs driven up by regulations and conditions proposed by DERM. If this authority really can cut through the red tape, this is surely its opportunity to do so.

Lastly, the foreshore in Cardwell was very badly affected after Cyclone Yasi. All Queenslanders saw the extraordinary damage to the Cardwell foreshore with the eastern lane of the Bruce Highway undermined, the whole highway covered in sand and the recreational areas along the Cardwell foreshore destroyed. I have seen the damage firsthand, as has the Premier, as have other ministers, as has Major General Mick Slater and Chief Superintendent Mike Keating. The restoration and protection of the Cardwell foreshore needs to be a project that is urgently considered by the government and the Queensland Reconstruction Authority.

The LNP opposition is committed to supporting the reconstruction of Queensland following the devastating floods in central and southern Queensland and the horrific damage caused to North Queensland by Cyclone Yasi, damage that was regrettably centred on my electorate of Hinchinbrook. That support of the LNP opposition extends to supporting the passage of this bill. I submit these infrastructure priorities to the government and the Queensland Reconstruction Authority for its consideration in good faith, in the interests of my constituents and the communities that I represent which have been so terribly affected by Cyclone Yasi.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP)
(5.02 pm): In rising to join the debate on the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011, I once again place on record my deep sympathy for all who were affected by the tragic natural disasters wrought upon Queensland during the summer of 2010-11. As honourable members have heard, the LNP will be offering our support for this bill as we want to progress the rebuilding of our great state as soon as possible. We are keen to help the people of Queensland affected by these floods and cyclones to move on with their lives, to regain some sort of normalcy and to have a sense of control and ownership. As honourable members have also heard, the LNP have a number of reservations about aspects of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011, especially with regard to priority items, accountability and the role the Premier will be playing. In other words, we are taking the government’s word on this for the sake of getting on with the job of helping Queenslanders recover from the massive destruction caused by one natural disaster after another.

The floods of December 2010 and January 2011 affected more than 80 towns and cities and claimed 36 lives, with three more people missing. The Premier had already mentioned that legislation would be required to give power to the government or an established authority to allocate funds for the extensive recovery program before the fury of category 5 Cyclone Yasi was unleashed on the good folk of Hinchinbrook and surrounding areas.

The Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011 amends the Building Act 1975, the Disaster Management Act 2003, the Integrity Act 2009, the Land Valuation Act 2010, the Public Service Act 2008 and the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act 1971. Provisions in this bill will allow for the establishment of a single entity, a new independent statutory authority, to oversee and intervene in the reconstruction of flood affected zones, including implementation of flood mitigation recommendations, infrastructure reconstruction and social, economic and environmental recovery in the communities.

The chair of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Board will be Major General Mick Slater. The chief executive officer will be former Coordinator-General Mr Graeme Newton. The other six positions will be held by persons with relevant and extensive experience. In essence, the authority will primarily be responsible for coordinating, implementing and monitoring the rebuilding and recovery, working across all levels of government in planning and facilitating the recovery program. These responsibilities include flood mitigation, community protection and rebuilding, expedition of regulatory approvals and setting the priorities for community infrastructure and services. As a result of the damage caused by category 5 Cyclone Yasi and Anthony before it, a dedicated North Queensland office will be set up to deal with the reconstruction in the Cassowary Coast region.

The authority will be separate from the commission of inquiry and not be responsible for hindsight issues. ‘Nor should it,’ I can hear many government members say. It is little wonder that this government does not want to include hindsight issues, as it reneged on its promise to the North Queensland region five years ago after the devastation of Cyclone Larry and failed to build the shelters and protection that then Premier Beattie pledged. How foolish people were to believe him. But then, these were vulnerable people--or should I say that these were resilient people caught in a vulnerable moment. They were honest, trusting people who must be feeling so much anger mixed in with their pain and despair.

All in this House heard the honourable member for Rockhampton duck for cover in question time on Wednesday and again today when asked by the honourable member for Hinchinbrook to commit to release the timetable for cyclone shelters promised within 100 days of the 2006 state election. In his usual blustery, evasive manner the minister told parliament that government policy was being reviewed--an admission that the Bligh government has failed to honour its commitment to the people of Queensland. Worse still, the minister and his Labor government had left vulnerable communities exposed to the serious dangers of cyclones.

I note that Minister Schwarten addressed the parliament prior to lunch, whilst I was in a stakeholder meeting, to announce his retirement and resignation from the Bligh ministry. This must have been a difficult decision for him and his family and I wish to acknowledge his service to this parliament over many years.

The explanatory notes inform us that the authority, which will have considerable powers, will be able to enter into contracts, to acquire, hold, deal with and dispose of property and to appoint agents and attorneys. It will advise on the possible implementation of the commission’s recommendations, including future flood mitigation, land use and regulation of planning. This is worrying. Already we are seeing escape mechanisms for the government to weasel out of fixing this mess. Surely the findings of the commission and its recommendations should be taken seriously and not risk being treated with contempt by the government if it does not like what it hears.

Included in this bill is a two-year sunset clause, with transitional provisions to transfer relevant powers and responsibilities to the Coordinator-General following cessation of the authority’s operations. This bill does include a number of breaches of fundamental legislative principles, such as compulsory acquisition of land and powers to enter land. However, it is considered to be in the broader public interest for the authority to be provided with these powers in order for it to progress its undertakings.

Poor direction from the minister of the day--that is, the Premier--who, together with the Treasurer, was responsible for selling Queensland’s assets in a fire sale, could spell further disaster for traumatised communities as decisions about their future float in the Premier’s hands. The authority will have a suite of powers that it would appear can be overruled by the Premier, who has decided to appoint herself as the minister for reconstruction. I guess we should have seen that coming, such is her addiction to hard hats and media opportunities. The LNP believe that it is important to have a stand-alone minister charged with such a great responsibility. The last time a Premier took charge of this was under Beattie’s rule, and I have spoken of his and his government’s trail of broken promises to North Queenslanders after Cyclone Larry.

It concerned me greatly, as the new shadow minister for small business, to see that small business have been pretty much ignored and left to fend for themselves until recently. Here we see a big party policy difference. The LNP is unashamedly pro small and medium sized businesses. We recognise the important role they play. This role was magnified for me in the aftermath of these terrible floods and cyclones. I note the recent announcement of a package under category D to assist small businesses and primary producers, and this is a move in the right direction.

The Chamber of Commerce and Industry Queensland undertook a survey of Queensland businesses for the week commencing 18 January and ending on the 25th of that month 2011 and reported on the demographics of 555 survey respondents. It has publicly stated that at this point there is no clear indication that any of the Premier’s flood appeal money will be used to assist business. CCIQ’s view is that it is better to assist the employers of flood affected victims in order to be able to offer secure, ongoing employment and, as a result, provide a livelihood rather than a one-off payment to the victim and have their employer fold. I mentioned the key findings of CCIQ’s survey during my contribution to the condolence motion for flood and cyclone victims. I will just touch on the main points again here.

One in five businesses in Queensland has had to close and the average number of days that businesses were forced to close was eight. It was 31 days on average before they could return to normal operations. Like many inundated residents, most businesses are unsure if their insurance will cover them for this type of damage, with many reporting difficulty in getting clear positions on where they stand. Many businesses have suffered an indirect impact through the floods with affected customers, affected suppliers, employee inability to attend work or due to the loss of appeal of Queensland as a tourism destination. Unsurprisingly, 22 per cent of all businesses within Queensland have indicated that the floods have had a major to critical impact on their business’s viability with the very real threat of job losses.

CCIQ’s recommendation is for the Premier’s flood appeal to be extended to business including those experiencing a loss of income. In addition, it believes there are many revenue neutral things that government can be doing to assist business through these difficult times. When asked what assistance is needed for impacted businesses, a very clear picture emerges. This includes financial assistance with cash flow and concessional loans from government to help businesses meet their immediate debtor obligations and a marketing campaign highlighting that Queensland is open for business and as a tourism destination is unscathed. I understand this particular initiative is underway. Deferral of tax and bank debt, flood proof infrastructure, more effort to buy and holiday locally, higher priority for business in power restoration and reduced red tape for businesses to get back up and running were further things on the list from CCIQ.

It believes the financial assistance currently provided by government must change in three key ways. Firstly, in relation to the $25,000 special disaster flood assistance grant, many businesses have not been inundated with floodwater and, as such, are not eligible for this payment, yet they have experienced power outage that has prevented them from trading. The resultant loss of income is currently not a criteria for this special grant payment, yet they are experiencing significant financial hardship at present. Equally, many businesses have had their customer base decimated as a result of the floods. CCIQ believes the $25,000 should be extended to those small businesses who have been adversely affected by loss of income or are able to demonstrate significant financial hardship. Secondly, the $250,000 concessional loan via the Queensland Rural Adjustment Authority is currently only available for small businesses which have sustained damage to property, plant and equipment or stock. Many medium sized businesses have also been impacted by the floods and suffered loss of income. They, too, should be eligible for this concessional loan. CCIQ believes the $250,000 loan should be extended and possibly increased to medium sized businesses for those who are able to demonstrate serious loss of income or business hardship. Thirdly, the CCIQ says these amended measures should be immediately extended to cyclone affected businesses.

The Property Council put out a media release today stating that we had been too slow to restore confidence as images beamed across the world of a flooded South-East Queensland. These images have embedded a perception interstate that damage was so widespread that we could not possibly be back to business yet. They are calling for a bigger push by the government for a ‘back to business’ message. Just by coincidence the Treasurer put out a release mirroring this message a few hours later.
Amendments to the Building Act of 1975 will provide--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... a six month exemption period from 8 January 2011 for pool safety certificate ... for leasing of houses and units with non shared pools; to extend ... standard ... for tourist resort complexes; and to restore the capacity of building surveying technicians employed by local governments ...
XML.Hansard-Body: In order to comment on these new laws I looked back over my contribution to the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) from September last year, which implemented the new pool safety laws. In that speech I said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: My colleagues and I fear that we will be back here within a year debating another change to this legislation to rectify the mistakes made by this incompetent Labor government.
XML.Hansard-Body: It only took five months, but here we are. The LNP voiced a number of concerns with the implementation of this rushed legislation during debate in September last year. However, we supported the government’s pool safety laws in good faith because we believed in the premise that every life is valuable. After all, according to the explanatory notes, the objective of the government’s pool safety reform is ‘to help reduce the incidence of pool related immersion injuries and death, particularly for children under five.’ Unlike the Bligh Labor government, our position has not changed. Labor is compromising children’s safety by postponing its own pool safety laws. Evidence shows that most drownings occur in the first 90 days of people moving to a new residence, yet properties that do not meet the new standard will be able to be rented.

This government cannot have it both ways. Postponing new laws for some pool owners will add to the confusion that is already widespread in communities. Premier Bligh’s excuse that we need to use common sense in the aftermath of these disasters is flawed as is her comment that delaying the decision was practical. Since when has it been right to place practicality above a child’s safety? It was practical to allow bananas that had fallen to the ground during the cyclone to be harvested and sold, but it is an entirely different case when we are talking about a child’s safety.

Unreasonable time frames for the implementation of these pool laws have been further impacted by flood damage, but that is no excuse to put safety, particularly that of children, on the back foot. The new laws were poorly planned in the extreme and the start date of 1 December was unachievable as there simply were not adequate numbers of qualified pool inspectors. Now we have a situation where the Premier has decided to relax the new laws to allow pool owners to lease their properties without a valid certificate. All they have to do is give the tenant a notice to say the pool may not comply with pool safety laws and may pose a risk to young children. What is this nonsense? Either it does or it does not pose a risk. It is disgraceful to play roulette with children’s lives in this manner.

Safety in and around pools is vital. Virtually every member of this House agreed on that premise. We need to ensure that we have a workable system that best meets that aim, not a bureaucratic headache which puts pool owners in a jam and is discriminatory to boot. Postponing these fencing laws has also affected inspectors who have invested thousands of dollars in training and gear-up only to have their small businesses put on hold, at this stage, for six months. I had a call from one fellow who has been a pool fence builder on the Gold Coast for 34 years and trained in the first pool inspector group since the new legislation. He said that all inspectors who are properly trained need to carry public indemnity insurance, which costs between $2,000 and $5,000 and only offers cover for $1 million. This man is very angry as pool safety inspectors had received no consultation or notification regarding this legislation. As the Gold Coast and the Sunshine Coast were spared flooding and contain a high number of swimming pools, there is a strong argument. Why is the Premier exempting them for six months while homeowners have to comply? This inspector claims postponements will have a significant impact on him and other people in his industry. He says it will be devastating to his new business.

I am led to understand that almost 600 people have completed the course and with the passing of this legislation they will have trouble finding work. The Bligh government rushed through these pool laws and a rush of people trained to become qualified pool inspectors. I imagine a number have rushed to cash in on these laws using unscrupulous methods, too, passing themselves off as qualified inspectors when they are not, but that is an issue for another day.

Qualified inspectors on the Gold and Sunshine coasts have had their business opportunities crushed for the next six months by Labor’s actions. So much for jobs, jobs, jobs. Laws aside, the best defence against drowning accidents is constant supervision and teaching young children to swim. Parents and carers will need to be doubly vigilant in keeping a watchful eye on youngsters near pools.

In closing, the people of Queensland are pinning their hopes on the new Reconstruction Authority to enable the process of rebuilding to advance in a timely and orderly manner. The authority has broad-ranging powers, some of these yet to be defined. There is much trust being placed in it. Likewise, it is to be hoped that the Premier will use her intervention powers wisely and that recommendations from the commission of inquiry will be adopted where possible. The LNP are wholly committed to seeing Queensland, our great state, rebuilt and powering again soon.

Hansard-Body.A: (Gregory--LNP) (5.20 pm): In rising to speak to this unique piece of legislation, the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011, I say at the outset that it is absolutely paramount that the Reconstruction Authority has the powers to shine the spotlight on every corner of Queensland, because every corner of Queensland has been damaged and affected by the horrific events that we witnessed in this great state in December 2010 and January 2011.

XML.Hansard-Body: The fact is that we in this state have been through what I termed during the condolence debate as the equivalent of a war zone. It is probably something that many of our people have never been subjected to or witnessed and I hope they do not witness again, especially the people in the Toowoomba and Lockyer region, where life was lost. Because of the wonderful work done by the police, SES and other state authorities and agencies and the prewarning that people were given, we did not have loss of life in the far north when Cyclone Yasi struck in January this year.

The Premier and the government have created this Queensland Reconstruction Authority, which is about the reconstruction of damaged Queensland. But the plan must be to do more than just correct the problems that have been created by these disastrous events. I was at a meeting in Emerald a few weeks ago when Major General Mick Slater met with the council. The Minister for Main Roads, Craig Wallace, and the federal minister for agriculture, Senator Joe Ludwig, were also present. One thing Major General Mick Slater said that I liked was that we have to apply a bandaid treatment at the start but we are going to rebuild the infrastructure of this state to better than what it was before. That was music to my ears, because I have to say that a lot of the infrastructure of this state was crumbling, decaying and falling to pieces before this.

It is all very well to stand here today and be critical--and I could criticise--but, if we are going to be fair dinkum about this, it is constructive and positive comments that I believe are going to enhance the opportunity to see our great state once again become the productive and prosperous state that it once was, and still is. We do not need to get the message out there that it is not, because it is. In some areas the rail is working again, especially in the central area which you and I represent, Mr Deputy Speaker Hoolihan. Some of the coalmines are working and the ports are opening up. They are very important to the economy of this state. Some of those communities are seeing the dollars coming back in. We are seeing roads opening up in some areas, and we know of the devastation in the far north and the need there.

I believe that the powers of the authority have to be such that if the authority does make constructive comment then the government--both state and federal governments, in conjunction with local government--has to embrace it and make certain the necessary money is made available for the reconstruction of the infrastructure that has been damaged, ruined or destroyed. Also, we have to get the businesses in those regional areas back to full productivity. We have to get families back to being complete units within those communities and make certain that they are a functional, constructive part of their communities. As the Premier said in her second reading speech, it is about the largest communities down to the smallest communities.

I think the devastation we witnessed in other parts of the state before the horrific events that struck South-East Queensland made a lot of people realise just how important regional Queensland is to the productivity of this great state--the coalmines, the agriculture industry, the tourism industry and all other aspects of rural and regional Queensland, where the dollars are generated for the needs of all people. There are other industries in the south-east that are vital and important. But one thing the disasters have made people aware of is that the south-east needs the regional areas of Queensland and the regional areas of Queensland need the south-east, because we are all stricken for the same obvious reason--because of a natural disaster.

In areas that I represent in the far west we had highways cut off, like the Carnarvon Development Road from Roma right through to Emerald and ultimately up to Charters Towers. You could not go east to Rockhampton because the Capricorn Highway was cut at the Dawson River. You could not go west because there was no way around Chinchilla and those places. All those highways were cut. You could not go north because Rockhampton was cut off. You could not go anywhere. I think that situation demonstrates that we have to give the authority the necessary powers to identify and correct these anomalies so that in future it does not happen again.

When the far north of the state was cut off but you could go via Longreach when the road was open through Chinchilla, Dalby and those places and ultimately via Winton or come back in from Barcaldine to Emerald and up the Gregory Development Road to Townsville, we then saw the destruction of the road pavement with heavy transport pounding the road day in, day out. Somebody counted 87 serious potholes as well as pavement deterioration of that road in that time. That shows that the Bruce Highway is not 100 per cent flood proof in natural disasters, but it also shows that we need alternative routes.

In saying that, the road from Roma right through to Charters Towers--I hope the Queensland Reconstruction Authority will have a look at this artery, because it is very important--is a duplicate artery to the Bruce Highway. But it is no good without further upgrade of the Warrego Highway, which goes west from Brisbane out to Morven, joins the Landsborough Highway and ultimately goes north to Mount Isa, becoming the Barkly Highway at Cloncurry and going on through the Territory. It is a significant, main artery of Western Queensland and it is a conveyor of commerce for the whole of Australia, not just Queensland.

The fact of the matter is--and I hope the Reconstruction Authority will identify this in relation to the events that happened in Toowoomba and the Lockyer Valley--that there is no time like now to identify and demonstrate to the people of Queensland and Australia that a second range crossing at Toowoomba is paramount. It has been outstanding for so long now that everybody has been embarrassed by it. Former federal governments and the current federal government have dragged the chain on it. There is no time like now to allocate the money necessary for that upgrade. The Warrego Highway, not only from here to Toowoomba but also from Toowoomba further west and right through to Roma, is an absolute disgrace.

I have travelled the Bruce Highway from Brisbane to Rocky recently. That National Highway is a disgrace. On the road from Toowoomba to Dalby there are potholes that one could bury a bullock wagon in. The destruction on that road due to the heavy rain is huge. I was on that road in December and I know how disastrous it was then. The heavy rain that we have had in that region since then and the events of December and January will have further compounded the problem.

Nobody should stand in the way of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority in making certain that they identify the issues in question. The crossing at Panorama Creek on the Comet River on the Carnarvon Developmental Road at Rolleston has been out for six weeks late last year and this year. During the heavy rain 24 kilometres of that road had a metre and a half of water over it. Nothing could progress along that road. Panorama Creek has been identified to the Premier and Major General Mick Slater as an important link. It must be upgraded, and the upgrade must be expedited. That road is important.

I hope that the Queensland Reconstruction Authority will look at Cape River crossing on the Gregory Developmental Road between Clermont and Charters Towers. That road culvert is a low crossing. That river cuts the road there for weeks on end. It is paramount that that crossing is made a high-level crossing to allow traffic to be taken off the Bruce Highway in events like we have just witnessed.

There are many issues that the Queensland Reconstruction Authority is going to have to address in its area of responsibility during the two years of the authority. First and foremost, it has to get the social and environmental issues right before it can do the corrections in a lot of places. There have to be realignments of some of these roads in question so the arteries to communities can be opened up and we can make them all-weather surfaces. I know that the events of this year and late last year are extraordinary but they could occur again at a minute’s notice.

We saw Emerald cut off in January 2008 and we have seen it cut off in December 2010 and January 2011. I am pleased to see that my colleague the Minister for Main Roads is in the House this afternoon. I will make some positive comments, Minister. I will talk about the road infrastructure in the far western areas of the state. We have seen some patching work done on the Landsborough Highway. It was done during the wet. It is had it again because the materials are not out there.

For what is it worth, I believe--and this is a constructive comment--Queensland Rail should be used as a carrier of road pavement material to assist in the upgrade and maintenance of roads in the western part of my electorate, the western part of the electorate of Warrego and the electorate of Mount Isa where those pavement materials are not readily available. The cost of hauling this pavement material is a very big capital cost. Queensland Rail could haul gravel from places where we can get the good red gravel soil and drop it at strategic points along the way and then it could be hauled into these places in question and used as road base. I believe this would be a worthwhile initiative. Instead of building roads that are only going to last 10 or 20 years we could be building roads that could last 50, 60, 70 or 80 years as we have seen in the western part of the state where we have good road pavement material available.

We have to get the social issues and the environmental issues sorted out so that the dollars that will be spent as the Queensland Reconstruction Authority goes about implementing the agenda that the government has directed it to implement are not wasted. There are many issues that have to be addressed. The most important issue is how we can do things better.

I have examined some of the people who will be in this authority under the direction of Major General Slater. When I see people like the former director-general of Main Roads, Stephen Golding, I am very excited because he is a man who has intellectual capacity and engineering skills and an understanding of road building right across this state. He can help address some of the anomalies that have existed over the last 30, 40 or 50 years.
Mr Hinchliffe: Great Queenslander.
Mr JOHNSON: There is no doubt about that. I echo the words from the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning; he certainly is and a gentleman with it.

The point I make is that we have to get it right the first time. I have seen situations occur for people in my electorate, such as for people in the Arcadia Valley, and for people in the electorates of Warrego and Callide where graziers and pastoralists cannot get their cattle out. I say to Major General Slater that the situation in Emerald is that while they cannot get their cattle out, the abattoirs are not working, the cattle are not being processed and the export dollars are not coming in.

I believe that the Reconstruction Authority’s first agenda item must be to identify how to make our railways and roads better when we face a disaster of this nature again. The magnitude of this disaster has been a wake-up call for all of us in Queensland. Whilst the Reconstruction Authority has the power to work with the federal, state and local governments, I urge it to take advantage of local knowledge. There is nothing better than local knowledge. There are some old timers who have been there for 40, 50 or 60 years.

Every cyclone, every fire and every flood is different. There are no two the same. We can witness what is going on in Darwin now. Some 27 inches of rain have fallen over the last two or three days. Please God, I hope they are not going to be subjected to what we have been subjected to in Far North, South-East or Central Queensland.

The important thing is to correlate all that information--whether it is from experts or from people who live in the regions. It is paramount to get the balance right before the dollars are spent. I know the chaff is short and it is not easy to get hold of, but it has to be done correctly. When it comes to road infrastructure in the Far North and redeveloping roads in the Far North, it can cost $2 million a kilometre to build roads. In my electorate it is $250,000 to $300,000 a kilometre. We have to get the equation right so we keep the avenues of commerce open and moving. It is about creating jobs, preserving jobs and keeping people employed.

There are many issues. The task of the Reconstruction Authority is not easy. I talked about the conveyance of goods by rail. I hope that the Minister for Main Roads can talk about that with his engineers across the state.

The fact of the matter is that we do have good local knowledge. That local knowledge is going to be very important in this equation. When it comes to our inland roads and our coastal roads we have to get it right. They are the main arteries. There are going to be some significant upgrades around Rockhampton and that is very good. We should all learn from our mistakes and if we do not learn from our mistakes we are not true to the cause of what we are doing.

I urge all of those people right across this state to join with the Queensland Reconstruction Authority and volunteer their knowledge, their information and their constructive comment to assist it to make this state great again.

In the couple of minutes I have left I want to pay tribute to two of my colleagues who have announced that they will be standing down as of today--Robert Schwarten, the member for Rockhampton, and Desley Boyle, the member for Cairns. I have great respect for those two people, and Robbie and I came into this place together in 1989. He is one of the colourful blokes; he is a larrikin. But there is one thing about Robbie Schwarten: you could ring him and he would always get the job done for you. I have always found him a good neighbour and I have always found him a good mate. I know that he and Desley as the Minister for Local Government have always been there, and I thank them for that. We might disagree in this place from time to time, but after all we are all people. We are all here for a common cause--the common good of the people of Queensland. I say to both Robbie and Desley: I wish you well in the future and, whatever course you take, I trust that you will be blessed with health and happiness. It has been great working with you both.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!

Mr McLINDON (Beaudesert--TQP) (5.40 pm): I endorse the words the good member for Gregory made in his speech supporting the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. At the outset I thank the Premier for organising the briefing to the crossbenches and thanks also to Lachlan who went more in depth alongside Graeme Newton in terms of our questions and queries before being able to fully support the bill. Naturally it was a tragedy that 36 lives were lost, and now that we have gone through the condolence motion we are now in a position to focus on the rebuild and recovery, which will undoubtedly be an enormous task ahead for each and every single person on the board, for the government and for every single MP in this parliament.

I support the bill. This is something that we have to get underway, as the member for Gregory said, constructively and efficiently. There is nothing more important--I will reiterate what the good member for Gregory has said--than local government. We have to look at that local intelligence and local knowledge to work out exactly how we are going to put the pieces together and ensure that our communities become stronger than ever. The recovery will be long and varied and there will be a lot of questions asked and there will be a lot of people still hurting, and it will not happen straightaway and it will be frustrating for many people. I wish the board every success as it puts the pieces together and oversees the enormous task ahead of it. I want to acknowledge the chair of the board, Major General Mick Slater, for the huge effort that he made throughout the tragedies of these natural disasters and the task that will be ongoing for quite some time ahead.

However, I am pleased to see that the board and its unreserved powers have a sunset period of two years. That is a rational time frame in order to ensure the reconstruction is undertaken and does not go on indefinitely. That was one of my concerns from the outset, and I am satisfied that the government has thought this through. That time frame should be enough for the board to make all of those recommendations and implementations. I am also pleased to see that on the seven-member board there is an expert from the local government and planning sector and also the former CEO of Townsville council. From a local council perspective, that is critical and it is good to see that two of the seven on the board have a local government background and experience to ensure that our councils are sustained, because councils have had a rough run post amalgamations. Within a two-year period, total debt for councils rose from $2 billion to $4 billion. That doubled in a short two-year period before the natural disasters. I will certainly do everything I can to champion each and every single one of those 73 councils to ensure that they rebuild their communities and have all of the assistance from both the state and federal governments that is required to ensure that they get back on track.

There will be many towns that did not get the media coverage that will need the same, if not more, not only physical support but also emotional support, because there will be many people struggling to get their lives back. Some may never be able to do that. That is something that we must bear in mind--that is, to also look at the emotional toll that it will take. After talking to some friends in Cairns, I am aware that there is a lot of concern after Cyclone Yasi about dead cattle and the influx of feral animals such as dogs and pigs. With that will come a lot of health problems as well. So it is going to be an enormous task. It is not all going to be done the way that many of the people in those towns will want it, but I am sure that with the bipartisan support of this bill this process will be in safe hands for Queenslanders as they rebuild their communities, especially the farmers. I spent quite some time with farmer Derek Schultz in Grantham. He had 60 employees, had lost all of his crops and has tens of thousands of dollars worth of repayments to make every month. When you hear stories like that right across Queensland you wonder how these people get up in the morning and embrace the day knowing that they are not only starting from scratch but starting well behind. That is something that we must also bear in mind.

It is also important to note that the rebuilding efforts will be able to be done more successfully if the insurance companies can go that little bit extra above and beyond the written word in those contracts. Those insurance companies that do lend a compassionate hand and do go that little bit extra for their customers will be remembered. Last night the member for Yeerongpilly launched his campaign for compassionate insurance companies, and there will be five or six launches across the state. Those insurance companies need to lend a helping hand because it will make it that much easier to put the pieces together.

One of the issues that has been brought to light was on the front page of the Cairns Post today in an article titled ‘Hundreds of far northern tradies rally for post-Yasi jobs’. Some 300-odd people met yesterday under the organisation of Rob Fraser who addressed the crowd and demanded that the main contracts and ‘not just the crumbs’ go to locals of what the industry says is $1.2 billion in work. I say to those far northern tradies that we will be championing to ensure that that employment does go local, and I table that article.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Article, dated 17 February 2011, from Cairns.com.au, titled ‘Hundreds of Far Northern tradies rally for post-Yasi jobs’.
XML.Hansard-Body: I thank Senator Jan McLucas and the member for Leichhardt, Warren Entsch, for supporting and championing that cause and being right behind them. It is one thing to lose so much, but then it would be another to not give that work to locals so they can put the pieces together and have employment so they can earn an income. It would certainly hurt a lot of families seeing people coming in from interstate or overseas taking those local jobs. I want to stress and emphasise that it is absolutely key that we get local expertise in putting the pieces back together.

I note that in the Courier-Mail today there is an article about the $1 million Derrabungy Creek bridge which collapsed before it was actually even officially opened. That was at a cost of $1 million and these are the sorts of stories we will see in local government right across Queensland. It is no different with the Scenic Rim Regional Council. There was an estimated $10 million worth of damage in the Scenic Rim region area caused by localised flooding. Many of the projects for the Scenic Rim have been postponed. There was a $6 million project for a new library in Beaudesert which will now be postponed for up to two years, and this is typical of what is going to happen right across councils in Queensland. However, I want to emphasise and stress that the financial sustainability of the Scenic Rim Regional Council is absolutely critical. We have seen major projects postponed. $10 million is a huge amount of money for a ratepayer base of only 17,500 homes. I have attempted to lobby the good Minister for Local Government about this. Whilst she has a good heart, she is a tough nut to crack in trying to get those boundaries changed. But I tell you what: that will be the first thing on my agenda for the new minister. I do thank the minister for executing her job well in the time that she has been the minister. As I said to her, I remember the time that she chauffeured me back from Government House. I thank her for making me feel very welcome in my first few days here in the parliament. Well done and all of the best for your future endeavours, Minister.

I have raised in the local media in Beaudesert the fact that the new satellite city of Flagstone--one of the three satellite cities that the Premier has announced, greater Flagstone at the top end of the Scenic Rim--should undoubtedly be part of the Scenic Rim Regional Council. That will then inject that council with anywhere above and beyond 40,000 ratepayer homes on top of the existing 17,500. That makes sense. There is a connectivity in terms of local communities of interest. The proposed Flagstone station runs straight into the state development area in Bromelton. Most of the localised catchment employment areas will be there, and this is one way that the government can do something positive to assist in the rebuilding and reconstruction of areas of the Scenic Rim. It is very important to realise this, and I have also raised this issue with Scenic Rim Mayor John Brent. I spoke to him last week and he said that that would be a matter that he is happy for the community to have input on to let the community decide whether it wanted to go that way.

Yarrabilba is going to the Logan City Council, which is already sustainable. It would be good to see one satellite city go to the Logan City Council area and then Flagstone and Greater Flagstone come into the area of the Scenic Rim Regional Council. It is absolutely paramount that that council has a viable ratepayer base to be able to repair a lot of the damage that has occurred in the past couple of months.

It is important to note also that there are some 900 kilometres of unsealed roads throughout the Scenic Rim Regional Council area. There is a huge job ahead of that council. There are also 32 bridges that are in need of urgent repair or upgrade. Certainly, many of those bridges were flooded and many roads were damaged quite heavily through localised flooding. The council will need every bit of help that it can possibly get. It only makes sense and I will certainly be lobbying both the government and the opposition in the lead-up to the state election to ensure that these boundaries are changed and that this community can once again become thriving and viable.

This morning I gave notice that I will move a motion in relation to rebuilding Queensland and the need to look at a long-term strategy because, while we fix up the physical, in terms of the primary industries sector I think it is absolutely crucial that a campaign of ‘buy 100 per cent Queensland’ begins immediately. This sort of campaign, similar to the proudly made in Australia campaign, will certainly be able to give hope and confidence to the primary industry sector in Queensland and will ensure that the consumer is empowered by the knowledge that they can contribute to a local farmer and to the primary agricultural secretary. This is absolutely critical. There are people who are starting from scratch and some may even end up throwing in the towel. We need to give them the confidence that they are going to have 4.5 million Queenslanders backing them up. People can see the sticker on the apple or the banana to show whether it is 100 per cent Queensland made. They will then be able to make that informed choice to support local farmers. Last week I wrote to the Premier about this issue. I hope that the government can take this idea very seriously. This morning I heard the Treasurer by his words certainly encouraging Queenslanders to buy Queensland made. So I think such a campaign would be a great initiative that would be able to attain bipartisan support. It would ensure that these good farmers know that we are right behind them, that we will get them back on their feet and that we will certainly pay for the goods that they are able to produce for us.

I want to thank the minister for the success of Wyaralong Dam and the good work that his office did in contacting my office. I would like to congratulate the CEO, Frankie Carroll, and the staff there. They did a fantastic job. Frankie Carroll was in touch with me two or three times a day right into the late hours of the night. I think I got a text at about 11.30 at night and I was wondering who was texting me. It was Frankie to let me know how the water was flowing and how it was all going. So he certainly went above and beyond his duty. As I said yesterday, this is one of the few success stories in terms of the tragedies that occurred across the state.

One of the terms of reference that I would have liked to have seen for the board, even though it is not directly involved in the rebuilding and recovery, was that dams need to be looked at--what worked and what did not work. I know that the Wyaralong Dam certainly prevented the possible flooding of the Logan River into Logan. After the sunset clause of two years for this authority is over, it would be great to see that we can identify where flooding can best be prevented and also to look at the big picture and educate people on water usage. I think Queenslanders have been completely compliant in their water usage. In terms of water use, there is a time and place for when we can ease up a bit and loosen our belts a bit. Queenslanders have demonstrated that they can conserve water. I am a strong advocate for making sure that water charges can be decreased in a period where we have a huge influx of water. The tolls were waived for a period of a week and I think that was another good initiative of the government. Some one million vehicles went along those roadways in that period when the government waived the tolls.

Only a couple of hours ago I received an email from a couple of people in the Cairns region. I will read out some of their concerns. I said that I would raise this issue in the parliament. I will make sure that I do that, because it would be remiss of me if I did otherwise. The email states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Southern interstate building companies have arrangements with insurance companies and they are getting the rebuilding jobs ahead of local tradesman. A Melbourne company has set up an office in Tully saying they have 5,000 jobs on the books already and have been chasing local builders to come work for them. They basically threaten them saying if they register and do the work in a timely manner they’ll get more. If not or if they knock a job back that’s offered to them they won’t offer the jobs to the tradie after that.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is a concern, and rightfully so. Certainly, I think these people need to understand that the interstate workers will not be taking precedence over those locals who are on hand and ready to be employed. Apparently, after Cyclone Larry, out-of-town tradesmen came in, undercut the locals and then took off out of town and they were not there to rectify the faults. That is something that needs to be considered in these rebuilding efforts. While people might think that they are getting a good deal in the short term, you cannot beat a local tradie who will back up any repairs or work that needs to be done in the future.
Another email that I have received states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Also on recovery issues, they have finally started getting in to Tully heads to commence clean up. It is being reported that the military contingent has been stood down. This is a major issue as there are still many places such as Kurrimine Beach, Colwey Beach, Tully heads, Hull Heads etc that still need a lot of work and didn’t get the same media coverage as Tully etc.
XML.Hansard-Body: I have mentioned that before. A lot of small towns will be struggling. They did not get the attention and they will certainly need every bit of effort that we can stretch our resources to provide. Another concern that a lady raised was the major issue of depression. I think we need to be very mindful that there will be people going through a terrible time. We need to make sure that the rebuilding efforts are not just done physically but also emotionally.
The email states further--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The cyclone went over there on the way to Mt Isa. A lot of rural properties have been smashed and the council is overwhelmed in their ability to get to these rural properties. They are having problems getting through due to the workload etc and the need for heavy machinery across such a large council area.
XML.Hansard-Body: The email goes on to state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: If the army are no longer needed on the coast they could sure be used in the tablelands. There are a lot of farms etc that have had sheds and houses damaged etc that will need help with clean up but because there’s no access in yet they’re being left out. By the time the council is able to get into these areas the recovery efforts will have been scaled down and extra SES, army crews etc will have left and these farmers will be left holding the bag.
XML.Hansard-Body: I think it is important that at a state level of government we do everything that we can do to lobby the federal government to make sure that the necessary coffers are brought into local government. I am very passionate about local government. I am very passionate about the fact that local government has a lot of local intelligence and it will need every bit of assistance that it can possibly get.

I congratulate Mick Slater and the team. I wish them well in the huge task ahead of them. I thank the government for moving swiftly on this bill and I also thank the opposition for supporting it in a bipartisan manner. I think it is now time to get on with the job. I wish all the best to each and every single one of those board members. My thoughts and prayers are with all of those Queenslanders who are still struggling.

Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (5.56 pm): I rise to speak in support of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. None of us will forget the natural disasters of this summer. The recent floods left 35 dead and 70 per cent of the state impacted, while category 5 Tropical Cyclone Yasi threatened the region between council and Cairns and contributed to one fatality. The gravity of the situation and task head is apparent in the statistics. More than 5,400 houses and over 3,500 businesses have been inundated. More than 5,900 people were evacuated. There were commercial losses of $4 billion in the agricultural, tourism and mining sectors and over a $1 billion worth of cyclone damage. However, behind each of these numbers is a resident or a business owner, their families and their friends. I doubt that there is anyone in Queensland who does not know someone who has been severely impacted by the events of this summer. Few also would be unaware of the spirit experienced in the face of adversity and of the good humour and resilience that was evident from Innisfail to Indooroopilly.

I now turn to the main purpose of the bill, which is the creation of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority. Independent planning powers will provide the authority with the ability to slash red tape, the capacity to intervene in approval or regulatory processes and the capacity to declare designated reconstruction areas in the face of flood and cyclone recovery. These powers will help ensure that the reconstruction of impacted areas will occur as quickly and as efficiently as possible--helping Queensland get back on its feet.

I welcome the appointment of Major General Mick Slater as chair of the authority board. The major general is very well suited for this role and I know that he will get the job done. We have heard great testament of his efforts already by a number of members during this debate. I further welcome the appointment of the former Coordinator-General and director-general of the Department of Infrastructure and Planning, Graeme Newton, as the chief executive officer of the authority.

The real test in these circumstances is how you rebuild better, more resilient than before. To that end, I commend to the authority and the affected communities the principles of adaptive building design. As I have told this House on occasions before, the vernacular Queenslander has design features that were developed by bitter experience and typical ingenuity.

Late last week I joined the Premier, the Deputy Premier, the Treasurer and the Minister for Local Government--who I know would have enjoyed that meeting but who will now go on to more enjoyable opportunities--at a meeting with mayors from flood and cyclone affected areas across our state. I believe that an important role for the Queensland Reconstruction Authority is to consult and, in turn, work closely with relevant local authorities. As the Premier noted during debate on the condolence motion, our disaster management arrangements rely heavily on local responses, local people and local authorities. I highlighted the important role of day labour in local authorities during the recovery and the management of the crisis. I applaud the responses of these organisations and believe that they will continue to have a very large role to play in our recovery.

Further, this bill includes three building related reforms that will assist in the flood and cyclone recovery. Firstly, it introduces a six-month exemption that will allow owners of properties with non-shared swimming pools to lease their properties without first obtaining a pool safety certificate. This will add to the stock of rental accommodation in areas where rental accommodation is most needed to rehouse flood and cyclone evacuees and accommodate tradespeople relocating to disaster affected areas to help with the recovery effort. This change is being made with the safety of children squarely in mind.

Pool safety certificates remain a requirement for homes sold. This is an appropriate balance for those who have committed to the pool safety inspection business. The amendment includes a requirement for a prelease notice that alerts the new occupier of the property to the fact that the pool may not comply with the new standard and may pose a risk to children. Nothing in the exemption absolves the owner of responsibility to comply with the currently applicable pool safety laws. Further, consultation on this matter has occurred with members of the Pool Safety Council, including Hannah’s Foundation, the Local Government Association of Queensland and the Real Estate Institute of Queensland.

Secondly, the bill extends the ability of all hotels, motels and resorts to apply to the chief executive officer of the Department of Infrastructure and Planning to implement a pool safety management plan. It must be demonstrated that they can implement appropriate safety measures to provide child safety, such as an onsite lifeguard. Historically, this was only available to 19 resorts across Queensland. It is envisaged that this may benefit those resorts in flood and cyclone affected areas by providing them with more flexibility in relation to their duty to comply with pool safety requirements. The CEO of the Queensland Tourism Industry Council, Mr Daniel Gschwind, has advised my department that the extension of the pool safety standard exemption to all resorts will provide relief to resorts during the reconstruction and that it is very much appreciated by our very important tourism industry.

Finally, a transitional amendment will reinstate and validate certifying functions performed by local government building surveying technicians. Prior to 1 January 2010, these local government employees were authorised to certify buildings up to two storeys in height and a total floor area of 500 square metres. This amendment will directly benefit people in remote regional areas who require the services of local government building surveying technicians to approve flood and cyclone related building works. This will improve recovery in those communities and is another significant measure of this bill.
The bill provides for the rebuilding, recovery and reconstruction effort in the face of these terrible natural disasters. On that note, I commend the bill to the House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Townsville--ALP) (6.03 pm): I rise to make a contribution to this debate on the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. The weather events of the past two months in Queensland have been unprecedented and, as such, require special and urgent action in order that our great state is rebuilt as quickly as possible. The recovery process will be a whole-of-community responsibility. As we know, all parts of affected Queensland have been hard at work getting on with the job of doing just that. This bill enables the very important recovery of critical infrastructure either by project or geographic area, and I am supportive of this.

XML.Hansard-Body: Before discussing some specific aspects of the bill, I place on record some additional comments relating to cyclone damage sustained in North Queensland and the recovery effort in the area of Townsville and North Queensland. The Townsville city area obviously sustained quite a large amount of damage. It was not as much as our northern neighbours, but we have millions and millions of dollars of roadworks and green waste to be dealt with. To give people a sense of the amount of trees that were destroyed, it is estimated that once all of the green waste is collected and mulched the city will have enough mulch to last for 10 years. We have issues with kerbs and channels, roads, potholes, sealed roads, unsealed roads, damaged parks and damage in other parts of the city.

Palm Island is the other council area in my electorate that obviously sustained some damage as well. Some council buildings were damaged, lots of trees were damaged and there was foreshore damage in that area. Our councils are obviously in the process of assessing the damage and will feed into this process. I commend the Palm Island council and its local disaster management group on its communication with the Palm Island community in the lead-up to Cyclone Yasi and during and after Cyclone Yasi hit our community. The council took a proactive step to provide vouchers to people on the island so they could purchase goods from the store whilst the ATM machines were not operational. That was welcomed by people there. I thank Ergon for getting power restored to parts of Palm Island very quickly so that things could get back to normal.

Our schools sustained a lot of damage. I thank Public Works, Education Queensland, Ergon Energy and all of our local teachers, staff and parents who got in and cleaned up our schools on the weekend after the cyclone. I was pleased to help the teachers and staff at the local Hermit Park State School so it could open again on the Monday morning and our kids could have some normality.

For me, one of the issues of concern in the schools is that there has been a lot of damage to not only trees and fences but also shade sails. We have a very serious risk of skin cancer in the north, and it is important to me and the parents in my community that those shade structures are repaired as soon as possible. One P&C group has already contacted me about this so I will take it up with the minister as soon as I have an opportunity.

I want insurance companies to be accountable to policyholders in the wake of the cyclone. I know of at least one insurance company that has already received over 5,000 claims. I have arranged to meet with the general manager of that insurance company because I want to make sure that people get a fair go from these companies.

I want to place on the record my thanks to all the people who sent messages of support and concern to us both in the lead-up to and during Yasi. In particular, I thank the Premier, the Hon. Anna Bligh, for her leadership and communication with the Queensland community during these times and for taking the time to speak to me personally in the lead-up to Yasi with advice and information about the most sensible and effective way to get people prepared in advance of Cyclone Yasi. I know that the people in Townsville and North Queensland relied on the regular updates given by the Premier and by Deputy Commissioner Ian Stewart. We thank them for providing that during the very, very scary and uncertain times of the Tuesday, the Wednesday morning and into Wednesday night.

The leadership shown by the Premier during this crisis demonstrates to me that she is absolutely the right person to undertake the responsibilities of the minister in charge of the reconstruction of Queensland, and she has my full support in that. As I said, I really do want to place on the record my thanks to Deputy Commissioner Stewart. I also want to thank David Smith from Minister Neil Roberts’s office for providing his endless and tireless updates to us. It was incredible the way we could get that information.
Mr Cripps: Hear, hear!

Ms Johnstone: The member for Hinchinbrook is saying the same thing. We had power at different times, but getting those updates on our mobile phones was invaluable. We could get the message out to our local media outlets on different things and keep our communities as informed as possible. So thank you, David.

I also want to mention the entire team at Ergon Energy. They really have gone above and beyond. It is inconceivable that a city the size of Townsville could have 85 per cent of its area without power. Parts of the HInchinbrook electorate have had the entire network blown out of the ground, and the reconstruction of that network alone will be a massive job. As far as Townsville goes, I think we are now down to a handful of people who do not have power, and my understanding is that most of those people have generators to get them through. I thank the Ergon workers for the work they did to get Magnetic Island and Palm Island restored; it was amazing.

The local disaster management groups of both Townsville and Palm Island made very difficult decisions in short time frames. It is a testament to the planning that goes into our counterdisaster groups that there was no loss of life during the immediate impact of Yasi, although tragically a life was lost after that.

It has been said that adversity brings out the very best in most people and the absolute worst in a minority of others. I was appalled when I was contacted by several workers post Yasi who could not get to work because of Cyclone Yasi and were told by their employers that they would need to take leave without pay or recreational leave for those two days. One employer even went further, saying that if workers chose not to come to work then they should not be paid. I understand that businesses have been impacted heavily by these events. However, I ask them to show some compassion and consideration to the circumstances of their staff members where they can. In some cases these workers have given up recreational leave days in the past to support other disaster relief efforts. Employees did not go to work on Wednesday or Thursday of that week, not because they did not want to but simply because it was unsafe and it would have been irresponsible for them to do so. It would have also been acting against the advice of the authorities.

I commend the Townsville Community Legal Service in its efforts to ensure people are protected legally by any impacts of Cyclone Yasi and our local union organisers who are also assisting affected workers. A huge number of people in our community have been assisting in the recovery that started immediately the winds died. There are a few who I want to place on the record. The Northreach Baptist Church and family emergency accommodation in Townsville saw 400 families in the week post Yasi. Food Relief NQ provided 900 boxes of food between Townsville and Innisfail. I thank the SES volunteers from all over Australia who volunteered around the clock, including my husband Carl who volunteered for a number of days. I give a special thankyou to Corrective Services. The general manager of the Townsville Show Society contacted me on Monday saying how Corrective Services had been in touch and prisoners had been out assisting in the clean-up at the Town and Country Club. This caravan park is home to 66 permanent residents. They have not been able to stay in the park since the cyclone because electricity and water services were not able to be restored due to tree damage. The show society general manager asked me to personally place on the record his thanks to those people who came in on Monday this week. Now we have 66 people who can go home, which is fantastic. The port of Townsville was operational 48 hours after the cyclone passing. This was no mean feat given the precautions they were required to take to secure port assets in advance of what could have been a catastrophic storm surge.

Finally, thankyou to the people of Townsville who participated in Rescue Townsville last weekend. Hundreds of volunteers came out to work all weekend to clean up the yards and residences of people who could not do that for themselves. I was fortunate to volunteer with the team from WHK. Thankyou to those people for doing that. Thankyou to Errol Young, the team leader. I also know that there was an extensive clean-up effort on Magnetic Island. That is highlighted best by an article out of the Magnetic Times that George Hirst has published online just in the last day showing how many people came out on Magnetic Island. There is a great pictorial display of the work that went on over there. That community really does pull together when it needs to. I understand that the percentage of workers who came out to volunteer was way in excess of the number on the mainland in Townsville. Well done to Magnetic Island.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Article, dated 16 February 2011, from MagneticTimes.com.au, titled ‘Yasi clean-up: It gives you a bit of a feeling’.
XML.Hansard-Body: I want to place on the record again--I think I said it yesterday in the condolence motion--that it is essential to Townsville and the people of North Queensland that the small towns of Cardwell, Mission Beach, Tully and Ingham are rebuilt and receive the help they need to get back to normal as soon as possible. These small towns are founded on the jobs and industries that have been destroyed. We need our schools back up and running as soon as possible. They are the lifeblood of our regions and we could not survive in major regional centres such as Townsville without being very interconnected with those smaller communities. I wish them all the best.

The Queensland Reconstruction Authority will be a statutory authority for the efficient and effective coordination of the reconstruction effort.
