To councils in North Queensland that may be concerned as to what that means for their local responsibilities, I assure them that local government will retain principal responsibility for local issues including local planning policy. When this is coupled with the fact that the north will have its own dedicated North Queensland office in Innisfail, more than ably led by Superintendent Mike Keating, I am confident that the views of those local communities will be well and truly heard. Others have spoken about Mike, but he really is a man for the job. He has connections with all of the communities up and down that part of the coast, and he has their respect. He is certainly more than qualified to undertake the responsibility given to him and I wish him all the best with that.

The bill is structured around the fundamental principle that responsibility for land use and building approvals continues to rest with the relevant local government. As the Premier said to all mayors when she met with them last week in briefing them on the intent of the authority, it is the government’s intention that these powers be used in cooperation with local councils rather than being imposed against their will. The Reconstruction Authority’s powers will be used by exception, not as a rule, and only where essential to facilitate reconstruction. Councils should see the establishment of the authority as an opportunity for mayors to have the same sort of access to the resources of the state government and its key decision makers during the recovery that they have had during the immediate disaster response. This is not about control but rather capacity building to assist local governments. It is about facilitating and not frustrating the most efficient recovery for our North Queensland communities.

Built into the legislation are a range of mechanisms to give councils and communities a say on how the authority would operate in their towns. Before declaring a reconstruction area or a declared project the authority will consider the responsibility of local governments for land use and the granting of development approvals in each area, recognising that for the most part they will retain primary responsibility. The authority will work collaboratively with local governments and other agencies to secure approvals and to expedite reconstruction works in the first place using the existing local planning scheme. Where the authority makes its own development scheme in a reconstruction area, the authority will be required to consult with local councils and local communities about the scheme. A period of at least 30 business days will apply where the authority must publish its proposed development scheme on its website with ads in local papers to invite public submissions. The local planning schemes that councils already have in place will remain in place, with the authority’s scheme only prevailing to the extent of any inconsistencies.

Local governments will also retain primary responsibility for assessing and deciding development applications made under the new QRA development scheme. Councils will keep undertaking the nuts and bolts of planning in their local areas. Another mechanism available to the minister for reconstruction will be the ability to direct local governments to take an action in relation to a local planning instrument, such as making or amending a local planning instrument. This is similar to the power that exists under the Sustainable Planning Act. Again it is intended that such power be exercised at the request of a local government to fast-track the reconstruction. Before giving such a direction, however, the minister must give notice of the proposed direction to the council and give them an opportunity to make submissions about the proposed direction. This tool will allow the authority to intervene in situations where more significant interventions, such as declaring a whole development scheme, may not be warranted.

I am confident that the powers afforded to the authority in its interactions with local councils will be focused on harnessing the spirit of cooperation, cutting through red tape and rapidly working together to determine reconstruction priorities in order to get funding out of the door to repair the infrastructure local communities so desperately need in order to rebuild their sense of place.

If I could finish on something that the Minister for Housing was talking about when she was giving her speech, there are people who we are helping already in our communities. People should not think that there is no help. Just today I had a woman from Bushland Beach contact us about her rental property being uninhabitable. The Department of Communities, through community recovery, has already assisted her. People just need to ask for help. We are trying to get the information out there as much as we can. I commend the bill to the House.

Mrs MENKENS (Burdekin--LNP) (6.18 pm): In speaking to the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011, I endorse the position taken by the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for flood recovery in their support of this bill. As we have heard so very emotively in this chamber over the previous two days, Queensland has endured loss of life and considerable damage to public infrastructure, businesses--both rural and urban--and to people’s homes. There was a bipartisan message also that we must look to rebuild and to add resilience and robustness to various infrastructure. There was also a general statement that we must learn from these events, to look for and close the gaps, to revitalise and to look with fresh eyes and a fresh approach. There was also a feeling that we owe it to those whom we have lost and those picking up the pieces and looking to start again from whatever natural event has befallen them.

The task is a bit like the geographical state of Queensland: it is huge. To do the state justice there needs to be a separate, dedicated, devoted minister for reconstruction. This needs to be appreciated to ensure that processes are kept on track, with no short cuts that will need to be revisited. These short cuts and oversights can cost in a financial sense but, more importantly, they create potential for future physical harm. The Premier is to shoulder this mammoth task along with the other important matters of state. While this stance may have the best of intentions, there is a question about what will be given up when there are so many and varied demands on the Premier’s very limited time.

With the state still in its normal wet and cyclone season, there needs to be ongoing vigilance. Flood mitigation measures and recommendations need to be prioritised once the commission of inquiry has put forward its recommendations. Effective implementation is paramount to ensure that the potential for the vagaries of the series of events leading to the Brisbane flood is minimised. Confidence needs to be restored so that such measures are implemented prior to the next wet season.

The need for evacuation centres, especially in cyclone prone areas, has been discussed for many years. Following Cyclone Larry the then Labor Premier, Peter Beattie, promised the provision of specially equipped cyclone shelters from Bundaberg to the Torres Strait. I acknowledge that this is a difficult task, but there has been ample opportunity to incorporate so much more over that time.

The federal Labor BER program is one of these missed opportunities. Some of those buildings could have been cyclone rated. I appreciate that people cannot expect to all be housed in a cyclone shelter; that is not the point. However, we are still in a cyclone season and many people’s homes have been damaged. Should there be another system, where do those people go whilst their own homes are compromised? Not everyone may be in a position to call on others to provide safe haven during a cyclone event.

Some of those BER buildings could have been built to fulfil a dual role of assisting with educational infrastructure and serving as purpose-built shelters. I am certainly aware that the Burdekin Shire Council, for one, made representations to have at least one of the BER funded facilities built to a category 5 standard. This was not done--again, an opportunity lost to build once and build well. So much for the Smart State mantra when a valid request put forward for the safety of northerners was overlooked.

In his response to the member for Hinchinbrook yesterday regarding cyclone shelters we heard the Minister for Public Works gloss over and pay scant attention to the people of North Queensland. He summed up with this response--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I think we really need now to revisit this whole question in terms of whether we want to squander money on evacuation centres that will ultimately not be required.
XML.Hansard-Body: This is not helpful when the BER buildings that are in place throughout North Queensland communities could have been built for a dual purpose. A generic, one-size-fits-all approach has not been helpful with this program. North Queenslanders can now view this promise, made in good faith to people in cyclone prone areas, as one with little likelihood of being honoured.

The local authorities know the grassroots issues and often feed these opportunities up for consideration and implementation. With this in mind, I note that the Queensland Reconstruction Authority has the power to override others. I further note that local government is subject to this authority as well. Overriding powers are not necessarily helpful in achieving longer term outcomes. There needs to be more consultation and acknowledgement of the issues dealt with by groups within frameworks, particularly the areas such as the local disaster management groups. These must not be ignored.

This government has put authorities such as the Urban Land Development Authority up on a pedestal under the guise of undertaking meaningful two-way consultation. From my rather limited experience with the Oonoonba UDA I can say that preconceived ideas were foisted on nearby residents. Some concessions have been made after the fact, but the nearby residents are still aggrieved at the lack of true and meaningful consultation. It is very concerning that this authority could result in a similar situation. Nearby residents have had their homes devalued when there was an opportunity for the UDA to build onto the existing adjoining developments. A person who shared with me their feelings about the lack of consultation afforded by the ULDA said that it could be an acronym for ‘under Labor developments anger’.

With this authority there needs to be a fresh respect for the geography that has been impacted and an appreciation of the local respected people who have considered input. There is an opportunity for cooperation and consultation, and this can be carried out expediently. I certainly hope that the sentiment ‘under Labor development angers’ does not come out when this authority begins implementation of infrastructure.

With the approach of Cyclone Yasi as a severe category 5 system there was also the potential for a storm surge. There was a broad call for people to consider evacuation of their homes and districts. Many people heeded the call to evacuate to higher ground and many evacuated further south in an effort to ensure the safety of family members. I am aware of this exodus firsthand as I saw the many cars heading south to move away from Yasi’s path. However, once Yasi passed these same good people wanted to go home. They were confronted with road closures due to flooding associated with the cyclone. Locally, the same trouble spots came up: Sandy Gully, Yellow Gin Creek, the Barrattas, Haughton River and the reed beds. I am certainly aware that many of the local police had to deal with the frustration of these motorists who were anxious to return home and wanted to cross these closed roads.

I am not at all being critical of the call for evacuation. What I am pointing out is the fragile nature of the Bruce Highway in times of flooding. It has not been helpful for the federal government to cut North Queensland road funding. That will set back the ongoing push to mitigate against flooding on the Bruce Highway. The federal member for Dawson and I both voiced our concerns. We stated that ongoing improvement to the Bruce Highway in North Queensland is critical.

Coming from North Queensland, I am mindful that there is little potential to fully flood-proof the Bruce Highway against one-in-50-year events and so on. That is a panacea and is a notion that is not likely any time soon. For the highway to be cut numerous times each year is not safe or efficient. Every wet season there are road closures at places such as those I have mentioned. Many of these are trouble spots that occur with minimal rain in the catchment area. This must be addressed.

A dedicated North Queensland office to deal with the reconstruction required following Cyclone Yasi is welcomed. This will be important to ensure that the smaller towns that were severely impacted are rebuilt within a reasonable time frame. I note that the minister will have overseeing and overriding powers. This will be inclusive of development approval and local planning instruments. These powers, if used, need to be used in a very judicious manner. Too often we have seen the overarching power of bureaucracy intervene to the detriment of long-term viability and social structure.

With regard to the authority advising on the possible implementation of recommendations of the commission of inquiry, any deviation from the recommendations will need to be judicious, transparent and scrutinised.

In summary, the Queensland Reconstruction Authority impresses as having the best of intentions. These need to be converted into timely outcomes relevant for the geographical area concerned. Sound local input must be sought and must be utilised to ensure there is a minimum of legacy issues.

As we are all well aware, natural events do not wait for areas to be prepared. The last two months will go down in history for the chain of events that have caused heartache, misery and cost to a great number of Queenslanders. What is important in the two-year term of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority is meaningful, less bureaucratic and sensibly prioritised outcomes to meet the real needs of Queenslanders, wherever they live.

Hansard-Body.A: (Buderim--LNP) (6.28 pm): I rise to contribute to debate on this bill, the need for which has arisen from the tragic circumstances this summer. Mother Nature unleashed a virtual inland tsunami across the Lockyer Valley, the most violent storms bringing torrential rain with them and then, of course, Cyclone Yasi. In October last year, barely two months before these disasters, renowned weather forecaster Mr Hayden Walker said to me and my staff in my office in Buderim, ‘In relation to rainfall and floods, it’s going to be quite spectacular. And at the same time, with the increase in subdivisions, increase in roof area and loss of vegetation, the run-off will be increased. So, therefore, if you get run-off increase and the high tide, well, it’s going to be absolutely out of control. It is going to be the biggest storm season we have seen for quite some time.’

XML.Hansard-Body: The floods affected more than 80 towns and regional cities, 36 lives were tragically lost and, indeed, there are still three more people missing. The Holmes commission of inquiry into the flood has been tasked to hand down its interim report, aimed at the pre-summer flood mitigation, this coming August. The inquiry’s final report is due in January 2012. However, as with most royal commission inquiries of this nature, it is not until the evidence is heard that the practices and procedures and the people who implement them are put under the microscope. Will we see a need for the time frame of the inquiry to be extended or will the terms of reference need to be expanded? Only then will we get some sense of whether there has been any culpability.
The commission of inquiry will examine, among other things, the infrastructure and flood mitigation procedures, especially at Wivenhoe Dam. The Queensland ALP website--
Sitting suspended from 6.31 pm to 7.30 pm.
Mr DICKSON: The Queensland ALP website quotes the Premier--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... and now is the time to forensically examine the devastating chain of events and the aftermath ...
Our Government knows that it is by learning the lessons of this disaster through this open and transparent review of our preparation and response that we can protect future generations.
This will be an open, transparent and honest review into what we have just experienced.
XML.Hansard-Body: I sincerely hope that Justice Holmes and her deputy commissioners are allowed to conduct an inquiry without any political interference leading into an election year. We shall see.

Cyclone Yasi has been included in the scope of the authority since the original announcement. One dedicated office will be established in North Queensland for this purpose. The Queensland Reconstruction Authority jurisdiction only covers areas affected by the December-January floods and Cyclone Yasi. Future disaster areas can be included by regulation, but areas unaffected by the disasters are not covered.

The bill establishes a new independent statutory authority to coordinate reconstruction of infrastructure and community recovery in areas impacted by the floods and Cyclone Yasi. Sensibly, this bill seeks to amend the Building Act 1975 to provide a six-month exemption period, from 8 January 2011, for pool safety certificates by leasing of houses and units with non-shared pools, to extend the standard to tourist resort complexes and to restore the capacity of building surveying technicians employed by local governments.

The authority will not be responsible for ‘hindsight’ issues. This will be a job for the Holmes inquiry. The authority will advise on the ‘possible implications’ of the commission’s recommendations, including future flood mitigation, land use and regulation of planning. The authority will primarily be responsible for coordinating, implementing and monitoring the rebuilding and recovery. The authority will be working across all levels of government in planning and facilitating the recovery program.

As the authority will be working across all levels of government, the entire community is keen to know how all this reconstruction is going to be paid for. Queensland is apparently the only state in Australia that does not insure its infrastructure assets. The state Treasurer was quoted in the media two weeks ago as saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Previous market soundings have indicated reinsurance is not cost-effective, given Queensland’s history of natural disasters and the length of the state’s road network.
XML.Hansard-Body: Not cost-effective! I understand that the premiums for such is between $50 million and $100 million. Now, we are faced with infrastructure losses worth billions of dollars. The Treasurer further quoted that, while the state government did not buy reinsurance on the commercial market, the Treasury Insurance Fund had ‘sufficient reserves to meet the claim’. Well, it would appear not, and now the state government has had to go cap in hand to the federal government in order to fund the reconstruction of our state assets. But is that funding guaranteed? They do not seem to have a clue in Canberra. The Prime Minister and Wayne Swan say that the only way they can pay for the reconstruction after the floods is to introduce a levy. But, since Cyclone Yasi, the Prime Minister says that they can find savings in the budget to pay for the cyclone damage.

As I said, they do not have a clue in Canberra how disaster funding will pan out. For one disaster they say we need a levy. Another disaster comes along and they say they can fund it from savings in the budget. And the flood levy has no certainty of getting through the federal parliament. It was reported only yesterday that the Independents and some of the Greens are having second thoughts about the imposition of a flood levy.

I mentioned earlier that the Reconstruction Authority will advise on the ‘possible implementation’ of the commission’s recommendations including the regulation of planning. Let us not forget that weather experts are telling us that we can expect cyclones all along the South-East Queensland coast possibly this year and into the future. In relation to the planning for future infrastructure needs, do we continue to build infrastructure on flood plains and other areas that are prone to cyclone generated flooding? Look at what happened during Cyclone Yasi with patients and staff having to be evacuated from Cairns hospital. What would have happened had Cyclone Yasi struck Cairns head on? The people of Cairns, many of whom may have been injured, would have been left without a functioning hospital. It was reported in the Australian newspaper on 4 February--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The government might also consider whether it is wise rebuilding Cairns Base Hospital on its present site, so close to the shoreline that it was evacuated for fear of flooding, leaving the city vulnerable had the cyclone caused major casualties.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Minister for Public Works and I disagree on a lot of things, but the minister made a statement in this chamber on Tuesday that I could not agree with more. I am sure the minister will not mind me quoting him. Minister Schwarten said during a condolence motion, ‘Anybody who suggests of course that you could flood proof a flood plain really does not know a lot about hydrology or real life.’ I will repeat that: ‘Anybody who suggests of course that you could flood proof a flood plain really does not know a lot about hydrology or real life.’ Similarly, during the Premier’s condolence motion, the Premier made the following statement.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... we are already ploughing ahead with an official inquiry; and, secondly, to rebuild and reconstruct Queensland. Where possible, those buildings and assets that mean so much to our communities and that have been destroyed will be replaced and they will be replaced to more flood-resistant standards.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is interesting. To that end, I believe that the government should seriously consider a moratorium, and that moratorium should be placed upon allowing the approval of any new construction on flood plains or land which could be impacted by flooding from cyclone generated torrential rainfall until after the Holmes inquiry final report is tabled in parliament.

On this side of the chamber, we are particularly concerned that this reconstruction task is not the subject of a separate portfolio with a minister in a stand-alone role dedicated to that very portfolio. It seems that the Premier does not accord the importance or attention to the job required. It is a huge job and the priority of the state, and as such should be the focus of a dedicated minister.

I note that part of the Premier’s new role affords her the power of ministerial intervention. The Premier in her new role as minister has oversight and intervention of powers, including over development approval and local planning instruments. It seems unclear how this authority relates to the existing bureaucracy and where the chain of command will lie.

The Premier has in fact taken authority away from the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning for such development and planning decisions which will need to be made in the areas subject to the Reconstruction Authority. There is a risk of creating yet another bureaucratic jungle. I encourage everyone to visit the Reconstruction Authority website. On the home page there is a map of Queensland with another map overlaying it showing the extent of the area that will be covered by the Reconstruction Authority. It is most of the state! I hope the Premier, along with running the state, really pays her new role the attention it requires and that it does not merely end up amounting to a nightly media opportunity.

Finally, I note there is a two-year sunset clause, winding up the Reconstruction Authority at the completion of its work. Faced with the mammoth task ahead of it, I doubt that the Reconstruction Authority will have completed its work within two years.

Quickly, while I am on the subject, I would like to talk about Buderim. We had a couple of houses in Buderim slip off the side of a hill. People by the name of Miller own this particular property. They thought they were covered by insurance as well. I am going to name the insurance company. It is called Apia. It looks after people over 50. It is not looking after these people over 50. It has decided to void their insurance contract.

Some $440,000 would replace their house. I am calling on APIA to do the right thing by the people of Queensland, particularly the Millers and others who have had their insurance policies voided. This is a time for Queenslanders to pull together. If insurance companies want to represent the people of Queensland appropriately then maybe they need to pull together and do the right thing by people. There are many people in need. It is a time in this state’s history when we should all work together.

I think we need to be very careful of the weather ahead of us. I spoke earlier about Hayden Walker. He has predicted that we are going to be hit with some very nasty weather towards the end of this month and early March. He has also predicted that it will be the wettest year in 100 years. I hope he is wrong and I am sure all Queenslanders do. I hope we are ready for what is coming next.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP)
(7.40 pm): I rise this evening to contribute to the debate on the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. The bill before the House will establish a single authority to oversee and assist with the reconstruction of the flood affected zones, including implementation of flood mitigation recommendations and infrastructure reconstruction.

The authority is charged with the sole task of rebuilding Queensland in the wake of these two devastating natural disaster events. A commission of inquiry has also been established to examine the procedures of flood mitigation and the management of our dams and waterways.

The bill before the House will create a separate act of this parliament and amend several other acts for the purposes of establishing this Reconstruction Authority. Given the amount of damage to vital infrastructure and services that has been incurred, there are relevant time line factors which will need to be taken into consideration with the rebuilding efforts across the state.

Priority needs to be given to projects and communities which need assistance as a matter of urgency. Accordingly, it is vital that the Queensland Reconstruction Authority is not simply another layer of bureaucracy. The focus of this new body is to ensure that communities, supporting infrastructure, industry and the plethora of services offered to Queensland communities are operational in a short period of time. All of the relevant social, economic and environmental impacts in this period of rebuilding Queensland must also be considered.

The responsibility to oversee the local rebuilding efforts of many communities across Queensland is of paramount importance. That is why the LNP moved swiftly and decisively to appoint one dedicated spokesperson for the recovery process. My colleague the member for Redlands has tremendous local government experience, having been elected to serve on the Redlands Shire Council from 2000 to 2009. During that period, the member for Redlands was also a representative on the water and waste committee, chairman of the development assessment committee as well as serving as deputy mayor.

The LNP is committed to the task of rebuilding Queensland and the long journey of recovery ahead for many communities. I concur entirely with the sentiments of the Leader of the Opposition in welcoming the appointment of a reconstruction minister in the Queensland government, as was already the case in the federal government and the Queensland opposition.

The task of rebuilding Queensland will need to be undertaken in a manner of due process and will take a considerable amount of time. The responsibility for this task should be bestowed on one dedicated minister. I question the Premier’s ability to fulfil this responsibility with the required attention, given her other roles and responsibilities as Premier of the state. After all, this role will require more than being a good newsreader or weather reader.

Queensland is Australia’s second largest state in terms of area, third largest in population, but most decentralised in terms of the population of Queenslanders who reside outside the capital city. The majority of Queensland’s towns and cities are either built on the coastline, a river or both. Whether it is the northern coastal rivers of the Herbert, Proserpine or Flinders, the Fitzroy, Burnett, Mary or Bremer or the inland rivers of the Condamine or Barcoo, Queensland is renowned for its system of rivers.

With this in mind, the overall issue of flood mitigation becomes important for most regions in the state. In Goondiwindi, the levee bank of some 11 metres was built in 1958 and serves the town well given its location on a flood plain and that it is split in half by the Macintyre River. Temporary flood defences can be constructed relatively quickly and in many cases, such as in St George, these temporary defences protected property from flood inundation.

The development of flood risk maps is essential in reducing the risk to people and property of rising floodwaters in communities which are particularly flood prone. There has been a call for these maps to be published on the relevant local government websites so that information can be disseminated to the community when required.

There are provisions in the bill before the House which are of concern. Local government jurisdiction and planning authority can be resumed. This does set a concerning precedent as the best people to undertake local planning are local people in local governments. Cooperation between local government and the relevant authorities should be the priority, rather than the local government being overridden by state government authorities.

A constituent has raised with me an issue regarding the urban footprint in the South-East Queensland Infrastructure Plan and Program 2010-2031, where flood plains are built up and landfill often disturbs the natural flow of the watertable. I would envisage that the government is undertaking a review of this urban footprint to ensure that appropriate caution is heeded in considering the planning requirements of local communities across Queensland.

The major Queensland industries of tourism, mining, agriculture and small business have been dealt a massive blow by these two natural disasters. It is important that governments rebuild infrastructure to assist in the transport of goods and services across the state. Many areas which were not directly affected by the floods or cyclone have been indirectly impacted following the closure of many major regional roads and rail lines. Over 25 per cent of our road network has been impacted by the recent disasters and will need some form of repair or rebuild.

The damage to agriculture is heartbreaking. After enduring years of drought, many farmers had crops which were heading for harvest. In another cruel blow, floodwaters and cyclonic winds and rain struck our agriculture sector at a time when many farmers across the state were heading for the best season in years. The resilience of our farmers will again be tested, but government needs to recognise a role in supporting this sector with subsidy and employment assistance.

The Queensland tourism industry is a major employer and contributor to the economy. The Bligh government has already commenced a $10 million advertising package to rejuvenate this sector, but more needs to be done to send the message to the rest of Australia and indeed the world that Queensland is open for business and back on its feet. The development of the tourism sector should be a priority for local regions and the Queensland government. The industry is intrinsically linked with other sectors of the economy and needs to be given additional support and attention.

This morning we heard the Minister for Tourism blame the media for all the hype and hysterics in relation to the cyclone. The Minister for Tourism needs to look at who was standing at the front of all those press conferences and actually putting this in the minds of people around the world and not be so quick to blame the media when it was the Queensland government giving the media all the information in the first place. It is easy to blame the media, but when they are feeding the media with hourly updates they cannot turn around and blame the media and the rest of the world for thinking Queensland is closed for business.
Mr Reeves: It saved lives.

Mr BLEIJIE: I understand that, but those opposite cannot blame the media today for their operational role when they had a role to play. They cannot turn around and blame the media for closing Queensland. It was the statements of those on that side of the House that made people in the rest of the world believe that elements of Queensland are closed for business. Over the past 13 years this government has racked up an $84 billion debt during a period of mining boom and prosperity for the state.

In closing, I want to reiterate the points that many of my colleagues have made today. We seriously doubt whether the Queensland government, whether this Labor government and all its task forces and the Reconstruction Authority has the competence to actually deliver, has the competence to get our AAA credit rating back and has the competence to restore faith and trust in Queenslanders that it can rebuild Queensland.

I think the case is in the negative. The Queensland community cannot trust this Labor government. If we base it on nearly 20 uninterrupted years of Labor rule in Queensland, can Queenslanders now turn around after three weeks of tremendous disaster in Queensland and trust the Labor Party? They cannot.

Mrs MILLER (Bundamba--ALP)
(7.48 pm): I rise in support of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. As the member for Bundamba, people in our community are aware that there was widespread damage in Goodna, Redbank, Riverview and Bundamba. I outlined all the damage to the House in the condolence motion on Tuesday.

This bill establishes a Queensland Reconstruction Authority. The purpose of this authority is to coordinate and manage the rebuilding and recovery of affected communities. This will include the repair and rebuilding of community infrastructure. The bill will also establish a Queensland Reconstruction Board. The role of the board is to oversee the work of the authority. The Premier has announced that Major General Mick Slater will chair the authority with Graeme Newton being appointed the new CEO.

I am pleased to note that clause 10 of the bill says that the authority will work closely with affected communities to ensure that our communities’ needs are taken into account in the rebuilding and recovery process. Clause 10(1)(e) also gives the authority the power to coordinate and distribute financial assistance. This is very welcome. Our communities have expressed a strong desire to be listened to, to be heard and to be consulted throughout this process. Each suburb and each community is different, and they all need to have their say in this process.

I am pleased to report to this House that Major General Mick Slater has been on the ground in Goodna. He told me personally that he was aware of the needs of the Goodna area. Graeme Newton has also visited the Goodna area. I explained to him the community facilities that were destroyed in the flood and how important it is for them to be rebuilt in our community--infrastructure like the Goodna rugby league club, the Goodna Bowls Club, the RSL club, the Goodna pool and the Goodna netball club facilities. The Goodna Rugby Union Club is also an important sports club. The Frank McGreevy centre of the Goodna RSL Services Club had been finished for only about 12 months when the flood hit. It was built with environmental considerations in mind--for example with solar panels--and we were very proud, particularly our ex-servicemen, of that building.

Clause 30 of the bill relates to membership of the board. There will be a chairperson, two members appointed by the Commonwealth, one member nominated by the LGAQ and three other members. Clause 35 relates to time and place of meetings. I note that the board may hold its meetings when and where it decides. Can I now invite the board to meet in our suburb of Goodna. Our local people would consider it an honour to host the board in its community. I advise the House tonight that I have faith in Major General Mick Slater. He has already visited our area, as I said, and he knows just how important our community infrastructure is to the wellbeing of our community.

I have listened to many MPs’ contributions to the debate on this bill and particularly took into account the comments of the member for Moggill in his assessment of the folklore that the river would not flood again. In Goodna we have a community elder who has studied floods in the area over many years. His name is Reg O’Dea. Reg and his family were inundated by floodwaters in 1974 to the height of just over one metre. He was then living at 222 Brisbane Terrace in Goodna. About four years ago Reg asked me if I could organise a meeting with the Queensland Public Service hydrologists to discuss with them whether there was any possibility of another flood event at Goodna. I was more than happy to arrange this and together we visited the experts in Brisbane. The meeting went for about three hours and all sorts of flood issues were discussed. He asked a direct question: can another flood occur? He was advised that it was quite possible.

Reg and I remember having a tour of the control room and particularly how courteous and efficient the staff were and also their patience with the both of us. Reg had been worried about the floods in Goodna for many decades, even before 1974. He predicted this flood, he says, but he thought the flood would come two weeks earlier than it in fact did. He says that he was out by one metre; this flood was one metre higher than he thought it would be. Reg and his family were very lucky not to be flooded this time, but he is thankful that they were evacuated for their own safety.

Reg has told me that he is prepared to provide whatever assistance necessary to the flood inquiry and also to the Queensland Reconstruction Authority as he, too, loves the Goodna area. Reg told me today that he will be making a submission to the flood inquiry but that it would definitely not include any criticism of the Wivenhoe Dam operators or anyone associated with the operations of Wivenhoe Dam. As a highly respected community elder in our community, Reg wants the flood inquiry and the Reconstruction Authority to particularly focus on town planning issues, especially in relation to the units built around Mill Street and also units built in other low-lying areas at Goodna and Redbank. This is an important issue in our area as many poor people--our most impoverished, many pensioners and the working poor--live in these units and now they are faced with ruin. They are faced with ruin physically, emotionally and financially.

In conclusion, on behalf of our community, which has been affected by these devastating floods, I give our commitment to work with Major General Mick Slater and his officers to rebuild and reconstruct where appropriate. Let us never forget that folklore can become urban truths, and we have to push that back. We have to make sure that this folklore--that it could never flood again--is never, ever raised again. The fact is that the river did flood again, and that is the fact that we should learn from and recover from together as a community with the help of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority. I commend the bill to the House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Cleveland--LNP) (7.54 pm): I rise to make a short contribution to the debate on the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. The LNP is not opposing this bill as we need to move quickly to restore and rebuild Queensland. We continue to approach the flood and cyclone recovery process with the bipartisan spirit of what is best for Queenslanders. We continue to put Queensland first. The purpose of the legislation is to establish a single entity to oversee, coordinate and intervene in the reconstruction of flood affected areas impacted by the 2010-11 floods and Cyclone Yasi. This includes implementation of flood mitigation recommendations, infrastructure reconstruction and social, economic and environmental recovery in the communities.

XML.Hansard-Body: Before going any further with specific comment on the bill--and, as I said, I plan to make only a short contribution in that regard--I want to take this opportunity to pay my respects and express my condolences and sympathies to all who have suffered during Queensland’s summer flood and cyclone events. In particular my thoughts and prayers go to those who lost loved ones and who are trying to rebuild their lives. Many people lost homes, property and personal possessions. Some were uninsured and many more were underinsured. It has been a time of anguish and suffering. Having lived in North Queensland for 13 years, I know firsthand what it is like to have a cyclone bearing down on you. I empathise with those who sat in their homes and waited out the cyclonic winds, not knowing for sure what would happen. It is a truly frightening thing for many people.

The speeches made by members of parliament of all political persuasions during debate of the condolence motion were heartfelt and moving. I was happy to step back so that other LNP members from flood and cyclone affected areas could use the time allotted to me to talk about the greater pain their constituents have suffered. While I did not speak to the motion at the time as Cleveland and the Redlands were not directly affected by the flood, I now pay my respects at this first available moment. I also commend the member for Redlands for his condolence speech as the shadow minister for flood recovery and, further, I echo the heartfelt sentiments of the Leader of the Opposition in his most presidential condolence speech.

As I have said, the Redlands as a region of greater Brisbane was not directly affected by the flooding of the Brisbane River. We are most fortunate that the Redlands was far removed from the destruction that followed when a large volume of floodwater was suddenly released from Wivenhoe Dam. I am extremely proud of every Redlander who stood alongside their Brisbane, Ipswich, South-West Queensland and Central Queensland neighbours in their hour of need, whether as emergency service personnel or as volunteers in the mud army, by providing machinery, monetary donations or donated goods or by helping in other ways. I know that the Redlands will continue to do these vital things when called upon in the reconstruction stage. We witnessed a true case of loving thy neighbour as thyself.

The response of the Redlands community to flood affected areas of southern and Central Queensland was nothing short of amazing. I want to commend my parliamentary colleagues in the Redlands, Peter Dowling and Michael Choi, for their partnership with me in coordinating the relief effort in the Redlands. I was probably the least of the three. Tonnes of goods were donated, collected in a warehouse and trucked to flood affected areas of Brisbane, Ipswich and South-West Queensland. I want to acknowledge Susie Masters, Stephanie Pearce, Terri Davidson and the team of more than 1,000 volunteers who gave their time over a 10-day period to do their bit for fellow Queenslanders.

I want to acknowledge those businesses from Cleveland that donated their time, machinery and expertise to the flood response and relief effort. I also want to acknowledge the critical role that Unimin, the sandmining company of North Stradbroke Island, played in providing huge loads of sand for the house-saving sandbags. This community minded and socially responsible sandmining company, which has been unfortunately greatly maligned by this government, came to the rescue of many Queenslanders by providing the key ingredient of the sandbags. I wonder how many houses and other buildings and properties were saved from flood damage because of Unimin’s generosity. I thank it on behalf of the people of Brisbane, and I call on the Premier to publicly acknowledge the role that the sandmining company played in saving Brisbane homes.

When it comes to the rebuilding and reconstruction of Queensland, we need all of our big businesses to do their bit. So I call on the Premier to quit her petty attacks on the mining company and to treat them as they truly are: the helpful Queenslander who did their bit in the floods.

While the Redlands was not directly affected by the floods, the tentacles of the floods reached into the lives of many Redlanders who had family members and friends, homes and businesses in flood affected areas. Many of my constituents, while grateful that they did not lose loved ones, have lost much and it will take a long time for some of them to recover and rebuild their lives and livelihoods too.

Having made clear the goodwill of the opposition in the coming reconstruction stage, it would be remiss of us as the opposition to give the government a blank cheque on the reconstruction. This government has a long history of promising much and delivering little. Queensland is littered with the debris of Labor’s good intentions, overpromising and underdelivering. The lost AAA credit rating, the Queensland Health payroll fiasco, the Traveston Dam, the dysfunctional Tugun desalination plant, the sell-off and sell-out of Queensland Rail, regular budget overruns and costs blow-outs are just a few examples of Labor’s failures and mismanagement. Based on their record of failing Queensland, when it comes to the detail and to the actual delivery of infrastructure and services, the eyes of the opposition are watchful to ensure that the reconstruction occurs effectively and timely. We will not turn a blind eye to government incompetence as it emerges, because we care for Queenslanders.

Examples of potential areas of concern in the reconstruction process include things like the government’s lack of a separate minister for reconstruction, the length of time it will take for the commission of inquiry to make its recommendations and the potential conflict with local councils should the government not properly consult and consider local council advice. The skills shortage, particularly in trades, is another area of concern and it will be a challenge to keep the reconstruction on track due to a lack of availability of tradies. As shadow parliamentary secretary for apprenticeships and trade training, I look forward to contributing in a way that speeds up the factory line so that we have the carpenters, plumbers, electricians and other tradies who will be needed over next few years. It is disappointing that this government has not kept pace even with the current demand for tradies. They are already in short supply and it speaks of a planning failure by the government prior to the flood and cyclone events. We are not in a strong position with the labour that will be required. Queensland needs rebuilding and I have major concerns that this government is up to the challenge.

Hansard-Body.A: (Gaven--LNP) (8.02 pm): When 35 fellow Queenslanders tragically lose their lives, 20,000 homes are totally destroyed--650 of those in North Queensland alone--and 200,000 homes are severely damaged, too many unable to be lived in, and 80 per cent of our coalmining is shut down, there will be a need for reflection, rebuilding and future planning. Sadly, floods and cyclones are part of the price we pay for living in a place that we proudly advertise as beautiful one day and perfect the next. We must not lose sight of the need to ensure that, whilst no-one forgets this, we must also not forget to prioritise the concerns of those who are the immediate victims. The Reconstruction Authority’s role is to primarily address this issue, among others, at its forefront.

XML.Hansard-Body: Despite many years of apparent good luck, especially after having seemingly dodged a bullet after the GFC and a recovery from drought, we were all given a tremendous reality check in the form of a severe rain depression and Cyclone Yasi. The unremitting wind and rain washed far too many lives, too many homes and businesses, and all our hopes away. I ask members to allow me to discuss an approach to recovery in a manner that this bill might facilitate.

Natural disasters can have the capacity to destroy everything from one’s life to the permanent excision of a community from a region. Useful lessons from past disasters assist us to understand what we need to do for future disasters. Whilst two floods, cyclones and in some ways wars are never the same, each event adds to our cumulative knowledge of what it takes to resume normality. Good preparation provides the framework for facilitating disaster response and recovery, but it is how we rebuild that we are judged to have succeeded or failed. Perception rules, because memories are short.

It is testament to our planning, our key staff, our courage and some good luck that the loss of life from the recent disaster was actually so low. In 1995 in the Kobe earthquake, 6,430 people lost their lives, 150,000 houses were destroyed, 150,000 houses were partially damaged and 310,000 people were evacuated to shelters. In 1995, the economic damage was US$130 billion, with only $3 billion of insurance cover, an 80 per cent decrease in freight, 1.2 million people affected by water disconnection and 2.6 million people with no electricity supply, the majority for up to two weeks. I put it to members that these disasters are, in fact, similar to our own and, by comparison, by virtue of preparation, we may have saved over 6,000 lives. All other comparisons are similar, excepting that our damages were spread over 70 per cent of our state’s 1.7 million square kilometres. Therefore, our primary role in this January 2011 disaster was, indeed, successful, but to avoid total loss of life must remain a key objective.

The Reconstruction Authority, as proposed by this bill, needs to do many things and it represents a great challenge to those on it. Major General Mick Slater, whom I went to school with, will do a great job. The sunset clause of two years is sensible and will drive all of those involved to take action and to not procrastinate. What is universally known is that housing is usually the largest category of property loss. Historically, there is no strict linear correlation between the magnitude of housing loss and the recovery process. The short-term recovery of economic activity is often more rapid than the rebuilding of housing stock or the reconstruction of a community. It must be noted that, despite rebuilding, there may remain a handicapped economy with social and environmental stresses and I wish to discuss those.

Again, Kobe, has lots of lessons for all of us. All but 10 per cent were housed within four years of the disaster, but the delays in reconstruction were shortened by a dedication of the reconstruction authority initially to analyse the deficiencies in infrastructure and, when reconstructing and rebuilding, correcting these anomalies. In Kobe’s case, they were dependent on the one main elevated motorway to drive their port, which, in fact, occupies 30 per cent of all the business in Japan. They reorganised their parks, which act as safety refuges in times of disaster. They helped the city realise its strategic objective, which had been identified at the time of the earthquake--actually, almost immediately prior to the earthquake.

Honourable members, Brisbane and Kobe--and this bill is not entirely about Brisbane--are sister cities and the parallels are far closer than is initially apparent. Brisbane is a port city located on a flood plain with a series of hills within and around it. It is reliant on one major arterial road from the west, with a single range crossing at Toowoomba that carries the vast bulk of our porting goods. The flood plain is our Achilles heel and we cannot change that. Kobe is located in an earthquake zone, which is obvious. Kobe’s homes were old. People were very reluctant to move. Many of those who died were elderly and lived alone in small wooden structures. Brisbane, Ipswich Condamine and Theodore homes are older. Many of the residents are elderly and do not want to move. Tragically, some of them are multiple occupants and, yes, some of them are in the lower socioeconomic band.

Insurance claims were very restricted in both areas. As I say, insurance claims were a contentious issue in both our situation and in Kobe’s situation, for slightly different reasons, but they were significant issues. Kobe and Queensland are huge cash generators. As I said, Kobe’s port moves 30 per cent of total Japanese freight, as does Brisbane’s port. I will not go on about the comparisons, but they are very similar.

We have done the same as Kobe did in the early reparative phase. Federally, the Gillard government chose to impose a flood levy and a series of cuts to non-essential budget programs, but they strangely did not countenance a deficit. Kobe was rebuilt and funded by municipal bonds issued by the federal Japanese government. They were issued early but were sold as safe instruments as opposed to what is described as a high-yielding junk or zero-coupon bond. That provided the financial horsepower to drive the issuing of new contracts to private industry and some government entities to build with confidence. GNP did fall across Japan by 1.2 per cent, but there was no recession. Business--industrial, retail, construction and transport--actually boomed. But they did issue these bonds early. The social problems were marked.

I would like to discuss the principles they used which we could use. These are wider reconstruction principles for these disasters and they go beyond Brisbane, Ipswich, the Lockyer and Toowoomba and beyond the Condamine, Darling, Nogoa, Burnett, Mary, Balonne and Dawson rivers. Our communities need unique approaches, but there is a similarity with what was done there. Clearly, Gympie has a unique history of dealing with floods. They build to allow for floods and they do not allow housing on the fringes of rivers. We need better levies on those rivers. The authority needs to investigate, analyse, plan and build a series of levies around our regional towns that are affected.

Councils cannot be expected to fund any capital expenditure, nor should they shoulder any of the interest expended on the 26,000 kilometres of rural roads that need a part or complete rebuild. These roads are our economic arteries. The rail has degenerated into almost a coal-freight-only option. We have to decide whether our below-rail infrastructure in these non-coal areas will actually be replaced. Our major highways need to be made for all weathers, torrents and current flood peak levels. Airports are critical, as was found out. The airports at Gladstone, Alpha and Emerald need to be updated. Alpha requires a new hospital which is appropriately staffed to cater for the $33 billion Galilee coal expansion which was announced today.

In those cyclone affected areas, we must learn the lessons of Cyclone Larry and do all of the things that we did not do then. We need to use the opportunity presented by serious adversity and tackle that problem in a three-year plan, similar to the master Kobe plan, which I will table tonight. The aim of the plan is the five key points in ordinance. All residents will be housed within that time frame. It will occur within commercial and governmental reconstruction and it will integrate. We should provide a five-year rental subsidy plan--which is what they did to achieve success--and the variations of public housing, group title and collective housing should be incorporated within that. I would utilise that system proposed in the Kobe plan. It is universally accepted as the best that came out. I table that document.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Supporters Network for Community Development ‘Machizukuri’ regarding housing reconstruction.
XML.Hansard-Body: I would recommend that the authority stay away from the differentiating divisions within itself that wish to pander to the issues of sectional interests, however important they believe themselves to be. The government’s role is to reassure every different group. For example, if we start with tourism, we should use our existing Tourism Queensland infrastructure. If we are dealing with industry, we should use our existing industry infrastructure--in other words, reassure the coal industry, the steel mills, the power stations and our overseas buyers by reactivating our ports and railway lines and reassuring businesses that we are good providers et cetera. These are constant themes and we should utilise what we have already got.

I discussed the social problems earlier. These have all been reviewed extensively both in Australia and overseas. Basically, they have shown that there are adjustment problems but if we focus on them early we will end up with a much better result. With housing in Australia, we have to accept that we have got intergenerational people within the one structure. As such, we are going to end up with what they believe are social and environmental problems which may be ramped up from what previously occurred. This does obstruct economic recovery. Some people believe it can actually lead to a two-year lag in economic recovery. This was extensively reviewed in 1979. The government held and supported a seminar which was reported on in a book titled Response to Disaster . I would like to stick to the sections regarding social and economic activity--those by John Western and John Price and those by Kearney and Reagh.

They described that we have to address the issues of the psychiatric problems, the psychological problems and the recovery phase. I know that you, Madam Deputy Speaker, as a clinical psychologist, might have a greater knowledge of this, but I will cover it without being too boorish. They said that the public do understand that disaster strikes without reason and that we have to stop describing them as ‘victims’. People fatigue, volunteers fatigue and reconstruction authorities fatigue. Those reconstruction authorities need to resist that because when the reconstruction authorities fatigue it leads to problems. Bad news travels fast; good news is slower.

One of the greatest psychological needs after a disaster is involving the disaster victims in making decisions for the future of their own community. It is called active involvement. We need to address that straight-up. We need to resist creating an authority that overly controls everything. Protest is what most people do as a recognised response to loss. Actively involving people is part of the restitution mechanism so that they can go forward. It should act as a basis for what the authority should be doing.

It is normal for most people to go through all sorts of stages of grief. According to Kubler-Ross there is denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance. This is normal. In a disaster there are three major phases. First there is the phase of the disaster itself, which includes the pre-crisis, the crisis, the community response and the emergency response. We have all seen that. Immediately after that there is what they call the social response, which is the physical stress, the issue of reclamation--when people go back into their homes--and the transition, when people have to make a decision about what they will do. The authority has to have a role in this stage. The third stage is rehabilitation. These days this includes issues of compensation and insurance. In Kobe, they just had to accept that they were not going to get insurance because the insurers were going to battle them all the way through.

Planning and organisation are important. We have to focus on recovery. There has to be a series of review and recrimination, and we have to accept that there will be people who do not like what has happened. Then we have to aim for closure and we have to include a period of thankyous. We should start thinking about who we are going to thank at this stage and try to be as inclusive as we can.

In terms of long-term needs, we cannot deny the fact that people do actually have responses to stress. We have to accept that there are multiple forms of adaptation and we have to try to encourage that adaptation to evolve. We have to continue this active community involvement and it has to be multilevel; it has to be what they call horizontal and vertical.

We have to use the community as a therapeutic community. We have to use the external agencies and make sure they remain sensitive and understand what we are doing. We must gradually remove the dependence on all external providers. The aim must be to focus on the word ‘optimism’. ‘Optimism’ is used widely; its definition is actually ‘looking forward to the future with a positive sentiment’. It must follow on from chaos and conflict.

To drive that optimism, there are four key points that must underpin the whole response and not just that of the reconstruction authority. The authority must come back to these key points all the time to ensure it is relevant and it does not follow the inherent tendency to become insular, which is what happens with most of these authorities. It must accept broader views, and these positive messages must come from all people interacting with it.

The four points are as follows. First, governments can and must be prepared to mitigate the economic and social impact of disasters by better planning and coordination across all government responsibility. In other words, they have to implement that as part of their strategies in all their departments. Second, public trust as well as consumer and investor confidence are key elements to ensure rapid and systemic recovery. Third, governments need to work more closely in partnership with the private sector, from disaster prevention through to recovery. We actually have to be starting to plan for our next disaster as we talk about it. This must start in tandem with reconstruction. Fourth, major disasters have multiple international dimensions. We are a global village. This calls for more systematic international cooperative agreements. In other words, we have to tell the people that we have had a problem. We have to say, ‘This is what we’re going to do about it, this is what we are doing about it, and this is what you will see within a fixed time.’ In other words, we need to be proactive by being honest with what we are doing.

In relation to the authority itself, it becomes interesting. There have been multiple reviews. The best one that most people may have seen at some stage is the one by Tony Powell, the ex-chair of the Darwin Reconstruction Commission. He is a town-planner and accountant. He said that the authority staff must live and work in the prescribed areas so they can maintain constant contact with people and issues and have a view of a high sense of urgency about fixing problems. Time is the enemy. The authority must understand the individual’s anxiety about priorities for fiscal investment. Other government priorities must not stop fair rebuilding and recovery. We need to set up mechanisms internally within all government departments at all levels to stop the politicisation of public administration, because people tend to block when they find things are difficult or uncomfortable.

Curiously, at a time when we have proposed a Commonwealth Games application, the challenge for the Premier is to set the Reconstruction Authority the Olympic Games challenge to plan, develop and reconstruct buildings and infrastructure in the prescribed disaster areas using both private and public sector resources to achieve the best possible result. The bill itself is merely the tool by which all of this would happen. I cannot see any major problems with it. It has been carefully dissected by multiple people, including the shadow minister and previous speakers. I do not wish to challenge any of those details that they have discussed. For a lot of good to happen, barriers to the reconstruction and recovery need to be removed. The bill attempts to do this. Altering the valuation to a later June date will bring fairness to those whose valuations are pre-flood or are cyclone stressed rather than the March closing date which is often used by the councils.

The task ahead for the Reconstruction Authority is a sobering one. It will be a long, painful, expensive and great challenge, despite it being only two years. It will require great tolerance, sympathy and perseverance on the part of many players. Rebuilding one million square kilometres of affected state is a big call. We must seek to rebuild the foundations of sustainable communities that reflect that we live in a hostile world where we cannot control many of those things we wish we could. The authority must address the serious issues of goemorphology, hydrology, civic planning and design. These are all points that we are debating all the time at the moment in relation to the problems that are occurring. It must not fall into the pattern of one-size-fits-all as a mindset. John F Kennedy was quite right when he reminded us all that we must use time as a tool and not a couch.

Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind)
(8.21 pm): I rise to participate in the debate on the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. As other members have indicated, the authority’s job will be to manage and coordinate the state government’s program for infrastructure reconstruction and recovery in disaster affected communities throughout Queensland. The authority will have significant new powers to undertake what are currently local government planning responsibilities. The authority is currently set a limited time span of two years.

I note that the authority will also be able to act on the direction of the relevant minister. There has been a bit of debate during this sitting as to whether the appropriate minister should be the Premier or a stand-alone minister. My view is that there is no better person to be responsible than the Premier of the state. I know that there is criticism and that the view has been put that the Premier will be too busy to be able to apply the resources and the time that is necessary. The reality is that the Premier has many more resources at her disposal than ministers of the government. I put on the record that I believe it is appropriate that the Premier of the day should be the relevant minister. In the past when problems have occurred in state government we have seen situations where the Premier has taken charge and taken responsibility away from the relevant minister.

This leads me to the next issue which is very important. I believe that we need to ensure that there will be total stability in Queensland for as long as is possible during the life of this stand-alone authority. Prior to the resumption of this sitting of parliament the Premier was on the record saying that 2011 will be the year of the rebuilding of Queensland and that there will be no state election until next year. Yesterday I understand that it was reported in one of our media outlets that approaches had been made to the Queensland Electoral Commission about a possible election date in April. Tonight on the 5 o’clock, 6 o’clock and 7 o’clock news there was banter that the resignation of some of our ministers may be the trigger the Premier may use to call an early election. I believe that we need the Premier in her reply to this bill to state very clearly whether there is going to be an election during this year. Queenslanders need stability and certainty. I believe that if the Premier cannot give a commitment that there will be no election this year she should go to the people and have the election tomorrow so that we can get over this hurdle and we can make sure that for as long as possible for the duration of this Reconstruction Authority it will know who the appropriate minister is that it is answerable to so that it knows where it is going with the proposed tasks that this government and this parliament will hand to it.

We have heard from the government, the opposition and the Independents overwhelming support for the intent of this Reconstruction Authority to take charge, to take control, and try to lead the reconstruction and recovery of our disaster affected communities throughout Queensland. The bill provides the opportunity for future communities that we are not aware of at the moment to come under the umbrella and the ambit of the power of this proposed Reconstruction Authority. That leads me to the issue of other authorities that have similar powers to the proposed Reconstruction Authority. In particular I refer to the Urban Land Development Authority.

One of the core responsibilities of the Urban Land Development Authority is to provide affordable housing to Queenslanders. I and other members in this House have stated that we understand that one of the core responsibilities of this Queensland Reconstruction Authority is also to provide affordable housing to Queenslanders. Yet when I read the bill I see how this bill provides the authority with the capacity to override local councils, to take matters out of councils’ hands, either because the board thinks it appropriate or the Premier of the day has directed it to do so. There are similar powers under the Urban Land Development Authority. I will quote from an Urban Land Development Authority publication--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: How does the ULDA development assessment process differ from the Sunshine Coast Regional Council?
Development applications over land outside a UDA are made to and assessed by the local government authority under the Sustainable Planning Act 2009 (SPA) and the planning scheme.

Development applications over land within a UDA are instead made to and assessed by the ULDA under the Urban Land Development Authority Act 2007 and the land use plan for a UDA. Under this Act, the assessment process has been streamlined to enable a development application to be assessed and decided within 40 business days after lodgement. This shortened timeframe does not include circumstances where there is a need for additional information or public notice of the application.
XML.Hansard-Body: I will quote from another section on the topic of the similarity between these two authorities--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: What will happen when a development application is lodged with the ULDA?

When lodging a development application within a UDA, the application will be assessed against the Urban Land Development Authority Act 2007 and the Interim Land Use Plan, until such time as a Development Scheme becomes effective for the area.
XML.Hansard-Body: There are places throughout the length and breadth of our great state where the Urban Land Development Authority is responsible and is effectively doing what our local councils were previously doing--developing affordable land. When I look to section 149 of the bill, which sets out how the chairperson of this proposed authority has significant powers to give a notice to a council in relation to development applications before that council, I see no reason why this authority should not have similar powers to give similar directions in relation to land that is the responsibility of the Urban Land Development Authority. Why should we have a difference where this proposed authority has the capacity to override local councils in Queensland but it does not have the capacity to interfere at all or have anything to do with land which may be in that same area but is, because of our legislation, under the responsibility of the Urban Land Development Authority and that Urban Land Development Authority is doing the very thing that the council could have done?
I table for the benefit of members an amendment that I intend to move when we proceed to the committee stage. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Clause 149, page 83, after line 18, insert:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: ’(6A) The Chairperson may give a notice to the Urban Development Authority if the Chairperson forms the opinion that the Urban Development Authority needs to suspend work on a site or sites of land for which the Authority has responsibility.
(6B) If a notice is given to the Urban Development Authority under subsection (6A), the notice is of the same effect as a notice applicable to a local government under this section.’
XML.Hansard-Body: I believe we need to seek consistency in Queensland. In one breath the government says, ‘This authority is independent,’ yet we see that authority has the capacity to be clearly directed by the relevant minister, and that happens to be the Premier. When we refer to the Urban Land Development Authority, again there is a very clear link between the Urban Land Development Authority and the relevant minister of the day.
I table for the benefit of members the amendment I propose to move and debate during committee stage.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill, amendments to be moved in consideration in detail.
XML.Hansard-Body: There should be no difference in Queensland--no difference at all. We need to see consistency. On one hand we have the Premier as the relevant minister who has the capacity to give directions and have direct discussions with this authority and on the other hand we have the minister--another minister, not the Premier--who also is in a different position responsible for land of which the Urban Land Development Authority has control.

We know where the disasters have occurred. This bill provides the capacity during the next two years for this authority to take responsibility for future areas if a disaster should occur. If a disaster occurs in the next few months, later this year or in the future the authority will have the capacity by regulation or by gazette notice to take responsibility for the planning and the reconstruction of those respective communities. I note that late last year when the Premier and I spoke about the very contentious issue of the Caloundra South development area--Mr Deputy Speaker, can I have some quiet? I can hardly hear myself.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): You have got the call.
Mr WELLINGTON: Thank you. Last year in October when speaking on the issue of the Caloundra South Urban Development Land Authority the Premier told the House on page 3487 of the Hansard --
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Overall, the government wants to see more than a third of the total site delegated as non-urban open space primarily for environmental protection and enhancement. The ULDA will be tasked with making rapid progress on this site. I want to see early construction works in the first quarter of next year--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: that is now, the first quarter of 2011--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: and planning for the entire site completed within 12 months.
XML.Hansard-Body: When the Premier responds can she please clarify this for me? Should we have a disaster on the Sunshine Coast--and I pray and hope that we do not--of such a magnitude that it falls under the umbrella of the proposed Queensland Reconstruction Authority, in light of the possible impacts on the Sunshine Coast Regional Council and on land for which our government has passed responsibility to the Urban Land Development Authority, what involvement does she propose the Queensland Reconstruction Authority will have in relation to the Queensland Urban Land Development Authority, especially in the proposed Caloundra South area? I passionately disagree with the government on this issue and on its position on Caloundra South. I disagree with the justification the government has put forward to this parliament and to Queensland as to why this matter had to be taken out of our Sunshine Coast council’s hands.

Hansard-Body.A: (Condamine--LNP) (8.34 pm): I rise to make a contribution to the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. The LNP supports this bill with some reservations relating to the amount of bureaucracy involved and the priorities of the bill. The bill establishes the Reconstruction Authority through the proposed Queensland Reconstruction Authority Act 2011. The bill amends the Building Act 1975, the Disaster Management Act 2003, Integrity Act 2009, the Land Valuation Act 2010, the Public Service Act 2008 and the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act 1971. The bill’s purpose is to establish a single entity to oversee the reconstruction of flood affected zones and to implement flood mitigation recommendations, infrastructure reconstruction and social, economic and environmental recovery in all affected communities. I hope it does relate to all affected communities. We notice that category D has already been applied to a number of communities and a lot of communities have missed out on it. Queenslanders need this bill to assist in the rebuilding and re-establishment of our communities, the restoration and reconstruction of our infrastructure, and rejuvenation of our industries and economies.

XML.Hansard-Body: Many Queenslanders have suffered horrific personal and financial losses during these disasters. The LNP will be supporting the bill to ensure the recovery occurs in a practical, appropriate and timely manner. Many communities within my Condamine electorate have been affected by flooding, some directly and others indirectly. Houses and businesses were inundated at Dalby, Oakey and many other small downs. Primary producers along the river and flood plains lost crop and stock, farm infrastructure, roads, fencing and topsoil. These communities will welcome the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011, but they want to see outcomes that will vastly improve the preparedness for future disasters.

I join with the people of Condamine in wanting to see effective and timely implementation of flood mitigation measures and assurance that the recommendations from the commission of inquiry will be implemented as soon as possible. We cannot afford to see the bill overtaken by wasteful bureaucracy. The Reconstruction Authority will be able to cut through the red tape and allow for quick, responsive action to occur.

It should be a priority to get primary production up and running as soon as possible. This will provide an immediate economic injection into the communities that they support. Our country towns thrive from primary production. Agriculture is the production base of Queensland. It saved this state and country from falling into recession on more than one occasion. It was agriculture that saved Australia from going into recession. The importance of agriculture to our state’s recovery can never be overstated.
