This is the time to support one of our three major industries--agriculture. The dividends will be reaped many, many times over. The job to rebuild Queensland is absolutely immense. It will take a huge amount of money and a great deal of time. However, I am confident that the resilience of Queenslanders will be evident as the recovery takes place.

It is important to have as many early warning systems in place for when unexpected events occur. Within my electorate and neighbouring rural electorates there is a great need for more automatic river height gauges while still maintaining the manually read gauges. The lack of these gauges became evident at the height of the flood in the Condamine River, its tributaries and other waterways. We need gauges between Oakey and Cecil Plains. We need gauges down the Condamine River. We need gauges from Cooby Dam to Oakey. The town of Oakey was flooded. The people did not even know it was coming. There were people on roofs in Oakey who were absolutely terrified. All they could do was wait until the water went down. If we had these gauges local authorities could have warned these people. We could put in place this type of mechanism. We could use text messages on phones to warn people. The warning system would be much improved. I hope this facility is seriously looked at with the establishment of this authority. The massive volume of water coming down and the reported failure of one of the automatic gauges meant that there was less time to prepare downstream. These farmers and communities were waiting to hear of the measurements upstream so they would know whether they would need to move their stock or whether they had to get out of their house, and those warnings failed.

The gauges provide excellent data to townships and communities downstream but only if they are working. Automatic rainfall gauges that trigger advice to emergency service departments and local government would enable advance warnings of potential flash floodings when isolated rainfall events have occurred. No-one knew that the massive rainfall in Toowoomba, only a couple of kilometres away, had happened. These gauges should be included in flood mitigation plans as important early warning devices that provide vital information to communities.The Reconstruction Authority will need to make certain that the recovery and reconstruction process will be effective and will provide effective outcomes. We hope this is not just a farce coming up to an election.

Local government will be the key to the recovery of affected communities. Working in cooperation with local authorities is essential. Problems have come from and are associated with the amalgamation of the shires. This was highlighted as an issue during the floods. Some areas were left out of the initial disaster declarations due to local council personnel not being aware of local flooding events. Now the councils are so big but with less representation that there were no local leaders in small communities. We are trying to get category D disaster assistance for farmers in the Condamine region but because they are in the Toowoomba shire they will have to declare the whole shire. We could have used the old shire boundaries like Millmerran shire or Wambo shire or we could hire some statesmen from within those areas who know the areas and who know the farms that are affected to the extent that would need category D disaster declarations. Some of those farmers are going to go to the wall unless they get the same declaration that the people up north affected by the cyclone have just been granted.

The lack of communication was very distressing for the individuals concerned. They sat and waited and did not know. They were completely devastated by the flooding and struggled to be heard. This is an issue that really needs addressing. Road and rail infrastructure has been badly affected in the Condamine electorate. Roads still remain closed and much of the rail line has not started to be repaired. This has pushed all the freight, coal, stock and grain travelling east to the already overloaded Warrego Highway and down the Toowoomba range. Upgrading of these roads and rail is absolutely essential, not repairing but upgrading and renewing. The lack of maintenance, repair and renewal of these transport assets is long overdue and is an example of the lack of foresight and planning that the long-term Labor government has inflicted upon the people of Queensland. So many times I have gone to Main Roads to try to get a road fixed. It might be the Cecil Plains-Toowoomba road and the answer is, ‘We have no money.’ That has been the story for a number of years. Thus the predicament we are in now. The infrastructure was weak. The roads were ruined before the flood started. Smaller communities need to be supported with infrastructure and services to ensure that they remain viable.

Queenslanders would like assurance that this Reconstruction Authority will properly prepare us for any future disaster, that the mistakes made in the past will be rectified. The lessons learnt from these devastating events are a reminder to us all that effective planning is vital for effective recovery. My hope is that the Reconstruction Authority will bring effective, long-term recovery to Queensland. My hope is that the purpose of this bill will bring efficient, responsive recovery that enables Queensland to bounce back rapidly, sustainably, economically and spiritually. So many bills that have come before this House have been a farce. We have lived on promises under a Labor government for the last 10 years that I am aware of since I was elected. Let us hope that the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill is not just another promise.

Mr GIBSON (Gympie--LNP) (8.44 pm): I rise tonight to also speak on the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill. In doing so, I note the objectives of the bill: the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011 will establish the Queensland Reconstruction Authority to coordinate the reconstruction and recovery following the floods of December 2010 and January 2011 and Tropical Cyclone Yasi of February 2011. I also note that the bill amends the following legislation for particular purposes: the Building Act 1975, the Disaster Management Act 2003, the Integrity Act 2009, the Land Valuation Act 2010 and the Public Service Act 2008.

Whilst the opposition supports the setting up of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority as the best method of organising and rebuilding the areas of the state of Queensland that experienced significant and widespread flooding over this summer period and the areas that have been impacted by the tropical cyclone in February this year, I must stress though that I am concerned that the government wants to push this legislation through quickly without allowing it to be considered in great depth. There is always a concern in my mind whenever this government introduces legislation and then wishes to push it through quickly.

I have some concerns in particular with regard to the areas of the bill that cover this authority’s power to take land. Section 99 of the bill discusses the authority’s power to take land. I am concerned by subsection (6), which says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: To remove any doubt, it is declared that the taking of land under this section is not a taking of land under the ALA--
even though the process for taking the land and paying compensation for the land is the process stated in that Act.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Acquisition of Land Act is a piece of legislation that has served the state of Queensland well. Within that piece of legislation there are protections. There are checks and balances. That subsection is the equivalent of saying, ‘Trust us. We are a Labor government.’ Well, if there are words that strike fear into the heart of any sane Queenslander, it is when a Labor government says, ‘Trust us.’ That is more so for my residents in Gympie than perhaps in other parts of state, because we have gone through this, particularly with the acquiring of land when it came to the Traveston Crossing Dam. As I read this section of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill, what concerns me is what it does not say as opposed to what it does say. I wish to place on the record my concerns with regard to disputes that may arise over the valuation of land that will be acquired under this section.

The Acquisition of Land Act provides, if there is a dispute, that it can be taken to the Land Court to be resolved. My community did not have that privilege. When the government went through the purchase of land for the Traveston Crossing Dam, what we found was that landholders were bullied and cajoled by this government into selling their land to them.
Mrs Sullivan interjected.

Mr GIBSON: I take the interjection from the member, because the land was good. To state that the land of the Mary Valley was no good highlights the ignorance of Labor members opposite, because this land is productive farmland. That is the equivalent of saying that the flood land is no good. That is the equivalent of saying that the land up north is no good.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): Order!
There is too much audible conversation and too much interjection. The member for Gympie has the call.

Mr GIBSON: What we heard from that interjection is that they look at Queensland and they say it is no good. They believe that this government should be able to come in at any time and, without having the protections that we have provided within the Acquisition of Land Act, be able to negotiate, supposedly, a price. What happens when those negotiations are skewed? Because the power imbalance is immediately there. The power imbalance exists, because what we find is that we have the state government, through this authority, tapping on someone’s shoulders and saying, ‘Look, sunshine, we have the authority to take your land, and we will.’ And what we have there is an immediate power imbalance.

I note the concerns that have been raised by the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee with regard to this issue. I want to touch on the principle of natural justice. The principle of natural justice is one that is critical to legislation that we bring in and ensures that the residents of this state are protected. The committee states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The principles of natural justice require that a person whose interests might be affected by a decision be given a fair hearing and an opportunity to present his or her case, that a decision be made by an unbiased and disinterested decision-maker and be based on logically probative evidence. At common law, a person denied ‘procedural fairness’ may seek review of an administrative decision affecting his or her interests.
XML.Hansard-Body: Yet within this legislation there is no opportunity for a review. There is no opportunity to take it to the Supreme Court. We find in this legislation a sunset clause for two years. Let me place on the record that two years of a Labor government having unfettered control is two years too long. We must ensure that within the legislation we have the protections so that people can enter into negotiations in good faith and that they can have confidence that they are empowered to move forward.
Mr Moorhead interjected.

Mr GIBSON: I take the interjection from the member because it comes back to the point that I indicated at the very beginning. The manner in which this has been rushed through this parliament does not provide the opposition with the opportunity to draft amendments in a timely fashion. Had we had the normal procedure of this bill sitting on the table for two weeks there would have been the opportunity, I am sure, for many amendments to be drafted.

Clearly, it was not of such great concern to the government that it would recall parliament to bring forward this bill. It was happy to wait until parliament came back. But we then find that there is urgency to move forward without allowing us time.

Can I suggest that we must ensure that community members who must deal with this authority are empowered in such a way that they can have confidence in the decisions of the authority. Let me state right now very clearly that I have full confidence in the chair, Major General Slater. I am sure that he will do his job and discharge it with the greatest of professionalism. I cannot say I have confidence in the CEO, Graeme Newton, because we dealt with Graeme Newton as the CEO of Queensland Water Infrastructure. The experience of the community in the Mary Valley was such that he was not a man of integrity. I place on the record here and now that I do not have confidence in the CEO. However, we do have confidence in the chair. If any man can ensure that the Reconstruction Authority works properly it will be Major General Slater. However, that does not give any government the right to strip away the rights of its citizens.

In preparing for this speech I looked at the reconstruction authority that was established after Cyclone Tracy. Clearly with regard to Cyclone Tracy we saw a disaster of a magnitude that was unheralded. Approximately 41,000 of Darwin’s 47,000 inhabitants were made homeless. Approximately 33,000 were evacuated following the passing of the cyclone. Some 71 people passed away. Approximately 70 per cent of the city’s homes were either completely destroyed or suffered severe damage. Public services such as communications, power, water and sewerage were also damaged.

In looking at how the federal government of that day, in 1975, set up an organisation for the reconstruction of Darwin, the Darwin Reconstruction Commission, I note that within the legislation for that commission it provided for the establishment of a citizens council. The legislation provided for the establishment of the Darwin Citizens Council which comprised a maximum of 20 members, appointed by the minister after the commission called for nominations from those interested in council membership. The chairperson and deputy chairperson of the council were both elected by the council members.

The function of the council was to give advice to the commission concerning the exercise of the commission’s reconstruction powers. That is a very strong check and balance. That is a citizens council that can directly approach the reconstruction authority and ensure that advice can be provided as to how they are exercising their powers. That type of mechanism should be considered for the Queensland Reconstruction Authority.

We need to ensure that the voices of individuals are heard and that their concerns are able to be taken to the very top. Whilst I am sure that those of us who are members from areas that were flood affected or affected by the cyclone will do an outstanding job, it is nevertheless important that the community has the opportunity to exercise its voice and to be heard. I would encourage the government to consider the inclusion of a citizens council type model for the Queensland Reconstruction Authority.

I would now like to briefly move to a couple of other points. First and foremost, we have heard much from both sides of the House with regard to how this Queensland Reconstruction Authority will cut through red tape. Let us make it very clear: the fact that we need to have this Queensland Reconstruction Authority is an admission that red tape has got out of hand. It is an admission that our local governments, with the normal structures that are in place now, are unable to effectively and efficiently operate because their hands are tied by red tape. We must ensure not only that this red tape is stripped away in the dealings with the Queensland Reconstruction Authority but also that it is removed permanently so local governments can get on with the job day to day of enabling their areas to grow without having this red tape bound across them.

I will now briefly touch on my area of Gympie and the importance of the reconstruction efforts. As I indicated in the condolence motion, the community of Gympie is one that has great experience with flood events. As such, it has been able to ensure that over time it has developed the experience and the framework for dealing with floods.

No absolute flood protection measures can be applied. Any plan or any objective is simply to reduce the flood effects. That clearly happens in Gympie. The reduction in flood damage is as a result of a well-organised and well-aimed response and the actions of the local disaster management group. What we see from their efforts are objectives being achieved that can be summarised in three areas. There is the reduction in the risk of damage from floods, there is a reduction in the impact to businesses and homes from floods and, most importantly, there is an increase in flood awareness on the part of the community.

This flood awareness is as a result of experience but it is also as a result of the community being able to follow the information that is put out. One of the concerns that we have is with regard to automatic river gauges. On the Mary River we watch the river heights at various gauges and we can indicate very clearly the time frame that we have before the floodwaters will hit the township of Gympie. However, we only had two automatic river gauges along the Mary River that were operating and were of benefit during this flood--one at Moy Pocket, which is basically at the base of the Conondale Range at the commencement of the Mary River Valley, and one at Dagun.

We clearly need to have more automatic river gauges so we can also take into account the inflow from streams within the area. The information provided by an additional automatic river gauge would enable the community to have a more accurate estimate of when the river was to peak. That could result in conserving effort. We were expecting a flood peak of 20 metres. As a result some businesses evacuated their premises and their stock and, at the end of day, they did not need to. It was prudent that they took that measure but if we had more accurate information we could have ensured that those businesses that were clearly going to be affected could have been helped and those of lesser risk could have been evacuated based on information that came through at a different time.

The other issue with the Gympie electorate is the condition of roads and bridges. As we heard from the main roads minister, the impact from the flood and cyclone events upon roads of this great state has been major. For Gympie, the impact upon our bridges was such that in many cases communities were isolated. Some of the bridges in those areas are over 100 years old, they are timber structures and they are clearly no longer suitable to withstand major flood events. We need to ensure that those bridges are replaced and that those bridges are upgraded to a level such that, whilst they may be flooded, after a flood event they are able to be operated and used quickly.

I note that in her second reading speech the Premier made it very clear that the Reconstruction Authority would be covering all of Queensland. As I indicated in the condolence motion debate, the people of Gympie accept that there are places in this great state that have been devastated far more than we ever were or would like to be, and as a result they deserve to have the priority in those reconstruction efforts. But I will be holding the Premier to her word that the smaller areas and the smaller communities, like Imbil, Widgee and Woolooga--whilst not all of them are in my electorate, they certainly fall towards Gympie as their commerce area--are also included in the reconstruction effort, that those communities, along with the community of Gympie and others, receive their fair share in the reconstruction so that we can have confidence in moving forward, that we are able to rebuild at a time that will enable us to face disasters again, as we unfortunately know this great state will. In particular, we know that Gympie will indeed face floods again, as it has done 19 times in the past with major flooding events. That being said, I commend the bill to the House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Gladstone--Ind) (9.01 pm): I rise to speak to the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011. Many speakers have already stated that this debate is a natural follow-on from the condolence motion yesterday in that a lot that was said yesterday is reiterated in part today and reinforced, and that is appropriate. This bill follows on from the disasters and the trauma that occurred in the last few weeks.

XML.Hansard-Body: I want to thank the Premier for the briefing that was made available to the Independent members Monday. Quite a number could not make it because of the timing of it, but I appreciate the staff who were made available for that briefing. During that time a number of matters were canvassed. The proposed CEO, Mr Graeme Newton, was in attendance, albeit late. The Major General was not able to attend, but the two staff members who were there were very competent in being able to address the matters that were raised.

I note from the briefing we received that the establishment of this authority is not intended--although the bill could be read this way--to overrule local government. In the briefing there was discussion about the interaction between the authority and local government. It was reiterated on a number of occasions that the intention is for the authority to work with local government, not in competition with or in opposition to it. It is my hope that that occurs--that is, with all of the local authorities throughout the state that have been affected by floods, there will be a cooperative agreement and a cooperative relationship between the authority and the relevant local authorities.

One of the frustrations that I have had expressed to me in relation to flood damage is the directive that local government day labour staff are not able to do flood rehabilitation work, other than the absolute critical work that was done at the time of the flooding, because of risks, I am assuming, that the day labour crews may do more than flood rehabilitation and therefore the state and federal governments will be asked to fund works that should be maintenance works funded by local authorities. The argument that it would be easy for local authorities to misrepresent the work that they are doing is dated. There is a lot of electronic equipment now that can photograph and detail the works that are being done by local government day labour gangs and it would be very easy to be able to differentiate between flood damage and ordinary maintenance work.

The larger councils that have a high level of maintenance work on an ongoing basis--and perhaps the Brisbane City Council is one of those--may have enough work to be able to maintain their day staff alongside those undertaking the rehabilitation work that has to be done as a result of the floods. However, for a lot of other councils the priority will be to carry out the flood work, and the day labour could be the most cost-effective and appropriate staff to use for that. Additionally, setting up the contracting process to get the work done on a contract basis is going to cause even greater delays--there may not be contractors who want to go that far out west--so I would ask that that process and that mandate be reviewed.

Another issue raised with me in relation to reactions to the flooding--this was particularly raised with me by residents in the Brisbane region, but I think the principle applies to residents right across the state--is that many people lived in Brisbane in 1974, and I will use Brisbane as the example because that is where it is probably the most stark. There were reports in the media in January as the floodwaters were rising that it was going to be worse than the 1974 floods, that it was going to be less than the 1974 floods, that it was going to be the same as the 1974 floods. If you lived in the same premises, you would know what that meant--that is, there would be a mark on the wall or a biro line or a felt pen mark that said, ‘This is where the floods were in 1974.’ But there have been a lot of changes not only in people’s place of residence but also in people who have moved into the district, and town planning and development have changed the topography and the drainage in areas.

A flood of significance occurred in 2011 and people have said to me that, with the GPS data, with other modelling data that is available, with the capture of information and photographs, now is the time to have a database set up, either on people’s rates notices or as a general data storage, detailing the flood heights. If that happened, when the media said, ‘This will be a 14-metre flood,’ somebody at Jindalee could say, ‘That’s where a 14-metre flood reaches,’ and somebody at Yeerongpilly would know that that is where a 14-metre flood reaches. Therefore, if it is a 12-metre flood they can measure down from that; if it is projected higher, they will know.

Now is the time when that information and data has to be captured and stored and has to be disseminated, because it is fresh in everybody’s mind. The people who have commented to me have said that that would give flesh to the warnings that came over the radio and TV, albeit those warnings had a lot of detail. People would be able to know what 14 metres was--whether it would reach their house, whether it would inundate or whether it would just go to the first storey if they are in a high-block house. I support that call. It is not only an important call; it is also very realistic for people who live in this region and in other regions to have that sort of information--information that is precise, practical and means something to the house owner.

At the briefing there was a question asked about the cost of operating the board that will oversee the Queensland Reconstruction Authority. We were told that the cost of the board would be meeting fees only plus costs incurred, and I welcome that. I believe that the community, whilst it is 100 per cent supportive of rebuilding our state, wants to see the money that is available for reconstruction as much as possible go to reconstruction. Having said that, I am not saying that people are not worthy of proper remuneration. However, I believe that the community, as it does with the Premier’s flood appeal, wants to see that money go to where it is needed the most.

As other speakers have said, the authority will have significant power. It will be calling up in instances the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act and the operation of that act is something that people in my electorate are very much aware of. It has significant power. It has powers of entry, which a lot of acts carry, and it has powers for compulsory acquisition. The ability for members of the public--owners of property--to be able to cope with the process of compulsory acquisition is in direct relationship with a number of factors: their understanding of the powers within the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act, the ability of the employees of the government to administer that act and the attitude, competence and compassion of those people who administer the act.

The member for Gympie in his contribution made some very negative comments about the CEO of this proposed authority. I cannot comment, because I am not in Gympie and I certainly had no experience with the Mary River compulsory acquisitions. But I have experience with the operation of this act up in the Targinni area. There were people there who were treated appallingly. Because there was a five-year period or there abouts where there could be negotiated sales as opposed to compulsory acquisitions, there were older people who were told, ‘This is how much we are going to give you.’ If that person indicated concern, they were told, ‘Take it or leave it. If you don’t take it, we will just come and take you when we want you.’

I do not believe that is the intent of the Premier. I do not believe that it is the intent of the director-general of the department. But the implementation of that act is directly related to the people who are given the powers on the ground to go to speak to the people affected and it is critical that those people are the right people. There should be a fair deal for the taxpayer--100 per cent--but there should also be a fair deal for the occupier or the owner of that property because, in all instances of compulsory acquisition as opposed to negotiated acquisitions, and in some instances for negotiated acquisitions, those people are being moved on against their desires. They want to stay. So the treatment of those people is critically important. In this instance, we are talking about people who have faced tragedy and trauma. Unless they are treated appropriately in the way in which the act is implemented and the manner in which they are dealt with, those people will be traumatised again and they do not deserve that.

Other members have talked about cutting through red tape. Again, I do not have a problem with that. There will be times when due process will take time. The end of that due process would be the same as what will be achieved without the process because of the extenuating circumstances. However, again, people’s rights and liberties must be respected and they must be afforded as much as possible an opportunity to present any concerns that they have.

During the condolence motion I mentioned the infrastructure in the Gladstone region. We were very blessed. We only had localised flooding. Infrastructure was affected. Roads were damaged and they will be repaired, I have no doubt. We certainly did not face the wholesale destruction that places such as the Hinchinbrook, Yeerongpilly and Bundamba electorates suffered. We have a breadth of socioeconomic residents and particularly there are areas in this state of Queensland where the majority of residents do it tough and they need help. They are often not insured and their opportunities to bring their homes back to a habitable state are limited. We need to be compassionate with them.

My constituency have asked me to bring to this chamber the fact that stress, not from floods but stress from industrial development, is bringing pressure on our infrastructure--things like our airport and our hospital. We were pleased to welcome the Premier and the Prime Minister to Gladstone. They landed at Gladstone Airport and then were helicoptered out to inspect affected places such as Theodore and Rockhampton and we welcomed them. But the message that my constituency asked me to convey is that our stresses in the next year will not be flood related; they will be related to industrial development. I have not heard one person in my electorate not wish success and rehabilitation for anyone who has been flood affected. However, there are people in my electorate now who are facing eviction from their houses and flats because they cannot afford the increased rentals and they will be in similar positions as the flood victims unless infrastructure investment in relation to the LNG development occurs through this government.

Those are the main points that I wish to raise in this debate. I place again on the record, as I did in the condolence motion, the thoughts and prayers of the people in my electorate for those throughout Queensland who have been so tragically affected. Our hope is that the Queensland Reconstruction Authority will be able to bring this state back into an operating, welcoming, homely and rehabilitated condition as fast as possible. We wish for all of those who have suffered physically, psychologically, financially, emotionally--in whatever way--a speedy recovery.

Mr DEMPSEY (Bundaberg--LNP) (9.15 pm): Across this vast state of Queensland we have all witnessed the blanket of destruction that engulfed the streets, neighbourhoods, towns and cities that we all call home. However, throughout this destruction we also witnessed the best in people and showcased to the world the true fibre of mateship that links together all Queenslanders. This mateship extended beyond the boundaries of race, religion, age or creed and brought people of all different footprints to stand together as one. The people of Queensland have spoken through their actions and now it is time for this parliament to allow words to be put into action and to allow Major General Mick Slater and the Reconstruction Authority to get on with the job and cut through the red tape and bureaucracy that is strangling Queensland and the community of Bundaberg. This cutting of red tape, coupled with an open and transparent administration, will assist the hundreds of homes and approximately 120 businesses that were inundated with floodwaters and the 2,000 people who were assisted in our recovery centre in Bundaberg. There is also the indirect effect on businesses that did not go underwater through loss of trade and the reduction of the backpacker trade, which has severely affected the accommodation houses, hospitality and agricultural businesses throughout my region.

Destruction has occurred to key community infrastructure, including roads, bridges, drainage, sewerage, water treatment facilities, jetties, pontoons, pavements, parks, play equipment, play amenities, sporting facilities and the Bundaberg port, just to name a few. We have experienced a loss of stock, contracts, normal trade and tourism packages due to media negativity that was assisted by comments such as ‘floods of biblical proportions covering an area the size of France and Germany’.

The financial impact of the flood on the community of Bundaberg is also devastating to our local cane, timber, horticultural, fishing and tourism industries, which are all affected. In dollar terms, Bundaberg’s cane industry has lost approximately 2,000 hectares, worth approximately $30 million. Millions have been stripped from the region’s horticultural sector, consisting of tomatoes, capsicums, zucchinis, rockmelons, watermelons, pumpkins, sweet potatoes--all damage and destroyed. Several thousand hectares of productive farmland were inundated, resulting in soil erosion and a loss of topsoil, coupled with increased costings due to hand-picking and damage to cane train networks. These cane train networks need to be repaired in a timely manner or more heavy trucks will be pushed onto our already fragile road networks.

On another note, the Port of Bundaberg is very important for the export of sugar and molasses. With so much silt carried down the river, this vital infrastructure is still closed. That means that all the sugar--approximately 120,000 tonnes--in these enormous sugar sheds cannot be exported. This issue becomes another anxiety for farmers, who are tied up with forward payments. Four seafood processors were also badly damaged and people along the side of the river cannot get flood insurance.

The local marina was totally washed away, including the fuel facilities used by a large number of the trawlers that travel along the east coast of Australia. In particular, ASP Holdings lost its catwalk worth approximately $300,000. Its fuel facility went under water and that cannot be restored by a grant of $25,000 or even a loan of $250,000. The Bundaberg slipway on the north side of the Burnett River also sustained many hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of damage. The Midtown Marina, owned by Ray Foley, was totally obliterated and the fuel facility, which is one of the busiest on the east coast of Australia, was also washed downstream.

The fishing industry has been decimated, and most in the industry were already struggling prior to this devastation due to the state Labor government’s industry reforms. These facilities in Bundaberg are used by 41 trawlers and countless beam net, crabbing and line fishermen for mooring, refuelling and repairs. The destruction of these facilities and the direct threat to several hundred jobs will have a significant impact on the marine and fishing industries in Bundaberg. I am saying to this state government that what we have on offer is not enough for these industries, and I respectfully request that this government work with the federal government to extend category D funding to the Bundaberg region. The business community needs confidence so that when governments say they will do everything possible within their means to help we are not overridden by cynical comments.

For some of these agricultural industries, having skilled work is the most important component to their existence and we need financial incentives to keep workers in the region. The statistical data for our region and the information provided also have to be taken into account whilst comparing our current population and the high percentage of socio and economic issues and the unemployment both pre and post the Christmas floods.

In conclusion, we need significant infrastructure projects brought forward to increase the stability and confidence in our community. We need better monitoring and reporting of flood heights and we need a review of flood mitigation schemes and incentives. This bill represents the beginning of the official reconstruction. More than that, it represents a promise to the people of Bundaberg. They cannot afford to lose their trust in our parliament that we can rebuild our communities. We owe it to the communities and these people to ensure the rebuilding is undertaken with practicality, efficiency and compassion. Our communities deserve a response that will give them back the communities, facilities and infrastructure they lost; they also deserve a response that will provide them with optimism, hope and great expectations for the future.

Mr McARDLE (Caloundra--LNP) (9.22 pm): I rise to make a contribution to the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill before the House tonight. On behalf of the people of Caloundra, I pass on our condolences to all of those who have suffered the loss of loved ones, property and other matters and will suffer for some considerable time. I want to confine my comments to the terms of section 10(1)(h) of the bill before the House. Subsection (h) explains what the authority will do. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... if asked by the Minister, to give the Minister advice about putting into effect the recommendations of the commission of inquiry issued by the Governor in Council under the Commissions of Inquiry Order (No. 1) 2011 , particularly any recommendations about flood mitigation or land use planning.
XML.Hansard-Body: I will come back to that subsection in a moment. If we hark back to the last flood in Brisbane, the 1974 flood, we can see that between 1974 and 2011 there has been a significant population growth and a significant increase in dwelling numbers. In addition, we know that the dwellings have spread much further than they were in 1974 and we know that there are plans across the state to increase the number of dwellings into even newer areas.

The floods and cyclone of 2010-11 were one of the most devastating events that occurred across the state for well over 100 years. Of course, it cannot be considered that it was a one-in-100-year event because when we look back at La Nina over the past century we find that there have been 12 strong classic years of onset of La Nina--1910, 1916, 1917, 1938, 1950, 1955, 1956, 1971, 1973, 1975, 1988 and 1998--prior to 2010. The reason I have listed that series of years harks back to the subsection I quoted before and the power of the minister to obtain recommendations in relation to flood mitigation or land use planning.

One would anticipate that the commission of inquiry will have wide-ranging powers. One would also expect that the commission of inquiry will comment upon and make recommendations about future building proposals and the future use of land that may not be under construction at this time but may be being considered by various authorities for construction in the foreseeable future.

Again, I stress that the subsection I referred to allows the authority to give advice about flood mitigation or land use planning as a consequence of the commission’s recommendations or findings. Given that the commission is required to give an interim report by August this year, there are a number of factors that would be prudent. Before going into what those factors are, I note that the member for Nicklin touched on the ULDA and that is exactly the point I want to raise. I want to raise the ULDA in the context peculiar to Caloundra South and tie the ULDA into the terms of the subsection I quoted and the powers of the authority to give advice.

Let us leave aside the issue of Caloundra South’s other matters of infrastructure et cetera and let us just consider the size of Caloundra South. The total block is 3,000 hectares and the area for construction is 1,600 or 1,700 hectares. There is a plan to develop that block to accommodate some 22,000 homes and 50,000 residents over a period. We know that block is now subject to ULDA and we know that the ULDA has an obligation to issue a draft plan for consultation with the public by March or April this year. At that time, the people of Caloundra and the Sunshine Coast will make recommendations about what they think should or should not occur or amendments in relation to the proposed plan. However, we know that the commission of inquiry is required to produce an interim report by August of this year.

I mentioned that there are certain things that would be prudent. Bearing in mind 1974 and the devastation that occurred at that time and bearing in mind the devastation that has occurred this time and the loss of life, there is nothing to be lost by the ULDA deferring any further plan in relation to Caloundra South until such time as the interim report is available. Let us not wait for a disaster to happen. This commission will have a far-reaching impact in regard to planning for many years to come. Given this area would house a population of 55,000 and a dwelling capacity of 22,000 and given the short period of time between now and August this year, it would be extremely prudent for the ULDA to halt any further planning and take into account the recommendations of the commission of inquiry. That would be a logical step and a logical process to adopt.

With that report in front of it, the ULDA could then make informed decisions based upon an independent commission assessing and making recommendations as to what would be prudent for future development. What I do not want to see is some time down the track we are standing in this House saying that Caloundra South was a disaster waiting to happen. The opportunity now exists, and the chink is there for a short period of time, to make common-sense decisions that are thoroughly researched and investigated and proper recommendations are taken into account in relation to future development.

The LNP has made it quite clear that we support the development of Caloundra South, but we do not support the development at all costs. We support a development that is rational, that is thought through, that is modern and takes into account the needs not just of the population who reside there but the population across the coast. If the 2010-11 disasters have taught us anything it is that history will repeat itself. If we have forgotten the lessons of 1974 we now have an opportunity to regather that information by use of an independent body to assess where we went wrong but, more importantly, where we can do better in the future. I therefore request and suggest most strongly that planning by the ULDA be suspended until at least the interim report becomes available and a properly informed decision can be made in relation to the development of that site.

Mrs PRATT (Nanango--Ind)
(9.31 pm): I rise to speak to the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill. There has been a lot of talk tonight. I will not go over too many things that have been raised today, but I would like to touch on a few things. This bill is the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill and I think that that tells us exactly what it is all about. Its job is to rebuild, restore and progress this state--to restore not only our infrastructure but also people’s confidence in themselves and the future of Queensland. There are many questions that will be raised over the next few months in relation to the inquiry. That is where many of the questions that have been raised here tonight should be directed. I believe that housing those people who have lost their homes is the No. 1 priority. Nobody should be left without a roof over their head. That roof should not be a tent or a make-do shelter; it has to be a home, because as soon as people are back in their home their confidence builds.

We also have to ensure that our roads and infrastructure are back in place. We have to be honest and recognise that for quite a number of years now our roads have deteriorated. There have been patchwork quilts on a lot of our roads. Our bridges have been reduced from two lanes to one. We see a lot of that in the rural areas of Queensland. Most members would remember the old joke about the woman who died and on her gravestone was, ‘I told you I was sick’. I have been telling people for almost 13 years that the Blackbutt Range was in bad need of repair and that as soon as there was a heavy deluge it would come down. Maybe now they will believe me that that range needed a lot of attention a long time ago. I hope that the attention it gets now will be looking 50 years into the future and not just be a patch-up job to allow people to go through. I am not saying that we are not appreciative. I really do thank the minister for getting that range road open. It seemed a long time coming. For many country areas perhaps the flood may have been welcome in that we will get a lot of repairs done over time.

The boundary redistribution for the regional shires is flawed in this instance. Yarraman, which is part of the Toowoomba Regional Council, was well and truly cut off in several ways. The South Burnett Regional Council picked up a lot of the load with regard to Yarraman. They did not mind picking up that load but it really did show that Yarraman is definitely in the wrong regional council. That does need to be looked at very closely in the future.

There will be questions about the operation of Wivenhoe. There will be questions about insurance. I hope that there will be a lot of changes in that regard. SunWater has a chart--I saw one a few years ago and an article in one of the letters to the editor today reminded me of it--that records the previous 100 years that shows periods of drought followed by rain. Everyone on the land knows that. A common saying in the country when people say, ‘When will the drought end?’ is ‘When there’s a bloody good rain’. That tends to be what we say: it will not be finished until we get a flood. It is a standard conversation. We have to be aware that this is not just today’s history; it has been the history of the past. We have had floods left, right and centre through the two centuries we have been on this land. They will continue in the future as they would have happened long before.

This event must not be forgotten. A flood map needs to be drawn up. This was for many areas a high flood. It has to be recorded and people have to be discouraged from building in flood-prone areas. I know of an instance where people I know fought like crazy with the council to a build a house that could be, in extreme circumstances, subjected to flood and it was subjected to flood in this particular instance. One has to wonder when people who do that say they are going to now sue the council because they have had a flood through their house and they should not have been allowed to build there. It is quite disturbing when one hears stories such as that.

We should also not forget that many farmers have lost lots of land. The river has carved wide areas of land off people’s property. That has to be reassessed because I do not think it is appropriate that they be charged for X amount of land pre-flood and be charged the same after the flood when in fact they may have lost 20 or 30 acres to the waters. The shire councils will no doubt have put in a huge list of requirements. They have done it tough. They will do it very, very tough for a long time to come and they should not be expected to pick up the entire bill. The South Burnett Regional Council, on the second or third day after the floods receded, came back and said that it had probably lost $300 million worth of infrastructure. The very next day, and the next and the next, that kept going higher and higher and higher.

I endorse almost everything that people have said in this House. I will be supporting the member for Nicklin’s amendment and his concerns about the ULDA. With those few words I trust that we will do the right thing in the right order, that there will be very few delays and people’s lives will be back on track within a very short space of time.

Mr HORAN (Toowoomba South--LNP)
(9.38 pm): I join with my LNP colleagues not only in speaking to this bill but also, in a spirit of bipartisanship, in supporting this bill so that it is passed and we can start very quickly bringing about the various engineering and regulatory changes that are needed to be brought about by this bill. I will also provide some warnings. We have to be careful in introducing the Queensland Reconstruction Authority that we do not add another entire level of bureaucracy that gets in the way of all the decisions that are being made by councils which are going ahead with repair work and that it does not get in the way of the normal decision-making processes of departments. We have to ensure that this is kept as a lean and mean organisation that acts quickly to provide the opportunity for reconstruction to proceed at a fast rate and to adhere to the principles that it was set up for.

The key issues for the Reconstruction Authority under the bill are reconstruction, preparation so that we will be well prepared for any future disasters and flood mitigation. Its provisions enable it to expedite regulatory approvals and put in place priorities for community infrastructure and services. The task of the QRA will be massive. Never in our lifetime or in the history of Queensland have we seen something so extensive. Up to 80 per cent of the state has been hit by flooding, freak storms and deluges, inland tsunamis or one of the fiercest tropical cyclones that Queensland has ever seen.

In my speech earlier this week on the condolence motion I mentioned the human tragedy that has beset Toowoomba and also the Lockyer Valley. I continue to provide my condolences to all of those families who have suffered from other losses that occurred throughout the floods in Central Queensland and in Brisbane and also the cyclone in North Queensland as well as the people who have suffered damage to businesses, homes, farms and so on.

The inland tsunami in Toowoomba was catastrophic and shocking. It shocked everybody. Being on top of a mountain, we never thought we would see a wall of water like that. Prior to the event and also after it, we had weeks and weeks of rain that delivered the massive floods of the Condamine and surrounding areas. Our city was isolated for large periods. Well before Monday, 10 January, when we were hit by the inland tsunami, the range highway had been closed on a number of occasions. I was caught at the bottom of the range for a couple of hours on 5 January, when water poured down the range through Withcott. It rolled rocks and rubble all down the range and over the road. It poured about two feet deep across the four lanes of the highway at Withcott. As a result, the range was closed because of land slips after weeks and weeks of rain.

We started to get more land slips then. I have railed in this House for many years about the problems of the range and the desperate need for the Toowoomba bypass. Not only is it land slips that close the road; often it is accidents--truck rollovers in particular--that cause road closure. Because the large semitrailers drive in the left-hand lane, when they lose their brakes, which happens on occasions, often they cannot move across to the right-hand lane to get up into the safety ramps because there are cars with passengers on the inside of them. Then they bravely go up the back of another truck. So we face all of these problems.

This road is the artery of Australia. It allows trucks to take goods to and from South-East Queensland, the southern states of Australia, the north-west and the north of Australia. Three million to 3 million people live in South-East Queensland. Some 4,500 B-doubles a day travel through 16 sets of traffic lights, through the biggest inland city of Australia. It takes them about an hour to get from the bottom of the range, up the range and through the city. No other city in Australia would have to be subjected to such a social blight. Some $44 million was spent by the previous Howard government on the purchase of the corridor, on the drilling of the test holes for the tunnels and for the finalisation of the detailed plans. It is ready to go.

I implore the QRA to examine this matter closely. I know that Mick Slater, as chairman of the QRA, is a very strategic person. Not only is there this massive transport task for all of Australia; there is also the social blight on Toowoomba. Now we see the absolute disaster of land slips, crashes and all the other problems that isolated our city. During this disaster we were isolated from the east on the range highway and to the south as Cunningham’s Gap and the New England Highway to New South Wales were closed. Roads to the west and roads to the north were also closed. It reached the point where petrol, food, milk and bread--just about everything--was all running out. The west could not be supplied and people were desperate for supplies. It really was a disaster. In a nation like ours, a region like the south-west of Queensland, where about a quarter of a million people live--part of the most productive export earning area of the state--should not be left in a situation like this.

This has to be the No. 1 priority for Queensland. It has to be one of the major priorities of the QRA. It must take a lead role to ensure that both the federal government, in terms of providing the funding, and the state government, in making it a road priority, are not only alerted but pushed to do this because this cannot go on.

The whole problem has been exacerbated by the absolute destruction of the railway line down the range. The port of Brisbane was sold on the basis of moving about 10 million tonnes of coal a year. The bulk of that coal comes down the railway line or it comes down in B-double trucks through Toowoomba. This railway line is still out and it will be out for at least another seven or eight weeks, until a week or two into April. There is increasing production at mines like New Hope at Acland and Cameby Downs and other mines in the Surat Basin. There is the grain to be carried, which cannot be carried at the moment because of the destruction of the line. We are looking at hundreds, if not another thousand, of trucks that will be going through Toowoomba with all this extra freight.

In the immediate aftermath of this inland tsunami in our city there was absolute chaos. The two alternative roads, Murphys Creek Road and Blanchview Road, were cut off by substantial damage and the city was isolated. Once they opened the range, with just one lane up and one lane down, there was up to three hours wait. I was there one afternoon when I saw stretching from the top of the range back to the CBD four lanes of traffic--two lanes on the Warrego Highway right back to the CBD. About 70 per cent of those two lanes were B-doubles. Traffic on Herries Street and Margaret Street was stretched back to the CBD. It was absolute chaos. No city, especially a city of 100,000 people that serves another 150,000 in our immediate region, should have to put up with that. Strategically for the people of Toowoomba, for Australia and for Queensland, but particularly to cope with disasters like this and flooding that can occur in the west, it is so important that this matter is addressed.

The Toowoomba Regional Council has suffered massive damage. It is a council made up of eight previous councils stretching from Clifton and almost out to Inglewood, almost up to Dalby and up to Yarraman--
Mr Hoolihan interjected.

Mr
HORAN
: Seven previous councils plus the Toowoomba council. It has been a massive job. Most of the service centres spread all around this area were separated by floodwaters and basically had to do what they had to do. The Toowoomba council did a magnificent job in the city, in the areas that I was able to get to after our inland tsunami on Monday the 10th. It had the area cleaned up very quickly, which gave great heart to the shopkeepers in the area.

There is massive damage to infrastructure such as the sewage treatment plant at Oakey that has been destroyed, the roads and the bridges that have been damaged and the railway lines through the city that have been damaged. Strategically, it all has to be looked at. It may be that, as a strategic move, the railway line should be moved to skirt around the city on the western side. We would still have the old corridor there, which would be great for movements of some form of public transport in the future. That railway line caused such chaos where it crosses the creek. It acted like a dam wall. That could be taken out of our city and with it all the crossings over the railway line.

I think issues like that have to be looked at strategically. When you look at this storm--nine inches fell in about three-quarters of an hour after days and nights of non-stop rain--it is almost impossible to cope with such a mountain of water coming down the two creeks, East and West Creek. But we have to consider that, when the 1974 floods occurred, the catchment areas were all small crop farms, kikuyu farms and so forth, and now they are all suburbs with bitumen roads, tin roofs, landscaped lawns and so forth. So there can be the potential for a greater flow.

Millions of dollars of work has been done in flood retention, particularly on things like the waterbird habitat on East Creek, and on West Creek, in particular, a large number of retention basins were built during the time of the Howard government. Obviously we have to look at this problem that has occurred. We could still have more flash flooding. It is really important that this is looked at strategically so it can be fixed or moderated. Certainly, to have carried that water during that flood, you would have needed a concrete channel on both East and West Creek that was about 50 to 70 metres wide and probably 10 to 15 metres deep. That is the amount of water that had to be carried at that particular time.

The other issue, in terms of safety and prevention that I have discussed with the Toowoomba council, is the need for a system of gauging. People drive over the crossings that flood on both East and West Creek all the time. There are flood gauges with black and white lines, and I am sure a number of people do not know exactly what they mean. I think better designed permanent gauges that have red marks for danger and so forth should be considered. I also believe that we need robust gauging systems. It could be as simple as a bore pipe with a slot on the down side of the water flow so it does not get hit with debris and a ball that goes up and triggers a mechanism that turns on flashing lights with a sign under it that indicates dangerous water levels or flowing water. Also, when people get their driver’s licences they should be taught that you put your car into low gear and drive slowly, not to go fast which can spray the water up and stall the car, and also things like opening the car door to let the water in if the car starts to move to try to stabilise and hold the car. That is important, particularly for young people.

The Toowoomba Regional Council has a particular issue with day labour. The staff are employed on day labour doing particular roadworks and earthworks that are funded by certain funds. When those staff were diverted to do all the flood work that they had to do, it has cost the council because they cannot use those specific funds that were designated for day labour. It is so important that, under the NDRRA, councils like Toowoomba do receive proper funding and are not denied that funding because they operate on a day labour basis.

The QRA will have to look at not only the areas that have been flooded in cities like Toowoomba but also the surrounding areas and townships that have been flooded and cut off for days and days. They have to look at systems. I certainly think the inquiry needs to look at systems. I think decentralisation is a great thing in a crisis, because it is the councils on the ground--and I saw this in Toowoomba--that have the people, the mobility, the machinery, the equipment and the local knowledge to make decisions. We need the Defence Force to be able to make quick decisions. Toowoomba was desperately trying to get a little Bell helicopter from the Army aviation base to take medical supplies to Cecil Plains when it was marooned, but it could not get a decision. We should enable decision making like that. Some of the organisations that provide such wonderful volunteers, like the Red Cross, need to be able to make faster decisions. People were evacuated from Oakey and from the Lockyer Valley to the Toowoomba Grammar School. The Toowoomba Grammar School dealt with it all before some of the agencies who were wanting to go in and help got permission from their head office to go in and do that some two to 2 days later. We need decentralisation, trust, responsibility and preparation.

This has been an enormous learning experience. The Toowoomba council were fortunate that they had just formed their disaster management committee and that it was put in place just days before the crisis hit us on Monday, the 10th. All councils need to have some form of training process so they are ready for whatever it might be, and to do that perhaps at the beginning of the summer season. I do compliment the Toowoomba council for the way they devolved responsibility. They told their service centres in the other seven former shires, ‘Do whatever you have to do,’ and they just got on with the job. I would like to compliment the people of Toowoomba who just got stuck in. The people who were hit by the water in the middle of the town were cleaning up the next day, shoulder to shoulder with all the council workers and volunteers. The people whose houses and yards were inundated just got in and cleaned up. Everybody just felt so sorry and so much sympathy for our friends and neighbours down in the Lockyer Valley.

I think it will be an important education for people. Younger generations who had not been through floods before thought that, because the floods were going to go to 5.4 metres in Brisbane, that meant 5.4 metres where they lived up river. It needed to be explained to them that halfway up the river to Ipswich that rise might be 13 or 14 metres. We do need a proper warning system. Everyone is so concerned about what happened at Wivenhoe. There was an old guy from Somerset who rang the ABC in Toowoomba on Monday morning and he said, ‘We had 400 millimetres last night in Somerset. That’s 16 inches.’ His exact words were, ‘Brisbane better be warned.’ That was the time to open the gates and let out 200,000 or 300,000 megalitres so that the next Tuesday--midday Tuesday or late on Tuesday--they would not have had to let go 635,000 megalitres which then swamped Brisbane.

The water that hit above Grantham landed on about 330,000 hectares and funnelled down to Grantham. That water did not get to the Brisbane River until about midnight on Monday night. So there was all that time, from say five or six on Monday morning. We were in the midst of one of the worst rain events that had been going on for days and days and days, with the BOM showing a great long cloud of red and yellow and blue on the weather map. That was the time, at five or six in the morning, to start letting water out, because it was obvious what was going to happen. There was the inflow from that 16 inches that fell at Somerset and the water that was pouring in from other areas. Perseverance Dam on the Monday overflowed. That meant Cressbrook Dam went up by one metre an hour and it eventually overflowed into Wivenhoe as well. There have to be major improvements made to the way we manage our dams.

It has been said often that every good drought ends with a good flood. But we know now with modern technology that a good drought is El Nino, and once you move into a La Nina system you come into a time of more storms, more water and so forth. So obviously the system of management of dams--those dams like the Wivenhoe, whose purpose is approximately half for drinking water and half for flood mitigation--have to be managed under a La Nina regime, not an El Nino regime, and even so at a time like this when water was pouring in for weeks and months from all the creeks and streams above that wall and then particularly that weekend, with the non-stop, constant rain. When we had 16 inches that night at Somerset, that was the time. Everybody should have been there and made absolutely sure that water was released, and thousands of houses in Brisbane and Ipswich could have been saved.

I wish Mick Slater and the members of the authority well in doing everything they can to bring about robust engineering principles and good modern design for the future and to work cooperatively with councils and departments. I hope that the bureaucracy is kept to an absolute minimum and that this can result in a better build up of services and facilities for people who have been devastated by all these disasters.

Mr HOOLIHAN (Keppel--ALP) (9.58 pm): I have sat here and listened to the arguments put by so many members, and it really intrigues me that they do not seem to have any concept that we are talking about the Queensland reconstruction bill. I mentioned in the motion of condolence a Latin maxim which is my family motto: dum spiro spero, which means ‘while I breath, I hope’. What this bill, the Queensland reconstruction bill, does is to give the people of Queensland hope, to give the people of Queensland satisfaction that they will be looked after and that they will be looked after across the whole of Queensland.

I draw the attention of members to certain matters in the explanatory notes. These are the real thrust of this bill. Everyone should stop and listen to this. If you can read, you can always go back to the explanatory notes and have a look. The explanatory notes state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The damage to Queensland homes, businesses and infrastructure caused by the floods and cyclone is unprecedented, and the recovery effort will require the dedication of significant resources for assessment, coordination and management of the reconstruction program across the State and involving all levels of government.
XML.Hansard-Body: All levels of government means local, state and federal governments. The explanatory notes outline the process for the achievement of the objectives. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Authority will work across all levels of government to plan and facilitate an effective and coordinated program of reconstruction of community infrastructure and other property.
XML.Hansard-Body: The authority will not be tasked with dealing with anything that has happened before this. It will not be responsible for looking at any events prior to the devastating floods--bearing in mind that one of the first areas to be flooded was Rockhampton--as we have a commission of inquiry to do that.

This act will grant to the authority an overriding power to make sure that the people of Queensland effect recovery and enjoy recovery. As the explanatory sets out, reconstruction will be managed and implemented by local authorities and existing government entities. There are some that it cannot utilise so this bill ensures that the authority has the statutory powers to intervene where necessary. To facilitate this in the bill there is a notice to decide. To expedite things there is a progression notice. To undertake reconstruction efforts there is a step-in notice. These are powers that presently exist and are exercised by the Coordinator-General under the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act.

What this act does is give to the authority the ability to make those decisions that may not be made because some other level of government or some other authority drags their feet. This act is designed to ensure that the reconstruction of Queensland is affected smoothly and effectively. It has a two-year time frame. There is a sunset clause that limits it to two years.

I have heard members make comments about whether or not it will work. The Coordinator-General works and the Coordinator-General has been very effective in making sure that Queensland has proceeded and been able to develop. What this bill and the subsequent act will do is give the authority the power to make sure that Queensland can get back to being the Queensland that we know and love. I would like to thank the Premier for introducing the bill and for the work that has gone into the production of the bill. I commend it to this House.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (10.03 pm), in reply: At the outset, I would like to begin by thanking all members for their contributions to the debate. This bill is a vital plank in the rebuilding of Queensland following the devastation that has been inflicted on our state this summer. The rebuilding and recovery task facing us is immense, but we will, through the authority, remain focused on ensuring that the reconstruction of our state happens as quickly as possible. I thank the opposition for its support of the bill. It is essential that we act in a bipartisan way and focus on the reconstruction, recovery and protection of the state in the interests of all Queenslanders.

XML.Hansard-Body: I note that earlier today the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee tabled its report on the bill. I thank the committee for reporting on the bill in such a short time frame. I table my response to the issues raised in the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s report for the benefit of the members of the House.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 17 February 2011, from Hon Anna Bligh MP, Premier of Queensland to Ms Jo-Ann Miller MP, Chair of the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee, regarding the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill.
XML.Hansard-Body: Let me address some of the comments made by members during the debate. The Leader of the Opposition made comments on a number of aspects of the bill. In particular, the leader and other members of the opposition have spent a great deal of the debate arguing about the need to have a separate minister responsible for reconstruction. In arguing this case, it seems the opposition is determined to judge me and my work ethic by their standards. I can assure them they will make a grave mistake in doing so.

It is apparent from the comments by the members of the opposition that their approach to the issue of bureaucracy is entirely inconsistent. While the Leader of the Opposition says he has reservations about how the extensive powers and responsibilities of the authority will operate, he also suggested in the same debate that we should extend those powers to other areas of the state not affected by natural disasters. He thinks the current planning and approvals process is too bureaucratic but, at the same time, has reservations about an alternative that cuts through them for these purposes. Meanwhile, the member for Redlands appears to be of a view that the authority simply represents a new bureaucracy. So, as usual, there is a very inconsistent approach.

To address the Leader of the Opposition’s particular concerns about the operation and outcomes that stem from the authority, the reality is that the QRA will exist within the existing structures of government--that is, ministerial approval of its activities in the same way as every other statutory authority of government operates, subject to cabinet processes and subject to audit and probity requirements. It is not a law unto itself. In fact its powers and responsibilities are consistent with those afforded to the Coordinator-General in facilitating state development and the existing ULDA in facilitating affordable housing. It cannot be said that in either case the powers of those authorities have been abused in their operation.

Further, in relation to the Leader of the Opposition’s comments on the need for transparency and scrutiny of the authority’s powers and its spending let me say that I can advise that the authority will be subject to an extremely high level of scrutiny because of the legitimate and very strong interest from Queenslanders across the state in how the disaster recovery is going and what I expect to be a very high level of interest from the media. The board will be required to provide a monthly report on the authority’s operations, including details of how it has exercised its functions and powers. These monthly reports will be available on my department’s website and will ensure that all Queenslanders are kept informed about the progress of the reconstruction efforts.

It will be overseen by a board of management and be subject to both state and Commonwealth oversight in performing its functions. It will be subject to the oversight of the Auditor-General, the Ombudsman and the CMC. The authority will also be subject to right to information and privacy laws and the state procurement policy. Further, the Commonwealth government has established a reconstruction inspectorate to oversee the expenditure of Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangement funds in jurisdictions across Australia by scrutinising contracts, inspecting projects and investigating complaints, reviewing requests for reimbursement and analysing tender processes. I would venture to suggest that this may in fact be the most scrutinised statutory authority ever established in the history of the state.

I also note that some members have sought assurances that reconstruction moneys will only be used for reconstruction purposes. Let me be clear about this: all funds flowing to the authority--both state and Commonwealth funds--can only be applied to the reconstruction and recovery effort consistent with the functions of the authority as set out in its legislation. The state’s funding to the authority will be identified in the documentation of the authority’s budget as part of the state’s budget papers and will be subject to the estimates process and the normal questioning available in the parliament.

A number of members made comments about the amendments to the Building Act 1975 and the Land Valuation Act 2010 to delay new statutory requirements for swimming pool fencing and land valuations. They questioned why there is a need for these delays to apply state-wide rather than being limited to declared disaster areas. Despite the suggestion that we should have two parallel statutory regimes in Queensland, where one set of pool fencing and valuation time frames apply to flood affected parts of the state and another for non-flood affected parts of the state, a number of major stakeholders are on the public record supporting these state-wide amendments. The REIQ has described the pool fencing amendments as ‘a sensible approach’. The LGAQ has said on valuations, ‘Given the impact of natural disasters is widespread across Queensland, the decision to delay the issue of valuations so that valuations are as accurate as possible is a logical approach.’ The Property Council said, ‘It is vital that we get it right. A short delay is a small price to pay to achieve this.’ I venture to suggest it is not often that we get agreement between the LGAQ and the property industry, but it appears that everybody except those opposite agree with this common-sense approach.

In relation to pool fencing for example, the reason we have brought about that delay is recognition that there is a lot of pressure on the rental market right now and a lot of people who have been made homeless because of these disasters. We want to ensure that they can get into rental properties as quickly and as easily as possible. So if we only applied this to flood affected areas, it would mean that the people who are homeless would be delayed if they wanted to move out of the flood affected areas, which is of course precisely what they would want to do because the flood affected areas are flood affected. The reality is that the scale of these disasters has meant that the impact of the floods and the cyclone have been felt state-wide. It would be impractical and confusing to commence new statutory requirements for pool fencing or to issue new statutory valuations only in certain parts of the state or, in the case of the city of Brisbane, only in some suburbs.

I can advise the House that implementation of both of these new laws relating to pools and the new valuation regime is continuing successfully. Prior to the floods valuations were on track for delivery prior to 31 March, as required. However, additional time is now required. Why? To ensure that the impact of the disaster events can be fully assessed. Valuations, by and large, were done of properties at the end of last year prior to the disasters, prior to the floods. So we ran the risk that people’s valuations would in fact basically be inflated and higher than the actual value of their properties now and they would be exposed potentially to higher costs. Fair and accurate valuations will be an important part of the rebuilding process in many regions, and in fact the local governments affected sought this consideration from government.

I note the member for Burnett has written to me about eligibility for NDRRA assistance. I will investigate the issues raised by the member and respond in due course. I thank the member for Nicklin for his clear support for my decision to be the minister responsible for this legislation. I do so because, sitting in the centre of government, this recovery effort will require not only the legislative activities but the attention and funding of a range of government departments, and it is sitting in the centre of government that you can make those things happen. So I thank him for the recognition for that. I also note his comments in relation to an election. Can I say two things. He alluded to some rumour that the AEC was checking out possible election sites in April. Can I tell him that it is certainly not the state government making those inquiries, so perhaps there is an early Commonwealth election I do not know anything about. But I can give him an absolute guarantee that there have been no inquiries made to the Electoral Commission with regard to not only that date but to any date in 2011.
Mr Wellington interjected.

Ms BLIGH: Well then, it must be true! But I am happy, if there is that rumour, to put that one to bed.
