Can I also say that in relation to speculation on tonight’s news that in fact that speculation was made contrary to the question that was put to me, and which I denied, that the movements by some ministers meant anything about an election. In fact, what it meant was that we had an opportunity to reshape government for the task ahead. This is a rebuilding year and we need to make sure that this cabinet has the best people on the job focused on just that.

I also wish to advise the member for Nicklin that the government will not be supporting the amendment to clause 149 that he has circulated, not because we do not agree with the intent of it but because we believe that under the legislation the authority has the power through its step-in powers to achieve the outcomes that he is seeking. The ULDA is a statutory authority of the state government. If the Reconstruction Authority is of the view that action that it is taking should be stopped in the interests of mitigation and recovery, then it has the power under its step-in power to do that. So what the member is seeking is actually already contained in the legislation and is implicit in the step-in power.

The member for Gladstone raised the very important issue that I spoke a bit about in question time this morning, and that is the importance of making sure that as we focus--rightly--on recovery and reconstruction as our No. 1 priority we do not take our eye off those other priorities for communities both affected by flood and not affected by flood. Without doubt the realisation of the opportunities from the liquid natural gas industry are now more important to our economy than they have ever been, but getting them right is just as important as it has ever been. I absolutely concur with the comments from the member for Gladstone and can reassure her that this will continue to be a very top of the agenda item for government and she is going to see a lot of activity from us in and around the Gladstone region.

Finally, I note that various members have, in the course of the debate tonight, spoken about the damage to specific infrastructure and assets in their respective electorates and that just about every member of those opposite argued for more money for many worthy purposes. What I did not hear from any member opposite was a declaration of support for the flood levy. I would suggest to them that when they roll out their long list of claims for more money for more things they might like to think about talking to Tony Abbott and their colleagues federally, because the sooner we can settle the source of Commonwealth funds the sooner they can legitimately have a debate about extra things that you might add to the shopping list.

There was some debate about whether or not this might hold up the activities of getting things moving while we put all of the machinery in place. Can I assure the House and those opposite that councils are not waiting for this to happen, and nor should they be. If you get out and about and have a look at what is happening, councils are out there on the ground and are in fact putting in place repairs whenever they can. A lot of the roads have already had temporary works to make them trafficable, and those temporary works over time will have to be prioritised for permanent works. But they are getting on with the job, as they should be, and it is not intended that this authority will stop them from doing that. It is there in case they need assistance to move.

As individuals, businesses and farms and communities now work to re-establish themselves, the Queensland government will continue to be there, standing alongside them doing whatever it takes to get Queensland back on her feet. This bill is the centrepiece of our strategy for the reconstruction of Queensland’s infrastructure and assets and the rebuilding of our communities. I want to thank those Public Service officers who have worked hard on the development and drafting of these bills. As members can appreciate, it has been an extraordinary effort to bring them to the parliament in the first week of the parliamentary sitting year so soon after the devastating effects of the disasters that we have seen. They have worked very hard and I particularly thank officers from the Department of the Premier and Cabinet, the Department of Infrastructure and Planning and of course those mighty drafters from the Office of the Queensland Parliamentary Counsel, and I commend the bill to the House.
Question put--That the bill be now read a second time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 1 to 4, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 5--

Mr WELLINGTON (10.17 pm): This clause relates to definitions and states that the dictionary in the schedule defines particular words used in this act. There is no definition of the word ‘minister’. Is it intended that you as Premier will have sole power to do what the minister’s powers are under the bill, or is it intended that there will be, say, the director-general and the deputy director-general with delegated powers to make those decisions in lieu of the minister? Often I understand in other legislation they refer to a minister having powers, but senior departmental staff in various departments have that power and it is actually not the minister personally making that decision; these other people have delegated power to make the decision on behalf of the minister.

Ms BLIGH: It does not define ‘minister’ because ‘minister’ generally is defined by the Constitution of Queensland. But in this case I have not put the word ‘Premier’ in because it leaves it open that, following an election next year, a different government or a different Premier--whatever--might want to change that without having to come into the parliament. You would not want to restrict anybody in the second year of the operation of this, and I do not think that makes sense. In relation to delegation of powers, it is open generally under the Acts Interpretation Act for powers to be delegated, but it is my intention that the minister’s powers in relation to this bill would be exercised by myself as the relevant minister.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 7 to 9, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 10--

Hansard-Body.A: (9.19 pm): My question to the Premier is about data sharing, which I think we would all acknowledge will be excellent to see. Under clause 10(d) there will be data sharing across all levels of government. That will obviously be effective and efficient. My question is whether that is going to be a permanent arrangement or just for the duration of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority’s term.

XML.Hansard-Body: Ms BLIGH: This provision is there predominantly to provide for the sharing of data such as flood mapping to ensure that the Reconstruction Authority has the information that it needs to make good decisions in relation to redevelopment and reconstruction. At the point at which this authority ceases to exist, whether those provisions need to be saved and put into other relevant pieces of legislation is a judgement that should be made at the time. I would suggest that there would be an arrangement put in place. If there was a problem, if it needed a legislative base, then a government at the point at which this expires--because there are other provisions in this bill that will need to be transported, at the point that the QRA ceases to exist, to the department administering the state development act or the department administering the ULDA, for example. I envisage that this provision would likely lapse, but it is one that could be saved if at the end of the two-year period it needed to be.

Mr LANGBROEK: I thank the Premier. My second question is about another aspect of this clause. It is about the balance between flood mitigation and early reconstruction. I know that there are communities that at the moment are unsure of exactly what the priority rationale is between those two particular areas. They are not sure whether particular areas may be prescribed for flood mitigation and they are not sure whether they are all going to be able to get on with reconstruction first. I would like to have a potential explanation from the Premier about the authority’s function in that regard.

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question. I appreciate that there are some questions and confusion. I made a public statement in relation to this issue about two weeks ago--it was published in the Sunday Mail --and I was backed up by similar public comments at the time by the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, that those people who are in a position to make any adjustments to their homes that will make them livable should do so. If at some point down the track there is a judgement made by their council or by this authority that they should do something different then there would have to be other arrangements put in place to facilitate that. But we do not want people out of their homes or in temporary situations for a minute longer than they need to be. People who are in a position--for example they have insurance, they have a builder and they can get on with it--should do so.
Clause 12--

Hansard-Body.A: (10.22 pm): I refer the Premier to clauses 12(3)(a) and 12(3)(b). Clause 12(3)(a) states that the authority must--it is mandatory--include in its annual report a range of things. By way of comparison, clause 12(3)(b) is discretionary and states that the authority ‘may include in the report a comment about the effect on the authority’s activities of complying with the direction or notice’. My view is that that paragraph should be mandatory, just like the requirement in paragraph (a) before it. I seek clarification as to why it is not.

XML.Hansard-Body: Ms BLIGH: I think it is as simple as in some cases there may in fact be no effect on the authority. The paragraph is there to provide expressly that if the authority believes there is some comment it should put in the public arena about the minister’s direction then it is authorised to do so. But if there is nothing upon which the authority wishes to comment, or nothing that had any effect on the authority, then there is no requirement on them to do so.

The member will find that this clause--and similar clauses--is a very standard clause in GOC legislation and in statutory authority legislation. It is a recognition that these bodies are slightly more independent from government than a government department and that they are not directly at the direction of the minister in the same way as a government department might be. Nevertheless, they are government bodies and they should be subject to the direction of the elected government. But if they are subject to that direction, that should be publicly made known. So it puts a bit of weight on the minister to only give a direction where the minister believes that the reason for doing so is publicly justifiable.
Mr WELLINGTON: But I still do not understand why. There is a suspicion of people not doing the right thing. Would it be such a significant request to have it made mandatory?

Ms BLIGH: It could be a bit non-sensical if the authority has no comment to make. I do not believe that this paragraph in any way hampers. In fact, it frees up the authority to make as much comment as it wants. Say, for example, a minister directs the authority to expend money on a certain project. The authority is then at liberty to say, ‘Because of this direction we were unable to spend money on this other thing, which was equally or potentially a priority.’ But if there is no effect, if there is nothing on which the authority wishes to comment, as I said, it seems a bit non-sensical to somehow force the authority by legislation to make a comment on something that may not require it.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 13 to 17, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 18--

Hansard-Body.A: (10.25 pm): I seek some clarification from the Premier about the relationship the CEO has with the board. In most commercial situations there is a board that comes together. The board would elect its CEO and the board would then give directions to that CEO.

XML.Hansard-Body: In this case, from my reading of the functions and powers of the chief executive officer, this has already been preordained. You have a CEO who, under subclause (1)(b), takes ministerial directions, or the minister directs the CEO. I cannot see anywhere within that clause where it states the functions and powers of the chief executive officer where that CEO must take directions from the board.

The nearest I can find to this model of board is the Queensland Health boards or the local hospital boards, where you have at the moment community representatives but they can merely make recommendations to the CEO and all the power exists within that board with the CEO. The way the legislation is written now, there could be recommendations made from the board to the CEO, but the CEO may not follow through with those recommendations. The CEO’s direct focus is through to the minister, who will be directing the CEO. In a nutshell, what I am trying is find out is: we have a general on the board but does a CEO outrank a general?

Ms BLIGH: In relation to the relationship between the board and the CEO, I direct the member to part 3 of the bill which outlines the functions. These include setting the strategic priorities for the authority, making recommendations to the minister about priorities for community infrastructure or the need for the declaration of declared projects, and ensuring that the authority performs its functions and exercises its powers in an appropriate, effective and efficient way.

Those are the sorts of general provisions that you would find in most statutory authorities, which generally mean that the board sets the strategic direction and is then responsible for ensuring that the authority as a whole, including the CEO, implements that strategic direction and takes the authority in the set of priorities that have been identified by the board and approved by the minister. So the CEO is responsible to the board. The chair reports directly to the minister. It is no different in this authority than in every other statutory authority.

Mr MESSENGER: I appreciate the answer that the Premier has given. However, the way it is written in the legislation at the moment is that there is only one direction. The CEO takes directions from the minister and at all other stages there are merely recommendations made from the board through to the CEO and then the CEO may or may not carry through with those recommendations. You would obviously think that with this group of people that would never happen. Nonetheless, there is a fundamental difference between this QRA board and any other board that most other people in corporate life would be aware of.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 19 to 23, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 24--
Mr WELLINGTON (10.29 pm): I am happy with the explanation the Premier gave to the question raised by my colleague.
Clause 26--

Mr LANGBROEK (10.30 pm): Premier, I have not thanked the staff for the briefing we had for this on Monday. I do want to thank the staff from the Premier’s office and the CEO, whom we met. I know it is in the early stages of preparation in terms of getting ready for the authority, but I am interested in potential staff numbers, which is covered by this clause. The clause states that the authority may employ other staff under the Public Service Act. Could the Premier give the House an idea of the projected full-time equivalents who may be allocated to this and how many may come from other government departments or may be externally hired?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question. I hope that he appreciates that it is genuinely too early to give any accurate response in terms of numbers. What I can say is that this is a short-term authority and it will rely on people with expertise in other agencies whom we know are sitting there. I acknowledge that in a smaller scale disaster many of the activities and functions that the authority will carry out would have otherwise been conducted by the department of main roads, the Department of Communities or the department of environment and planning. What we are doing with this is bringing those resources into one central place to minimise the amount of time it takes a council or another constructing authority to go around and knock on the various doors of government.

We are looking to second officers into the authority from other parts of the Queensland Public Service. So while they will appear on these books, they are people who would have been paid to do this work in another agency. Given the scale of what we are dealing with, this will require additional resources beyond that. We are certainly not looking for a large bureaucracy; we are certainly looking for an authority that is reasonably light on its feet. As you will appreciate, this is something I will be able to report on as the authority gets established and gets a sense of the exact size of the task, which is the phase it is currently engaged in.
Mr WELLINGTON: I am happy with the Premier’s answer to the question raised by the Leader of the Opposition.
Mr MESSENGER: The Leader of the Opposition took the words straight out of my mouth.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 27 to 34, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 35--

Mr WELLINGTON (10.33 pm): In relation to the relationship between the CEO and the board, what is the linkage between the CEO’s requirement to report to the board or the board’s requirement to give direction to the CEO?
Ms BLIGH: I am not sure if I have quite understood the question but I think you are asking about the relationship between the board and the CEO.
Mr WELLINGTON: Yes.

Ms BLIGH: As I said, it is the role of the board to set the strategic priorities, to set the overall plan. It is the role of the CEO to implement that plan and then report to the board regularly on the progress of that implementation. It is also important to recognise that it is the role of the board to make sure that, if there is any slowing down in the progress or if there is any problem, they are interrogating the CEO and other relevant officers of the agency about that problem. I certainly see them as being high level and strategic. If they identify, for example, that the progress reports of the CEO are unsatisfactory--if that is the case--they will be very actively involved in delving down and getting to more detail.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 36 to 39, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 40--

Mr MESSENGER (10.34 pm): From the answers we have had from the Premier, it appears that we still do not know how many staff will be employed. As yet, I do not believe we have an estimate of how much money this authority will administer. Obviously, this authority will be administering funds in excess of billions if not tens of billions of dollars to carry out its core objectives. Therefore, I want to talk about clause 40 and the disclosure of a conflict of interest. The way I read this clause is that there is no provision within clause 40 for board members or the CEO or staff for that matter to make disclosures of a conflict of interest on a register prior to them beginning their job. The clause states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: If--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) a member has a direct or indirect pecuniary or other interest in a matter being considered or about to be considered at a meeting of the board; and
(b) the interest appears to raise a conflict with the proper performance of the member’s duties in relation to the consideration of the matter;
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: the member must, as soon as possible after the relevant facts have come to the member’s knowledge, disclose the nature of the interest at a meeting of the board.
XML.Hansard-Body: I may be wrong and I hope to be corrected but it does not appear their pecuniary interests are treated the same as a member of this place, whereby we must place them on the public record.
Ms BLIGH: Is this in relation to members of the board?
Mr MESSENGER: Yes.

Ms BLIGH: This again is a very standard clause. It is not possible in all circumstances to anticipate where a conflict of interest may arise. What it does is impose on a board member if such a conflict arises an obligation to disclose it and to absent themselves from the decision. As I said, this is a very standard provision not only in legislation establishing government bodies but in private board arrangements. There is a requirement that the chief executive must make a disclosure of their pecuniary interests to the Integrity Commissioner; that is in clause 153, which is an amendment of schedule 1 to do with statutory office holders. It is a consequential amendment at the back of the bill that will require the CEO to make a declaration as other CEOs are required to.

Mr MESSENGER: I just think we are dealing with uncharted waters here, so to speak. We have had unprecedented natural disasters and this is unprecedented legislation. The Premier has just described the method of managing the pecuniary interests of the CEO, and I would have thought that all members of the board would have to place their pecuniary interests on a similar register so that it is beyond reproach, it is there and it is transparent for all to see just exactly what interests they do have. These people will be making decisions about billions and billions of dollars. This state government has a budget of around $40 billion, so I just repeat and reiterate that, in the best interests of prudential account keeping, openness and transparency, all board members and all those associated with those senior positions should have their pecuniary interests on a register prior to them making decisions.

Ms BLIGH: There is no such registry for board members. There is no such requirement on any other board of any other government agency. I appreciate the member may be well motivated but this is the standard clause by which these things are managed and I do not see any cause for that to change in this instance.
Clause 42--

Mr WELLINGTON
(10.39 pm): In light of the Premier’s reply to my question about the relationship between the Reconstruction Authority and the Urban Land Development Authority my question is specifically in relation to clause 42 subclause (4) where it says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Before declaring a declared project, the Minister must have regard to the responsibilities of the relevant local government--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: And my question is: why haven’t we also got--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: must have regard to the responsibilities of the relevant local government and/or the Urban Land Development Authority for matters about land use, and the giving of development approvals, for the local government’s area and/or Urban Land Development Authority.
XML.Hansard-Body: In subclause (5), again if the same laws apply to the Urban Land Development Authority as they apply to local councils, why do we not have in the bill the following words--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Minister may make the declaration on the Minister’s own initiative or at the request of a local government or the Urban Land Development Authority.
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms BLIGH: It is not the intention that the Urban Land Development Authority would be seeking powers under this act for the purposes of flood recovery. We would not be giving the Urban Land Development Authority the ability to use the powers under this act. They have an entirely different purpose. Flood recovery mitigation and reconstruction is the role of this agency and I would not want to see the two of those confused. If, however, and I understand your concern is predominantly in relation to the Sunshine Coast, there is an urban land activity happening and the Reconstruction Authority is of the view that it is contrary to the aims of flood mitigation and reconstruction it can step in and order that that activity cease, but under a different provision than this one.
Clause 43--

Mr LANGBROEK
(10.41 pm): My question to the Premier is about clause 43(4) where it is not quite clear whether acquisition land has to be declared at the time of the declaration of a reconstruction area. The question is: can acquisition land be declared at a time after the reconstruction area is declared?
Ms BLIGH: The answer is, yes, it can be, but it would require an amendment to the regulation and that would have to be gazetted et cetera.
Clause 44--

Mr DOWLING
(10.42 pm): In relation to notice about declaration of acquisition land, I am just wondering when the land is declared and one goes down the path of either acquisition or taking of land what will be the decision-making process through that as to whether we are taking the land or we are declaring it as acquisition land?

Ms BLIGH: Once land is declared as acquisition land the process of acquiring it will be the process that is outlined in the Acquisition of Land Act. It is the same as if one is acquiring land under the Acquisition of Land Act for a highway. It is completely separate to this.

Mr DOWLING: I understood there were to be two processes, one where land is acquired right upfront and taken now and another where the land may still be retained in ownership but must revert back to the state or a government department or a council authority at some time in the future. I am just wondering about the difference between those two choices and how those decisions will be brought about.

Ms BLIGH: They would be decisions made by the authority. I cannot imagine a circumstance where the authority would make that without it being the recommendation of the relevant local council. While it is technically possible under this bill for that to happen one does not have to think too much about how difficult that would be if it was against the will of the local council. Whether it is done straight upfront or later on, in both cases when it comes to the point of sale then the Acquisition of Land Act provisions would apply in terms of someone’s rights to valuations and appeals et cetera.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 45 to 64, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 65--

Mr WELLINGTON
(10.44 pm): I note 65(b)(i) refers to a government entity or GOC and (ii) is a person or other entity. Is it intended that the other entity refers to the Urban Land Development Authority?
Ms BLIGH: The answer is yes.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 66 to 76, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 77--

Mr WELLINGTON
(10.45 pm): Very briefly, clause 77(2) states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Minister must, when the regulation is tabled in the Legislative Assembly under the Statutory Instruments Act 1992, section 49, also table a copy of the development scheme or amendment.
XML.Hansard-Body: Would it be possible to also have ‘plus explanatory notes’?
Subclause (3) states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A failure to comply with this section does not invalidate or otherwise affect the regulation.
XML.Hansard-Body: I would have thought it would have been better to make it mandatory so that we make sure this information is provided when we are intending that it will be.

Ms BLIGH: I thought the member might be going to talk about explanatory notes. The government has indicated that it will be moving to make all subordinate legislation require explanatory notes. The drafting practice requirements changed to that effect on 1 January. The amendment to the relevant act has not been brought into the parliament yet but it will be. But as a matter of practice that has already started occurring.
Mr WELLINGTON: The second part of subclause (3) states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A failure to comply with this section does not invalidate or otherwise affect the regulation.
XML.Hansard-Body: I was wondering why we cannot have the removal of ‘not invalidate’ and say ‘a failure to comply with this section will invalidate’.

Ms BLIGH: I acknowledge that it looks a little odd but my advice is that it is a very standard provision in relation to regulation-making power because the regulation needs to serve the purpose for which it was intended. I would suggest that if it did not, the price would probably be a political one rather than disadvantaging the person or the entity for whom the regulation was intended. I am happy to find other examples of it in legislation for the member, but that is the advice that I have.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 79 to 81, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 83 to 91, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 93 to 112, as read, agreed to.
Clauses 113 and 114, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 115--

Hansard-Body.A: (10.50 pm): Clause 115 is part of a range of clauses that deal with offences under this bill. The penalty under this particular clause is 200 penalty units, which I believe is the maximum number of penalty units for any offence under this bill. In other clauses penalties range from 165 to 200 penalty units. So we are looking at $16,500 to $20,000 in fines. When compared with other legislation, these fines are significantly lower. I would like the Premier to detail for this place how they came up with that $20,000 fine.

XML.Hansard-Body: I raise this because I am dealing with a number of other issues at the moment. For example, under the fish habitat legislation the maximum fine for damaging a riverbank is $300,000. I am dealing with a number of people in the Burnett who are facing those fines at the moment. There is one gentleman, a Vietnam veteran, who is facing a maximum fine of $300,000, causing him great concern. There is also a lady, a widow, whose husband tragically killed himself during a court case late last year in Bundaberg over a fine of $300,000 under the fish protection legislation for damaging a fish habitat. In the case of a member of the board or an officer of the authority failing to act honestly in the exercise of their powers and functions, I am wondering whether a maximum fine of $20,000 is enough.

Ms BLIGH: In terms of offences, the legislation has been drafted in comparison to other similar legislation for boards dealing with matters of a similar nature. As always happens with drafting, the Office of Parliamentary Counsel tries to ensure that, across the broad spectrum of matters that we deal with in this chamber and the broad spectrum of legislation, there is not too much discrepancy between offences of a similar nature. Not every offence is comparable, but I think the drafters do a pretty good job of ensuring some level of consistency.

Obviously I cannot comment on the cases that the member has just talked about, but I am satisfied that the work has been done to ensure some consistency between the offences for board members and others in this legislation compared with similar breaches of duty in similar legislation.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 116 to 148, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 149--

Hansard-Body.A: (10.53 pm): I do not intend to proceed with the amendment I circulated earlier as a result of the answers the Premier has provided to the questions I raised about the relationship between the proposed Reconstruction Authority and the Urban Land Development Authority. I am now reassured that if the Reconstruction Authority wants to take over matters that the Urban Land Development Authority has control of then it certainly has capacity to do that--just like if the Reconstruction Authority wants to take over matters that the local councils in Queensland have current responsibility for. It has the capacity to do that. I thank the Premier for her answers.

XML.Hansard-Body: Ms BLIGH: I am happy to confirm again for the benefit of the member for Nicklin that his interpretation of my answers is correct.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 150 to 161, as read, agreed to.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (10.54 pm): I move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a third time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a third time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a third time.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (10.54 pm): I move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (10.55 pm): I move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House, at its rising, do adjourn until 9.30 am on Tuesday, 8 March 2010.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (10.55 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House do now adjourn.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Barnes, Mr F; Collard, Mr B

Hansard-Body.A: (Coomera--LNP) (10.56 pm): On behalf of the people of the Coomera electorate I offer condolences to all those who have suffered in these horrific natural disasters. There are some amazing people in the northern Gold Coast and southern Logan areas. At the risk of missing many, I am compelled to mention just a few.

XML.Hansard-Body: One such person is Frank Barnes, OBE. We joke about Frank Barnes, OBE--‘over blinkin’ eighty’. Frank is a guy who has been around for many years. In fact, I first met him when he was the chaplain at the Beenleigh State High School, before there were school chaplains in any number. He was paid for a day a week and worked five days a week. If it is about youth, as far as Frank is concerned it is about him. So he was right in there looking after these young people. He now coordinates the school chaplains in the area. He is the Police Citizens Youth Club rouseabout. By that I mean he is the chef, the waiter and the organiser. In fact, he organises and runs the Beenleigh Junior Chamber of Commerce--and the list goes on.

Frank does not know this, and he will probably be cranky when it happens, but tomorrow morning at the Beenleigh-Yatala Chamber of Commerce breakfast Frank is going to be honoured by those who appreciate him and his efforts--for all that he has done and continues to do--for the Police Citizens Youth Club. They are going to cause this man’s name to be recognised forever. From tomorrow the extensive commercial kitchen area in the Police Citizens Youth Club will be known as the ‘Frank Barnes Kitchen’. Of course, Frank is still around so it is not going to be the ‘Frank Barnes Memorial Kitchen’. However, I dare say that at some time in the future we are all going to fall off our twig--and so will Frank. His name will live on in the Beenleigh area for many years to come. It is a fitting tribute to the man who has meant so much to the youth of the area.

Brian Collard was born on 17 December 1943 and he passed away suddenly last Saturday afternoon. Together with the member for Albert I attended a celebration of Brian’s life today, as did some 600 to 800 people--the celebration of the life of Brian, and what a life it was. For almost 50 years he did so much for the people in and around the area of Beenleigh, Woongoolba and all of the other areas that are joined. Brian leaves behind his wife, June, sons David, Anthony, Timothy and Matthew, together with his daughters-in-law and 11 grandchildren. Clearly, he touched so many lives, as is evidenced by the number in attendance. I am sure all members join me in passing my condolences to June and the family.

Ms CROFT (Broadwater--ALP) (10.59 pm): This coming Sunday I will chair the annual general meeting of the Runaway Bay RSL Sub-Branch, for which I have been a patron for a number of years now. The Runaway Bay RSL Sub-Branch currently has 185 members and, like most RSL clubs, offers its members welfare assistance, advocacy and representation on important issues affecting ex-servicemen and women and their families.

However, for most RSL members, being a member of an RSL branch is also about mateship and the opportunity to catch up monthly with fellow ex-servicemen or women to reminisce over a beer or cuppa. The Runaway Bay RSL Sub-Branch is well known for being a friendly sub-branch and very supportive of its members. What is not so well known about this sub-branch is that, whilst some could consider it small, it is a very active branch in our community and in its efforts to continue the tradition of supporting serving troops.

The Runaway Bay RSL Sub-Branch is one of the biggest supporters of the parcels for troops program. This program is a Gold Coast district RSL project and involves the packaging parcels filled with specialty food items such as lollies, cheese sticks and of course vegemite for our serving officers overseas. They also remember man’s best friend, putting together parcels for the explosive detection dogs that include dog treats and tennis balls.

People are invited to donate to the parcels for troops program. The Runaway Bay RSL Sub-branch members will be packing all day on 3 March at a stall to be located at the Runaway Bay shopping centre outside Rockmans clothing store. The next batch of parcels, I understand, will be going to serving troops in Afghanistan.

This sub-branch has also been dedicated to helping the local community and in particular the youth. To date, the sub-branch has distributed around $15,000 for scholarships, bursaries and donations to local schools, local scouts and also the local SES unit. It has formed strong relationships with the local police, ambulance and fire station staff.

The strong association the RSL sub-branch has with the Runaway Bay Junior Leagues Club has stemmed from an invitation that was extended to it to hold its meetings at the junior leagues club. That has now been extended to offering a room on site for office space for the RSL sub-branch. The Runaway Bay RSL Sub-Branch provides sponsorship for junior rugby league representatives, and many of the sub-branch members help out as volunteers for the Australian Rugby League Masters event held every year.

It is very clear that the Runaway Bay RSL Sub-Branch has a very important place in our local community, and since its inception has been a strong force in ensuring RSL clubs are relevant in our community now and in the future.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Central Queensland Mines, Fly in, Fly out
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr MALONE (Mirani--LNP) (11.02 pm): This morning I tabled a petition containing 3,317 signatures to totally reject the imposition of a 100 per cent fly in, fly out proposal for mines in Central Queensland. I now also table a non-conforming petition with 954 signatures.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Non-conforming petition in relation to 100% fly-in, fly-out workforce plan.
XML.Hansard-Body: The size and scope of this petition shows the significant public angst caused by this proposal. My view is--and I have expressed it many times--that there has to be a choice for the workers and that a fly in, fly out operation should only be a percentage of the total workforce.

Mining operations go through many phases of development--refurbishment, rebuilding et cetera--and the number of workers on site can vary greatly from time to time. During shutdown operations, for instance, contractors can bring hundreds of workers with different skill sets on to the work site for varying lengths of time. There is a real need to cater for the change in conditions, and the only way to do that in most cases is through fly in, fly out.

Our communities in the mining towns--including the essential services such as schools, police, emergency services, councils et cetera--rely on a stable population base to remain sustainable. For instance, for secondary schools to provide a comprehensive curriculum, they need a critical mass of students to effectively achieve that. It is also true that business outlets are in the same boat. They need a critical mass of residents to be profitable, and if they cannot achieve that they will pack up and leave the community. This is the reason why there is a huge concern about the application for 100 per cent fly in, fly out and, once approved, it will become a precedent for further expansion into other mines. Therefore, I totally reject the imposition of 100 per cent fly in, fly out.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Toorbul and Donnybrook, Funeral Information Session

Hansard-Body.A: (Pumicestone--ALP) (11.04 pm): Last week I hosted a free funeral information session at the Toorbul-Donnybrook hall. The event was attended by nearly 70 local residents from the Toorbul and Donnybrook area and provided a wide range of information with speakers from the funeral industry, a law firm and the DonateLife organ and tissue donation program. There were also other industry representatives present to provide information.

XML.Hansard-Body: I would like to thank the people and organisations who gave up their time freely to provide information to locals in my electorate: Annette Lourigan from Metropolitan Funerals; Katharine Macleod from DonateLife; Alicia Loakes and Sean Ryan from Turner Freeman Lawyers; Ian Mellor, who is the coordinator of Queensland University of Technology’s Body Bequest Program; and celebrant Ruth Watson, who also volunteers running the free justice of the peace sessions at the Bribie Island Library.

This forum was all about providing information on issues we often do not want to talk about. And, while talking about death can make us uncomfortable, it is important to make sure we are well informed and prepared.

Annette Lourigan from Metropolitan Funerals discussed the funeral industry in general and particularly talked about her passion for environmentally friendly and sustainable coffins and funerals. This is a passion that I share, and I believe that we have an opportunity to improve the environmental outcomes of our funerals and to minimise the environmental impact of our passing. I will continue to encourage my constituents to consider environmental options when it comes to funerals and will work towards more sustainable funeral services across Queensland.

Katharine Macleod from DonateLife talked about the process of organ and tissue donation. I am also very passionate about this because I am an organ donor and I feel it is very important for all of us to think about donating our tissue and organs.

Alicia Loakes from Turner Freeman Lawyers talked through many of the legal issues that can arise after death and took a large number of questions regarding wills and estates. I would like to take this opportunity to particularly thank Sean Ryan. Sean is a partner at Turner Freemen Lawyers. During the forum he generously offered his firm’s services free of charge to assist one of my constituents look further into a legal issue.

It was particularly good to have David Dart, the President of the Queensland Funeral Directors Association, at the session and taking an interest in the session. Finally, I would like to thank the Toorbul-Donnybrook Pensioners Association for their assistance in organising this forum. The association are a key part of the Toorbul and Donnybrook communities, and they always make everybody feel very welcome in their hall.

My electorate includes a number of areas which have a large population of older Australians, and this group is growing. People who attended the forum were keen to know about more environmentally friendly disposal of body methods, and I have undertaken to get information out as soon as possible. The fact that the funeral industry is not regulated and continues to use conventional methods of burial and cremation, which have significant environmental concerns, has disturbed some people. They believe these issues should be investigated, with more environmentally friendly choices being made available. For further information on environmentally friendly burials, you can log onto: www.direct.gov.uk/en/environmentandgreenerliving/greenerlifeevents/dg_178752 or https://sustainableburials.discussions.nsw.gov.au/.

Mrs PRATT (Nanango--Ind) (11.07 pm): I am glad the member for Pumicestone has not asked me to memorise that and repeat it! I would like to bring to the attention of the House the proposed Coopers Gap wind farm, which AGL are planning for the future. This has caused a lot of consternation within the community of Cooranga North, which is in the vicinity of the proposed wind farm.

In the first instance people were very supportive and they signed up to have wind towers put on their properties and were quite content. Then they started to receive a lot of information garnered from various other areas in Australia where wind farms are, in South Australia and Victoria predominantly but also right around the world. There have been quite a few forums now in Cooranga North at the little hall there, and they have been very well attended considering this is a very small farming community.

What worries them the most is the growing worldwide concern about health issues and the wind turbines. I had a meeting with AGL’s Adam Mackett and Nigel Bean and there was another lady, but I cannot remember her name. What concerned me most about that particular meeting was that, regardless of what arguments, concerns or considerations were put forward, it always came back to the simple fact that AGL’s representatives--in this came Adam Mackett and Nigel Bean--seemed to be sticking steadfastly to the fact that they will abide by state legislation with regard to the proximity of the towers to any particular dwelling.

That concerned me because there is very little buffer between the house and the tower. Victoria is moving towards a two-kilometre buffer. That state has a particularly long history with regard to wind towers. If it is moving towards a minimum two-kilometre buffer then I believe it is imperative that Queensland also consider moving to such a buffer. There has been a precedent set in Victoria. It would be appropriate that Queensland take a little interest in what is happening down south and protect the communities of Cooranga North and the surrounding areas in the Coopers Gap area. I thank Minister Kate Jones for the decision that was made recently with regard to UCG in the Burnett.

Hansard-Body.A: (Kallangur--ALP) (11.10 pm): This week in parliament has been both heart-rending and heart-warming. The stories of tragedy and triumphs, of loss and effort, have made us all take stock of just how fortunate we are to still be here and still have our homes and our loved ones. While I know that many areas have severe damage and face massive reconstruction, I want to take a couple of minutes tonight to talk about some of the issues in my electorate.

XML.Hansard-Body: We have ongoing issues with water levels in North Pine Dam. The residents fear that there will be another rain event that may send a large flood down the river. This will obviously impact on those already damaged properties and the recovery efforts. There is already damage to the AJ Wyllie Bridge, which crosses the river at Petrie-Lawnton and is the main arterial for residents travelling between Strathpine and Kallangur, Dayboro and points north. This means that there is only one lane open each way, to the frustration of commuters and businesses alike. Any further rain will mean a river rise which may damage the bridge further, delay repairs or even result in more closures.

There are concerns that more rain will close Young’s Crossing, the only other crossing nearby other than the Bruce Highway, and cause further congestion and traffic chaos. Our lovely parks and recreation areas are washed away and we cannot get to work fixing them for fear of more inundation.

There has been rainwater damage in many public buildings, not least at the fabulous Dakabin State High School, which has had so much water damage that the stage is warping, there is mould growing in several rooms and the gutters are so full that there is no way to protect their walls and roofs in the next downpour. Union members at Dakabin have met to consider the mould and have concluded that the rooms are unsafe for the students and the staff and have, quite rightly, banned use of the rooms until they are repaired.

The school has been battling for some time to get funding for amenities. For example, there are only 71 seats for 1,000 students. The young people sit on the ground, near ant nests and on the uneven concrete. Buildings need painting, lots of maintenance is needed and massive upgrades of resources are required to deliver a quality education. Just as the P&C, staff, principal and I joined forces to try to get all of these problems sorted and get more resources allocated, the state faced the worst natural disasters in our history. We are all mindful of the shocking damage done to schools in the flood and cyclone areas and understand the huge cost but wonder again at the bad luck of Dakabin and its long campaign to get the school looking its best and to have the same resources as other schools in Brisbane.

Many wonderful people in Kallangur collected goods, donated money and volunteered in the recent floods. I sincerely thank them for their generosity and hard work. The comparatively small problems in our electorate will be faced with the same generosity of spirit and a steadfast commitment to overcoming them.

Dr ROBINSON (Cleveland--LNP)
(11.12 pm): I rise to report to parliament about a fishing event in the Redlands that raises concerns about the way this government is treating the fishers of Cleveland and surrounds and the 750,000 individuals across Queensland who fish. On Monday, 14 February Fisheries Queensland hosted a meeting at the Redlands Bowls Club, Victoria Point to explain the government’s four options in the snapper regulatory impact statement.

The meeting was attended by 150 local people including members from recreational fishing groups such as Sunfish and Ecofishers; charter boat operators; commercial fishers; Fisheries Queensland staff and the managing director, Jim Groves; the shadow fisheries minister, Ray Hopper; the member for Redlands, Peter Dowling; the federal member for Bowman, Andrew Laming; and me. No Labor MPs or Greens representatives were in attendance.

During a lengthy Q&A period, the mood in the room became one of mistrust towards the government, disbelief of the government’s claim that the science shows that snapper are overfished, anger, frustration and rejection of the future four-month snapper bans in the options. The impact of regular four-month bans would be significant. The bans would decimate the charter boat small businesses in my electorate and elsewhere and deeply hurt recreational fishing tourism in Moreton Bay.

Fisheries Queensland could not rule out the four-month bans starting in June this year. This is at a time when local tourist operators and marine industries are struggling to recover from the worst floods in our state’s history. This would be kicking Queenslanders when they are down.

Dr Barry Pollock, president of Queensland’s peak recreational fishing body, Sunfish, was at the meeting. His views are outlined in a Sunfish brochure that individuals can fill in and send to the Premier. The brochure reads--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Dear Premier,
I am extremely concerned by the proposals released by Minister Mulherin for the management of Snapper and other rocky reef fish species.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. The latest scientific review found that the exact status of Snapper stocks is uncertain due to the limitations of available data
2. It is misleading for the Minister to state unequivocally that Snapper stocks are severely depleted
3. Claims of good Snapper catches by recreational Snapper fishers have been disregarded by Fisheries Qld
4. Snapper stocks must remain sustainable through sensible management measures
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I urge the State government to reconsider the validity of this extreme and unwarranted management plan.
XML.Hansard-Body: Finally, the government has been caught out trying to sneak the current six-week snapper ban into Queensland just days before Christmas. It did this to escape public attention and avoid appropriate debate in the parliament. I urge the government to not delay the debate on the LNPs disallowance motion related to this ban. It would be a cowardly and cynical thing to postpone the debate until after the current six-week ban is over.

In closing, like the tremor before the full earthquake hits, the greater concern among Queensland’s 750,000 recreational fishers is that Labor’s six-week ban is just the beginning of tougher measures to come, as early as June this year.

Hansard-Body.A: (Chatsworth--ALP) (11.15 pm): I thank the Premier and the cabinet for coming to visit the Chatsworth electorate earlier in the year and holding a community cabinet at the Camp Hill State School. I know that the principal, Debbie Driver, and the student leaders were very excited about meeting the Premier and the ministers. I would also like to thank the education minister, Geoff Wilson, for taking the time to walk around the school and visit new preps on their first day of school. It was a very exciting day for the school.

XML.Hansard-Body: I would like to talk about a few other things that the schools in my electorate have been doing, in particular some of the work that has been done by the schools in relation to the recent floods. Whites Hill State School, under the leadership of principal Karl Shrubsole and the staff, did a lot of work during the flood clean-up. The school helped to clean up Rocklea. It assisted the Brisbane City Council with letterbox drops and donated two car loads of food, cleaning agents and hygiene items to the relief centre at Yeronga. Today the students also had a flood relief appeal at which they collected further money. The Whites Hill State School has just opened its fantastic new BER building. The school is looking terrific.

The Belmont State School, under the leadership of principal Noel Seawright, donated some furniture that they had to some of the schools that had been flood affected. There has been a lot going on in my electorate.

I would also like to give recognition to one person who lives in my electorate. Mr Richard Gorey is a friend of mine and we joined the airport fire service together many years ago. He is still a firefighter serving in the Queensland Fire and Rescue Service. He spent many weeks away in different parts of the state as part of the rescue teams that travelled the state. He was part of the rapid assessment team. They are the guys who went around and drew the Ns and Ys on the houses that the member for Hinchinbrook spoke about earlier.

Not only did Richard spend many weeks away during the flood effort; he was away in Far North Queensland, in places like Tully and Tully Heads, for a number of days after the cyclone. When he came back he swapped his fire brigade uniform for his Navy reserve uniform and spent a week diving in the Brisbane River clearing the Brisbane River. He put in a fantastic effort.

I would also like to acknowledge four-year-old Jade Nicholson, who is the daughter of my assistant electorate officer. She was quite upset watching the floods on TV. She did not like the idea of kids having to sleep in a wet bed. She was very upset that some kids’ beds were wet and they would not have a dry bed to sleep in. She wandered in to my electorate office with her mother and her piggy bank. She tipped it out and counted it up and then walked next door to the Bank of Queensland to make a mighty donation of $8.75. Congratulations to Jade and everyone else in my electorate who helped out during the floods.

Hansard-Body.A: (Buderim--LNP) (11.18 pm): I rise to advise that it was reported only last week, on 8 February, that disaster expert and planner Dr Ed Blakely called for national consistency in planning rules and building regulations in vulnerable coastal zones. The CEO of the Queensland Building Designers Association, Russell Brandon, supported Dr Blakely’s call and said--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We need to look at everything so that we have a better understanding of the weather and what happens to water over land.
XML.Hansard-Body: I am sure that most Queenslanders--in fact, most Australians--are familiar with the surname Walker when it comes to weather analysis and forecasting. Lennox Walker returned from the Second World War after serving Australia on the Kokoda Track. He worked as a surveyor with the Queensland and New South Wales forestry commissions. In 1953 Lennox became an understudy to world renowned weather forecaster Inigo Jones. Lennox learned as much about forecasting as he could from Inigo Jones. He developed his own theories on how sunspots affect weather patterns. A combination of these studies, correlated with the particular time of year, provided the basis of his forecasts. He went on to make many extremely accurate weather predictions, including that of Cyclone Tracy on Christmas Day 1974. At the age of 68, after 41 years of weather forecasting, Lennox Walker retired and his son Hayden stepped into his shoes. As his website states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Hayden also uses his knowledge of the sun, combined with the tendencies to cyclic patterns of sunspot activity and energy flow, to predict both the short- and long-term future of our weather.
XML.Hansard-Body: In October last year Mr Hayden Walker came to my electorate office and spoke at length with my staff and I. Among other things, Hayden said, ‘In relation to rainfall and floods, it’s going to be quite spectacular. And at the same time, with the increase in subdivisions, increase of roof area and loss of vegetation, the run-off will be increased. So, therefore, if you get run-off increase and a high tide, well, it’s going to be absolutely out of control. It’s going to be the biggest storm season we have seen for quite some time.’

I say again that Hayden Walker told us that in October last year. It is time the government started to seek out weather forecasters such as Hayden Walker, listened to what they have to say and embraced their ideas. If this man got it right and he has predicted what is going to happen in the not-too-distant future, we need to start to listen to these people.

Hon. MM KEECH (Albert--ALP) (11.20 pm): In responding to the dreadful flooding in South-East Queensland, together with my two Gold Coast colleagues the member for Broadwater and the member for Burleigh I initiated a school stationery drive across the Albert electorate. With the help of Albert and Logan News , I asked Albert residents to lend a helping hand to ensure students in flood affected areas could begin their school year on time and on track. As the backpacks overflowing with lovely school stationery items were brought into my office by pensioners, schoolchildren, businesspeople and friends and relatives, I was genuinely amazed by the wonderful generosity of my constituents during this time of need. As many members of parliament this week have commented, the natural disasters of our state have not only brought devastation to families and businesses and farms but with it we have seen an outpouring of incredible community spirit. On behalf of my constituents, I offer my sincere condolences to those families who have lost loved ones.

Many of those donating had already pledged significant financial support to the Premier’s disaster appeal, but were still ever-willing to dig deeper and give more. Not only were those in Albert offering needy students support; they were giving top-quality materials. One constituent delivering the donations from her mother to my electorate office joked, ‘Mum never spent this much money on my school supplies!’ When my husband, Peter, and my electorate officer Natalie Main hand-delivered the donated goods to families in Ipswich, Esk and Fernvale, we saw firsthand the severe devastation caused by the floods. In a time of disaster, loss and grieving, parents appreciated that a brand-new backpack with matching lunch box and folders and colouring-in pencils could go a long way in putting a smile back on their children’s faces.

I wish to pay tribute to my husband, Peter Keech, who did a sterling job in leading the Department of Communities’s flood recovery effort in Esk. I know that Minister Struthers is very proud of the very tough work her departmental staff have done in providing financial, practical and emotional relief to affected families in the Lockyer Valley. In their generosity to help flood affected students of the Lockyer Valley get back to school, my constituents in Albert stood out as a shining example of the community spirit which swept the state. I am so very proud to represent an electorate prepared to dig deeply when our fellow Queenslanders are in need. On behalf of all of the children and families whose lives they have touched, I sincerely thank my wonderful constituents for their kindness, generosity and compassion.
Question put--That the House do now adjourn.
Motion agreed to.
The House adjourned at 11.23 pm.
